content:
After more than five years of gushing red ink, 2025 was the year when streaming across the board started to turn a profit.

There are caveats attached to that statement, of course. NBCUniversalâ€™s Peacock is still making losses, and Apple TVâ€™s economics are impossible to disentangle from its trillion-dollar parent companyâ€™s, but nevertheless the year in general will go down as a milestone.

With that long-sought economic maturity has come greater scrutiny of the balance sheet. Although it sometimes feels like streaming is the only arena that counts, a recent report from Morgan Stanley media analysts noted that spending on linear TV remains about double that on streaming. Gone are the days of the firehose of content; even the sector leader, Netflix, has held the line on content expenses of late.

In 2026, Morgan Stanley predicts, â€œstreaming market repairâ€ will be a key phrase across the sector, as â€œcorporate spin-offs and continued cord-cutting are rapidly shrinking legacy TV as an investment factor.â€

Watch on Deadline

Streaming remained a headline-grabber this year even before a game-changing deal centering on the assets of Warner Bros. Discovery (with Netflix and Paramount both in hot pursuit as of this writing) was finalized. Disney launched a beefed up new ESPN app, which blends linear feeds from more than a dozen of its networks with a range of streaming-only fare. Fox Corp., for similar strategic reasons, launched a similar flagship, Fox One.

While profits and losses are probably the ultimate measure of success, the metrics of streaming underwent a rethink this year, with Netflix and Disney announcing plans to phase out quarterly reports of subscriber numbers. Revenue per user, engagement and other metrics are now en vogue, though success or failure in streaming, as ever, is subject to interpretation.

Below, in alphabetical order, are the top streaming players and Deadlineâ€™s view about how they fared in 2025 as well as what theyâ€™re facing next year. This is intended as a comprehensive look at these services â€“ programming, product and overall status in the field, not just value as M&A chess pieces.

HBO Max

2025 Highlight: Becoming the belle of the ball. While HBO Max had gradually earned a place among the top handful of services since its problematic launch in 2020, that slog was supercharged by the acquisition interest by Netflix and Paramount. While either company taking over would mean more upheaval for a company that has cycled through three owners in a decade, for the streaming business the injection of resources will be dramatic â€“ at least until Netflix merges it out of existence.

2025 Lowlight: The rebranding fiasco of Max going back to HBO Max. While Casey Bloys, Chairman and CEO, HBO and HBO Max Content, did his best to own the mistake when revealing the revamp at the companyâ€™s upfront presentation last May, it still belongs in the corporate annals next to New Coke and Qwikster.

Challenge for 2026: Now that it has finally made it to long-forbidden territories like the UK, Germany and Italy (which were unavailable due to a Sky output deal), what can HBO Max make of it? Netflix has become Netflix by incubating global hits from non-U.S. territories. HBO Max should lean into its prestige reputation and take a page from that playbook.

Biggest question for 2026: Can movies throw around more weight? As solid a hit as Superman and other releases were in theaters during Warner Bros.â€™ best year in ages (not to mention Materialists and other A24 releases making their debuts on HBO Max), they made minimal waves in streaming. With Harry Potter set to rekindle interest in the film franchise with a series take due in 2027, the clout of movies could be HBO Maxâ€™s not-so-secret weapon.

Netflix

2025 Highlight: K-pop Demon Hunters. The roaring success of Sonyâ€™s animated musical, which landed at the streaming giant under the companiesâ€™ pay-1 output deal, gave Netflix something it has been craving: a bona fide franchise. Riding a tide of pop-culture goodwill, a sing-along version of the movie raked in $19.2 million last fall, topping the weekend box office charts. The film also just recently surpassed 500M views on Netflix.

2025 Lowlight: Yet another video game course-correction. Co-CEO Greg Peters, who has overseen the games effort since it began in earnest in 2022, has not tried to put lipstick on a pig. But this year saw the latest strategic shift away from pricey franchise plays and toward casual games suited to the living room. Last fall, Peters made the news personally at an L.A. conference that an adaptation of the board game Boggle was joining the lineup. While the overall business had a banner year, that damp squib of an announcement seemed to sum up the entire gaming misadventure.

Challenge for 2026: How can management keep the troops focused as they pursue Warner Bros.? At $82.7 billion, the deal would be exponentially larger than any prior M&A transaction in the companyâ€™s nearly three-decade history. The most important task for Peters, Ted Sarandos and other top execs is keeping the industry-leading operation humming.

Biggest question for 2026: Will the movie portfolio undergo any more changes under film chairman Dan Lin? The producer and former Warner exec was installed in mid-2024, so his fingerprints may not yet be evident on a recent slate marked by Frankenstein, Electric State, A House of Dynamite, Jay Kelly, and Wake Up Dead Man: A Knives Out Mystery. Linâ€™s best-known credits include The Lego Movie, It, and other properties with profiles that stand out from Netflixâ€™s recent output.

Paramount+

2025 Highlight: Taylor Sheridan, aka Paramountâ€™s golden goose, kept filling the basket. New seasons of Landman, Tulsa King and Mayor of Kingstown clicked with viewers, as did MobLand, which wasnâ€™t created by Sheridan but was exec produced by his close collaborator, David Glasser. Despite the upheaval of the merger with Skydance, which closed in August and entailed thousands of layoffs, the content kept flowing.

2025 Lowlight: Losing Taylor Sheridan. With more than three years left on his overall deal with Paramount, the Yellowstone creator announced he would segue to NBCUniversal in 2029. Of course, there is spin on both sides, especially with high-priced talent deals under a microscope across the industry. But the notion that newly minted CEO David Ellison spent time courting Sheridan and came up empty didnâ€™t send the ideal signal to the troops.

Challenge for 2026: Ordering off the menu. While Sheridanâ€™s world, South Park, the UFC, CBS programming (including the NFL) and Paramount movies are continuing to be marquee draws for the streaming service, it needs to break new ground if itâ€™s going to muscle its way into the top echelon. Should the WBD quest or other M&A deals bear fruit, they would be a quick route to scale. Regardless, Netflix alum Cindy Holland and her troops will need to come up with an equivalent to Orange is the New Black or the many other follow-ups to House of Cards she presided over in her old job. Those originals positioned Netflix as not just intriguing but essential.

Biggest question for 2026: Will David Ellisonâ€™s long-promised tech overhaul of Paramount+, with or without the Warner Bros. Discovery assets, bear fruit in the new year? Since the media business set off on the expensive path of chasing Netflix nearly a decade ago, it has made a number of investments that were billed as pixie dust capable of transforming them into true tech giants. AI is the latest element said to confer such power. Technology is ever-present in the ecosystem, so the fact that it exists isnâ€™t new. The main question facing Ellison & Co. is: How will they use it?

Disney+

2025 Highlight: ESPNâ€™s streaming service finally has something to offer. For years, Disneyâ€™s sports streaming efforts were hindered by fragmented rights that made it nearly impossible to watch consequential games on its ESPN+ app, but the Mouse House finally upped its game in 2025. After acquiring NFL Network/RedZone, ESPN launched a brand new comprehensive streaming service in August that offered not only every Monday Night Football matchup across both ESPN and ABC this season but a ton of other streaming-exclusive games as well. The WWE also began offering premium live events on ESPNâ€™s app as well.

2025 Lowlight: Although it wasnâ€™t exclusively related to streaming, Disneyâ€™s decision to temporarily pull Jimmy Kimmel off the air while facing pressure from the Trump administration was a lowlight for democracy and may have had a negative effect on public perception of the company across the board. Campaigns circulated online encouraging Disney+ and Hulu subscribers to ditch their plans. Independent data reports have estimated millions of Americans canceled their subscriptions in that aftermath, though the economic fallout is hard to quantify. Disney is about to stop reporting streaming subscriber numbers in quarterly earnings reports, so the full impact of that backlash may not be known, since only a portion of those effects were documented in the companyâ€™s Q4 earnings. Regardless, it was yet another year of controversy for Disney.

Challenge for 2026: Stay in consumersâ€™ good graces. This year was as tumultuous as ever for Disney, and 2026 looks to present its own challenges as the company looks to dip its toes further into user-generated AI content. That ventures could go either way, as consumer sentiment specifically around AI is constantly shifting, but any rollout will surely spark backlash from the creative community. The one thing that is clear is that Disney could benefit from a little less turbulence with consumers in 2026, so it should proceed with caution.

Biggest question for 2026: Disney isnâ€™t the only company to tease AI-generated content might soon be available on its streaming platforms, but it certainly has the biggest IP to work from in that regard. After inking a blockbuster deal with OpenAI, how might Disneyâ€™s AI ambitions intersect with its streaming offerings in 2026?

Apple TV

2025 Highlight: Severance. The show returned for its second season this year and quickly became both a critical and cultural darling. It earned 27 Emmy nominations and won eight, including Outstanding Lead Actress for Britt Lower and Outstanding Supporting Actor for Tramell Tillman. The streamer is also closing out the year on a high note with Vince Gilliganâ€™s Pluribus, which is already shaping up to be a strong awards contender after earning Rhea Seehorn a Golden Globe nomination. It would be wrong not to acknowledge that F1 scored Appleâ€™s biggest ever box office opening this year, too.

2025 Lowlight: The streaming era has brought about many conundrums, and one that it appears has confounded multiple media companies is what the heck to call their service. While not nearly as egregious as the HBO Max debacle, Apple TV quietly rebranded earlier this year too, removing the â€œ+â€ sign due to apparent confusion it caused. The problem? It only created more confusion, given that Apple TV is also the name of the streaming hardware it sells, as well as the name of the app within the device.

Challenge for 2026: Eddy Cue, Senior Vice President of Services at Apple, admitted in October that the streamer has experienced a few setbacks that have left it â€œa little further behind than where Iâ€™d like to be.â€ While he pushed back on claims that the serviceâ€™s subscriber numbers sit around 45M, arguing that it is â€œsignificantly more than that,â€ the point remains that Apple seems to still be small potatoes in the streaming world despite some heavyweight content. The streamerâ€™s financials are pretty impossible to disentangle from its trillion-dollar parent companyâ€™s, but it seems to have a ways to go before itâ€™s in the big leagues.

Biggest question for 2026: What is the tech giantâ€™s next move in streaming? As all the chess pieces are moving rapidly across the board, Apple is a peculiar one that seems to have removed itself from the whims of the streaming wars. Apple TV remains the only premium streaming service without an ad tier. The company is also decidedly not joining the furor over Warner Bros. So, it begs the question, will Apple make any big moves next year, or quietly stick to what works?

Peacock

2025 Highlight: Peacock had a lot riding on Season 7 of Love Island USA after the reality show finally took off last year, and, boy, did it deliver. The season broke every viewership record it possibly could, becoming Peacockâ€™s most-watched original season ever with 18B minutes viewed throughout the two months it aired this summer. For better or worse, the show was everywhere, and so were its contestants. Notable wins on the scripted front: The Paper and All Her Fault both performed quite well. The Office spinoff was renewed before the episodes even hit the streamer, and All Her Fault topped the Luminate weekly TV rankings in the week it premiered. It was the first time that a Peacock original series had been No. 1 since the Luminate rankings were introduced.

2025 Lowlight: Ads, ads, and more ads. Every major premium streaming platform, save for Apple, has introduced an ad-tier by this point. So, why does Peacockâ€™s approach to ads feel particularly obnoxious? NBCUniversal recently touted â€œarrival ads,â€ which will bombard users with an ad as soon as they log onto the platform. The company also says itâ€™ll use AI tools to scan live content and place ads at pivotal moments with which â€œadvertiserâ€™s ad or creative automatically aligns.â€ Think big moments, like when a team hits the 10-yard line â€” aka, the time when a viewer would arguably be most agitated by being confronted with an ad.

Challenge for 2026: Peacock has certainly had its moments, but is it considered a must-have? Having canceleld Poker Face, Based on a True Story, and more this year, the streamer just doesnâ€™t seem to be winning viewers over with its scripted content. The looming sale of WB to one of NBCUniversalâ€™s rivals, Netflix or Paramount, would supercharge either of those studiosâ€™ content libraries and could potentially be spell bad news for Peacock, unless it can hold out until 2029 when Taylor Sheridan arrives.

Biggest question for 2026: Can sports be its saving grace? A three-year rights deal with bring the MLB to NBC and Peacock in 2026, and the platform will also host the Winter Olympics in February. Peacock also just began streaming WNBA coverage in addition to its ongoing Premier League, NFL and NBA coverage. Oh, and since NBC is hosting the Super Bowl, Peacock will simulcast that as well. While the streamer has yet to make itself essential in the scripted content space, sports buffs would be hard pressed not to have it.

Prime Video

2025 Highlight: Undoubtedly, Prime Video had two home runs this year: The Summer I Turned Pretty and Thursday Night Football. The third and final season of Jenny Hanâ€™s young adult romance came roaring back to the streamer this summer with an audience unlike anything it had ever seen before. Per Prime Video, it amassed 70M viewers globally in 70 days. On the NFL front, Prime Videoâ€™s fourth season of TNF is up 13% over last year, marking a third straight season of double digit growth.

2025 Lowlight: Amazon canceled a lot of series this year including Ã‰toile, Butterfly, Countdown, Bosch: Legacy, Motorheads, The Wheel of Time, Cruel Intentions, and The Runarounds. Lots of arguments to be made as to why any or all of these series should or should not have been canceled, but itâ€™s becoming pretty clear that frequent cancellations negatively impacts consumer sentiment.

Challenge for 2026: Prime Video ended the year with the return of Fallout, and Season 2 of Mr & Mrs Smith is delayed indefinitely, leaving just a few heavy hitting scripted series to come in 2026. The Boys set to end next year with its fifth and final season, and Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power will also return (although, the latterâ€™s second season struggled significantly compared to the first, so Season 3â€™s performance isnâ€™t a sure bet, either). Given all the cancellations listed above, Prime Video may be hard pressed to make a mark with anything new in 2026. Titles to keep an eye on is the Legally Blonde prequel series, Elle, and the Michelle Yeoh-led Blade Runner 2099.

Biggest question for 2026: Will Amazon finally become the one-stop content discovery hub? Analystsâ€™ predictions indicate that the tech giant might eventually introduce a universal search experience that allows users to navigate directly to other external streaming services to watch content. The streamer already quietly introduced a â€œnews hubâ€ that aggregates content from across hundreds of news channels, signaling its desire to become the central online marketplace for not just goods, but entertainment, too.

content:
The first two seasons of the Fox series Animal Control are available on Netflix after Fox Entertainment Global recently closed a deal with the streamer for the U.S. streaming rights to the single-camera comedy starring Joel McHale. That surprise Dec. 26 drop will be followed by the release of Season 3 and eventually the upcoming fourth season, which debuts on Fox later today, Dec. 28.

The previous seasons migrated to Netflix from Hulu, which has in-season rights to all Fox series, getting new episodes the day after they premiere on the broadcast network and Fox One. As of Dec. 28, only the â€œrolling 5â€ most recent Episodes 6-10 of Season 3 are available on the Disney platform.

Fox has been selling its fully owned series across platforms and countries. On the scripted side, Animal Control follows the sale to Netflix of its two other fully owned returning series, animated comedies Krapopolis and Grimsburg.

Watch on Deadline

Additionally, Sony Pictures Television recently made a deal with Netflix for the domestic library rights to Fox medical drama Doc, whose proceeds are shared by Fox Entertainment as a co-producing partner.

Animal Control follows a group of local Animal Control workers whose lives are complicated by the fact that animals are simple but humans are not. McHale stars as Frank Shaw, an overqualified, over-opinionated Animal Control officer who has an almost superhuman ability to understand animals. But humans â€¦ not so much. A former cop, Frank tried to expose corruption in his department, but his efforts got him fired, which might explain why heâ€™s so cynical and curmudgeonly. It also stars Michael Rowland, Vella Lovell, Ravi Patel and Grace Palmer.

The series, which premiered in February 2023, was created by Bob Fisher, Rob Greenberg and Dan Sterling. It is produced by Fox Entertainment Studios with production services provided by Jax Media. It is exec produced by McHale, Fisher, Greenberg, Sterling and Tad Quill.

title: â€˜Marty Supremeâ€™ Cements Timothee Chalamet as King of the Christmas Box Office
summary: TimothÃ©e Chalamet is officially the king of the Christmas box office. It’s the third consecutive holiday season where the A-list star has dominated at the box office, a reign that began with 2023’s family-friendly musical “Wonka” and continued with 2024’s Bob Dylan biopic “A Complete Unknown.” This year’s ping pong adventure, “Marty Supreme,” extended the […]
content:
TimothÃ©e Chalamet is officially the king of the Christmas box office.

Itâ€™s the third consecutive holiday season where the A-list star has dominated at the box office, a reign that began with 2023â€™s family-friendly musical â€œWonkaâ€ and continued with 2024â€™s Bob Dylan biopic â€œA Complete Unknown.â€ This yearâ€™s ping pong adventure, â€œMarty Supreme,â€ extended the trend, serving up a stellar $27 million over the four-day frame. And Chalametâ€™s domination around the merriest of holidays should endure with 2026â€™s â€œDune: Part III,â€ set for Dec. 18.

â€œSeemingly every year, TimothÃ©e has a major hit during the important holiday moviegoing corridor,â€ notes Comscoreâ€™s head of marketplace trends, Paul Dergarabedian. â€œNo matter the genre, whether itâ€™s a musical, biopic, sci-fi or comedy, his choice in the material and collaborators has made him not only a bona fide movie star, but a box-office draw.â€

Popular on Variety

â€œMarty Supremeâ€ confirms Chalametâ€™s status as the kind of actor whose name alone can sell a movie ticket. Itâ€™s a rare distinction these days, especially to have a star be synonymous with a season for moviegoing. The most recent example is probably Will Smith, who used to be known as Mr. Fourth of July. Starting with 1996â€™s â€œIndependence Day,â€ several of Smithâ€™s biggest blockbusters â€” 1997â€™s â€œMen In Black,â€ 2002â€™s â€œMen In Black IIâ€ and 2008â€™s â€œHancock,â€ among them â€” were released in theaters around July 4th weekend.

With $17 million over the traditional weekend, â€œMarty Supremeâ€ debuted at No. 3 in North America behind â€œAvatar: Fire and Ashâ€ ($64 million) and â€œZootopia 2â€ ($20 million). Those initial ticket sales stand as the second-biggest debut to date for A24 after Alex Garlandâ€™s â€œCivil Warâ€ ($25 million over the traditional three-day weekend). â€œMarty Supreme,â€ which launched a week earlier in limited release, has generated $28.3 million to date. The movie, which cost $70 million to produce, is expected to remain a box office draw into the new year due to positive reviews (a 95% on Rotten Tomatoes) and great word-of-mouth (a â€œB+â€ grade on CinemaScore). Josh Safdie directed â€œMarty Supreme,â€ a frenetic comedy-of-errors that follows the fictional Marty Mauser as he pursues his dream of becoming a table-tennis champ.

â€œThis was a gutsy, creative risk â€” a period sports drama â€” and itâ€™s going to pay off, thanks to Chalamet and great holiday playing time,â€ says David A. Gross, who runs the movie consulting firm Franchise Entertainment Research.

In terms of opening weekends, â€œMarty Supremeâ€ ranks between Chalametâ€™s other Christmastime releases. â€œWonka,â€ a fantasy musical about a young, aspiring chocolatier, Willy Wonka, opened to $39 million in mid-December and remained a force, eventually earning $218 million domestically and $634 million worldwide. Then â€œA Complete Unknown,â€ a drama about the counterculture icon Bob Dylan, bowed to $11.6 million on Christmas Day and, by the end of its run, strung together $75 million in North America and $140 million globally. Those films didnâ€™t have record-breaking debuts, but they all benefited from playing over the lucrative holiday season. This stretch between Christmas and New Yearâ€™s is traditionally the busiest week of the year.

Chalamet, who just turned 30 years old, elevated his profile through blockbusters such as â€œDuneâ€ and indie favorites such as â€œCall Me By Your Name,â€ â€œLady Birdâ€ and â€œLittle Women.â€ The projects that followed were commercial risks, even if they appeared like obvious wins on paper. Although â€œWonkaâ€ benefitted from brand awareness â€” itâ€™s a prequel to the beloved â€œWilly Wonka and the Chocolate Factoryâ€ â€” itâ€™s the kind of execution-dependent film that doesnâ€™t work without audiences buying into Chalamet singing and dancing about a world of pure imagination. Ditto â€œA Complete Unknown,â€ which, of course, has the advantage of great music from the â€œLike a Rolling Stoneâ€ composer in his earlier years. But name recognition and a passionate fandom arenâ€™t enough to bring audiences to theaters. See: This Octoberâ€™s Jeremy Allen White-led biopic â€œSpringsteen: Deliver Me From Nowhere,â€ which faltered at the box office after failing to breakout beyond the core fanbase of the Boss.

Since â€œMarty Supremeâ€ is completely original, Chalamet has been relentlessly marketing the film to avoid the fate of too many 2025 indies that collapsed at the box office. Heâ€™s captured the attention of the social media masses by gifting his famous friends the viral 1950s-esque windbreaker, flying a Nickelodeon-orange blimp around the country, climbing to the top of the Sphere in Las Vegas and turning the refrain â€œMarty Supreme. Christmas Dayâ€ into a mantra.

â€œTimothÃ©e Chalamet is the â€˜it guyâ€™ right now. Thereâ€™s no denying it,â€ Exhibitor Relations analyst Jeff Bock told Variety after the filmâ€™s limited release. â€œThe promotional work heâ€™s done with this film is high-level genius.â€

content:
The movie business grew up in the pages of Variety.

There is no more comprehensive chronicle of film history than Variety â€“ hands down, no contest, case closed. This gallery backs up that bold statement by offering an array of amazing movie and movie-related advertisements drawn from Varietyâ€™s 120 years of covering entertainment and Hollywood.

Truly, the pages presented here only scratch the surface of the jewels and historical artifacts in our voluminous archives. This is definitely not an exhaustively researched selection. These are but some of the fantastic finds that we came across while working this year on the 120th anniversary issue, published Dec. 10 in print and online.

Some of these ads are for long-forgotten obscure titles, some are for classics like â€œKing Kong,â€ â€œCasablanca,â€ â€œSunset Boulevard,â€ â€œDr. Strangelove,â€ â€œButch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid,â€ â€œThe Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie,â€ â€œChinatown,â€ â€œStar Wars,â€ â€œPlatoon,â€ â€œSilence of the Lambs,â€ â€œRushmore,â€ â€œThe Matrixâ€ and â€œThe Talented Mr. Ripley.â€ Some are for movies produced far outside of the U.S.; as youâ€™ll see, even the Soviet Union touted its Sovexport Film operation in Variety in the 1960s and â€˜70s. Some of the pages presented here simply capture a moment in time.

We hope cineastes enjoy this trip through the past century of film as seen through the pages of New York-based Variety, which began publication in December 1905, and Los Angeles-based Daily Variety, which had a proud 80-year run as Hollywoodâ€™s hometown paper, published Monday-Friday from 1933 to 2013.

And remember, when you need to know what the O.G. â€œStar Warsâ€ grossed in its opening weekend in markets like St. Louis, Detroit and â€œCincyâ€ â€“ now you know where to find a handy chart.

title: Rob Reinerâ€™s Absence From New York Times â€œLives They Livedâ€ Explained; 2025 In Memoriam Featured Diane Keaton, Angie Stone & David Lynch

content:
EXCLUSIVE: Itâ€™s now that time of the year when In Memoriam lists are being compiled and posted commemorating those who passed in 2025. For New York Times readers picking up the paper today, amidst tributes to Diane Keaton, David Lynch, Angie Stone and 20 others, two names were noticeably absent from the Gray Ladyâ€™s â€œThe Lives They Livedâ€ section.

Rob Reiner and Michele Reiner.

For a Hollywood community deeply saddened and shaken by the December 14 murder of the Reiners, as the tributes to the long married duo from presidents, producers, directors, actors, agents and collaborators have made clear the past two weeks, the Misery director and his photographer spouseâ€™s nonappearance on the NYT Magâ€™s eccentric annual tally has raised more than a few eyebrows.

â€œIs it because they were violently killed?â€ one C-Suiter texted me this AM as he sat down to read his Sunday paper. Another industry insider wondered if the Martin Scorsese penned Christmas Day op-ed on his friendship with fellow filmmaker Reiner was the substitute for a â€œThe Lives They Livedâ€ piece.

Watch on Deadline

Neither theory is true. It was, like so many things, all about timing.

â€œThe Lives They Lived is a New York Times Magazine feature,â€ the NYTâ€™s Danielle Rhoades Ha told me today. â€œThough the print publication date is Dec. 16, the content was finalized and sent for publication on Dec. 11 â€” three days before Rob Reinerâ€™s death,â€ the SVP Communications added.

In fact, with the exception of the breaking news A section, most of the often hefty NYT is fully locked in and printed days before it hits newsstands and doorstep. The vast majority of the Sunday editionâ€™s articles are available on the paperâ€™s website usually three or four days beforehand, including â€œThe Lives They Lived.â€

Discovered dead by their daughter Romy and a friend on December 14 at the coupleâ€™s Brentwood home, the Reiners were killed by multiple stab wounds. In the hours that followed on that first night of Hanukkah, police tracked down and arrested the Reinerâ€™s youngest son Nick.

Set for a full hearing on January 7, the 32-year-old, who has very publicly fought drug addiction for over a decade, has now been charged with two count of first-degree murder. As the LA County DA made clear on December 16, the currently incarcerated without bail Nick Reiner faces the possibility of the death penalty or life behind bars without parole if found guilty.

Over the past two weeks, the NYT has published and posted around 50 articles on the Reinersâ€™ deaths, legacy and reaction to their murders since that tragic night of December 14 The paper has also had detailed coverage on Nick Reinerâ€˜s arrest and subsequent charges since the 78-year-old director and the 68-year-old photographer were reported deceased.

The last SNL of 2025 saw a on-screen tribute to Reiner, who hosted the NBC late-nighterâ€™s third ever episode in 1975, at the end of its December 21 airing. Tributes to the When Harry Met Sally director and All in the Family actor are expected at the Golden Globes and the March 15, 2026 Oscars.

While a number of public figures from as far across the political spectrum as John Cussak to James Woods, not to mention close Renier friends like Barack and Michelle Obama (who were supposed to have dinner on December 14 with the Reiners at ex-Ambassador James Costos and Micheal Smithâ€™s LA home) Billy Crystal, Larry David, Meg Ryan and AITF co-star Sally Struthers, have offered praise for Reiner and condolences on his death, a petulant Donald Trump has lashed out at the filmmaker twice in quick succession.

title: Brigitte Bardot Remembered: In â€˜And God Created Womanâ€™ and â€˜Contempt,â€™ She Projected a Bold New Image of Feminine Identity and Erotic Power
summary: It has always been easy to trivialize Brigitte Bardot. In 1957, starring in the movie that made her a global sensation, “And God Created Woman,” what she did was not widely regarded as accomplished screen acting â€” or, in a certain way, as acting at all. The movie treated her as a ripe object of […]
content:
It has always been easy to trivialize Brigitte Bardot. In 1957, starring in the movie that made her a global sensation, â€œAnd God Created Woman,â€ what she did was not widely regarded as accomplished screen acting â€” or, in a certain way, as acting at all. The movie treated her as a ripe object of erotic fixation, and thatâ€™s just what she was called upon to play. She is introduced with shots of her bare feet arched just so, her body lying naked, face down on the ground. â€œSex kitten.â€ â€œBaby doll.â€ â€œTeenage temptress.â€ At the time, she was branded all those things. Was the movie a sober French drama or soft-core porn? It was marketed as something in between.

Yet there was more at stake. And part of it is that Bardot, who died Sunday at 91, made no less a figure than Marilyn Monroe seem a sex symbol from an entirely different era. Monroe, while a huge star, still had one arched foot in the straitlaced past; Bardot was the woman-child of the world to come â€” the brazen girl who already embodied and anticipated the spirit of the swinging â€™60s.

Popular on Variety

In â€œAnd God Created Woman,â€ sheâ€™s frisky, sheâ€™s sultry, sheâ€™s angry, sheâ€™s spectacularly uninhibited, and she signifies a new kind of erotic abandon that is liberated from the old strictures of the femme fatale. Her character, Juliette, is not a gold-digger; she rejects the advances of the rich men who come on to her. She simply does what she wants to do. â€œAll the future does is spoil the present,â€ she tells a potential new lover. Yet when she learns, a bit later, that his proclamations of love are for the birds â€” that he doesnâ€™t want a future with her, just a fling Â­â€” the wounded smolder on her face becomes the ripest thing about her. At the climax, doing a dance of abandonment to the music of a hot Caribbean band, you see her literally spinning out of the control of the men around her.

A word about the Bardot pout. Itâ€™s sexy as hell, but itâ€™s a pout of steel. It has resolve. Which is why itâ€™s so sexy. There was as much power in that pout as there was in Barbara Stanwyckâ€™s snarl or Rita Hayworthâ€™s come-hither glare. Maybe more. Because itâ€™s as if Bardot had absorbed the temptation vibrations of all the screen goddesses who had come before her and was standing on their shoulders, reaching for something moreâ€¦real.

Two years after â€œAnd God Created Womanâ€ came out, becoming the top-grossing foreign-language film of all time in the United States, the great French philosopher Simone de Beauvoir wrote of Bardot, â€œHer clothes are not fetishes, and when she strips she is not unveiling a mystery. She is showing her body, neither more nor less, and that body rarely settles into a state of immobility. She walks, she dances, she moves about. Her eroticism is not magical, but aggressive. In the game of love, she is as much a hunter as she is a prey. The male is an object to her, just as she is to him.â€

The title â€œAnd God Created Womanâ€ sounds grandiose, but what it meant is: God had now created a new kind of woman. A woman whoâ€™s effortlessly confident and coveted, whoâ€™s the quintessence (to quote Jim Morrison) of a 20th century fox, and one who will not be the victim of the gazes of the men who surround her. When Juliette, to avoid being sent back to the orphanage she came from, agrees to marry the nice, sweet, dorky Michel (Jean-Louis Trintignant), a priest warns him, â€œThat girl is like an animal. She needs to be tamed.â€ But actually, thereâ€™s no taming what Bardot had: a casual freedom that was there in the way she held her body, and in every glance she gave.

If she was triumphantly brazen in â€œAnd God Created Woman,â€ in Jean-Luc Godardâ€™s â€œContemptâ€ (1963) she broke the law of every film ever made about love. In movies, love and romance are the most powerful of religions, and when relationships fall apart itâ€™s for all kinds of reasons. They break down, crack up, go bust. But in â€œContempt,â€ Bardot plays Camille, the wife of a playwright (Michel Piccoli) whoâ€™s hired to rewrite the script for a film version of â€œThe Odyssey,â€ and when the fire goes out of their marriage, itâ€™s not for some tidy dramatic explanation. Itâ€™s becauseâ€¦she has decidedâ€¦that the fire is goneâ€¦just because. Because in the newly modern world, where women are no longer under the thumb of men, their feelings might change, and the reasons for that might beâ€¦inaccessible to the man left holding the bag of their now-empty union.

The way Bardot plays this, uttering the word â€œcontemptâ€ (the feeling she now has for her husband) as a wall made of stone, she exudes a tragic matter-of-factness that resides on the other side of cruelty. It is cruel, but not because sheâ€™s cruel. Itâ€™s that life is cruel. And her beauty, in cinematic terms, is part of the cruelty; itâ€™s part of what she will now withhold. Bardot portrayed all of this, in 1963, with what could be called the consciousness of the new woman. A new awareness of choice, and of how the old rules holding the world together no longer applied.

Discussing â€œContempt,â€ male critics tend to get fixated on the film-industry woes of Piccoliâ€™s screenwriter (a Godard surrogate), and the world-weary travails of the director Fritz Lang (playing himself). But the heart of the movie is the half-hour-long sequence in which Bardot and Piccoli wander around their apartment in Rome, having the kind of fight that sounds less like a movie fight and more like a real fight than almost any scene in movies you could name. The sequence suggests that if Godard hadnâ€™t decided to go the route of being an allusive postmodern brainiac creator of prankster-troll cinematic puzzles-that-never-quite-fit-together, he could have been an extraordinary poet of emotional naturalism. And the coldly beating heart of the film, which is arguably Godardâ€™s greatest, is Brigitte Bardotâ€™s performance.

Looking back and watching Bardotâ€™s movies now, you see hints and echoes of so many of the actresses who would come after her, from Maria Schneider to Nancy Allen to Dominique Sanda to Uma Thurman to AdÃ¨le Exarchopoulos to Sydney Sweeney. She was marketed as a pin-up, yet she was a singular presence who forged a path of sensual and spiritual fearlessness. And part of it is that she insisted, just as the Madonna of the â€™80s and â€™90s did, that for a certain kind of performer (her kind), sexuality was inseparable from artistry. Bardotâ€™s eroticized projection of female identity was itself a transcendent performance. If God created woman, Bardot made you feel like she had created herself. Only time will tell if the future is female. But once sheâ€™d made her mark, the future was most definitely Bardot.

content:
Iranian filmmaker Bahram Beyzaie, best known for his 1989 feature Bashu: The Little Stranger, which was restored at the 2025 Venice Film Festival, has died. He was 87.

Beyzaie died on his birthday, December 26, in California due to complications from cancer. The filmmaker had been teaching in the Iranian Studies faculty at Stanford University.

Bahram Beyzaie was born in December 1938 in Tehran. He was one of the leading filmmakers of Iranian New Wave cinema, with titles including Downpour (1972), Bashu: The Little Stranger (1989), and Killing Mad Dogs (2001).

Beyzaie was also a founding member of the Center for Progressive Filmmakers in Iran, the Iranian Writers Association, and the Society of Dramatic Authors and Composers. He served as the Chair of the Dramatic Arts Department at the University of Tehran. Following the Islamic Revolution in 1979, he was forced to resign from Tehran University, and the government banned his work.

Watch on Deadline

Beyzaie left Iran in 2010 and joined Stanford University as a lecturer in Iranian studies.

Filmmakers from across the Iranian diaspora have shared statements about Beyzaie following news of his death.

In a post on social media, filmmaker Asghar Farhadi said: â€œBahram Beyzaie, my great teacher, whose works, words, and above all, his love for the culture of this land I have followed with all my heart, has now left this world in exile. I have truly never known a more Iranian person than Bahram Beyzaie in this day and age, and how bitter it is that this most Iranian of Iranians, thousands of miles away from Iran, turns a blind eye to the world.â€

When naming â€œThe X-Filesâ€ to its list of the 100 greatest TV series of all time in 2023, Variety wrote, â€œLetâ€™s be clear: Your imagination has to be very large to appreciate the world of â€˜The X-Files.â€™ But thanks to David Duchovny and Gillian Anderson (and their undeniable chemistry), fans hung on to every surreal and fantastical thing Mulder and Scully said. Balancing a rich (if eventually frustrating) mythology with its famous â€˜Monster of the Weekâ€™ episodes â€” and balancing Duchovnyâ€™s true believer with Andersonâ€™s perpetually shocked skeptic, â€˜The X-Filesâ€™ was a canny, glossy mixture of FBI work with the endless possibilities of the universe. Paul Thomas Andersonâ€™s â€œOne Battle After Another,â€ â€œSinners,â€ â€œWeapons,â€ â€œFrankenstein and â€œWicked: For Goodâ€ led the 13th annual Make-Up Artists & Hair Stylists Guild Award nominations.

The films all three landed nominations apiece.

The makeup and hair team behind â€œOne Battle After Anotherâ€ was nominated in contemporary makeup and special makeup prosthetics. Arjen Tuiten, who was nominated in the latter category, used prosthetic pieces, contact lenses and dentures for Sean Pennâ€™s Colonel Lockjaw in the filmâ€™s third act after he survives a horrific car crash.

For â€œFrankenstein,â€ Mike Hill, the filmâ€™s prosthetics artist, steered clear of the classic zombie, and used 42 prosthetic pieces to transform Jacob Elordi in Guillermo del Toroâ€™s Creature.

Popular on Variety

Francis Hannon had her work cut out for her on â€œWicked: For Good.â€ Aside from keeping Cynthia Erivoâ€™s Elphaba green, she had to work with Mark Coulier to transform Jonathan Bailey into the Scarecrow and Ethan Slater into the Tin Man. 11 pieces were applied to Slaterâ€™s face, including cheekbone prosthetics that changed his cheek line and additional pieces to alter his jawline. On â€œWeapons,â€ the team created prosthetics that unlocked the inner darkness that lurks behind her Aunt Gladysâ€™ rimmed glasses. Amy Madiganâ€™s look needed to be ferocious and needed to mirror an animal that was preying upon its victims.

Other nominated teams include â€œBugonia,â€ â€œMarty Supreme,â€ â€œSupermanâ€ and â€œBattle of a Small Player.â€

The new and final season of Netflixâ€™s â€œStranger Thingsâ€ landed a total of four nominations, including a nod in the commercial category for the Discover x â€œStranger Thingsâ€ ad.

Lady Gagaâ€™s hairstylist, Sarah Tanno, was also nominated for her work on the â€œAbracadabraâ€ music video.

title: The Movie Theater Comeback That Wasnâ€™t: Why 2025 Was Such a Dud for Struggling Cinemas
summary: Some comeback! The past 12 months were supposed to turn things around for struggling cinemas. But instead of heralding a dramatic return to moviegoing, 2025 is running neck-and-neck with the middling 2024 box office, and will fall far short of the $9 billion in domestic ticket sales that most analysts expected the theatrical movie business […]
content:
Some comeback!

The past 12 months were supposed to turn things around for struggling cinemas. But instead of heralding a dramatic return to moviegoing, 2025 is running neck-and-neck with the middling 2024 box office, and will fall far short of the $9 billion in domestic ticket sales that most analysts expected the theatrical movie business to easily eclipse. Prior to the pandemic, North American revenues would regularly hit between $10 billion to $11 billion. The 2025 results are a massive disappointment that no amount of spin can change. (Already thereâ€™s talk of how much better 2026 will be.)

â€œThereâ€™s an unfortunate trend, which that we just canâ€™t get the industry to $9 billion at the domestic box office,â€ says Mike Sherrill, the chief operating officer of dine-in cinema chain Alamo Drafthouse. â€œIt looks like itâ€™s going to be two years in a row that the industry flatlined.â€

Popular on Variety

More worrisome is the reality that many of the movie businessâ€™s biggest franchises are showing signs of oversaturation or fatigue. Marvel continued to struggle with its B Team heroes; Februaryâ€™s â€œCaptain America: Brave New Worldâ€ and Mayâ€™s â€œThunderboltsâ€ lost tens of millions during their theatrical runs, while Julyâ€™s â€œThe Fantastic Four: First Stepsâ€ will only eke out a modest profit. And even though â€œAvatar: Fire and Ashâ€ ($760 million and counting), â€œWicked: For Goodâ€ ($504 million) and â€œJurassic World Rebirthâ€ ($869 million) will rank among the yearâ€™s top-grossing releases, they will fail to match the revenues of previous films in their respective series. Clearly, the theatrical industry canâ€™t thrive on sequels and spinoffs alone.

It would be easy to declare an end to comic book movies. That said, genres have risen and fallen throughout Hollywood history â€” just look at musicals or westerns or raunchy comedies, which have faded in popularity after once being surefire draws. What really has theater owners and some studio chiefs concerned as the year closes out is what the future will hold if Netflix is able to secure government approval for its $82.7 billion deal to buy Warner Bros. Already, Netflix co-CEO Ted Sarandos has hinted that he believes that â€œwindows,â€ industry jargon for the amount of time that movies play exclusively in theaters, are too long. He told Wall Street shortly after the pact was announced that he expects that they will â€œevolveâ€ in a more â€œconsumer friendlyâ€ direction. Everyone knows exactly what he meant by that.

For cinemas, itâ€™s nothing short of an existential threat. During COVID, studios abbreviated the gap between a filmâ€™s theatrical release and its home entertainment debut, only to discover that customers got accustomed to waiting to watch movies until they hit streaming or on-demand platforms. If windows keep shrinking, theaters may lose their competitive advantage.

There were also reasons to feel optimistic about the trajectory of an industry that has been knocked down and counted out for half-a-decade. China, which had been hostile to Hollywood fare since the pandemic, embraced a few major studio releases such as â€œZootopia 2â€ and â€œAvatar: Fire and Ash,â€ signaling that one of the worldâ€™s biggest moviegoing markets is still accessible to certain U.S. productions. Of course, China is doing just fine without Hollywood â€” thank you, very much. The yearâ€™s highest-grossing release isnâ€™t an English-language production but rather the Chinese animated sequel â€œNe Zha 2,â€ which has generated more than $2.1 billion globally, despite the fact that most Americans would draw a blank at the title.

Family films and video game adaptations proved irresistible to audiences, who flocked to theaters to see the likes of â€œA Minecraft Movie,â€ â€œLilo & Stitchâ€ and â€œZootopia 2.â€ The three films, all of which carry PG ratings, were the three highest-grossing Hollywood productions, with â€œA Minecraft Movieâ€ tapping out just shy of $1 billion and â€œLilo & Stitchâ€ and â€œZootopia 2â€ both crossing that threshold. Itâ€™s the second consecutive year that PG films outgrossed their PG-13 counterparts, which is notable because itâ€™s usually the other way around. Meanwhile anime proved to be a massive boon, with â€œDemon Slayer: Infinity Castleâ€ and â€œChainsaw Manâ€ scoring back-to-back wins for Sony-owned Crunchyroll.

â€œWhat happened with â€˜Demon Slayerâ€™ is great because it opens a new category of film,â€ says Sherrill of Alamo Drafthouse. â€œAbout 49% of the audience was under 24 years old. Thatâ€™s so important because we need to be thinking about whatâ€™s going to be relevant for the next generation of moviegoers.â€

Comic book content is no longer king. After being the most popular genre for over a decade, these movies have recently looked a lot less superhuman. The latest â€œCaptain Americaâ€ suffered from a prolonged post-production and extensive rewrites, with critics piling on when the film debuted in February. Although â€œFantastic Fourâ€ and â€œThunderboltsâ€ movies were much better regarded, they still failed to match the kind of grosses that Marvel movies used to routinely achieve before the pandemic. Marvel Studios will have a chance to recapture its box office prowess with next Julyâ€™s â€œSpider-Man: Brand New Dayâ€ as well as Decemberâ€™s â€œAvengers: Doomsday,â€ which brings back Robert Downey Jr. and Chris Evans.

Marvelâ€™s rival, DC Films, fared better with â€œSuperman,â€ a generally well-received Man of Steel adventure that grossed $616 million. A lot had been riding on the success of the film, which centers on the most recognizable name in DC Comics. James Gunn, who took over DC with Peter Safran in 2022, directed the film and positioned it as a reset for a company in desperate need of a fresh direction. For years, DC films such as â€œJustice Leagueâ€ and â€œThe Flashâ€ have been slammed as too dark and dense. Gunn and Safran wanted to recapture the humor and hope that defined Richard Donnerâ€™s 1978 classic, â€œSuperman.â€ DCâ€™s real challenge will come next year when the studio fields films like â€œSupergirlâ€ and â€œClayface,â€ which are based on far lesser known characters.

â€œWe needed to have the DC logo be synonymous with quality again,â€ Safran says. â€œFor too long, our movies had suffered from real inconsistency. It takes time to develop a positive reputation, but this put us on the right track.â€

It was a disappointing year for many adult-oriented dramas, with the likes of â€œThe Smashing Machine,â€ â€œBugoniaâ€ and â€œSpringsteen: Deliver Me From Nowhereâ€ failing to make much of a dent at the box office. However, some studios took artistic gambles that paid off handsomely, none more so than Warner Bros., which bet on idiosyncratic horror films like Ryan Cooglerâ€™s â€œSinnersâ€ and Zach Creggerâ€™s â€œWeapons,â€ both of which attracted huge crowds after they debuted to rave reviews. And awards buzz helped another of the studioâ€™s auteur-driven films, Paul Thomas Andersonâ€™s â€œOne Battle After Another,â€ gross more than $200 million. The only problem: With a budget of $140 million and tens of millions spent on marketing, the film stands to lose $100 million theatrically since studios and exhibitors essentially split ticket sales.

â€œThe good news is that when a movie catches the eye of a filmgoing audience, they are ready and excited to go. We saw all kinds of movies work this year,â€ says Adam Fogelson, chair of the Lionsgate Motion Picture Group. â€œThe challenge is if you have something that, for whatever reason, doesnâ€™t spark peopleâ€™s interest, the floor is non-existent, regardless of the level of star power. You can have a movie that the audience likes and no one goes to see.â€

Tom Cruiseâ€™s star power may be dimming, as evidenced by the diminished returns of the mega-budgeted â€œMission: Impossible â€“ The Final Reckoning.â€ It ranks among the yearâ€™s biggest bombs and may put Ethan Hunt on hiatus, at least until Cruiseâ€™s adventure films get less costly. But other talent is ascending to the A-list. TimothÃ©e Chalamet, for example, proved that heâ€™s one of the hottest names in movies. The 30-year-old actor has helped make A24â€™s â€œMarty Supreme,â€ a period movie about ping pong, into an unlikely holiday season hit. Credit goes to the star who helped mastermind a promotional push that saw him deploy everything from bright orange blimps to viral videos in service of the indie drama â€” the marketing blitz drew TikTok fans, as well as arthouse aficionados.

Movie theaters have also relied heavily on premium large formats like Imax and Dolby. The popularity of those screens, which more expensive than the average movie ticket, has helped to offset the decline in attendance. For visual spectacles like â€œAvatar: Fire and Ashâ€ or â€œF1: The Movie,â€ those PLFs have accounted for 50% to 60% of overall sales. Although industry sales were essentially flat, Imax delivered its best-ever year at the box office with $1.2 billion globally.

â€œWe branched out in genres,â€ says Imaxâ€™s CEO Richard Gelfond. â€œWe were known more in 2022 and 2023 for superhero movies and sequels. This year, we did a lot more in horror and family films. Three of the four biggest animated films in our history were this year, which I donâ€™t think is a coincident. The publicâ€™s attitude is expanding to the kind of films they like to see in Imax.â€

He suggests that â€œmore diversified content would help insulate theaters from some Hollywood changes.â€

Exhibitors have, in fact, been turning to alternative content to populate their screens during the slower months. â€œKill Billâ€ or â€œBack to the Futureâ€ re-releases or â€œJawsâ€ anniversary screenings have helped Alamo, for one, pace 5% ahead of the industryâ€™s year-over-year returns. But cinema operators are keenly aware that oldies arenâ€™t going to keep the lights by themselves. They need Hollywood to supply the kind of new releases that turn multiplexes back into the epicenter of culture.

â€œI would like to think that studios and distributors are looking at the trends and seeing that original, fresh stories are working,â€ says Sherrill. â€œSo donâ€™t just give me 20 more movies. Give me 20 more of the stuff thatâ€™s meaningful for people.â€

Will those type of films fill marquees in 2026? This year, they certainly didnâ€™t.

â€œMy life is fantastic now. All I had to do is stay away from my family,â€ a grown-up Malcolm (Frankie Muniz) says in the trailer.

That is about to change. In the revival, titled after the original seriesâ€™ theme song, after shielding himself and his daughter from his family for over a decade, Malcolm is dragged back into their orbit when Hal and Lois demand his presence at their 40th anniversary party.

Watch on Deadline

The trailer, which you can watch above, features the return of Muniz, Cranston and Kaczmarek as well as Christopher Kennedy Masterson and Justin Berfield as Malcolmâ€™s brothers Francis and Reese, respectively, and Emy Coligado as Francisâ€™ wife Piama. The trailer does not include Caleb Ellsworth-Clark, the actor who succeeded Erik Per Sullivan as Malcolmâ€™s brother Dewey, but he is in the key art alongside Berfield, Kaczmarek, Muniz, Cranston and Masterson.

Alex Scrimgeour, boss of the premium UK cinema operator Everyman Media Group, has stepped down.

Scrimgeourâ€™s departure was announced this morning by the company. He has been replaced on an interim basis by non-executive director Farah Golant.

Scrimgeour leaves just weeks after the company issued a trading update to shareholders as its shares plunged to record lows. The company said at the time that Q4 box office performance had been weaker than expected. Shareholders were told the company now expected revenues of Â£114.5 million for 2025, down from previous forecasts of Â£121.5 million.

â€œWe would like to thank Alex for his commitment to Everyman throughout his tenure,â€ Everyman chairman Philip Jacobson said in a statement.

â€œHe has played a pivotal role in the team that successfully led the business through its recovery from Covid, more than doubling revenue and delivering significant Ebitda (earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation) growth.â€

Peyton List, whose TV credits include the Paramount+ series School Spirits and Netflixâ€™s Cobra Kai, will take to the stage later this month when she joins the hit Off Broadway revival of Heathers The Musical.

Beginning Monday, January 26, List will take over the role of Heather Chandler, currently being played by Jodie Steele. List joins a cast that includes Casey Likes, Kuhoo Verma, Jackera Davis, Elizabeth Teete, Kerry Butler, among others.

Since beginning previews at New World Stages on June 22 and officially opening July 10, Heathers, directed by Andy Fickman, has broken the house record four times as well as building the largest advance in the venueâ€™s 21-year history. The production recently extended its run for the second time and is playing through May 24, 2026.

â€œIâ€™m drawn to characters who are powerful, complicated, and a little dangerous,â€ said List in a statement. â€œHeather Chandler is an icon for a reason â€“ sheâ€™s larger than life, hilarious, terrifying, and deeply symbolic. Stepping into this role is thrilling, and I canâ€™t wait to enter my bad girl era. Itâ€™ll be so very.â€

Watch on Deadline

List stars as Maddie Nears in Paramount+â€™s School Spirits, and serves as Executive Producer. The series returns for its third season this month. On Netflixâ€™s Cobra Kai, which ended its sixth and final season as one of Netflixâ€™s most popular series earlier this year, List played Tory Nichols.

Previously, List played Emma Ross on Disney Channelâ€™s Jessie before reprising the character in the spinoff series Bunkâ€™d. Other television credits include Huluâ€™s supernatural thriller Light as a Feather, the dystopian feature The Thinning, and CBSâ€™ Happy Together. Heathers features book, music and lyrics by Kevin Murphy (Reefer Madness The Musical) & Laurence Oâ€™Keefe (Legally Blonde The Musical, Bat Boy The Musical), based on the 1989 film by Daniel Waters.

Heathers has had three West End productions and three tours, which have broken box office records throughout the UK and Ireland.

But when sheâ€™s unexpectedly taken under the wings of The Heathers â€“ three beautiful and impossibly cruel classmates all named Heather â€“ her dreams of popularity finally start to come true. That is until J.D., the mysterious teen rebel, turns up and teaches her that it might kill to be a nobody, but itâ€™s murder being a somebody.

EXCLUSIVE: The BBCâ€™s most famous fringe is coming to a sofa near you.

Deadline can reveal that The Claudia Winkleman Show has been officially commissioned and will launch next spring. The news comes three days before the fourth season of the Winkleman-hosted The Traitors launches.

Winkleman, who is enjoying quite the purple patch after a 30-year career, will front the seven-episode primetime BBC talk show that will â€œwelcome the biggest names from the worlds of film, television, music and beyond to her sofa for lively conversation with the help of a studio audience,â€ the BBC said. Broadcast information and guests will be revealed â€œin due course.â€

The Claudia Winkleman Show will debut on BBC One and BBC iPlayer in spring 2026. We revealed that the long-gestating chat show was being produced by The Graham Norton Show maker So Television and Little Arrow in October. Those plans, we understand, will see Winklemanâ€™s series broadcast when The Graham Norton Show is off-air in the spring, meaning there will be no clashes between the shows and they will not be competing for guests. The BBC recently renewed The Graham Norton Show for another three years, while its recent run of episodes has boasted eye-catching bookings including Taylor Swift. Winkleman earned her chat show stripes by stepping in for Norton earlier this year when the Irish presenter was on a break from his BBC duties. title: Top-Rated Television Networks: Ranking 2025â€™s Winners and Losers
summary: What a difference a Super Bowl makes. Last year, Fox was down double digits in Variety‘s year-end ranker of the year’s most-watched networks in primetime. But in 2025, Fox had the Big Game: And a a result, the network was up double digits in both total viewers and adults 18-49 (where it was No. 1). […]
content:
What a difference a Super Bowl makes. Last year, Fox was down double digits in Varietyâ€˜s year-end ranker of the yearâ€™s most-watched networks in primetime. But in 2025, Fox had the Big Game: And a a result, the network was up double digits in both total viewers and adults 18-49 (where it was No. 1).

But donâ€™t count out the strength of regular programming, as CBS â€” even sans Super Bowl, which it broadcast in 2024 â€” managed to stay No. 1 in total viewers thanks to series like â€œTrackerâ€ and â€œ60 Minutes.â€ ABC, meanwhile, was up 5%, after being virtually flat in 2024 â€” meaning for two years in a row, the Alphabet net has managed to keep the viewership erosion at bay. In an age where primetime numbers are naturally going down as audiences flock to streaming, thatâ€™s nearly a miracle. (Well, and ABC has been helped by airing more NFL Monday Night Football games the past two years.)

This reps the first year that Nielsenâ€™s big data + panel ratings were implemented, which now mix both Nielsen panel data from viewers along with set-top box and smart TV datasets. That has caused some grumbling in the industry, given some missing data and inaccuracies that have been found. It also makes year-to-year comparisons that might be a bit apples and oranges. Most noticable in this yearâ€™s charts are a stabilization in the primetime ratings for kidsâ€™ networks Disney Channel and Nickelodeon. After years of annual double-digit declines, Disney was down slightly in 2025, and Nick was actually up (both saw gains in 18-49). No one believes that kids have suddenly started watching linear again â€” but no one can really explain the change there, other than perhaps a quirk in this yearâ€™s methodology.

Popular on Variety

Tomorrow, Variety will share the ranker of this yearâ€™s most-watched primetime telecasts. But here, we recount which networks were up and down in 2025.

WINNERS

Fox Corp.: Fox famously downsized after selling its studio operations and most of its networks to Disney â€” but the channels it held on to did quite well in 2025. Fox was up 10% in both total viewers and adults 18-49 (where it was No. 1), thanks to the power of the Super Bowl. Meanwhile, Fox News defied the post-election downward trend seen by MS Now (formerly MSNBC) and CNN.

The CW: Speaking of controversial companies that had reason to cheer, Nexstar saw its The CW network climb 13% in total viewers, while Newsnation grew 16% â€” albeit, from low numbers. But a shift toward more live sports is clearly having an impact on The CW, which also saw its adults 18-49 rating climb a hair.

ESPN: Sports! ESPNâ€™s still got it, and this year climbed 18% â€” the most of any network in the top 30 among total viewers. The other big story is ESPN in adults 18-49, where this year itâ€™s one of the Big 4 â€” jumping 10% to rank as the No. 4 network in primetime, beating out CBS.

TruTV: Ooh la la! The French Open clearly had an impact on Tru TV, a channel that has gone through many lives (starting as Court TV, then later as a reality-focused channel, then the comedy-focused home of â€œImpractical Jokersâ€). This year, which this year shed most of its remaining comedy product (â€œImpractical Jokersâ€ is now on TBS) to focus even more as a secondary home for TNT Sports fare. That paid off when it came to the French Open, which included wall-to-wall replays and coverage on Tru TV. Ratings for the full tournament were up 25% this year on TNT and TruTV, and that probably explains why TruTV bucked the trend of cablers (including its other Warner Bros. Discovery siblings), jumping 46% in viewers and 27% in 18-49. (Again, those percentages are huge because TruTV was coming in at a much smaller audience.)

LOSERS

Families: Channels with â€œFamilyâ€ in their titles did not fare well in 2025. Family Entertainment TV, down 29%. Great American Family, down 18%. Hallmark Family, down 14%. Discovery Family Channel, down 22%. To be fair, itâ€™s tough out there for virtually all linear cable networks. If families are still watching TV together, itâ€™s not on these â€œfamilyâ€ channels.

Dr. Phil: One-time talk powerhouse Dr. Phil McGraw launched his Merit Street TV network (now just â€œMerit TVâ€) in 2024 and got on the board with a paltry average of 27,000 viewers. Just a year later, Merit Street Media filed for bankruptcy and sued its joint venture partners at the Trinity Broadcasting Network. The channel still exists as a shell of its ambition, and in 2025 dropped the most of any network on our ranker: down 41%, to an average of just 16,000 viewers in primetime.

title: â€˜Father Mother Sister Brotherâ€™ Costume Designer on Jim Jarmuschâ€™s Red Theme and Why Saint Laurent Insisted on Making Everything â€” Even Tom Waitsâ€™ Hoodie
summary: Jim Jarmusch’s “Father Mother Sister Brother,” now in theaters, is made up of three very different segments, each with a notable cast discussing the nature of their family relationships. One thing they have in common is a specific color: A deep red, the color of a jammy merlot, is a throughline that appears in each […]
content:
Jim Jarmuschâ€˜s â€œFather Mother Sister Brother,â€ now in theaters, is made up of three very different segments, each with a notable cast discussing the nature of their family relationships. One thing they have in common is a specific color: A deep red, the color of a jammy merlot, is a throughline that appears in each characterâ€™s contemporary clothing.

Set in New York state, Dublin and Paris, the three segments each revolve around an adult sibling pair. While in the first two, the siblings have somewhat uncomfortable interactions with their parents, in the third Paris section, the twin brother and sister have only memories of their late parents to excavate.

The clothes worn by cast members including Adam Driver, Cate Blanchett and Charlotte Rampling appear to be everyday items, but costume designer Catherine George explains that all the pieces seen onscreen â€” even Tom Waitsâ€™ very mundane hoodie â€” were made by iconic French fashion house Saint Laurent, a backer of the film.

Popular on Variety

The idea for the red theme came from Jarmusch, about whom George enigmatically says, â€œIn the last few years, heâ€™s been seeing colors in a different way. Red specifically looks different to him than it used to.â€

â€œJim called me about the movie pretty early on,â€ George says.

â€œHe said, â€˜Weâ€™ve got this movie, itâ€™s shooting in New York, Dublin and Paris.â€™ Iâ€™m from Ireland and shooting at home was amazing, and also shooting in Paris, incredible.â€

â€œAnd then he said, â€˜Well, itâ€™s a little complicated, because YSL will be collaborating with us, but I want you to design the costumes. Weâ€™ll be using some of their pieces that already fit the characters, but if they donâ€™t, then youâ€™re designing them.'â€

â€œJim already had a color theme â€” I think it was for one character â€” a sort of red and pink combination, and he wanted to carry that theme through all the stories, at least the red.

â€œItâ€™s nice to start a project and already have a sort of a theme that youâ€™re working within, rather than just grabbing at straws,â€ she says. â€œIt sort of gave me a base to think about while I was designing.â€

George, who has worked several times with Bong Joon Ho and also has â€œDie, My Loveâ€ this year, previously collaborated with Jarmusch on â€œThe Dead Donâ€™t Dieâ€ and â€œPaterson.â€ Below, she breaks down how the wardrobe for each segment was created.

Tom Waits wore a hoodie custom made by Saint Laurent with a subtle burgundy lining. Â©Mubi/Courtesy Everett Collection

Part One: Father

Tom Waits is an eccentric, solitary dad who is visited in his rural New York home by his wary, traditional son (played by Adam Driver) and daughter (Mayim Bialik). Driver and Bialikâ€™s styles mirror each other; theyâ€™re both in conservative blazers over deep red sweaters, while Waits sports a casual zippered hoodie.

Driverâ€™s clothes were â€œnot unlike his real clothes,â€ says George. â€œTomâ€™s character was a little more involved,â€ says George, â€œbecause he lives in a cabin and heâ€™s portraying himself as a penniless father.â€

For Waits, they had originally though he would wear a robe or pajamas. â€œWe initially had thought of sort of a dressing gown for him. But when I went to fit him, I went to his studio in California and had the tailor from YSL with me, and Tom tried on the dressing gown and wasnâ€™t quite feeling it,â€ she says.



â€œWhen we arrived, he was in a hoodie,â€ she recalls. â€œSo we used the pajamas that weâ€™d made for him, and I said, â€˜Letâ€™s try your hoodie on with it.â€™ He felt more like the character, more comfortable and natural.â€

Of course, even the drab hoodie got a subtle burgundy lining.



â€œEach each item of clothing, they would either send me images of something existing, or I would send them an image of a particular piece, and they would source the fabric. So it was a back and forth across continents,â€ George says.

Though Waitsâ€™ character acts like heâ€™s possibly broke, it turns out that might be an act â€” one clue is a snazzy suit he dons at the end of the segment.

â€œWhen Tom changes at the end into a suit to go out, that was fun to make a really beautiful suit in the specific color, and his shoes I really loved,â€ George says. â€œHe wore some creepers, like he wears in real life. So we had a pair made in burgundy, which were unbelievably beautiful.â€

Charlotte Ramplingâ€™s red Saint Laurent shirtdress was adapted from a jumpsuit design. Â©Mubi/Courtesy Everett Collection

Part Two: Mother

In the second segment, strait-laced Cate Blanchett and free-spirited Vicky Krieps make a once-a-year visit to their rather stiff novelist mother Charlotte Rampling in her Dublin home. The trioâ€™s distinct personalities are evident in their wardrobes.

â€œWe seem to be accidentally color-coordinated,â€ Ramplingâ€™s character says, underlining the awkwardness. â€œHow embarrassing!â€

With pink-tinted hair and a fluffy fake fur coat over a printed red sweater, Kriepsâ€™ character is â€œa bit of a party girl,â€ George explains, though sheâ€™s also putting on a show â€” sheâ€™s possibly not the successful influencer she makes out to be.

Blanchettâ€™s character is frankly uptight, which is instantly signaled by the way she wears an oxford shirt over a burgundy turtleneck. Her clothes werenâ€™t pulled from existing YSL collections, George says. â€œWe had come up with the shirt, but then we wanted to incorporate the red, and that was, again, finding a balance. A whole red sweater would have been too much, but putting the shirt on top added to her sort of buttoned-up version of herself.â€

Ramplingâ€™s character, meanwhile, makes the most of the couture tailoring in a burgundy shirtdress that was based on a YSL jumpsuit design.

â€œThey made beautiful pieces,â€ George says. â€œThe thing with working with YSL is they have access to so much incredible fabric and their production is gorgeous. When the pieces arrived, they were beautifully made: the shoe, the bags. Even Kateâ€™s sort of dowdy pieces were really beautifully made and executed.â€

But even YSL pieces need to be aged to make them look lived in, she says.

â€œI find it jarring when I see something that looks too fresh, too new, if the character is not that kind of person. You know, Tomâ€™s hoodie, his his sweatshirt, his pajamas â€” they all went through a process of being washed and aged,â€ says George, though she adds that Ramplingâ€™s character is the type who would take very good care of her clothes.

Luka Sabbat and Indya Moore play twin siblings, who wear leather jackets with slightly different designs. Â©Mubi/Courtesy Everett Collection

Part Three: Sister, Brother

In the final segment, siblings played by Indya Moore and Luka Sabbat drive through Paris to their late parentsâ€™ empty apartment to talk about their family. Theyâ€™re as naturalistic and free-spirited as the other siblings are rigid.

â€œTheyâ€™re twins and they have some kind of psychic messaging system, and their biker jackets, even though theyâ€™re two different versions, are quite similar,â€ says George. â€œHis is a classic sort of motorcycle jacket, and hers is more of a fashion type.â€

Though the color theme isnâ€™t as obvious, Indyaâ€™s character does wear a red tank top, which was based on a piece George actually owned but in a Saint Laurent-designed version.

As for Sabbatâ€™s character, â€œWe decided to keep him in a classic white T-shirt as just a sort of iconic movie character,â€ she says.

After working on fantastical films such as â€œMickey 17â€ and â€œSnowpiercer,â€ George says working with Saint Laurent was a welcome change of pace. â€œIt was nice to get very specific and go back to a combination of costumes and fashion. I trained in fashion design, so it was nice to combine the two things.â€

Luka Sabbat, left, wore a classic white t-shirt, while Indya Mooreâ€™s red tank top was based on one owned by costumer designer Catherine George. â€œFather Mother Sister Brotherâ€ (Courtesy of Yorick Le Saux/Vague Notion)

title: Discovery Channel Realty Star Chad Ollinger Booked On Murder Charge In Death Of Las Vegas Cellmate

The 41-year-old son of the owner of Utah’s Blind Frog Ranch has been jailed since October at Las Vegas’ […]
content:
Chad Ollinger, who has appeared in five seasons of Discovery Channelâ€˜s reality series Mystery At Blind Frog Ranch, is facing a murder charge in connection with the death of his cellmate at a Las Vegas jail.

The 41-year-old son of the owner of Utahâ€™s Blind Frog Ranch has been jailed since October at Las Vegasâ€™ Clark County Detention Center on charges stemming from an alleged contempt of court.

According to the Las Vegas Metropolitan Police Department, Ollinger has been rebooked on an Open Murder charge (meaning, prosecutors will determine later when the charge is of the first-degree or second-degree).

According to LVMPDâ€™s Sheriff Kevin McMahill, corrections officers at the detention center were conducting routine checks on the night of December 26 when they observed a male inmate lying motionless inside of a cell. â€œOfficers made entry and observed the inmate was suffering from apparent blunt force injuries,â€ according to the police statement. â€œThe other cellmate who was identified as 41-year-old Chad Ollinger was taken into custody.â€

Watch on Deadline

Officers immediately rendered aid to the victim and requested for medical personnel to respond but the inmate was pronounced dead at the scene. LVMPD Homicide detectives were notified and responded. The Clark County Coronerâ€™s Office has identified the deceased cellmate as Christopher Kelly, 42.

According to McMahillâ€™s report, detectives soon learned that a physical altercation had occurred between the victim and Ollinger inside of the cell. Ollinger was then rebooked for Open Murder. The investigation is ongoing and led by the LVMPD Homicide Section.

Over the course of five seasons, the most recent of which concluded this past August, Ollinger appeared in nearly all of the 40 episodes. The docu-series chronicles the efforts of Ollinger and his father, Duane Ollinger, as he hunts for what the father and son believe to be some $3 billion in lost Aztec gold and other treasures hidden in extensive underground caverns on Duaneâ€™s Blind Frog Ranch in northeastern Utah.

The Discovery Channel series purports to investigate the mysteries and phenomena connected to the ranch, including ancient, lost civilizations and UFO activity. The ranch takes its name from the hundreds of blind frogs discovered underground in flooded tunnels on the property.

Ollinger has had numerous run-ins with the law in recent years, though nothing as serious as the latest charge. In 2024 he was charged with evading arrest after police in Amarillo, Texas, gave chase to Ollingerâ€™s motorcycle. He was later charged with driving with an invalid license.

This past October 27, he was arrested and taken into custody in Nevada after being identified as a fugitive from another state who was being sought for contempt of court.

He was arrested and taken into custody in Nevada on Oct. 27, according to Clark County Detention Center records. According to Amarilloâ€™s KFDA News Channel 10, Ollinger was sentenced on December 18 in Nevada on the contempt charge, with records indicating he was scheduled for release on January 12, 2026.

Ollingerâ€™s next scheduled hearing is now set for December 30. He is currently being held in Las Vegas without bond.

title: How A Utopian Society Broke Out In Song & Dance: Mona Fastvold On The Making Of â€˜The Testament Of Ann Leeâ€™ â€“ Crew Call Podcast
summary: This holiday season, Amanda Seyfried is double the force to be reckon with as an unhinged wealthy housewife in Lionsgate’s box office success The Housemaid and in Mona Fastvold’s period epic The Testament of Ann Lee about the iconoclastic, provocative founder of the Shaker movement. content:
This holiday season, Amanda Seyfried is double the force to be reckon with as an unhinged wealthy housewife in Lionsgateâ€™s box office success The Housemaid and in Mona Fastvoldâ€˜s period epic The Testament of Ann Lee about the iconoclastic, provocative founder of the Shaker movement.

Fastvold joins us on todayâ€™s Crew Call to chat about what brought her to Ann Lee; it was while she was doing research on her other 1800s-set drama, The World to Come (Ann Lee being set in the 1700s). The filmmakerâ€™s curiosity piqued on the subject of a religious female crusader at a time when many were immigrating to America for spiritual freedom. Similar to the 3x-Oscar winning The Brutalist, which Fastvold co-wrote and was nominated for as a producer in Best Picture with her partner Brady Corbet, The Testament of Ann Lee, was made for a thrifty net $10M; the duo knowing how to make ambitious cinema at an efficient price in an overpriced motion picture and streaming era. For alas, Ann Lee isnâ€™t your run-of-the-mill biopic. Itâ€™s punctuated with radical musical numbers and dance sequences, not quite seen before on the big screen.

Fastvold tells us how she came to the decision to flip this period pic on its head into a seductive dance epic, part of that inspiration coming from her background in movement.

Watch on Deadline

â€œI said to Brady, I think itâ€™s a musical-and-movement-based project. Brady said, â€˜Itâ€™s a musical, thatâ€™s what it is.'â€ Fastvold tells Crew Call, â€œSo quite early on in the writing process, I realized, I just had to embrace that they lived their life like they were in a musical.â€

Fastvold worked with choreographer Celia Rowlson-Hall after finishing the script to bring the yesteryear dance moves to life.

The movie, which Searchlight purchased following its Venice Film Festival premiere for mid-to-high seven figures, recently opened in four theaters in 70MM in LA and NYC this past weekend posting a $111K 4-day opening. Weekend shows at the Landmark Sunset Theatres in LA had two pre-receptions and live performances which included Rowlson-Hall presenting a bespoke 13-minute performance with ten dancers and three original performers from the film, all wearing their costumes from the movie. The movie expands on Jan. 16 to other cities.

Seyfried received a Golden Globe nomination for Best Performance by a Female Actor in a Motion Picture (Musical or Comedy) for her portrayal of Ann Lee. The film was also nominated for the Gotham Awards, and the Critics Choice (Seyfried for Best Actress and Daniel Blumbergâ€™s â€œClothed by the Sunâ€ in Best Song) and Film Independent Spirit Awards (Best Editing).
