title: â€˜Dandelionâ€™s Odysseyâ€™ Review: A Dialogue-Free Animated Epic Journey Floats With Wondrous Inventiveness
summary: Adrift in the wind, the protagonists of Japanese director Momoko Setoâ€™s French-produced 3D animated curio â€œDandelion’s Odysseyâ€ embark on an epic botanical journey into outer space and away from the tranquility of a planet that strongly resembles the Earth we know. After traveling through a black hole, they arrive on a different floating rock, where […]
content:
Adrift in the wind, the protagonists of Japanese director Momoko Setoâ€™s French-produced 3D animated curio â€œDandelionâ€™s Odysseyâ€ embark on an epic botanical journey into outer space and away from the tranquility of a planet that strongly resembles the Earth we know. After traveling through a black hole, they arrive on a different floating rock, where they face harsh elements and unexpected predators in order to resettle. The catch is that these cosmonauts landing in an undiscovered world are dandelion seeds tethered to delicate, umbrella-like structures, or pappi, comprised of numerous, fuzzy bristles.

Testament to the ingenious character design and astute writing behind the peculiar project (the screenplay is by Seto and Alain Layrac) is that the faceless heroes emote far more than one would ever expect from inanimate vegetation. Imbued with distinct physical attributes, the four seeds exhibit enough personality for audiences to understand their role in the group. One of them is heftier in size, while another appears almost frazzled, having lost most of its bristles. The other pair, including one with a bent stem or beak, resembles a romantic duo.

Popular on Variety

Each time they survive a seemingly insurmountable ordeal, the four of them hug and giggle â€” yes, they make sounds. Despite there being no dialogue, in Setoâ€™s universe, plants produce noises that communicate their emotional state. While the seed itself is presumably the most important part in their taxonomy, the way they move and interact with one another and their surroundings implies that their â€œfacesâ€ are in the middle of the bristles. Seto and the animation team have conceived endearing figures from their limited features.

Impressive photorealistic details in certain textures, especially in the closeups of some of the creatures the roaming seeds encounter on this planet that closely resembles Earth and its flora and fauna. Early on, a frog defrosted from its sleep looks so lifelike that one might make the honest mistake of thinking it was a real animal filmed in the wild. Later, a pair of slugs that help the seed cross an arid landscape, like camels in the desert, glisten vividly.

That level of eye-deceiving detail falters in wide shots, however, some of which suffer from unflattering flat lighting that in certain instances recall computer screensavers of yore, given their colorful artificiality. Similarly, as the four seeds float across the land, the integration between them and the environment occasionally reads visually clunky in its execution, making the viewer aware of the compositing.

In watching â€œDandelionâ€™s Odyssey,â€ audiences might find easy comparisons to Gints Zilbalodisâ€™ Oscar-winning â€œFlow,â€ not only because they are both entirely dialogue-free, but also because their narratives follow a similar arc. That said, Setoâ€™s film aims for a more realistic aesthetic. â€œDandelionâ€™s Odysseyâ€ also resembles 2016â€™s â€œMinuscule: Valley of the Lost Ants,â€ another French nature-based animated adventure, in which cartoonishly stylized bugs interact with natural environments.

While Setoâ€™s debut fits within this subset of wordless, observational exploits, the inventiveness and scientific research likely involved to envision obstacles and situations for the dandelion seeds to construct a high-stakes, compelling epic merits praise, even if the visuals can be uneven at times. Setoâ€™s vision for the foreign planet, where the seeds search for a suitable locale for life to thrive, differs from Earth in notable ways. On this new home, life evolves at incredible speed (a frogâ€™s eggs become tadpoles with the ability to float within seconds), and there are toxic liquids that threaten the seedsâ€™ viability for fulfilling their biological purpose, as well as a sky with multiple moons and Saturn-like rings.

After seeing the heroes fend for themselves, the resolution feels every bit as emotional as those in Don Bluthâ€™s â€œThe Land Before Timeâ€ or Disneyâ€™s â€œDinosaur,â€ achieved with a fraction of the resources.

content:
More musicians have cancelled planned concerts at the Kennedy Center following the decision by its Donald Trump-controlled board to add the presidentâ€™s name to the arts institution.

The Cookers, a jazz ensemble, said in a statement that they â€œare unable to perform as planned on New Yearâ€™s Eve.â€

In a statement, the group did not mention the name change, but said, â€œJazz was born from struggle and from a relentless insistence on freedom: freedom of thought, of expression, and of the full human voice. Some of us have been making this music for many decades, and that history still shapes us. We are not turning away from our audience, and do want to make sure that when we do return to the bandstand, the room is able to celebrate the full presence of the music and everyone in it.

Billy Hart, the bandâ€™s drummer, told The New York Times that the name change â€œevidentlyâ€ played a role in the decision to cancel.

Another group, Doug Varone and Dancers, said that it was cancelling April performances because of the name change.

In a statement on Instagram, the group wrote, â€œWhile we totally disagreed with the takeover by the Trump Administration at the Kennedy Center, we still believed it was important to honor our engagement out of respect for both Jane Raleigh and Alicia Adams, who curated a first-rate dance season, as well as for the dance audiences in DC.â€

â€œHowever, with the latest act of Donald J. Trump renaming the Center after himself, we can no longer permit ourselves nor ask our audiences to step inside this once great institution. The Kennedy Center was named in honor of our 35th President who fervently believed that the arts were the beating heart of our nation, as well as an integral part of international diplomacy. We hope in three-yearâ€™s time, that the Center and its reputation will return to that glory.â€

The board of the Kennedy Center voted earlier this month to add Trumpâ€™s name to the center, even though it was designated as the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts by a 1964 act of Congress.

Last week, musician Chuck Redd pulled out of a planned Christmas Eve concert, leading to the threat of a lawsuit from the Kennedy Centerâ€™s president, Richard Grenell. Another performer, Kristy Lee, canceled a planned performance on Jan. 14.

After the latest cancellations, Grenell wrote on X, â€œThe artists who are now canceling shows were booked by the previous far left leadership. Their actions prove that the previous team was more concerned about booking far left political activists rather than artists willing to perform for everyone regardless of their political beliefs. Boycotting the Arts to show you support the Arts is a form of derangement syndrome. The arts are for everyone and the left is mad about it.â€

The board of the Kennedy Center was set to be split almost evenly between appointees of previous Democratic administrations and Trump in his first term. But weeks after taking office for a second term, Trump fired board members appointed by Joe Biden and Barack Obama. With his loyalists dominating the board, Trump was named chairman of the center.

Congress also designates ex officio members of the board, who remain. One Democrat, Rep. Joyce Beatty of Ohio, filed suit earlier this month to remove Trumpâ€™s name from the center. Her lawsuit claimed that changing the name of the center can only be done by an act of Congress.

summary: Ricky Gervais is on typically unapologetic form in his latest Netflix stand-up special. content:
Ricky Gervais is on typically unapologetic form in his latest Netflix stand-up special.

The co-creator of The Office used Mortality â€” which premiered on Tuesday â€” to bemoan a â€œreally weirdâ€ time for comedy and declare victory over elites who â€œfind anything offensive.â€

Filmed at the London Palladium this year, Gervais said: â€œItâ€™s great to hear this sort of laughter again, because you probably donâ€™t notice it as much as comedians, but weâ€™ve had a really weird 10 years where weâ€™re really second-[guessing jokes].â€

He explained: â€œPeople find anything offensive, but we pushed back and we won. So f*** them. Until the next time. They havenâ€™t gone away. Theyâ€™re just licking their wounds. Theyâ€™ll be back with something madder. But remember who it is next time? Right?

â€œItâ€™s always these sort of educated, middle-class, privileged, elitist, sort of people telling ordinary working-class people what they can and canâ€™t do and say and laugh, not realizing how important comedy is to ordinary people.â€

Gervais has been at the sharp end of controversies around comments in his previous stand-up specials. His 2022 show Supernature came under fire for trans jokes, which he later said didnâ€™t target â€œtrans folk, but trans activist ideology.â€ In 2023, a petition was started requesting that Netflix remove material about young cancer sufferers from Gervaisâ€™ Armageddon special.

Gervais said there had been numerous attempts to get him canceled over the past 15 years â€” including from fellow comedians who criticize him for â€œpunching down.â€ â€œTheyâ€™ve always failed,â€ he said. â€œIâ€™m too old now not to say what I want. I want to say and do what I want all the time. I want to do my favorite thing all the time.â€

Gervais turned to anthropology to offer an explanation for the rise of cancel culture. He said: â€œThereâ€™s still two ways you can raise your status in society. One, be competent at something, like, â€˜Oh, heâ€™s a good hunter, go with him, heâ€™s good for the tribe.â€™ The other way you can raise your status is to have virtue like, â€˜Oh, heâ€™s not a great hunter, but heâ€™s wise or kind or whatever.â€™

â€œAnd then, with the advent of social media, people suddenly discovered they could just say they were virtuous. No evidence, no proof, just loads of flags in their bio. And they would raise their status by bringing other people down, catching other people out â€¦ And thatâ€™s where the term virtual signaling comes from, right?â€

He continued: â€œThe most annoying thing about virtue signalling is people being smug about having the morality of the age. Youâ€™re what youâ€™re like because of where you are and when you are.â€

Gervais said he considers himself to be anti-racist, but acknowledged that he could have been a slave owner in another century. Yeah, Iâ€™d be the best slave owner.â€

Golden Globes Gag

The After Life creator also reflected on his time hosting the Golden Globes, praising the Hollywood Foreign Press Association for never censoring his jokes. He did reveal, however, that he stopped himself from making a gag about Jason Momoa in 2020.

â€œI thought the meta joke would be to show my hypocrisy and my cowardice, like, â€˜Iâ€™m ok to slag off actors whoâ€™s scared of actors? â€œI told my mate I was gonna do that, and my mate went, â€˜Do you think people will think thatâ€™s racist?â€™ I went, â€˜Why is it racist?â€™ â€˜Well, because heâ€™s a person of color.â€™ I went, â€˜Itâ€™s nothing to do with that. Itâ€™s to do with the fact that heâ€™s so big, heâ€™d probably have a cock like a babyâ€™s arm.â€™ So I didnâ€™t do it.â€

Christmas week was reliably bountiful for Broadway, with early reports of record-breaking grosses for the holiday period coming in hours before the official numbers are released by the Broadway League this afternoon.

With news of more house record-busters likely to drift in throughout the day, preliminary numbers are more than impressive for Stranger Things: The First Shadow, Ragtime, Just In Time and Harry Potter and the Cursed Child.

Cursed Child had set the the previous eight-performance house record of $3,152,533 for the week ending November 30, 2025, which happened to include the Thanksgiving holiday.

Like First Shadow, Cursed Child has gotten a recent boost from some stage-screen crossover: Tom Felton recently joined the Broadway cast as Draco Malfoy, the role he played in the Potter film franchise (in the stage sequel he plays the adult Draco, while in the films he was the child Draco). Also have a snazzy holiday week was Just In Time, the cool cat Bobby Darin bio-musical starring a knock-â€™em-dead Jonathan Groff, whoâ€™s in the role until March 29 (a replacement hasnâ€™t been named). Although final figures for the week have not yet been released, sources say the holiday week saw Just In Time smashing Circle In The Squareâ€™s weekly gross record with the popular productionâ€™s highest grossing week to date. That means the Christmas Week figure must be steeper than Just In Timeâ€˜s previous record high of $1,470,023 reported for the week ending December 14.

One of the current fall seasonâ€™s unqualified musical successes is Ragtime, and Christmas Week was no outlier. The non-profit Lincoln Center Theaterâ€™s glorious revival of the musical first staged on Broadway in 1998 has been selling out consistently since previewing in October. Starring Joshua Henry, Caissie Levy, Brandon Uranowitz, Colin Donnell, Ben Levi Ross and Shaina Taub, Ragtime, based on the E.L. Doctorow novel, broke the box office record at LCTâ€™s Vivian Beaumont Theater with a Christmas Week gross of $1,588,107 (the venueâ€™s previous record holder was My Fair Lady).

The full box office report for the week ending December 28 will be posted later this afternoon.

title: George Clooney: â€˜Bari Weiss Is Dismantling CBS News as We Speakâ€™

content:
When George Clooney was preparing to make his Broadway debut appearing as CBS news correspondent Edward R. Murrow in â€œGood Night, and Good Luck,â€ he invited â€œ60 Minutesâ€ to sit in on rehearsals. As the cast gathered for their first read through, Clooney talked about the storyâ€™s prescience â€” though itâ€™s set during McCarthyism in the 1950s, he saw parallels with the political pressure that news organizations face in the second Trump administration.

â€œWhen the other three estates fail â€” when the judiciary and the executive and the legislative branches fail us â€” the fourth estate has to succeed,â€ Clooney said. With that he pointed his finger directly at â€œ60 Minutes'â€ cameras, which are owned by the same network that employed Murrow.

But Clooney feels that CBS has fallen short of its mission. In a new cover story with Variety tied to the release of his new movie, â€œJay Kelly,â€ Clooney faults top law firms like Paul, Weiss, universities like Columbia, and news networks such as CBS and ABC for folding and settling when Trump and his lieutenants sued them.

Popular on Variety

â€œIf CBS and ABC had challenged those lawsuits and said, â€˜Go, fuck yourself, we wouldnâ€™t be where we are in the country,â€ Clooney says. â€œThatâ€™s simply the truth.â€

In the case of CBS, the suspicion was that Shari Redstone opted to make Trumpâ€™s lawsuit with â€œ60 Minutesâ€ go away so he would approve Paramountâ€™s sale to Skydance. The deal went through and Paramount got a new owner in August. Clooney is horrified by how David Ellison, Skydanceâ€™s founder and Paramountâ€™s chairman, has moved to reshape its coverage by installing conservative commentator Bari Weiss as editor-in-chief of CBS News.

â€œBari Weiss is dismantling CBS News as we speak,â€ Clooney says. â€œAm I worried about film studios? Sure. Itâ€™s my business, but my primary loyalty is to my country. Iâ€™m much more worried about how we inform ourselves and how weâ€™re going to discern reality without a functioning press.â€

With Trump back in office, Clooney has continued to sound off on the threats that he poses to civil liberties and to Americaâ€™s standing in the world.

â€œItâ€™s a very trying time,â€ Clooney says. â€œIt can depress you or make you very angry. But you have to find the most positive way through it. You have to put your head down and keep moving forward because quitting isnâ€™t an option.â€

At one point, before Trump descended that golden escalator and set the country on a MAGA course, Clooney and the reality TV star were friends.

â€œI knew him very well,â€ Clooney says. â€œHe used to call me a lot, and he tried to help me get into a hospital once to see a back surgeon. Iâ€™d see him out at clubs and see him out at restaurants. Heâ€™s a big goofball. Well, he was. That all changed.â€

Clooney thinks the Democrats will re-take the House in 2026 and heâ€™s optimistic that the pendulum will swing back in the direction of liberalism after America has its full of Trump.

â€œJust straight up, itâ€™s the economy stupid,â€ Clooney says. â€œItâ€™s more expensive now than it was when Joe Biden left office. And powerful people tend to overplay their hands. I think that cruelty, like separating children from their parents, although popular with small groups of people, doesnâ€™t play well with most Americans.â€

He doesnâ€™t share the anxiety of many Democrats that Trump will refuse to give up his White House perch and run for a third term.

â€œHis popularity is very low and itâ€™s not going to be shooting back up,â€ Clooney says. â€œWe do have a constitution that we do abide by, and although Iâ€™ve been disappointed by many of the Supreme Courtâ€™s decisions, they are strict constitutionalists.â€

Not only is Clooney worried about the direction of the country, heâ€™s also concerned about the changes roiling the movie business. He doesnâ€™t fear streaming services. Heâ€™s worked for them before and though â€œJay Kellyâ€ is a celebration of cinema, itâ€™s being bankrolled by Netflix, a sign of how endangered movies for grownups have become as theatrical propositions. When we sat down in November, Netflix had yet to secure a deal to buy Warner Bros., but Clooney was already concerned about what the sale of the studio where he made many of his greatest movies would signal about the health of the industry.

â€œI liked having separate studios, and I liked them for what they were each good at, and that kind of specialization has gone away,â€ he laments. â€œI worry about things all getting rolled up into one giant company. That would be a very sad moment. Sometimes a big company buys all these little players, and they all lose their identity.â€

But Clooney believes that the future of movies is less important than the direction of America and its leading news organizations.

â€œIf youâ€™re asking if Iâ€™m worried about the film studios, sure,â€ he says. â€œThatâ€™s my business. But my loyalty is to my country, and Iâ€™m much more worried about how we inform ourselves.â€

Clooney is particularly concerned with the development of AI. Heâ€™s seen how much easier it has become to create fake videos that can distort and deceive.

â€œNow you can wash the watermark off of TikTok, and the only way youâ€™re able to discern whether itâ€™s AI generated or not is by the aspect ratio,â€ he says. â€œWhatâ€™s going to happen when we get an AI generated video of Putin saying heâ€™s launched the first strike? And do we have responsible enough people with their fingers on all the triggers to look at this and separate whatâ€™s real from whatâ€™s fake? We used to say, donâ€™t believe everything you read, but we always believed what we saw. Now you canâ€™t do that.â€

AI is changing the movie business, as well. Shortly before Clooney sat down with Variety, news broke that Tilly Norwood, an AI-generated actress, had drawn interest from agencies hoping to represent her. Clooney doesnâ€™t think he or his fellow A-listers will lose work to Tilly.

â€œAs a day player, sure she might be successful, but are you going to build a whole narrative around her?â€ he says. â€œYou can create an AI character, but is it gonna actually break you like Emma Stone? AI can combine all the characters that Emma Stone has played, but it canâ€™t capture her magic. Itâ€™s like that Supreme Court Justice who said, â€˜I canâ€™t describe porn, but I know when I see it.â€™ Itâ€™s the same thing with movie stars. I canâ€™t tell you why someone is one, but I canâ€™t take my eye off of them when theyâ€™re on screen. Itâ€™s very rare when that exists.â€

content:
George Clooney has a cold.

Other A-listers would call in sick, but Clooney, who is on his second round of steroids, is powering through. â€œMy body isnâ€™t up for a fight like it was when I was younger,â€ he says.

Weâ€™re sitting in an empty lounge at Ludlow House in downtown Manhattan to talk about his new movie, â€œJay Kelly,â€ and the Oscar-winning star of â€œMichael Clayton,â€ â€œUp in the Airâ€ and three â€œOceanâ€™sâ€ films is sifting through a small fridge in search of sparkling water. His hair is mostly gray, his face slightly lined, but at 64, heâ€™s still incandescently handsome in that effortless, Cary Grant-like way.

â€œMy kids get sick with something; theyâ€™re fine in three days.â€ Clooney finds the water, pops it open and takes a swig. â€œIâ€™m an old shit â€” it takes me forever!â€ He chuckles with that wry laugh weâ€™ve heard for four decades. â€œIâ€™d been traveling for work, and I got home and my son, Alexanderâ€ â€” who is 8 â€” â€œcame running up to me saying, â€˜Papa, Papa, I donâ€™t feel well,â€™ and he sneezed in my mouth. Iâ€™ve been sick as a dog.â€

Does that sound like a movie star to you? Clooney has been deeply enmeshed in the public consciousness for so long â€” since he became a phenom with â€œERâ€ in the â€™90s â€” that heâ€™s shaped our idea of celebrity as something not only glamorous, but good. Heâ€™s used his fame to draw attention to causes from Darfur to gun control while defending the role of a free press (he grew up the son of broadcast journalist Nick Clooney in Kentucky). At the same time, heâ€™s become Hollywoodâ€™s eternal prankster, pulling one over on Brad Pitt, Matt Damon and his other big-name buddies with elaborate gags that make him more relatable.

He was also committed to bachelorhood â€” that is, until he married human rights attorney Amal Alamuddin in 2014. Now a family man with two children, heâ€™s ready for his next era, showing an industry obsessed with youth how to age gracefully on-screen. â€œIf youâ€™re trying to hold on to being a romantic leading man at my age, it gets sad,â€ Clooney says. â€œI donâ€™t want to be pathetic.â€

Unlike his other big-screen contemporaries, you wonâ€™t find him clinging to the side of a plane or romancing starlets long after heâ€™s qualified for AARP membership. Instead, heâ€™s stretching himself artistically. Clooney made his Broadway debut this year in a stage version of â€œGood Night, and Good Luck,â€ the 2005 film about journalist Edward R. Murrow he co-wrote, directed and appeared in. He followed that up by playing a movie star past his matinee idol prime in â€œJay Kelly.â€ The complex character study pushed him in new directions as a performer, reigniting his creative spark and allowing him to dig deeper.

â€œI got my groove back as an actor,â€ Clooney says. â€œI rediscovered why I love this profession. Itâ€™s not that I wasnâ€™t challenging myself on my last few films, but I knew how to play those parts.â€ Heâ€™s referring to â€œTicket to Paradise,â€ which saw him in rom-com mode opposite Julia Roberts, and â€œWolfs,â€ an action comedy about roguish fixers that reteamed him with Pitt. â€œWith this one, I felt like I did when I started acting and was trying to figure it out,â€ Clooney says. â€œYouâ€™re thinking, â€˜Am I a fraud? Am I going to be found out?â€™ Itâ€™s a really good place to be, to feel off your game.â€

Clooney neednâ€™t have worried. Not only did he score his best reviews in years, but he also earned a Golden Globe nomination for best actor in a musical or comedy and is in the thick of the Oscar race.

â€œJay Kellyâ€ is kicking off Clooneyâ€™s career pivot â€” even though, on paper, playing a movie star doesnâ€™t sound like much of a stretch. But the A-lister he embodies in â€œJay Kellyâ€ is a self-absorbed, career-obsessed performer. He may be beloved by fans around the world, but heâ€™s estranged from his family and doesnâ€™t have any friends. When Jay accepts a lifetime achievement award in Tuscany, the only person who shows up is his long-suffering manager (Adam Sandler). Everyone else has other plans.

â€œWhen I watched it, I kept thinking, â€˜Thank God Georgeâ€™s life is the complete opposite of this,â€ says Roberts, a friend and frequent co-star. â€œYouâ€™d be sending people away if there was a George Clooney tribute. The event would be standing room only.â€

â€œJay Kellyâ€ follows its title character as he treks across Italy, flanked by publicists and stylists, trying to meet up with his daughter, who is backpacking through Europe. She resents him, as does the army of handlers he pays to airbrush his image. Clooney initially worried that Noah Baumbach, who co-wrote and directed the film, had the wrong idea about him.

Richard Phibbs for Variety

â€œI read the script, and there was a part of me that went, â€˜Does he think this is who I am?â€™â€ Clooney says. â€œBecause I knew Noah a little bit, and this characterâ€™s deeply unhappy and kind of a jerk. But then I thought it might be fun to play someone who thinks heâ€™s a good guy, but everything he touches, he destroys.â€

As they worked on the film, Baumbach sprinkled more details from Clooneyâ€™s life into the script, enjoying the meta-ness of the story. Like Clooney, Jay is from Kentucky, and the film includes a moment where one of the actorâ€™s fans urges him to run for president, pressure Clooney often receives from disaffected liberals.

â€œThe illusion, of course, is that George is somehow playing his alter ego,â€ says Baumbach. â€œIf George was playing a dentist, nobody would be asking about similarities. But because movie stars are reflections back at us, and we all have these histories with them, it feels more intense. They are kind of avatars for our hopes and dreams.â€

Clooney, unlike his character, doesnâ€™t stay cloistered in a celebrity bubble, untouchable and inaccessible. He acts like the mayor of any movie set, getting to know everyone by name and refusing to retreat to his trailer between scenes. â€œJay Kellyâ€ was no exception. Clooney and Sandler spent their downtime playing basketball, inviting everyone to shoot hoops with them.

â€œAnybody could walk up, and heâ€™d throw them a ball,â€ Sandler says. â€œBecause itâ€™s Europe, where itâ€™s more about football than basketball, George would show them the proper form and how to shoot. He turned about 20 Italian crew members into real hoops players.â€

Clooney fosters an easygoing work environment, partly so he can be loose when the cameras are ready to roll. â€œI grew up in the Spencer Tracy school,â€ he says, â€œwhich is, you know, come in, be prepared, know what your character wants in the scene. Then, when they say, â€˜Cut and print,â€™ you get on with your life.â€

Pulling pranks is all part of the Clooney package; it helps keep things light and shows he doesnâ€™t take celebrity too seriously. Friends say he spends years finding ways to catch them by surprise.

â€œHeâ€™s very patient, which makes him lethal when it comes to pranks,â€ Steven Soderbergh says. â€œHe had one teed up for [producer] Jerry Weintraub that was jaw-dropping that he never even used. Heâ€™d somehow gotten ahold of Jerryâ€™s golf clubs, and [when Jerry was napping] he took some very compromising photographs of them arranged in a way that clubs should not be arranged. It would have been seismic.â€

While making 2014â€™s â€œThe Monuments Men,â€ Clooney had the wardrobe department take in the waist of Damonâ€™s costumes by an eighth of an inch every day.

â€œI was in my early 40s at the time, and worried about going to seed,â€ Damon says. â€œHe just delighted in messing with me. Long after that happened, I came home from making another movie and put on a suit that was too tight. My first thought was that George had gotten into my closet.â€

In 1998, Clooney was shooting his final season of â€œERâ€ on the Warner Bros. lot in Burbank when he heard that Paul Newman was a few soundstages away working on â€œMessage in a Bottle.â€ He grabbed a golf cart and set out to meet one of his idols. He found Newman sitting outside, drinking beer and smoking cigarettes. At this point, â€œERâ€ was one of the most popular shows on TV, commanding roughly 30 million viewers an episode.

â€œI pulled up and I go, â€˜Hey, Mr. Newman,â€™â€ Clooney recalls. â€œAnd he clearly had no clue who I was. But he was friendly and we started talking. People would drive by going, â€˜George!â€™ â€˜Hey, George!â€™ â€˜Hey, man!â€™ Bit by bit, he figured out that I was well known in some way. And as I started to leave, he goes, â€˜Donâ€™t let them keep you inside.â€™â€

It took Clooney a while to appreciate what Newman meant, but gradually his warning became clear. â€œWhat he was talking about was fame, and the tendency to surround yourself with managers and PR people who build these walls of security so that you donâ€™t get caught doing something stupid,â€ Clooney says. â€œBut what happens is you can divorce yourself from whatâ€™s really going on out there. You need people in your life that tell you the truth.â€

Richard Phibbs for Variety

He thinks the character Jay liked staying in a self-congratulatory cocoon, a predilection that was exacerbated by his early superstardom. â€œI feel like Jay Kelly got famous young, and I donâ€™t know how young people handle fame,â€ Clooney says. â€œThereâ€™s too much attention on you. You believe too much about how great you are. Some actors can deal with it when theyâ€™re young â€” TimothÃ©e Chalamet seems to â€” but I donâ€™t think I would have been one of those people.â€

In contrast, Clooney spent years as a journeyman actor, shuffling through bit parts on â€œRoseanneâ€ and â€œThe Facts of Life.â€ (â€œI have probably the best mullet of all timeâ€ is Clooneyâ€™s assessment of his sitcom work.) It was his performance as a womanizing pediatrician on â€œERâ€ that made him a household name when the show premiered in 1994. By that point, Clooney was 33. â€œIâ€™d failed a lot,â€ he says. â€œIâ€™d been rejected a lot. And so I was better prepared for success.â€

It helped that he knew how fleeting fame can be, having watched his aunt Rosemary Clooney go from chart-topping singer and actress to cautionary tale as she struggled with drugs and lost opportunities. â€œShe did everything wrong â€” there was booze and pills. You name it,â€ he says. â€œI was a kid in Kentucky, but when I did get to know her, the career was long gone. She wasnâ€™t the beautiful blond from â€˜White Christmasâ€™ â€” she was trying to sing in clubs and having a real bad time.â€

Clooney has been called â€œthe last movie star,â€ and it is true that he has a kind of elegance and charm that seems increasingly rare. But he doesnâ€™t totally buy it. He thinks thereâ€™s a rising crop of actors who are ready to take up the mantle, rattling off the names of Chalamet and Glen Powell as younger performers who impress him. He also praises Zendaya, calling her â€œan exceptional talent.â€ But he does acknowledge that theyâ€™re inheriting a fractured entertainment landscape. He came of age in the monoculture â€” when hit shows like â€œERâ€ or movies like â€œOceanâ€™s Elevenâ€ commanded the entire publicâ€™s attention. That all changed as TikTok and YouTube made it easier than ever for anyone to achieve their 15 minutes of fame.

â€œThe thing where you put someoneâ€™s name above the title and you go see a movie because theyâ€™re in it has ended,â€ Clooney says. â€œAnd Iâ€™m part of the last generation of stars who were a beneficiary of a studio really investing in them. When I was on â€˜ER,â€™ Bob Daly and Terry Semel, who were running Warner Bros. at the time, brought me in and gave me a five-picture deal. Because their company had produced my show, they wanted to be in business with me for the long haul.â€

They also were patient with their investment. When Val Kilmer dropped out as Batman, Clooney was hired to wear the cape and cowl. He assumed the superhero movie would prove his bankability. Instead, when â€œBatman & Robinâ€ came out in 1997, it was a campy disaster that nearly killed the franchise and Clooneyâ€™s movie career.

â€œIt was a very painful suit, and you couldnâ€™t move,â€ Clooney remembers. â€œI would be laying on a board, and Joel Schumacher would direct you with a giant speaker, and he would go, â€˜OK, George, and here we go. And ready? Your parents are dead. You have nothing to live for. And â€” action!â€™ And then theyâ€™d just prop me up and I go, â€˜Iâ€™m Batman,â€™ and they go, â€˜And cut.â€™ And they drop me back down, and then they carry me out on the board.â€

Clooney regained his stride with 1998â€™s â€œOut of Sight,â€ a romantic thriller in which he smoldered alongside Jennifer Lopez in a sexually charged game of cops and robbers. It also kicked off his long association with Soderbergh. Critics embraced the film, and the response taught Clooney something valuable about believing your own hype.

â€œI got destroyed for â€˜Batman & Robin,â€™ and fair enough â€” Iâ€™m terrible and itâ€™s a bad film,â€ he says. â€œThe next film I do is â€˜Out of Sight.â€™ Itâ€™s one of the best films Iâ€™ve ever been in. Iâ€™m good in it because itâ€™s well written and has a great director and cast. I didnâ€™t learn how to act any better in those six months between projects. I was protected by the talent around me.â€

Going forward, Clooney made a point of surrounding himself with visionary filmmakers like Soderbergh, Alexander Payne (â€œThe Descendantsâ€) and the Coen brothers (â€œO Brother, Where Art Thou?â€), who made challenging stories mostly aimed at adults. And he largely steered clear of franchises that offered mega-paydays but would have locked him to a certain genre or a signature part.

â€œMost of my successes were middle-of-the-road hits,â€ Clooney says. â€œAnd thatâ€™s lucky, because I was never typecast. I could do all kinds of things. I could do movies that were very serious, like â€˜Michael Clayton,â€™ and then do something wild like â€˜Burn After Reading.â€™ It meant that once I couldnâ€™t kiss the girl anymore, I could still have a career.â€

Long before he was famous, Clooney learned about morality from his father, with whom he remains close. Clooneyâ€™s dadâ€™s career in journalism inspired him to be an engaged citizen and led to his interest in the story of â€œGood Night, and Good Luck,â€ a drama about how CBS News stood up to Joseph McCarthy. When the film was released, Clooney intended to draw parallels between Murrow and how the media was covering the lead-up to the Iraq War. Two decades later, with Donald Trump in office, it hits differently. When Clooney played Murrow last spring, CBS News was settling a frivolous lawsuit with Trump so that heâ€™d approve the sale of its parent company, Paramount, to Skydance. That enraged Clooney, as did ABC Newsâ€™ similar settlement with the president over a defamation claim.

â€œIf CBS and ABC had challenged those lawsuits and said, â€˜Go fuck yourself,â€™ we wouldnâ€™t be where we are in the country,â€ Clooney says. â€œThatâ€™s simply the truth.â€

Heâ€™s only grown more alarmed as David Ellison, Paramountâ€™s new owner, has reshaped CBS Newsâ€™ coverage in a more MAGA-friendly way by installing conservative commentator Bari Weiss as editor-in-chief. â€œBari Weiss is dismantling CBS News as we speak,â€ Clooney says. â€œIâ€™m worried about how we inform ourselves and how weâ€™re going to discern reality without a functioning press.â€

Clooney, who always seems to run cool, grows animated discussing how certain members of that profession have abandoned journalismâ€™s mission to hold the powerful to account. It makes him think about something Murrow says in both the film and the play. â€œâ€˜Letâ€™s not confuse dissent with disloyalty,â€™â€ Clooney says. â€œI mean, what a beautiful, important statement about who we are at our best. But all too often we fall short.â€

On the set of â€œJay Kellyâ€ in Italy Peter Mountain/Netflix

Clooney has long been one of the entertainment industryâ€™s most outspoken liberals, so itâ€™s no surprise to hear that he believes President Trumpâ€™s behavior flies in the face of Murrowâ€™s ideals. â€œItâ€™s a very trying time,â€ Clooney says. â€œIt can depress you or make you very angry. But you have to find the most positive way through it. You have to put your head down and keep moving forward because quitting isnâ€™t an option.â€

What is surprising, though, is that before Trump set the country on a MAGA course, Clooney and the reality-TV star were friendly. â€œI knew him very well,â€ Clooney says. â€œHe used to call me a lot, and he tried to help me get into a hospital once to see a back surgeon. Iâ€™d see him out at clubs and at restaurants. Heâ€™s a big goofball. Well, he was. That all changed.â€

In 2024, Clooney made a big political stir, not by criticizing Trump, but for a New York Times op-ed he wrote urging Joe Biden to drop out of the race following his debate meltdown. Many Democrats were relieved that someone was taking a stand that might save the country from Trump, but the Biden family has continued to criticize Clooney for being disloyal.

Soderbergh says, â€œI thought, â€˜Holy shit.â€™ Itâ€™s classic George. He knows there are going to be so many people pissed at him, but if something is wrong, heâ€™s going to speak out. Somebody had to say it.â€

Clooney wants to model his next phase as an actor on Newman, who he considers the gold standard in how to transition to elder statesman status. Instead of clinging to his heartthrob past, Newman focused on enriching the parts he played as he got older.

â€œHe went from performing love scenes in â€˜Absence of Maliceâ€™ to doing shattering work â€” and looking his age â€” in â€˜The Verdict,â€™â€ Clooney says. â€œAnd it was seamless.â€

Next up for Clooney is â€œIn Love,â€ a low-budget drama in which he will appear opposite Annette Bening as a man with Alzheimerâ€™s. Itâ€™s indicative of the more personal projects he hopes to make.

â€œIâ€™m not going to be doing a whole lot of major studio kinds of films,â€ Clooney says. â€œThe films that Iâ€™m going to be working on for the most part are going to be smaller. If Iâ€™m going to go off and do something and be away from my kids, there has to be a real creative reason for it. Money isnâ€™t an issue for me anymore.â€

But thereâ€™s one franchise Clooney plans to revive â€” â€œOceanâ€™s Eleven.â€ Although instead of a nostalgia play, he wants to explore what itâ€™s like to pull off a heist when youâ€™re no longer young and spry. He was inspired by the movie â€œGoing in Style,â€ a â€™70s comedy about a group of aging criminals, and heâ€™s enlisted Roberts, Damon, Pitt and Don Cheadle to return as an older, but wiser gang. They are scouting locations and hope to start shooting next October.

â€œThere was something about the idea that weâ€™re too old to do what we used to do, but weâ€™re still smart enough to know how to get away with something, that just appeals to me,â€ Clooney says. â€œTheyâ€™ve lost a step, and they need to find a way to work around their limitations.â€

Personally, Clooney says heâ€™s happier than ever. He has a large network of friends, and makes a point of planning boysâ€™ trips and keeping in touch with people through chat groups. He and Damon are part of a Wordle network that Clooney has dubbed â€œNerdleâ€ because of its intricacy â€” they do three puzzles every day, add up the scores and the winner gets to choose the word they start with the next morning. â€œGeorge is frustratingly good at it,â€ Damon says.

He also has loved having a family, brightening when he talks about becoming a dad to twins in his 50s.

â€œThis chapter of Georgeâ€™s life fills me with so much joy,â€ Roberts says. â€œAmal is an absolute rock star. I could never conjure up a dream girl like this for George, and to watch him with his kids is so special.â€

â€œJay Kelly,â€ with its portrait of a stultifying form of celebrity, may be very different from the way that Clooney operates on and off screen. However, Clooneyâ€™s art and life do converge at the end of the film as Jay sits in a theater watching clips of his performances. The scenes Baumbach splices together are all drawn from Clooneyâ€™s films â€” there he is, saving the world in â€œThe Peacemaker,â€ working all the angles as an operator in â€œMichael Claytonâ€ and sipping a scotch while playing a smooth criminal in â€œOut of Sight.â€

Itâ€™s impossible not to be moved by the sheer weight of the filmography, as well as to feel that the period of cinema he represents, one in which star power was the biggest special effect of all, is slipping away. â€œWhen we shot it, all I had told him was that I wanted to show him something,â€ Baumbach says. â€œHe didnâ€™t question it. He just remained open to what I was going to do.â€

The take Baumbach ended up using, one in which Clooneyâ€™s eyes begin to well with emotion, was the first one he shot.

â€œWhen youâ€™re young youâ€™re desperately figuring out a way to cry,â€ Clooney says. â€œYouâ€™re pulling out nose hairs and pinching yourself. But the older you get, the faster the emotions bubble up. I have no trouble tearing up now.â€

Some things do improve with age.

Location: Ludlow House

Richard Smallwood, the Grammy-nominated gospel singer whose music has been covered by Destinyâ€™s Child and Whitney Houston, has died. He was 77.

A rep for Smallwood confirmed to Variety that he died of complications from kidney failure on Tuesday at the Brooke Grove Rehabilitation and Nursing Center in Maryland.

Throughout his career, Smallwood established himself as a powerful vocalist, pianist and songwriter in the gospel space, earning eight Grammy nominations and winning several Dove and Stellar Awards. As leader for the Richard Smallwood Singers and later Vision, Smallwood scored several hits including â€œTotal Praise,â€ â€œTrust Meâ€ and â€œIâ€™ll Trust You.â€ Over the years, his songs were covered by artists including Houston, who remade â€œI Love the Lordâ€ for â€œThe Preacherâ€™s Wife,â€ as well as Destinyâ€™s Child, who covered â€œTotal Praiseâ€ as part of a 2007 acapella track â€œGospel Medley.â€

Smallwood was born in November 1948 in Atlanta, GA, and was raised in Washington, D.C. by his mother and stepfather. He began playing piano at the age of five and formed his own gospel group by 11. He attended Howard University, where he earned a degree in music, and was a member of the universityâ€™s first gospel group, the Celestials.

Popular on Variety

In 1977, he founded the Richard Smallwood Singers and signed to Onyx Records in 1982 to release their debut album â€œThe Richard Smallwood Singers,â€ which spent 87 weeks on the Billboard Spiritual Album Sales chart. They received their first Grammy nomination for their 1984 album â€œPsalms,â€ and continued to release five more records.

Smallwood disbanded the Smallwood Singers in the early 1990s and formed the backing choir Vision, which accompanied him on numerous albums through 2015. Their song â€œTrust Me,â€ which hit No. 9 on the Hot Gospel Songs chart, scored his final Grammy nomination in 2012 in the best gospel song category. In 2019, he published the book â€œTotal Praise: The Autobiography,â€ detailing his familyâ€™s personal history. In the last few years of his life, Smallwood battled mild dementia and other health issues that prevented him from recording new music.

Smallwood is survived by his brothers, sisters, nieces, nephews and godchildren.

Jared Leto stars as the personified AI alongside Greta Lee, Evan Peters, Jodie Turner-Smith, Hasan Minhaj, Arturo Castro, Gillian Anderson and Jeff Bridges, who reprises his role as protagonist Kevin Flynn from the previous two movies. The original â€œTron,â€ directed by Steven Lisberger, grossed $50 million in 1982. title: â€˜Heated Rivalryâ€™ Author on â€˜Listeningâ€™ to Connor Storrie and Hudson Williams Film Their First Sex Scene, Wanting 12 Episodes for Season 2 and How the Showâ€™s Success Is Helping Her Fight Parkinsonâ€™s
summary: Canadian romance novelist Rachel Reid first saw Connor Storrie and Hudson Williams in person on the set of â€œHeated Rivalry,â€ Jacob Tierneyâ€™s television adaptation of her queer hockey book series “Game Changers.” â€œThey were filming the very first sex scene, their first hookup and itâ€™s the longest sex scene on the show,â€ Reid tells me. content:
Canadian romance novelist Rachel Reid first saw Connor Storrie and Hudson Williams in person on the set of â€œHeated Rivalry,â€ Jacob Tierneyâ€™s television adaptation of her queer hockey book series â€œGame Changers.â€

â€œThey were filming the very first sex scene, their first hookup and itâ€™s the longest sex scene on the show,â€ Reid tells me. â€œIt was a closed set, so I was just sitting on a couch for four hours while they did that. I had headphones, so I could hear it and I had read the script, but I couldnâ€™t see it. I was just listening. I was listening to them pretend to have sex for four hours, and I didnâ€™t really know them, so that was weird.

â€œI do remember Hudson saying, â€˜Should I keep my socks on?â€™â€ she continues. â€œI was nodding, but nobody could see me. Iâ€™m glad he did.â€

Popular on Variety

â€œHeated Rivalryâ€ stars Storrie as Russian hockey star Ilya Rozanov and Williams as his archrival Shane Hollander. The six-episode series follows the two men as they carry on a secret years-long affair before eventually falling in love.

The show became a runaway hit as soon as HBO Max, which acquired the series for U.S. distribution from Canadian streamer Crave, dropped the first two episodes over Thanksgiving weekend.

On set, Storrie tapped Reid on the shoulder to introduce himself. â€œHe looked so much like Ilya and he speaks with a Russian accent all day while on set,â€ Reid recalls. â€œHe was asking all these thoughtful questions about the character. I couldnâ€™t even talk to him because itâ€™s like Iâ€™m explaining Ilya to Ilya. It was very weird, but I could tell right away he was really smart and funny and charming. Heâ€™s so talented and fearless. I mean, introducing yourself to the author for the first time while doing a Russian accent is, I think, a fearless choice.â€

She watched Williams film the moments before Shane and Ilya have their initial tryst in a hotel room. â€œHe was turning the lamp on and off waiting for Ilya to come for the first hookup,â€ Reid says. â€œHe had no lines, but I was like, â€˜Oh, thatâ€™s Shane.â€™â€

In just over a month, Storrie and Williams have become household names, the series has been greenlit for a second season and several of Reidâ€™s novels have become New York Times bestsellers.

â€œIâ€™ve been asked to speak at the University of Cambridge,â€ Reid says. â€œI write hockey smut. Iâ€™m not Kurt Vonnegut. They were like, â€˜Weâ€™ve had Robert De Niro and the Dalai Lama.â€™ And Iâ€™m like, â€˜Oh yeah, and me â€” I fit right in there.â€™â€

I caught up with Reid over Zoom from her home in Nova Scotia. â€œIâ€™ll warn you, I think Iâ€™m still in shock,â€ she says. â€œI donâ€™t know if I could speak coherently about any of this, but Iâ€™ll try.â€

When you initially talked to Jacob, was there any discussion of you having any sort of creative control or a say in what he does?

The first conversation I had with him, I could tell he understood the characters so well and the story so well. He laid out his whole vision for the show, and that really is exactly what everybody just watched. Thatâ€™s how he described it to me. He wanted that Scott and Kip episode. We talked about what we were going to have to do to make sure we got everything right, how the sex was going to have to be an important part of the show and it was going to have to be explicit. He wouldnâ€™t do it if he couldnâ€™t do that. As soon as we had that first conversation, I was like, â€œYou know what? He knows exactly what heâ€™s doing. Iâ€™m not even worried about it.â€ I wasnâ€™t really pushy at all. He just wanted me to read the scripts and I was really excited to do that. Obviously, he was very capable of doing this without my help, but he still included me. They [Tierney, Williams and Storrie] continued throughout all of the media and everything mentioning me and the books. I really appreciate that because I donâ€™t think a lot of authors get that.

Which casting did you know about first?

Connor was first. I didnâ€™t even hear about another possibility for Ilya. If there was one, I didnâ€™t know about it. I know that Jacob was very excited about Connor. But it was a thing where we said that he pretty much has to be actually Russian because if heâ€™s not, itâ€™s going to be so distracting. People will be able to tell. The whole thing falls apart if heâ€™s not believably Russian. So when he told me, â€œWell, heâ€™s American and does not have Russian heritage, but heâ€™s really good,â€ I was like, â€œWell, OK, if you say so.â€ I think it took a little longer to find Hudson, but as soon as they did their chemistry read, Jacob was very excited about it. I canâ€™t even imagine what other actors wouldâ€™ve been like.

When you saw Connor and Hudson, did they look like what you were imagining when you were writing Ilya and Shane?

At first, not quite, because I was just looking at still images of them [on Instagram]. Hudson had a lot of pictures where he looked like a badass and he was smoking or showing off all of his tattoos. I was like, â€œIâ€™m not seeing it.â€ But then as soon as I met them on set, I was like, â€œYep, theyâ€™re actually perfect.â€

Writing is such a solitary profession. What is it like going from being by yourself writing to now having all these eyes and attention on you?

Itâ€™s overwhelming. Authors donâ€™t want to be looked at. Itâ€™s not a natural thing. I used to be in a rock band, and thatâ€™s an art that you make where you get your audience feedback right away live and you can feed off of it. But writing, even if itâ€™s big and popular and you know a lot of people are reading it, you donâ€™t know about it. You donâ€™t get that feedback really until something like this happens. And then suddenly itâ€™s like, â€œOh, I can actually get mobbed sometimes.â€ People are just very excited to meet me in a way that kind of confuses me, but Iâ€™m trying to get used to it.

Have you spoken to Jacob about what youâ€™d like to see in Season 2?

I think weâ€™re on the same page about it. Obviously, the focus has to stay on Ilya and Shane. Weâ€™re not going to do Season 2 and itâ€™s a totally different couple. It wouldnâ€™t be very popular. Not that we werenâ€™t expecting it, but I think weâ€™re all surprised at how popular Scott and Kip were. So now itâ€™s, â€œOK, how do you get more Scott and Kip?â€ I think itâ€™s going to be mostly â€œThe Long Game.â€ Jacobâ€™s already said that in interviews, but thereâ€™s another book â€œRole Modelâ€ that kind of overlaps it. So Iâ€™m hoping that weâ€™ll get both stories told at the same time. I donâ€™t think thereâ€™s another way you could do it. Iâ€™m hoping we get more episodes.

How many episodes do you want?

Iâ€™d go as high as 12, but maybe if it was just eight or 10, that would be nice.

Brendan Brady, Jacob Tierney, Ksenia Daniela Kharlamova, Dylan Walsh, Hudson Williams, Connor Storrie, Christina Chang and Rachel Reid attend the premiere of â€œHeated Rivalryâ€ at TIFF Lightbox on November 24, 2025 in Toronto, Ontario. Getty Images

Do you have a group of gay friends who you have ask you to read your writing, specifically the sex scenes, to make sure theyâ€™re realistic?

I donâ€™t send them writing. Actually, I realized when the show came out that a lot of my gay male friends have never read my books because theyâ€™re all obsessed with the show and they were all on their edge of their seats. They couldnâ€™t believe things that were happening. I was like, â€œSo youâ€™ve not read the books?â€ I have discussions with them. I donâ€™t like showing anybody my writing until itâ€™s done. My husband is somebody that I can send them to because he is bisexual and does know what itâ€™s like to have sex with men. So thatâ€™s somebody I can bounce things off of. But mostly I just talk to people and get information that way.

Will there ever be a â€œHeated Rivalryâ€ Broadway musical?

I hope so, because I still hold the stage rights to that. It was the thing that when I signed the contract, I was like, â€œYeah, thatâ€™ll never happen.â€ But now Iâ€™m like, â€œMaybe.â€ Weâ€™re talking about all sorts of things right now. I was saying to Hudson a couple weeks ago that it feels like we could do literally anything. It just seems like we have too much power and we also have the power to destroy ourselves very easily. We could take it all down with one bad post, one bad tweet. We could destroy the whole show and everybodyâ€™s lives. I was just like, â€œThis is too much power.â€

You have talked about being diagnosed with Parkinsonâ€™s at the same time Jacob approached you about the television adaptation. How is your health today?

Itâ€™s making it hard to write because I can barely control a mouse. I canâ€™t type for very long. Itâ€™s hard for me to sit in a chair for very long. I need to figure out new ways to write. I donâ€™t know if that will be voice to text. I donâ€™t know if I can write that way. It doesnâ€™t feel natural, but I need to figure out something because it is taking me a very long time to write now. But an amazing thing thatâ€™s come out of this though is Jacob was on CNN a few weeks ago. For whatever reason, the interviewer asked him about my Parkinsonâ€™s diagnosis. I thought it was kind of odd, but then the next day, one of the top Parkinsonâ€™s experts in the world reached out to me and asked if he could help me. Iâ€™ve never gotten to talk to a Parkinsonâ€™s expert. Iâ€™ve been on a five-year waiting list here because I live in a very small place. Now heâ€™s found me a Parkinsonâ€™s expert, a neurologist, and I have an appointment in a couple weeks. That could change things for me because Iâ€™m not really getting the treatment that I should be getting. He also told me how to change my medication so I can sleep because I never slept. That change made me sleep through the night, which really helps with writing.

title: Michael Lippman, Manager and Lawyer for George Michael, David Bowie, Rob Thomas and Other Music Stars, Dies at 79
summary: Michael Lippman, who worked with David Bowie, George Michael, Matchbox Twenty and other top stars as a manager, lawyer or label executive, died Monday at age 79. No cause of death was immediately given. In later years Lippman was best known for serving as a manager to Michael, first at the peak of his fame […]
content:
Michael Lippman, who worked with David Bowie, George Michael, Matchbox Twenty and other top stars as a manager, lawyer or label executive, died Monday at age 79. No cause of death was immediately given.

In later years Lippman was best known for serving as a manager to Michael, first at the peak of his fame during the â€œFaithâ€ era in the late 1980s, and then again, after a 17-year gap, beginning in the mid-2000s.

But his first major notoriety came in his stint as attorney and, briefly, manager for Bowie from 1971 through 1975, with the rock star even living at Lippmanâ€™s home during the â€œStation to Stationâ€ period before an abrupt split.

Popular on Variety

After his experience with Bowie, Lippman switched gears and took a label role as VP of west coast operations for Arista Records for three years into the late â€™70s, after having become friendly with the imprintâ€™s founder while making a deal for Patti Smith to join the label. â€œClive Davis was the boss and I always thought my job was to take people to lunch and dinner for a living, and I did it very well,â€ he quipped. More seriously, perhaps, Lippman said Davis â€œreally made an impact on me. I never saw a man work that hard and that long every day. Heâ€™d be in the office until nine or 10 oâ€™clock and then would have Â­dinner. He inspired me to put in the time.â€

At Arista, Lippman worked closely with artists like Melissa Manchester. He took credit for forcing the Oscars to allow Manchester to sing two best-song-nominated numbers on the Academy Awards telecast in 1980, a first (the songs being â€œThrough the Eyes of Loveâ€ from â€œIce Castlesâ€ and â€œIâ€™ll Never Say Goodbyeâ€ from â€œThe Promise,â€ both of which she had sung on the original soundtracks).

Lippman was an innovator in seeing a need for producers and songwriters to have managers just as recording artists did.

â€œWhat I saw was that record producers and songwriters were really treated like low men on the totem pole and represented by a lawyer but never a manager,â€ he recalled in a 2010 interview. â€œI realized theyâ€™re artists in their own right and need to make sure their deals are done properly and their records they make are worked. Thatâ€™s what I did and started a company representing producers and songwriters.â€

In 1980, he began managing producer Ron Nevison, and soon took on Elton Johnâ€™s writing collaborator, Bernie Taupin, in a professional partnership that lasted for 37 years.

Lippman saw the advent of so-called 360 deals as a natural extension of the cross-platform interest he had always taken in developing artists as a manager.

â€œThatâ€™s what Iâ€™ve always done, taking are of all aspects of my artistsâ€™ career from touring to merchandising to selling records to making videos,â€ he said. â€œIâ€™m a unique breed when it comes to managers who have the experience on the business and the creative/marketing side. In the old days record companies would tell (managers) â€˜Donâ€™t talk to radio stations or TV stations!â€™ That was their control. I built these incredible relationships with TV and radio around the world. Now a managerâ€™s role is more important than ever in marketing an artist. Our motto is always to try to do something that no oneâ€™s ever done before. Iâ€™ve always been an international manager and it was always important for us to sell records worldwide, tour worldwide and market our artists worldwide. I still think you have to go to all of those territories, but itâ€™s easier to do it on a worldwide basis with the internet.â€

Lippman began working with his son, Nick, in an official partnership in 2004, under the name Lippman Entertainment.

â€œI believe Iâ€™m the luckiest guy in the world to have been able to work with my two sons and my brother in the same business,â€ he said in a Billboard profile in 2016. â€œAt the same time, I wasnâ€™t the greatest father because I was always on the road. So now that I have the opportunity to see them every day and work side by side, itâ€™s been incredible. Nicholas is my best friend today.â€

Lippman is survived by his wife, Nancy, and two sons, Nick and Josh.

His sons offered respective statements to Rolling Stone. â€œMichael was my mentor and the greatest teacher,â€ said Nick Lippman. â€œFor over twenty years, we traveled the world and shared a bond that grew deeper with time. We spoke every day and often finished each otherâ€™s sentences. Our relationship was shaped by the work we did side by side, and a bond of love, trust and mutual respect.â€

Said Josh Lippman, â€œDad was a relentless advocate for his clients, his friends and his family. He was the person you wanted in your corner in any situation. He transitioned from bulldog to effortless charmer on a dime, often multiple times in a conversation, and never met a challenge he couldnâ€™t solve.â€

content:
Tatiana Schlossberg, the granddaughter of John F. Kennedy who chronicled her blood cancer battle in a devastating recent New Yorker column, died Tuesday. She was 35.

The JFK Library Foundation announced her death, writing on behalf of her family, â€œOur beautiful Tatiana passed away this morning. She will always be in our hearts.â€ The social media message was signed George, Edwin and Josephine Moran and Kennedys Ed, Caroline, Jack, Rose and Rory.

Schlossberg was diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia after her daughter was born in 2024. In a widely read New Yorker essay published in November, she revealed that it had become a form of terminal cancer.

Popular on Variety

In the essay, she brutally took aim at Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and his health policies.

â€œIn August, 2024, he suspended his campaign and endorsed Donald Trump, who said that he was going to â€˜let Bobby go wildâ€™ on health. My mother wrote a letter to the Senate, to try and stop his confirmation; my brother had been speaking out against his lies for months. I watched from my hospital bed as Bobby, in the face of logic and common sense, was confirmed for the position, despite never having worked in medicine, public health, or the government,â€ Schlossberg wrote.

Schlossberg was a climate and energy reporter at the New York Times, and left in 2017. She wrote about the dead bear cub found in Central Park in 2014, and didnâ€™t realize it had been put there by her relative Robert F. Kennedy Jr. until he revealed it in 2024. Her book â€œInconspicuous Consumption: The Environmental Impact You Donâ€™t Know You Haveâ€ was published in 2019.

Schlossbergâ€™s mother was John F. Kennedyâ€™s daughter Caroline Kennedy; her father was designer Edwin Schlossberg.

Smallwood played piano as a featured artist on Kirk Franklinâ€™s 2000 single â€œDonâ€™t Cry,â€ which was a Top 10 gospel hit.

Along the way he won four Dove Awards on 19 nominations from the Gospel Music Association and was inducted into its Hall of Fame in 2006. He was up for Traditional Gospel Recorded Song of the Year at the 2025 Doves as a co-writer of Ricky Dillardâ€™s â€œWhen I Think.â€

content:
Deadlineâ€™s Read the Screenplay series spotlighting the scripts behind the yearâ€™s most talked-about movies continues with The Long Walk, Lionsgateâ€™s psychological thriller from director Francis Lawrence, adapted for the screen by JT Mollner based on Stephen Kingâ€™s first novel.

The story is set in a post-war, dystopian America where a military despot known as the Major (Mark Hamill) oversees an annual televised contest of pure will. In this brutal marathon march known as The Long Walk, 50 boys selected by lottery must maintain a constant pace of at least 3 mph. If a contestant falls below the speed, they receive a warning; after three warnings, they are executed, or out, leaving only one survivor to claim riches beyond belief and any wish they desire.

Lionsgate released the film in theaters in September and it has grossed $62.9 million at the global box office. Its ensemble cast will be the recipient of the Independent Spirit Awardsâ€˜ Robert Altman Award next year.

Watch on Deadline

At the center of the script is local contestant Ray Garraty (Cooper Hoffman), whose journey alongside Peter McVries (David Jonsson) forms the filmâ€™s emotional core. Their relationship evolves from one technical competition into a soulful, brotherly alliance that serves as an act of defiance against a merciless system. To capture this unraveling of the human spirit, Lawrence utilized a strategy of shooting in strict linear order, allowing the audience to witness the actorsâ€™ actual physical deterioration and psychological decline as they walked tens of miles per day.

Thematically, the script serves as a stark metaphor for the erosion of the American dream and the financial nihilism felt across modern society. While the original 1967 novel was an allegory for the Vietnam War, the 2025 adaptation re-frames the story to reflect contemporary struggles with inflation, stagnating wages, and the desperation of people who feel they must risk their lives to secure a future.

Beyond the sociopolitical commentary, the narrative explores the power of friendship to provide light in total darkness, examining how human connections can be forged even in a culture that thrives on carnage and division. By stripping down the world to primal sights and sounds, the script asks uncomfortable questions about human value and what makes life worth living when there is nothing left to give.

title: Rob Reinerâ€™s Death Records Sealed â€œUntil Further Noticeâ€ As LAPD Probe Into Director & Michele Reinerâ€™s Murders Deepens

Under suicide watch behind bars in downtown LA, the 32-year-old could facing the death penalty after being charged with two counts of first-degree murder with â€œspecial circumstancesâ€ on December 16 by the LA County District Attorney.

While not unprecedented, sealing such records like the Reiners after they have been out there already for a couple of weeks is a rare development. â€œOn December 24 at 10:30 a.m., the County of Los Angeles Department of Medical Examiner (Department) received a court order, initiated by the Los Angeles Police Department (LAPD), to place a security hold on Medical Examiner case numbers 2025-19480 and 2025-19481, Robert and Michele Reiner,â€ the Medical Examinerâ€™s office said late Monday. â€œWhile the cause and manner of death were previously released on these cases, due to the court order, the information is no longer available. No other case information or records, including the Medical Examiner report, can be released or posted on the website until further notice.

â€œThe Department understands the publicâ€™s interest in these cases and remains committed to transparency when possible. Information will be made available once the court order is lifted.â€

(L-R) Rob Reiner, Michele Singer Reiner, Romy Reiner, Nick Reiner , Maria Gilfillan & Jake Reiner at Spinal Tap II: The End Continues LA Premiere in September 2025 Getty

The successful Christmas Eve sealing ask from the police comes as the investigation into the death of the 78-year-old A Few Good Men director and 68-year-old the photographer deepens with more details emerging of what actually occurred in the coupleâ€™s Brentwood home on the first night of Hanukkah. ery publicly having struggled with addiction and the consequences of the disease for years, Nick Reiner had been living in the guesthouse on his parentsâ€™ property for several weeks before their death. The context of how the apparently quick stabbings occurred could proved essential to both the Alan Jackson-led defense and the prosecution â€“ especially in terms of if the younger Reiner was aware or not what he was doing, as alleged.

Simultaneously and with great sensitivity, DA Nathan Hochmanâ€˜s office is trying to set a face-to-face meeting with the grieving Reiner family, Iâ€™m told. As the DA said in the week before Christmas, he and his team want to sit down with the family, especially siblings Romy, her brother Jake and the adopted Tracy, to hear their perspective on if prosecutors should seek life in prison without parole for Nick Reiner or the death penalty.

The death penalty is rare in California but still permitted in such â€œspecial circumstancesâ€ such as what the younger Reiner has been charged with.

Neither the LA DAâ€™s office nor defense attorney Jackson responded Tuesday to Deadlineâ€™s requests for comments on the sealing of the Reinersâ€™ death records.

title: Warner Bros. Discovery Set To Reject Paramountâ€™s Latest Takeover Bid After Board Meets Next Week

content:
When business revs back up next week, Warner Bros. Discovery looks set to reject Paramountâ€™s amended hostile takeover bid due in part to concerns at the delay that could dog its planned cable spinoff if a deal falls through, Deadline hears.

WBD agreed earlier this month to sell its studio and streaming assets to Netflix in a cash and stock transaction worth $27.75 a share as it packages the rest into a standalone publicly traded linear television company called Discovery Global by the third quarter of next year. Paramount Skydance is offering to buy all of WBD, which would mean pencils down on a separation as the broader deal works its way through a potentially fraught regulatory process.

David Ellison-led Paramount has insisted that it has the easier path to approval and that may be, but some investors seem to feel that things are not quite as clear cut as they initially seemed. Trump described Netflix co-CEO Ted Sarandos as â€œfantasticâ€ but also noted that a combined Netflix-Warner would â€œhave a very big market shareâ€ in streaming. Further confusing the issue, he also said he opposes any plan in which WBD continues to own CNN.

WBD announced its Netflix deal in November over rivals bids from Paramount and Comcast. The NBCUniversal parent bowed out, but Paramount went over the heads of Warnerâ€™s board directly to shareholders with a hostile offer that WBD formally rejected. In an amended offer, Paramount added a $40.4 billion personal financial guarantee by Larry Ellison and raised its breakup fee to $5.8 billion, matching Netflix. But it did not sweeten the base amount of the bid, which still stands at $30 a share in cash. WBD last said Dec. 22 that it was considering the revised offer. Deadline hears the board will meet next week and no final decision has yet been made, but it seems a rejection is in the cards.

Beyond the personal guarantee, WBDâ€™s board raised other issues including its need for financial flexibility pending the close, which Paramount said it had addressed, as well as a $2.8 billion breakup fee that WBD would owe Netflix if it switches lanes.

Some WBD shareholders have said publicly that Paramount should sweeten its offer, which has a total equity value of $77.9 billion and an enterprise value of $108.4 billion (including net debt and non-controlling interests), and many Wall Streeters believe it will. Meanwhile, Par has been urging WBD stockholders to tender their shares by the new Jan. 21, 5 pm ET deadline. They can withdraw the shares at any time before then and the tender can also be extended.

If and when Paramount raises its bid, the question is whether Netflix will counter. Several media analysts told Deadline they think Paramount will ultimately prevail because itâ€™s smaller than Netflix and needs the deal more. One called the race â€œneck and neck right now.â€

Reps for WBD and Paramount declined to comment.

The DOJ announcement follows a disclosure of the same settlement last September by the Federal Trade Commission. According to the FTC complaint originally filed by the DOJ, Disney allegedly […]
content:
The Walt Disney Co. is paying $10 million to settle allegations over the labeling of children-focused videos onto YouTube, the U.S. Department of Justice reaffirmed Tuesday.

The DOJ announcement follows a disclosure of the same settlement last September by the Federal Trade Commission.

According to the FTC complaint originally filed by the DOJ, Disney allegedly violated the Childrenâ€™s Online Privacy Protection Act. By failing to properly label the YouTube-uploaded videos as â€œMade for Kids,â€ the FTC said, the company enabled the collection of data from children under 13 without parental consent.

The videos at issue were posted between 2020 and 2022, according to the FTC complaint filed by the Justice Department.

Watch on Deadline

The DOJ had filed the FTC complaint with the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California. In announcing the settlement Tuesday, the department said the court had ordered Disney, in addition to the civil penalty, to create a program to ensure proper compliance with COPPA on YouTube in the future.

â€œThe Justice Department is firmly devoted to ensuring parents have a say in how their childrenâ€™s information is collected and used,â€ said Assistant Attorney General Brett A. Shumate of the departmentâ€™s Civil Division. â€œThe department will take swift action to root out any unlawful infringement on parentsâ€™ rights to protect their childrenâ€™s privacy.â€

COPPA, which took effect in 2000, has recently been revisited in light of the rise in social media use among kids and teenagers and the ubiquity of digital content. An amended version of the law was passed by the U.S. Senate in 2024 but did not receive House approval. House Republicans have recently revived it and committees have been conducting hearings.

Disney is not the only company to be found at fault by the government for its offerings for minors. Microsoft paid $20 million in 2023 to resolve claims that it violated childrenâ€™s privacy with sign-ups for its Xbox video game platform. The FTC in 2024 put forward a recommendation that TikTok be sued for alleged COPPA violations.

A Disney spokesperson said last September, â€œSupporting the well-being and safety of kids and families is at the heart of what we do. This settlement does not involve Disney owned and operated digital platforms but rather is limited to the distribution of some of our content on YouTubeâ€™s platform. Disney has a long tradition of embracing the highest standards of compliance with childrenâ€™s privacy laws, and we remain committed to investing in the tools needed to continue being a leader in this space.â€

The media company had no additional comment Tuesday when contacted by Deadline.

After a settlement in 2019, YouTube started to require that content creators indicate if videos that are uploaded as â€œmade for kidsâ€ or â€œnot made for kids.â€ Content creators mark the videos or entire channels in such ways. The FTC claimed that Disney was told in mid-2020 that YouTube had changed designations on more than 300 videos to â€œmade for kids,â€ but the company did not change its policy of a blanket designation at the channel level. The videos in question included content from movies like Frozen, Inside Out, Finding Dory, and Encanto.

The FTCâ€™s complaint noted that the Pixar channel was marked as â€œnot made for kids,â€ while the similar videos on the Pixar Cars channel was designated as â€œmade for kids.â€ The complaint said that disparity â€œillustrates Disneyâ€™s failure to mark child-directed content as MFK when such content is uploaded to NMFK channels.â€

Axios first reported on the settlement last September.

This yearâ€™s honorees were George Strait, Sylvester Stallone, KISS, Michael Crawford and Gloria Gaynor.

title: Warner Bros. Discovery Board Poised to Reject Paramountâ€™s Latest Offer, Stay the Course With Netflix
summary: The board of Warner Bros. Discovery is poised to reject the amended takeover offer fielded by Paramount Skydance last week as David Ellison keeps up his pursuit of the assets he sees as crucial to building a 21st century Hollywood heavyweight. Bloomberg News reported Tuesday that the WBD board was expected to reject the amended […]
content:
The board of Warner Bros. Discovery is poised to reject the amended takeover offer fielded by Paramount Skydance last week as David Ellison keeps up his pursuit of the assets he sees as crucial to building a 21st century Hollywood heavyweight.

Bloomberg News reported Tuesday that the WBD board was expected to reject the amended offer that was made with fanfare by Paramount Skydance on Dec. 22. WBD has already struck an agreement to merge with Netflix in a deal valued at more than $80 billion.

But Paramount Skydance hasnâ€™t given up and is making a tender offer to WBD shareholders. As this tug-of-war has played out in press releases and conference calls and Securities and Exchange Commission filings, WBD shares have soared more than 170% this year, albeit shares were at a low ebb, having traded under $10 for most of 2024. Bloomberg reported the WBD board will meet next week to formally vote on a response to Paramountâ€™s latest offer. A WBD representative declined to comment on matter.

Popular on Variety

The WBD boardâ€™s expected decision is not a surprise given there have been no signs of a significant about-face in the panelâ€™s thinking about which company is the best fit for Warner Bros. and HBO Max. There is also much industry intrigue about how far Paramount is willing to go, if at all, in raising the financial value of its bid higher than the existing $30 a share.

Paramountâ€™s amended offer from last week largely dealt with the financing of the all-cash transaction. Software billionaire Larry Ellison, who is the father of David Ellison, took steps to address the WBDâ€™s stated concerns about the sources of Paramountâ€™s financing. Larry Ellison enlarged his personal stake in the transaction by making an â€œirrevocable personal guarantee of $40.4 billionâ€ toward Paramountâ€™s $108 billion all-cash offer for all of WBD. That includes CNN, TNT and a handful of other established linear cable channels that are now on track to be spunoff into a separate company next year.

Paramountâ€™s amended offer of Dec. 22 also upped the breakup fee to match Netflixâ€™s $5.8 billion figure, payable to WBD in the event that its deal does not clear regulatory review. Netflixâ€™s deal is valued at just under $83 billion but does not include the linear cable channels. Netflixâ€™s deal is a mix of cash and stock.

If the expected WBD board rejection spurs Paramount to raise its offer, then the ball moves to Netflixâ€™s court. Itâ€™s unclear what, if any, willingness Netflix has to raise its hand.
