We are getting a first look at guest star Sabrina Carpenter and executive producer Seth Rogen in a teaser for The Muppet Show special, a reboot of the classic series. Originally announced as a Disney+ event, the special will now be premiere on both ABC and Disney Feb. 4, coinciding with the 50th anniversary of the original series.

As Deadline reported in September, the variety special serves as a backdoor pilot and, in success, would spawn a new Muppet Show television series. That is referenced in the teaser.

â€œItâ€™s the return of The Muppet Show back on the very stage where it all started, and then ended, and is maybe starting again, depending on how the night goes,â€ Kermit says in it.

Watch on Deadline

The Muppet Show special features Kermit, Miss Piggy and the beloved Muppet gang for a blend of music and comedy â€” and a whole lot of chaos â€” as they once again take the stage of the original Muppet Theatre with Sabrina Carpenter as their special guest.

Carpenter, who has spoken of her love for the Muppets for years and channeled Miss Piggy with her outfit at the VMAs in September, is sharing a scene â€” and a dance â€” with the Muppet icon in the teaser, which you can watch above.

Meanwhile, Rogen gets a reality check from Fonzie.

â€œItâ€™s always been a dream of mine to be here,â€ Rogen says, to which the bear replies, â€œGot any other dreams?â€

From 20th Television, Disney Branded Television, The Muppets Studio and Point Grey Pictures, the special is directed by Alex Timbers, who also serves as executive producer. Rogen, Goldberg, James Weaver and Alex McAtee are executive producers for Point Grey Pictures; David Lightbody, Leigh Slaughter and Michael Steinbach are executive producers for The Muppets Studio; Carpenter, Albertina Rizzo, Matt Vogel and Eric Jacobson are executive producers.

Dave Goelz, who has performed with The Muppets for over 50 years, was one of the performers on the original The Muppet Show and originated the characters Gonzo and Dr. Bunsen Honeydew, among many others.

The Muppet Show, created by Jim Henson, ran from 1976-81 and aired in over 100 countries and featured notable guest stars including Elton John, Johnny Cash, Diana Ross, Debbie Harry, Gladys Knight, Liza Minelli, Paul Simon and many others. All five seasons are currently available to stream on Disney+

content:
Not everyone is happy about George Clooney and his family becoming French citizens. At the start of the year, news of Clooneyâ€™s French citizenship sparked criticism from Marie-Pierre Vedrenne, a junior deputy to the interior minister, who argued in a radio interview on Franceinfo that it raised â€issue of fairness.â€

Vedrenne suggested that Clooney had been granted French citizenship out of favor due to his fame rather than on merit, and she argued â€œthis is not the right message to send.â€ She also said she felt that it showed some â€double standardsâ€ and added that she will verify â€œthe entire procedure,â€ according to Le Monde newspaper. But shortly after Vedrenneâ€™s comments, the interior minister Laurent NuÃ±ez fought back the accusations of Vedrenne â€“ with whom he works closely â€” saying that Clooney and his wife Amal were naturalized â€œby decree,â€ from a â€œdecision of the public authority.â€ Nunez also said Clooneyâ€™s naturalization was â€œa great chance for our country.â€

Popular on Variety

The ministry of foreign affairs also reacted to the bashing over Clooney, arguing that the government â€œfollowed a rigorous procedure ranging from security checks to regulatory naturalization interviews at the prefecture, including the payment of tax stamps.â€

â€œLike many French people, we are delighted to welcome George and Amal Clooney to the national community,â€ said the ministry, who cited the civic code which allows â€œany foreigner (â€¦) who contributes through their distinguished actions to the influence of France and the prosperity of its international economic relationsâ€ to gain access to French citizenship.

Clooney, who lives in the South of France, in Brignoles, with his Amal and their twins, Ella and Alexander, recently joked, while promoting Netflixâ€™s â€œJay Kellyâ€ on the local pay TV channel Canal+, that his French was â€œhorrible.â€ He said his wife and kids, meanwhile, spoke French fluently. â€œThey speak French in front of me so that they can say terrible things about me to my face, and I donâ€™t know,â€ he said. Clooney previously told the French radio RTL in an interview in December, â€œI love the French culture, your language, even if Iâ€™m still bad at it after 400 days of courses.â€

U.S. President Donald Trump, meanwhile, took the opportunity to mock Clooney. â€œGood News! George and Amal Clooney, two of the worst political prognosticators of all time, have officially become citizens of France which is, sadly, in the midst of a major crime problem because of their absolutely horrendous handling of immigration,â€ Trump said on his Truth Social network.

title: 10 Directors to Watch 2026
summary: When Sean Bakerâ€™s â€œAnoraâ€ won both the Palme dâ€™Or at Cannes â€” followed by best picture at the Oscars â€” those honors reinforced what Variety had been saying a decade earlier, when the filmmaker appeared on the publicationâ€™s 10 Directors to Watch list, before â€œTangerineâ€ had even premiered at Sundance. The same goes for ChloÃ© […]
content:
â€œCoyote vs. Acmeâ€

Looking back, Dave Green recognizes the irony: â€œI think I was in self-protection mode after the previous experience Iâ€™d had [directing â€œTeenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadowsâ€], and I was just wanting to be very careful about who I was going to work with next,â€ he says, describing the excitement he felt pitching Warner Bros. his take on Ian Frazierâ€™s satirical â€œCoyote v. Acmeâ€ piece, first published in The New Yorker, in which Wile E. Coyote sues the company that manufactured all his faulty equipment.

â€œPretty much all of the Looney Tunes movies that had ever been made are ensemble movies,â€ he says. â€œThey are â€˜The Avengers,â€™ basically. But I felt like theyâ€™d never made the â€˜Iron Manâ€™ of the Looney Tunes movies, and I felt like there was an opportunity there to get to know one character in a really intimate way. And then from there, we can cameo and showcase the other characters.â€

Samy Burch wrote the script, and Green worked out an elaborate previs presentation, in which hand-drawn characters appeared alongside flesh-and-blood actors (Will Forte would later be cast as the shaggy lawyer representing Coyote), so execs could picture the film Green had in mind. The studio loved the idea, partnering him with producer Chris DeFaria, who had live action/animation hybrid experience from â€œTom & Jerry.â€

Making the film was a blast, insists Green, whose creative blending of beloved characters (including deep cuts for super-fans) with live-action footage recalls â€œWho Framed Roger Rabbit.â€ The sense of humor is similarly anarchic: â€œI felt like that edginess was always a defining element of the Warner Bros. cartoons over Disney stuff,â€ Green says.

Then, just when the film was finished, the studio bean counters decided to bury the project, choosing to take a tax write-off instead â€” a tough break for Green, who had bypassed film school, working as an assistant for Sam Raimi on â€œSpider-Man 3â€ after getting his American Studies degree at UC Berkeley.

His Amblin-esque 2014 debut, â€œEarth to Echo,â€ explored the bond between three boys and a hovering, mostly-computer-generated droid. Then came the â€œTMNTâ€ sequel, a crash course in motion capture for a young filmmaker hungry for such challenges. â€œCoyote vs. Acmeâ€ was supposed to be the solution to the compromises made on that film. Fortunately, Warner Bros. sold the rights to Ketchup Entertainment, which will release the film in August. Meanwhile, Green is being careful about his next project.

â€œIâ€™m always looking to do something I havenâ€™t done before, and getting to stretch into new areas,â€ says Green, whoâ€™s developing an R-rated high school party movie called â€œHexâ€ that has a supernatural element to it. â€œEverything Iâ€™m chasing these days is darker, allowing me to step outside the family space.â€

â€” Peter Debruge

content:
The year ahead in movies wonâ€™t be simply about spectacle, scale or franchise machinery. It will also be about watching actors attempt to stretch, surprise and sometimes completely reinvent themselves in front of our eyes.

Varietyâ€˜s annual slate of the most anticipated film performances is defined by momentum and ambition. Legacy stars are stepping back into the arena with something to prove, while a new generation edges closer to that elusive line between â€œpromisingâ€ and â€œarrived.â€

We have icons like Meryl Streep and Denzel Washington returning to familiar archetypes with the weight of history behind them. Elsewhere, performers like Charles Melton and Sadie Sink are chasing the kind of work that reshapes careers rather than simply advances them. Comedians are turning toward drama (Hannah Einbinder). Dramatic actors are flexing comic instincts (PenÃ©lope Cruz). And a handful of performers appear determined to make 2026 the year the industry finally catches up to what theyâ€™ve been doing all along.

What makes this year especially dynamic is the sheer range of tones and filmmakers in play. Alejandro G. IÃ±Ã¡rritu is pushing Tom Cruise into darkly comic, existential territory. Werner Herzog is orchestrating something gloriously strange with Kate and Rooney Mara at its center. Christopher Nolan is mounting a mythic adaptation of â€œThe Odyssey,â€ positioning Matt Damon as cinemaâ€™s ultimate wanderer. Elsewhere, Boots Riley skewers capitalism through satire, Steven Spielberg returns to alien awe with a sense of menace, and the long-awaited â€œPeaky Blindersâ€ film looms as either a victory lap or a funeral march for one of televisionâ€™s most indelible characters.

These performances arenâ€™t ranked by their award probability, though we expect many will land in that conversation. Theyâ€™re selected for the choices behind them. Some actors are testing whether they can carry a franchise. Others are trying to prove theyâ€™re more than one. A few are simply reminding audiences why their presence on screen still matters as much as ever.

title: From Will Arnett to Lucy Liu,  Performances That Shouldnâ€™t Be Overlooked this Awards Season
summary: As the year comes to a close, many standout actors have garnered attention. Of course, only a select few will continue on to Oscar glory â€” 20 to be exact. But there are many notable performances that, while well-received, have yet to be recognized by top awards associations. Here, we make a case for 12 […]
content:
As the year comes to a close, many standout actors have garnered attention. Of course, only a select few will continue on to Oscar glory â€” 20 to be exact. But there are many notable performances that, while well-received, have yet to be recognized by top awards associations. Here, we make a case for 12 actors who deserve consideration.



Will Arnett

Is This Thing On?

Arnett gets to flex his dramatic muscles in Bradley Cooperâ€™s comedy-drama. As his marriage to Tess (Laura Dern) crumbles, Alex (Arnett) finds a creative and psychological outlet in stand-up comedy. While we expect Arnett to nail the comedy bits, heâ€™s loving, confused, hurt and defiant in a scene with Dern in his bachelor pad. He has an old photo of Tess in her heyday on the volleyball court blown up and framed, but the angle is from behind. He says it shows their sons what a badass their mom is; she explodes because it doesnâ€™t show her face. The scene encapsulates all the issues in their marriage and both play it with heartbreaking poignancy.



Miles Caton

Sinners

Director Ryan Coogler describes Caton as an â€œonce-in-a-lifetime voice,â€ and heâ€™s not wrong. Itâ€™s certainly impressive when Caton, who plays the preacherâ€™s son, Sammie, in â€œSinners,â€ teases his vocals in the back of a car ride, but when he steps on stage for a big musical number, his singing blows the roof off the joint. Literally! Itâ€™s a memorable and captivating debut performance with Caton showing off his singing and acting chops.



Oona Chaplin

Avatar: Fire and Ash

â€œGame of Thronesâ€ alum Oona Chaplin is Pandoraâ€™s newest villain, Varang, the main antagonist leading the Ash people in James Cameronâ€™s â€œAvatar: Fire and Ash.â€ Chaplinâ€™s Varang is fiery and thrilling to watch. Sheâ€™s a highlight of the film â€” certainly with her powerful physicality, flashing eyes and stunning headdress, itâ€™s hard to take your eyes off her. Varang is terrifying, but her drive to save her people makes her a hero. And maybe, Varang isnâ€™t the bad guy after all. Hopefully, the next installment gives Varang and Chaplin more time to shine and help understand her origin story.



Kerry Condon

Train Dreams

Like Heath Ledgerâ€™s closed-off cowboy in â€œBrokeback Mountain,â€ Joel Edgertonâ€™s taciturn Robert Grainier in â€œTrain Dreamsâ€ struggles to put his feelings into words, retreating into himself after his wife dies. When Condon enters the picture, playing a widow who comes along at a moment when the wounded logger appears to have lost his purpose, she brings grace and warmth to the equation. Even just sitting quietly at his side, the Irish actress conveys the healing power of human connection in several quietly profound scenes that course-correct his attitudes on life.



Billy Crudup

Jay Kelly

While his co-star Adam Sandler is rightfully being recognized for his standout supporting role in the film, Crudup also delivers a master class in just a few minutes of screen time. Crudup plays Timothy, a counterpart of George Clooneyâ€™s titular movie star who never made it as an actor and sees his old friend as having taken the glory he deserved. As the two catch up, Crudup veers from good-natured to sorrowful to bitter to menacing in a matter of minutes. Itâ€™s no coincidence that even when heâ€™s offscreen, his character haunts the rest of the story.



Abel Ferrara

Marty Supreme

The â€œBad Lieutenantâ€ helmer gives his Ezra Mishkin an unexpected arc: he at first seems like a doddering old man down on his luck whoâ€™s overly attached to his dog. But by the time events with TimothÃ©e Chalametâ€™s Marty come to a head, Ferrara has drawn a sinister character â€” a gangster with a hair-trigger finger on his gun who will kill to get back his dog and money, in that order. While Ferraraâ€™s gangster is chilling, a climactic shootout in a farmhouse allows him to play Mishkin as the lead in the blackest of comedies.



Jacobi Jupe

Hamnet

Jupe might not be eligible for a SAG ensemble nomination due to technicalities, but he won over audiences in ChloÃ© Zhaoâ€™s â€œHamnetâ€ as the titular character. He plays the young son of William Shakespeare (Paul Mescal) and wife Agnes (Jessie Buckley). In the film, his dad has to travel to London for work and tells his son to â€œbe brave.â€ Hamnet takes those words to heart and sacrifices his life for his sisterâ€™s. Jupe delivers one of the best child performances of the year. Heâ€™s charming as a young boy who aspires to follow in his dadâ€™s footsteps, and act. But he pulls out all the stops for the death scene and breaks your heart as he promises to be brave and face death.



Lucy Liu

Rosemead

Liu has always been a scene-stealer, be it the slapstick comedy of â€œAlly McBealâ€ or in action pics like â€œKill Bill.â€ Whatâ€™s particularly impressive about her work in â€œRosemeadâ€ is how immediately you buy her as the grounded character of Irene, a Chinese immigrant. When she learns her cancer is terminal and her schizophrenic son will soon be legal age, she is driven to a desperate choice that might seem unthinkable. But in Liuâ€™s hands, you never doubt Ireneâ€™s love and you can empathize with her impossible plight. Itâ€™s a timely, urgent film made all the more harrowing knowing itâ€™s based on a true story.



Jay Lycurgo

Steve

As ensemble acting goes, Netflixâ€™s â€œSteveâ€ is a knockout, collecting roughly a dozen unfamiliar young performers to play rowdy reform-school cases opposite Cillian Murphyâ€™s unravelling headmaster. The novel that inspired â€œSteveâ€ was actually named for Lycurgoâ€™s character, Shy, who can turn from tender and introspective one moment to frighteningly aggressive on a dime. Lycurgo did earn a British Independent Film Award for his remarkable, unpredictable performance, but the young actor deserves further accolades. He succeeds in keeping audiences on edge, while also generating empathy for his troubled character.



Vahid Mobasseri

It Was Just an Accident

Iranian actor Mobasseri starred in helmer Jafar Panahi in 2022â€™s â€œNo Bears,â€ and here, the revered director casts him as a mechanic whose determination to extract retribution on his jailer is at once chilling, stomach-churning and even funny. Mobasseri plays Vahid as a relatable everyman that the audience latches onto â€” he is our surrogate. But Mobasseri infuses Vahid with decency that overcomes a thirst for revenge, and in the end, his fear is a startling reminder to not yield to oppression.



Sarah Niles

F1

Niles, as Bernadette, the mother of driving phenom Joshua (Damson Idris), brings charm, savvy and most importantly, a large well of confidence and love for her son to â€œF1.â€ Itâ€™s not so much one moment with her character, itâ€™s the way her spirit threads through the film: she believes in her sonâ€™s talent more than he believes in it. Sheâ€™s a rock, and when she tells off Sonny (Brad Pitt) â€” blaming him for her sonâ€™s crash during a race â€” she combines Mama Bear fury and admirable restraint to let Sonny and the audience know that this woman is not to be messed with.



Tonatiuh

Kiss of the Spider Woman

Straight and white, William Hurt won an Oscar for his then-revolutionary turn as Molina in Hector Babencoâ€™s non-musical 1985 film. But when it came time for Bill Condon to cast the role in his adaptation of the Kander and Ebb show, the â€œDreamgirlsâ€ director (who previously launched Jennifer Hudson to Oscar glory) searched practically the whole Western hemisphere and found his Molina in Mexican American actor Tonatiuh, who interprets the characterâ€™s queer identity quite differently, tapping into more contemporary notions of gender fluidity. Tonatiuhâ€™s Molina can be frivolous one moment, maternal the next, appearing clean-cut, closeted and Cary Grant-like in the fantasy numbers.

In We Bury The Dead, after a catastrophic American military disaster on the Australian island state of Tasmania, the dead donâ€™t just rise, they hunt. The military insists they are harmless and slow-moving, offering hope to grieving families. Set in the summer of 2003, at an all-boys water polo camp as socially anxious twelve-year-old Ben (Everett Blunck) struggles to fit into a ruthless social hierarchy. The Plague nabbed three Film Independent Spirit Awards nominations (Best Feature; Lead Performance for Blunck; and Breakthrough Performance for Martin). Blunk has a Critics Choice Awards for Best Young Actor.

Based on Amiri Barakaâ€™s 1964 Obie-Award winning play, the updated version premiered at SXSW, see Deadline review, and played at the San Francisco Film Festival and the Marthaâ€™s Vineyard African American Film Festival Holland stars as Clay, a successful but troubled black businessman attending therapy sessions with his wife, Kaya (Beetz) in an attempt to salvage their marriage. But their mysterious therapist is not all that he seems. On a New York subway train, Clay encounters Lula (Mara), a seductive but sinister white stranger who slowly begins to unravel his life. content:
EXCLUSIVE: Oscar-shortlisted live-action short film A Friend of Dorothy has dropped on Disney+. The British-produced short, directed by Lee Knight, is now available on Disney+ in the UK and across Europe. It is an intergenerational tale about an unlikely friendship between the titular Dorothy, an elderly woman living alone, and JJ, her teenage neighbor.

BAFTA-winner Miriam Margolyes stars as Dorothy and Alistair Nwachukwu (Shadow and Bone) plays JJ. Their friendship starts when his football lands in her garden. The story was inspired by a real-life friendship between actor-turned-director Knight, his husband, and their late neighbor. The cast also includes Stephen Fry and Oscar Lloyd.

JJ helps Dorothy with difficult household tasks and provides companionship to his octogenarian neighbor, whose husband has passed away and son lives abroad. Her mercenary grandson is the only family contact she has, and JJ becomes a firm friend. Meanwhile, she encourages him to follow his dreams to be a stage actor through reciting and reading plays.

Watch on Deadline

Knight won the Best Director and the film win the Best Drama accolade at the HollyShorts London event. Billed as â€œa story about loneliness, connection and unexpected friendship,â€ the film premiered at Raindance and has since been on a solid festival run. Its release on Disney+ allows the film to break out beyond the festival circuit and reach a mainstream audience.

â€œI want to extend my heartfelt thanks to the Academy for shortlisting A Friend of Dorothy in the Best Short Film category,â€ said Knight. â€œThis film speaks to the power of human connection and the importance of feeling seen, regardless of the differences we may perceive between one another. It is deeply encouraging to see stories of companionship, acceptance and authentic living recognized on the global stage.â€

The helmer gave Deadline a detailed take on the film back in December. His Filthy Gorgeous Productions banner made the film in association with A Marlowâ€™s Production, Double Dice Films and Namesake Films. James Dean (The Stolen Girl), Scottie FotrÃ© and Max Marlow produced. The roster of exec producers included Stephen Daldry and Sonia Friedman.

title: Directors on Their Favorite Films of 2025: From Janicza Bravo to Paul Thomas Anderson to Barry Jenkins and More
summary: Acclaimed filmmakers pen essays on the current movies that left them inspired â€” and sometimes envious.
content:
By Julio Torres

Full disclosure: I am friends with Emma Stone; I have never met Yorgos Lanthimos but I have been a fan since I saw â€œDogtoothâ€ in college. Transparency feels like a way of honoring a film about paranoia, gaslighting, lies and manipulation.

On first watch, my sympathy ping-ponged between Jesse Plemonsâ€™ Teddy and Emmaâ€™s Michelle. Heâ€™s a greasy, probably very unwell conspiracy theorist who has kidnapped a cold and robotic girlboss (my favorite little detail is her putting her trench coat on her shoulders to walk out of her mansion, taking three steps to her car and taking it off). Seeing her calmly listening to his deranged nonsense about how she must make contact with her ship made me sympathize with her even though Iâ€™m prone to dislike a calculating pharmaceutical CEO. She is after all, his victim. Her cruelty is revealed later though, followed by a series of violent and desperate escalations from both. Yorgos deliberately keeps his audience in the dark for much of the film and in doing so colors the film with his charactersâ€™ uneasy paranoia.

Itâ€™s in the dizzying, meticulous sparring between the protagonists â€” each working relentlessly to assert their version of the truth â€” that the heart of the movie lies. Yorgosâ€™ emphasis and restraint in these scenes make us feel like another person in the room trying to make sense of things, going mad in the process. That unnerving synthesizer score which follows the characters takes this sense of immersion even further. The result feels like scrolling online reading vastly different takes on the same issues. At a certain point, one begins to question â€¦ is he right? Could she be an alien?

I thought of all the times that I have been made out to feel like a conspiracy theorist for asking questions like â€œWhat else does this media company own?â€ â€œWhy does my school invest in weapon manufacturers?â€ â€œWhy is this vaccine no longer recommended?â€ â€œWhat would it mean if this company buys this streamer?â€

We have entered an era of necessary skepticism, easily dismissed as paranoia by a ruling class who have positioned themselves as the voice of reason. After all, the skeptics carry cardboard signs while â€œreasonableâ€ people wear suits. Michelle calmly tells her kidnapper that heâ€™s in an â€œecho chamber,â€ saying it almost like sheâ€™s trying to help him out of it. This reminded me of politicians saying that young people are getting all confused observing wars via TikTok, that theyâ€™re consuming propaganda. Never mind that special interest groups bankroll the career of these politicians in exchange for these opinions. Whoâ€™s the propagandist?

I find it impossible to meaningfully praise this film in a vacuum; it is because we as an audience are often manipulated and lied to by forces more powerful than us that this movie resonates and is being so talked about.

Truth is often kept from Yorgosâ€™ protagonists, and getting to the bottom of it rarely ever yields happiness. Theyâ€™re also almost always very lonely. Teddy proudly states that heâ€™s doing everything on his own, that heâ€™s not part of any movement. Skepticism is isolating, especially when youâ€™re told youâ€™re crazy by those whose agendas clash with the truth. But movies like these can make us feel less lonely.

â€œWe are not alone,â€ reads a tabloid article about aliens that Teddy has in his kitchen. I choose that as my takeaway here. Maybe we feel hopeless, maybe corporations and politicians can toy with our fates while making us feel crazy for pointing that out. But we are not alone!

Julio Torres is an author, comedian, actor, writer, director and producer. His credits include â€œSaturday Night Live,â€ â€œLos Espookys,â€ â€œFantasmasâ€ and â€œProblemista.â€

The hotel team is actively cooperating and supporting police authorities within the framework of the ongoing investigation.â€

Victoria acted as a child opposite her father in â€œMen in Black IIâ€ in 2002 and â€œThe Three Burials of Melquiades Estradaâ€ in 2005. title: Stephen Schwartz Says He Wonâ€™t Participate In Planned Kennedy Center Event After Trumpâ€™s Changes

content:
Stephen Schwartz said that he will not be part of a planned May event at the Kennedy Center after its board voted last month to add Donald Trumpâ€˜s name to the venue.

Schwartz, the composer/lyricist of Wicked, had been on the bill to host the Washington National Opera Gala on May 16.

In a statement to Newsday, Schwartz said, â€œIt no longer represents the apolitical place for free artistic expression it was founded to be. Thereâ€™s no way I would set foot in it now.â€

He said that before Trump took control of the board and became its chairman, he had been invited by artistic director Francesca Zambello to be part of the Washington National Opera event.

â€œBut Iâ€™ve heard nothing about it since February 2025, so I have assumed itâ€™s no longer happening,â€ Schwartz said, per Newsday. â€œI canâ€™t imagine Francesca continuing under the current circumstances. If it is happening, of course I will not be part of it.â€

Watch on Deadline

Kennedy Center spokesperson Roma Daravi said in a statement, â€œStephen Schwartz was never discussed nor confirmed and never had a contract by current Trump Kennedy Center leadership. Schwartz said himself that he â€˜heard nothing about it since February 2025â€¦assumed itâ€™s no longer happening.â€™ It is completely false to report otherwise.â€

The Kennedy Center website was still featuring access to ticket sales for a Stephen Schwartz event with the Washington National Opera. Schwartz said he would not participate in the event, planned for May 16.

But on the center website, the event was still on the schedule, with access to purchase tickets, and the logline: â€œWitness the links between musical theater and opera come alive in this thrilling concert! Acclaimed musical theater lyricist and composer Stephen Schwartz curates and hosts for one night only, bringing together an exciting lineup of soloists to perform beloved repertory.â€

Schwartz is the latest performer to drop plans to appear at the center. After Trump fired board members appointed by Joe Biden and Barack Obama, he took control of the center, becoming its chairman. That was followed by a series of performers canceling plans for the center, including the producers of Hamilton, while figures like Renee Fleming exited roles as advisers. After the board voted to add Trumpâ€™s name to the center, performers dropped out of planned Christmas Eve and New Yearâ€™s Eve shows, while Doug Varone and Dancers canceled a gig planned for April.

Rep. Joyce Beatty (D-OH), an ex officio member of the board, filed suit against the center last month, claiming that only Congress has the authority to change the name of the arts institution. In 1964, Congress designated it as the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts as a memorial to the late president.

title: â€˜Peter Hujarâ€™s Dayâ€™: Read The Screenplay For Ira Sachsâ€™ Experimental Snapshot Of A Day In The Life

content:
Deadlineâ€™s Read the Screenplay series spotlighting the scripts behind the awards seasonâ€™s most talked-about movies continues with the Sundance-premiering Peter Hujarâ€™s Day from Janus Films. Written and directed by Ira Sachs, the film is a mesmerizing time warp into the heart of New Yorkâ€™s queer cultural history.

Starring Ben Whishaw as the pioneering photographer Peter Hujar and Rebecca Hall as the writer Linda Rosenkrantz, the movie is based on a rediscovered 1974 interview transcript. In this unique narrative experiment, Rosenkrantz asks Hujar to narrate the events of the previous day in minute, exhaustive detail, resulting in a film that illustrates the life of the creative mind through both the quotidian and the imaginative.

Janus and Sideshow acquired the film after its Sundance premiere and released it in early November. It has since scored five Independent Spirit Awards nominations including Best Feature and Best Director for Sachs. The screenplay was also nominated for a USC Scripter Award.

Watch on Deadline

The narrative follows Hujar as he chronicles his waking hours from December 18, 1974, recounting everything from the moment he woke up until he went to sleep. This account is far from a dry recitation; it is filled with Hujarâ€™s observations, honest self-assessments, and amusing dollops of gossip involving a wide circle of 1970s cultural luminaries. The film captures Hujarâ€™s interactions and thoughts on figures such as Allen Ginsberg, Susan Sontag and Lauren Hutton, bringing the creative ferment and dodgy conditions of the eraâ€™s Lower East Side scene to life.

Sachs envisioned the project as an art project first and foremost, focusing on an intimate relationship between the camera and its subjects. Shot on 16mm film with a 4:3 aspect ratio, the production intentionally avoids a glossy, commercial look in favor of naturalistic, sometimes underexposed lighting that emphasizes simple elegance. This stylistic choice underscores a central theme of the film: the radical honesty of artists who produced work because they had to, rather than for commercial gain or bourgeois expectations.

Ultimately, Peter Hujarâ€™s Day explores the preciousness of lifeâ€™s fleeting, everyday moments and the perpetual struggle of art to capture them. The dialogue-driven film treats the small details of Hujarâ€™s day â€” what he ate, where he traveled, and what his friends wore â€” as monumental events.

title: Chevy Chase Says â€˜Iâ€™m Not Racistâ€™ When Asked About â€˜Communityâ€™ Exit: The Show â€˜Wasnâ€™t a Bad Experience. I Just Didnâ€™t Think It Was That Goodâ€™

Chevy Chase recently took part in a joint interview with The New York Times alongside Marina Zenovich, the director of the new CNN documentary â€œIâ€™m Chevy Chase and Youâ€™re Not,â€ and was asked about how the movie depicts Chaseâ€™s tumultuous stint on â€œCommunity.â€ Chase had a series regular role on the NBC sitcom and exited after Season 4 amid a public spat with creator Dan Harmon over creative differences and an incident in which he allegedly set the N-word on set.

When asked how he felt about his role ending, Chase answered: â€œI thought it ended great.â€

â€œIt was too great a misunderstanding of what I was saying and not saying,â€ Chase then added about his exit. â€œI thought that there was at least one person â€” and another who, for some ungodly reason, didnâ€™t get me, didnâ€™t know who I was, or didnâ€™t realize for one second Iâ€™m not racist. They were too young to be aware of my work. Instead, there was some sort of visceral reaction from them.â€

As recounted in the documentary and by The Times: â€œDuring production of Season 4, Chase became frustrated with his characterâ€™s increasing bigotry, in particular with a story line in which the character does a bit with a blackface hand puppet. The documentary recounts allegations that Chase, in frustration, asked whether his character would next be made to use a racial slur, and reportedly uttered that slur in reference. He abruptly exited the show.â€

â€œCommunityâ€ director Jay Chandrasekhar is interviewed in the documentary and says Chase had a â€œmeltdownâ€ on set after an incident in which he allegedly used the N-word on set leaked to the press. The alleged incident occurred between Chase and co-star Yvette Nicole Brown, with Chandrasekhar explaining: â€œI know that there was a history between [Chevy and Yvette] around race, and she got up and stormed out of there. Chevy storms off, so the producer is like, â€˜We need Yvette in the scene, right?â€™ Iâ€™m like, â€˜Yeah, sheâ€™s in the next scene.â€™ And he goes, â€˜Well, she wonâ€™t come out unless Chevy apologizes to her.â€™â€

Chandrasekhar said Chevy eventually returned to the set but claimed he â€œdidnâ€™t say anythingâ€ to upset Brown, adding: â€œ[Chevy] goes, â€˜You know, me and Richard Pryor, I used to call Richard Pryor the N-word, and he used to call me The Honky, and we loved each other.â€™ And Iâ€™m like, â€˜I know, man, I love that bit.â€™ I said, â€˜You know, can we just have a little apology?â€™ He goes, â€˜For what?â€™â€

The incident was later reported on by The Hollywood Reporter, who claimed Chase was â€œfrustratedâ€ with his character arc and used the N-word â€œwhen questioning the dialogue.â€ The report stressed that Chase did not use the racial slur directly at his Black co-stars Brown and Donald Glover, although both actors were reportedly on set at the time.

Chandrasekhar said that when production resumed after the THR story broke, Chase arrived on set and had a â€œfull meltdownâ€ as he came â€œstorming onto the set, and he goes, â€˜Who fucked me over?â€™ â€¦ My career is ruined! Iâ€™m ruined!â€™ Like, itâ€™s a full meltdown. â€˜Fuck all of you!â€™ And Iâ€™m like, â€˜Alright, letâ€™s shoot the scene.â€™ He never ended up coming back after that.â€

Zenovich previously told Variety that she tried to get more of Chaseâ€™s â€œCommunityâ€ cast members and crew members to participate in the documentary but â€œevery single person said noâ€ because â€œthere are things people donâ€™t want to talk about.â€

As the â€œCommunityâ€ incident resurfaced due to â€œIâ€™m Chevy Chase and Youâ€™re Not,â€ Yvette Nicole Brown took to Instagram and appeared to address it by writing: â€œThere are things Iâ€™ve never spoken of publicly and perhaps never will. Anyone currently speaking FOR or ABOUT me with perceived authority is speaking without EVER speaking to me about the things they claim to know about. They actually donâ€™t really know me at all.â€

Donald Glover notably told The New Yorker in 2018 that Chase repeatedly made racist jokes on the â€œCommunityâ€ set. Chase, meanwhile, told CBS Sunday Morning in 2022 that he â€œdoesnâ€™t give a crapâ€ about headlines and former co-stars painting him as problematic on set, adding at the time: â€œI donâ€™t give a crap. I am who I am. And I like who I am. I donâ€™t care. And itâ€™s part of me that I donâ€™t care. And Iâ€™ve thought about that a lot. And I donâ€™t know what to tell you, man. I just donâ€™t care.â€

title: James Gunn on Making â€˜Superman,â€™ Not Being Interested in â€˜Prestige Projectsâ€™ and DC Studiosâ€™ Future

content:
James Gunn looks tired but energized as he settles into his chair for the Variety Awards Circuit Podcast, having just flown in from Atlanta. Heâ€™s already into pre-production on â€œMan of Tomorrow,â€ the follow-up to this summerâ€™s â€œSuperman.â€ so exhaustion would be expected. Gunn is not only directing the film, but heâ€™s also running DC Studios alongside Peter Safran â€” an unprecedented balancing act he calls â€œthe hardest movie Iâ€™ve ever made.â€

The conversation is taking place only two hours before the entertainment landscape shifted, with Netflix announcing an $82 billion acquisition of Warner Bros. â€” a reminder of how quickly the ground beneath the Hollywood industry, DC, and Gunn himself, continues to move.

Nonetheless, weâ€™re talking about â€œSuperman,â€ where Gunn leans in, his eyes brighten and discusses what drew him to the character â€” which wasnâ€™t the scale or mythology.

Popular on Variety

â€œWhen I first talked to the cast and crew, I wanted to make something about goodness,â€ Gunn says. â€œThis guy isnâ€™t perfect, even though heâ€™s Superman. Heâ€™s really just trying to do his best. Heâ€™s good-natured. Heâ€™s loving. He sees the best in everyone.â€

That idea was Superman is not a god, but a sincere, sometimes awkward moral presence. That became Gunnâ€™s anchor â€” and he credits Grant Morrisonâ€™s â€œAll-Star Supermanâ€ for crystallizing that approach. â€œThat was the thing that hooked me,â€ he shares. â€œThat big lug of a superhero being genuinely kind. Thatâ€™s what I took from the book.â€

Unlike the relative freedom Gunn had with â€œGuardians of the Galaxy,â€ Superman came with a centuryâ€™s worth of expectations, and of course, disagreements. â€œEveryone in the world thinks something different about Superman. Everybody knows who he is.â€

The scrutiny extended beyond the cape. Gunn was aware that this film would be viewed as a referendum on the future of DC itself. â€œThere were all the eyes on us â€” on DC, on the DCU, on everything,â€ he says. â€œThat pressure was real.â€

Casting, then, was non-negotiable. â€œIf I couldnâ€™t find Superman, I wasnâ€™t going to make the movie,â€ Gunn says flatly. David Corenswet was the second audition he saw. â€œI remember thinking, â€˜If thatâ€™s the worst we do, weâ€™re in great shape.â€™â€

What emerged is a film that leans toward optimism at a moment when superhero cinema has often favored grit. Gunnâ€™s Superman isnâ€™t naÃ¯ve, but he is hopeful. Coming off the year we all had, that choice feels quite radical.

On this episode of the Variety Awards Circuit Podcast, Gunn talks about his process of making â€œSuperman,â€ why heâ€™ll never chase a prestige projects and what to expect from â€œMan of Tomorrow.â€

Screengrab courtesy of DC Studios

Read excerpts from her interview below, which has been edited and condensed for clarity.

What made â€œSupermanâ€ the hardest film youâ€™ve directed?

This was the hardest movie Iâ€™ve ever made. The next hardest was probably the first â€œGuardians.â€ With â€œGuardians,â€ you were building a corner of the universe that felt completely different from everything else Marvel was doing at the time. Here, I was reorienting something everyone already thinks they understand. Strangely, itâ€™s the most comic-book-driven thing Iâ€™ve ever done. More than any of my other superhero films.

How did assembling your creative team shape the film?

Iâ€™ve worked with many of these people for years. Beth Mickel, my production designer, has been with me on the last three films. Steph Ceretti has overseen visual effects for multiple projects now. Being in charge of DC meant I could finally keep the team together instead of losing people between films. That continuity matters.

What were you most proud of in the visual effects, especially with Krypto the Dog?

Framestoreâ€™s work on Krypto is extraordinary. Iâ€™ll put those shots up against anything Iâ€™ve ever seen. ILM was incredible as well. It was just a world-class group of artists working at the highest level.

How does it feel to be both a filmmaker and a studio head at the same time?

I donâ€™t think itâ€™s ever really been done. Even Walt Disney was more of a producer than a director. Itâ€™s an experiment. And yes, sometimes it probably sounds like madness â€” especially since I donâ€™t make the most conventional films. But I love big spectacle. Thatâ€™s my jam. I originally said no to the job. I didnâ€™t want to do what Kevin Feige does. But once Peter and I realized weâ€™d be doing it together, it became exciting. I still donâ€™t know if itâ€™s sustainable long-term. Itâ€™s a lot. There just arenâ€™t enough hours in the day.

What films made you fall in love with movies?

I think the first movie I saw in a theater was â€œThe Aristocats.â€ Then â€œThe Strongest Man in the Worldâ€ with Kurt Russell. But it was â€œStar Warsâ€ that completely changed me. That feeling of entering another world. And then â€œRaiders of the Lost Arkâ€ made me aware of filmmakers themselves â€” George Lucas, Steven Spielberg. Thatâ€™s when it clicked.

How do you think about prestige versus mainstream filmmaking?

I donâ€™t care about prestige. I mean, sure, would it be cool to be nominated for Best Director or something? Yeah, would I rather have that than not? But itâ€™s not really my concern. Occasionally I have ideas that are more independent movies, but I like making the kind of movies that I make, and I like making pop cinema, for lack of a better term. If I can have those things also be something that are emotionally resonant to people, or affect people in a deeper, more spiritual way, like a lot of people have told me that â€œSupermanâ€ did, a lot of people have told me that â€œGuardians 3â€ did, then thatâ€™s fantastic. Thatâ€™s what I would love to be able to do. But I like making the big movies too. Thereâ€™s an artistry to it, the creative flow. But then I also like the part of it thatâ€™s putting the big puzzle together and creating this machine that works for an audience to elicit a reaction from them, whether itâ€™s emotional, whether itâ€™s laughter, whether itâ€™s screaming, whether itâ€™s whatever it is. Thatâ€™s the fun part of it.

Why did â€œGuardians of the Galaxyâ€ feel like the right leap into big-budget filmmaking?

I had walked away from another studio project because they stripped everything personal out of it. Then â€œGuardiansâ€ came along and I thought, no one else can make this movie the way I can. I wanted to make a space opera. I love raccoons. It felt completely me. Thatâ€™s always been my goal â€” to make big movies that still feel personal.

What can you tell us about â€œMan of Tomorrow?â€

At its core, itâ€™s about Clark and Lex. I relate to both of them. I relate to Lexâ€™s ambition and obsession â€” minus the murder. And I relate to Supermanâ€™s belief in people, his Midwestern values. Theyâ€™re two sides of me.

What does your partnership with Peter Safran bring to DC Studios?

Peterâ€™s the best. He does everything I donâ€™t do well. He keeps the ship steady, keeps everyone aligned, connects us with Jim Lee and the comics side, and unifies departments that used to operate separately. What we share is a genuine love for these characters. We know what a privilege it is to help shape how people see them now â€” and that responsibility is something we take seriously.

In the interview below, the actor spoke with Deadline about his final days on set, his journey through Dustinâ€™s grief in Season 5, and his thoughts on whether Dustin really believes that Eleven could still be alive.

DEADLINE: How are you feeling now that the finale has been released?

GATEN MATARAZZO: A lot of relief. I like keeping secrets, but to a fault. They bubble up. Iâ€™m like, â€˜I want to talk about it so bad,â€™ and now I get to, which is very nice.

DEADLINE: Last time we spoke, it was for Volume 1, and so you teased a little about the emotional arc that was coming for Dustin. In Volume 2, his resentment and anger really comes to a head in that fight with Steve. What was it like working with Joe Keery this season on such an emotionally complicated journey for Dustin?

MATARAZZO: Oh, man, itâ€™s there was a lot of stress involved, especially as we were getting closer, and we started reading the stuff within Volume 2. I was like, â€˜Great. Okay, cool. So now the entire year is gonna be built around me being stressed about this fight and this blow up afterwards.â€™ Even the stuff in [Episode] 7, where we finally kind of settle into it, thereâ€™s a lot of nerves going in. Thereâ€™s a lot of stakes. I love this kid a lot. I love Dustin. I love playing him. I love watching him grow and growing alongside of him, and it breaks my heart to see what a place that heâ€™s in. Also, for it being the last [season], I was inevitably going to grieve that fun-loving side of him and being able to tap into it, because I had to jump into something new and find something something different. But, knowing that it would be with Joe is this most soothing part of it, understanding that I would get to do so alongside somebody who â€” not only who I trust, but who Iâ€™ve seen take on challenges like this and do so with seeming ease.

He is such a grounded, thoughtful actor, and you can look him in the eyes and fully settle in yourself. Heâ€™s very giving. Oh man, itâ€™s hard to explain what acting alongside somebody like him is like, but I think that also comes with being just a good friend of his and him being a good friend of mine. That makes a process like that a hell of a lot easier to where we have the ability to show the ugly parts of ourselves to each other and not feel the awkward pressure of like, â€˜I barely know you, so now I have to go and and hug you and cry in your arms.â€™ I donâ€™t think I could do that with a stranger. Thankfully, itâ€™s somebody as capable as Joe, so it made a big difference for sure.

From left: Natalia Dyer, Charlie Heaton, Joe Keery and Gaten Matarazzo in â€˜Stranger Thingsâ€™ Season 5

DEADLINE: As you say, it is a much different side of Dustin than we are used to seeing. Was it challenging for you to tap into that?

MATARAZZO: It was something that, at least I was warned about, which is very nice. My biggest challenge thereâ€¦it wasnâ€™t necessarily digging into grief. I feel like that was something that a lot of actors are expecting to tap into at some point. Part of acting is youâ€™re dealing with [and] showing the scariest parts of being human and doing so on a regular basis, because thatâ€™s what people are interested in seeing. Thatâ€™s what people are drawn towards, because maybe itâ€™s hard to see that and feel that in a day to day in your own life. Thatâ€™s why I was drawn to acting in the first place, is to be able to do that on a regular basis and learn about it in a low pressure situation where youâ€™re kind of given the ability to do it without judgment, which is very nice and really cool. The hardest part was doing so and still being Dustin. I didnâ€™t just want to be a different guy. I still wanted to feel like him, and I wanted to still show people that there was a part of him that was recognizable. Otherwise, I donâ€™t think people would really be engaged. Whoâ€™s this? This is a new person. I really wanted to make sure that people still felt drawn to the kid that they grew up meeting and knowing.

DEADLINE: What parts of Dustin do you felt like you were clinging to in order to make him feel recognizable through that?

MATARAZZO: Thatâ€™s hard to say. A lot of thatâ€™s in the script. A lot of thatâ€™s given to you before you go in. So a lot of that work is done in the writers room, and itâ€™s just your job to do justice there. You kind of tap into loss that youâ€™ve experienced throughout your life at some points. And Iâ€™ve lost people. Iâ€™ve lost people suddenlyâ€¦you go into a process of remembering what that can feel like, and whatâ€™s overwhelming is not just how overwhelmingly sad it is, but, really, how much rage and how much melancholy there is around it. Thatâ€™s something that I wanted to approach a bit there is that grieving isnâ€™t necessarily always just hiding in your room and blubbering into your pillow. Even after a week or two, you donâ€™t really have that in you anymore. So you find different outlets, and anger is one of them, and stress.

Now that itâ€™s all wrapped up, I think specifically why he took it out on Steve is, a lot of times, itâ€™s so much easier to say goodbye on bad terms than it is on good ones, because you really donâ€™t want to let go of people. Even breakups, itâ€™s so much harder to break up with somebody when you guys are standing there [on] great [terms], and you have respect for each other. I feel like losing people is kind of similar, and maybe if Steve didnâ€™t make it out of this, it would be easier to deal with that if I wasnâ€™t so engaged and invested in that relationship. Maybe cutting him out would make losing him easier. That was like vital, right? I think for Dustin specifically, because I think losing another friend would be too much, so maybe him not being a friend anymore would make it easier.

DEADLINE: Having gone through all of that with the character, how did you feel about Dustinâ€™s graduation speech? Heâ€™s finally honoring Eddie in a positive way.

MATARAZZO: Exactly, thatâ€™s the way to properly [do it]. Dustin is convinced throughout the whole process that being miserable is the way to service a friend or to remember him, because if heâ€™s not living through his grief and heâ€™s not hurting, then heâ€™s not loving and heâ€™s not missing him properly. He believes that trying to move on and be happy and joke around and make friends and live his life, it feels like he would think of it as a disservice to him, whereas, of course, we know itâ€™s distinctly the opposite. Nobody who loves you would want you to live miserably for them. That would be the scariest thing in the world. Thatâ€™s something he learns and learns to be excited about. Now, heâ€™s entered a place in his life where he can tell stories about him and listen to his music and show pictures of him to people and talk about him with new friends and reminisce and do so smiling and laugh about it and not have to be on the verge of tears with it. Thatâ€™s a new part of grief thatâ€™s actually quite beautiful, and itâ€™s weirdly fun and refreshing to enter, because itâ€™s inevitable.

Youâ€™re going to have to find a way. These people donâ€™t come back, and so you have to find a way to be okay with that. If youâ€™re not okay with that, accept it. Itâ€™s a beautiful thing that Hopper says to Mike at the end of the show of â€˜You donâ€™t have to like their choice or understand their choice,â€™ which is also kind of what Eddie did. Eddie made a choice to run back in, whether it was smart or not or even necessary. Thatâ€™s still a question as to whether or not it was even necessary for him to do it, which is also gutting. Maybe it was completely preventable, but learning to accept and be okay with understanding [that] it is what happenedâ€¦you canâ€™t change it, so you might as well do the best you can and live the best you can. [That] is the best takeaway from that, and I think thatâ€™s what all of them inevitably have to do. Now theyâ€™ve all lost a friend.

From left: Gaten Matarazzo, Finn Wolfhard, Noah Schnapp and Caleb McLaughlin in â€˜Stranger Thingsâ€™ Season 5 Netflix

DEADLINE: The final scene in the basement at the Wheelersâ€™ is so special. Dustin is the first one to say, â€˜I believeâ€™ after Mikeâ€™s speech. What did filming that scene mean to you?

MATARAZZO: Oh man, yeah, we anticipated that all day. It was really hard to know how weâ€™re going to deliver that, because you want to distance yourself from as much cheese in that moment as you can, I think. The audience can kind of leave it up to interpretation for them, whatever works for them as to Elevenâ€™s whereabouts, as to whether sheâ€™s alive or not, whatever makes you feel better about the show is fully okay for you to do. Thatâ€™s something that Iâ€™ve already seen is kind of a 50/50 split amongst people whoâ€™ve watched it, which I think is perfect. Thatâ€™s exactly how it should be. There should be a debate about it. There should be discourse. There should be no â€˜Hereâ€™s why this, hereâ€™s why this.â€™ Itâ€™s a great way for people to consistently engage in the show. Butâ€¦Iâ€™m not convinced that there is a consensus amongst the group as to whether or not they agree. I donâ€™t know if there is. I donâ€™t know if they all believe, right? I think I would rather leave Dustinâ€™s mindset on that more personal and up to peopleâ€™s interpretation, even though my mind is kind of made up as to what he feels. If they do believe, itâ€™s so special that they do, and if they donâ€™t, itâ€™s so kind of them to give them to give that to their friends, right? Thatâ€™s a really special way to wrap it up.

DEADLINE: I like the idea that they are allowing Mike to believe it, even if maybe they donâ€™t. Maybe theyâ€™re â€˜lettingâ€™ themselves believe it, too, even knowing deep down that it probably isnâ€™t true. Lots of layers there.

MATARAZZO: And itâ€™s not sweeping it under the rug, I donâ€™t think. Itâ€™s just airing it out. Itâ€™s acknowledging collectively that this is how he is deciding to cope with this. Whether he believes it or not, maybe he believes it the least out of them, who knows? But itâ€™s very kind of them to give to each other that that bit of love and hope, and at least the idea that maybe it turned out okay. I think itâ€™s really beautiful.

DEADLINE: That was the final scene you all shot, right?

MATARAZZO: Yeah, that was the last day.

DEADLINE: What was that experience like for you?

MATARAZZO: The best way to do it. Itâ€™s in the same set, that same table, that same styleâ€¦we leave it right where we picked it up. The first day of production on Stranger Things, was the day in the basement for the first D&D scene. That was day one for everybody. It seemed only fitting that the last day wrapped up the way that it started. Matt and Ross, they insisted on that happening. Iâ€™m sure there was back and forth from ADs and line producers and people, â€˜Yeah, maybe we got to do this, because we didnâ€™t get this finished up.â€™ And I think they were like, â€˜F*ck that. No chance. Thereâ€™s no way we wrap it up with anything else.â€™ That was very important to them and important to us, and it paid off.

DEADLINE: I heard that you went to a theater to see the finale with fansâ€¦in disguise? How was that?

MATARAZZO: I did. It was wonderful. I just wanted to make sure I can hear people see it for the first time. You know what I mean? I just wanted to feel an energy. I wanted to see people in T-shirts and in friend groups. Itâ€™s not something weâ€™ve been able to experience before, seeing people experience the show for the first time. Thatâ€™s really, really special, and itâ€™s kind of the only opportunity weâ€™ve ever â€” I mean, I guess I could have at some point I couldâ€™ve gone to a random house and been, like, â€˜I want to see this,â€™ but that would have been weird. That would have been odd.

Gaten Matarazzo and Joe Keery in â€˜Stranger Thingsâ€™ Season 5 Courtesy of Netflix

So, everybody was given the opportunity to go and experience it together, collectively, and understand that thereâ€™s something so special about the community. That is a theater and the importance that it brings to movie making and cinema. Thereâ€™s obviously a very glaring juxtaposition, being a huge streamer and a catalyst for TV and film being watched from home, and the convenience of that. Matt and Ross really did push. It was very important to them that this is experienced to the scale in which they always intended for it to be. Iâ€™m just happy that it happened. Iâ€™m happy that they were able to make it work.

DEADLINE: Youâ€™ve worked on this show for a decade of your life. Itâ€™s so rare for shows to continue for so long, and particularly in the case of Stranger Things, for much of it there was not a question about whether it would end unceremoniously. It was very consistent in a rare way. How formative was that for you as a young actor?

MATARAZZO: Itâ€™s something that I know actively not to take for granted and to acknowledge how special and rare a process like that really is. Because quality isnâ€™t even a measure of whether something runs for a while or not. Thereâ€™s so many great shows that, for one reason or another, whether itâ€™s a scheduling issue, whether itâ€™s a budgeting issue, a ratings issue, they struggle to ensure seeing their show through the way it was supposed to. Once we got into the groove of [Stranger Things], after our second season, going into [Season] 3, it seemed like it was very clear that Matt and Ross were going to be able to make whatever decisions they wanted to make to see the show finish the way they want to see it finish. That is so special and so rare, and itâ€™s going to be very hard to acknowledge the fact that thatâ€™s not something that will ever, probably, come again to the scale in which it did. Thatâ€™s something Iâ€™m honored to have been a part of and something Iâ€™m sure Iâ€™ll look back on and be like, â€˜Yeah, this was crazy.â€™

DEADLINE: What are you looking forward to now?

MATARAZZO: Oh, man. Iâ€™m looking forward to not knowing whatâ€™s next. Thatâ€™s something I would like to optimistically look at. Thatâ€™s something that also is a source of a lot of anxiety, because Iâ€™ve been very used to, like you said, having consistency in what Iâ€™ve done in this show. Whether things dry out between seasons, or whether I donâ€™t like a project that I do or it doesnâ€™t really mesh the way I wanted it to, at least I can go back into another [season of Stranger Things] and get a groove back going. But now it really is a matter of just deciding whatâ€™s next and shaping up what I would like my career to look like, and Iâ€™m not sure what that is yet, and I think itâ€™s just a matter of step by step understanding. Iâ€™m not too worried about a five-year plan, a 10-year plan. I would like to spend this time looking directly in front of me and seeing what comes up and what opportunities fall my way, and maybe even jumping into things where I can potentially create my own opportunities in some way. I donâ€™t really know what that would entail or would look like, but Iâ€™m excited to not know.

DEADLINE: Are there any particular opportunities that would intrigue you? Whether thatâ€™s a genre or character archetype youâ€™d want to explore, or perhaps stepping into a role off camera?

MATARAZZO: Yeah, thatâ€™s a good question. I really am not concerned genre-wise. If itâ€™s something that looks like itâ€™s going to challenge me, then thatâ€™s something Iâ€™m interested in. If it looks like a learning experience, then Iâ€™m interested. A lot of times things will come through like, â€˜This would be really fun. Iâ€™m sure it would fill time nicely. I think Iâ€™m comfortable in that type of part.â€™ Usually, when I see things like that, itâ€™s something I probably will not take. Also, I must acknowledge the fact that itâ€™s very rare that working actors have the opportunity to be able to choose what they want their career to look like, to shape their career in the way they want to represent themselves.

The show has given me the consistency and work and financial ability to be able to make that decision of something coming through and saying, â€˜I donâ€™t need to do that right now. Iâ€™m fine. Iâ€™ll wait it off and wait for the next thing to come around.â€™ Thatâ€™s not how working as an actor usually is. You take what you can get and you just grind and consistently do as much as you can, because you never these opportunities arenâ€™t guaranteed no matter what youâ€™re doing and for how consistently you do it. Itâ€™s a freelance career, and Iâ€™m very lucky to be in a position where I can choose what I want to do and what I donâ€™t. Thatâ€™s something I will cherish and not take for granted going forward.

title: Gaten Matarazzo Breaks Down His â€˜Stranger Thingsâ€™ Finale Graduation Speech, Elevenâ€™s Fate and Whether He Thought Dustin Might Die: â€˜The Point Is the Kids Make It Throughâ€™

content:
SPOILER ALERT: This story contains spoilers from the series finale of â€œStranger Things,â€ now streaming on Netflix.

Gaten Matarazzo was hardly a teenager when Matt and Ross Duffer cast him as the insatiably lovable Dustin Henderson in the first season of â€œStranger Things.â€ Now, nine-and-a-half years and five seasons later, the Netflix phenomenon has come to a close, with the seriesâ€™ epic finale releasing in theaters and on the streamer on Dec. 31.

Matarazzo caught the film on the big screen on New Yearâ€™s Eve while visiting family in Jacksonville, Fla. over the holidays. â€œI went dressed fully as the Grinch so no one recognized me,â€ Matarazzo told Variety, â€œbut the theater was small enough that I was like â€˜Ah, whatever,â€™ and took the mask off.â€

Popular on Variety

Wrapping up nearly a decade of storytelling, the finale concludes the arcs of the showâ€™s expansive ensemble, giving everyone at least one heroic moment. Dustin â€” a fan-favorite from the very first episode because of his infectious optimism and unapologetic nerdiness â€” is no exception. The hero uses his best qualities to contribute to archvillain Vecnaâ€™s (Jamie Campbell Bower) defeat. However, the characterâ€™s most memorable scene comes in the episodeâ€™s final act, when Dustin delivers his graduation speech as Hawkins High Schoolâ€™s Class of 1989 valedictorian. Articulating the themes of the show, Dustin speaks with endearing authority about how friendships have been forged and strengthened through strife. He then shifts his tone, ending the speech by telling off Principal Higgins (Bill Winkler) and shedding his robes for a Hellfire Club T-shirt, riffing on Eddie Munsonâ€™s (Joseph Quinn) iconic Season 4 line, â€œThis is our year!â€ to thunderous applause.

â€œA lot of shows donâ€™t really give characters the opportunity to kind of just, for lack of a better word, talk shit and air everything out and speak unapologetically about the way they feel,â€ Matarazzo says of the experience. â€œI didnâ€™t take for granted how special that opportunity was.â€

Despite tense moments aplenty, the finale concludes Dustinâ€™s story on an optimistic note, showing him going to college and still making time for adventures with his unlikely best friend from the past few seasons, Steve Harrington (Joe Keery).

Variety spoke with Matarazzo about his experience closing the book on â€œStranger Thingsâ€ after nearly a decade of growing up with Dustin.

When did you find out that the â€œStranger Thingsâ€ finale would play in theaters?

Officially we found out when it was released to the public. I think we expected it, but there were times when they said they werenâ€™t doing it, but it kept coming up throughout the show. Matt and Ross had been trying to get it done for a while and all of us kept going back to them asking for updates. Weâ€™d ask if there was anything we could say to make it happen and theyâ€™d say, â€œNo.â€ They had to work it out on their end because it went against the model that Netflix created and it wasnâ€™t something that had ever been done for TV before. Theyâ€™d done it for movies, though, so that was probably the kicker. It ended up being put together really quickly once it was confirmed. We went from hearing that itâ€™s not going to happen to, â€œNever mind, itâ€™s a goâ€ kind of out of nowhere.

Did you get a chance to see it in theaters with an audience?

Yeah, I went with my mom and my siblings when we were visiting her in Jacksonville for the holidays. We made sure that we reserved spots at a theater nearby. The theater itself was actually quite small, so it was really just like four or five other families. I went dressed fully as the Grinch so no one recognized me, but the theater was small enough that I was like â€œAh, whateverâ€ and took the mask off.

The finale looks great in the theater, especially those scenes in the Abyss. What was it like choreographing those battles with the giant Mind Flayer?

Oh man, those days were crazy. They can be the most stressful days because youâ€™re not saying much for a long time. Youâ€™ll just be doing so much cardio and then you look up at a tennis ball and go â€œAhhhhâ€ and hope it looks good. Luckily, when we ended up watching it, it looks great. The final form of the Mind Flayer, that crazy big Lovecraftian thing, looks unreal.

I know that my theater was very nervous for the fate of all the characters. Did you know how Dustinâ€™s story would end before reading the final script? Were you ever worried that he might not make it?

We were all curious going in, and I think everyone was open to the idea of our characters dying, but I just donâ€™t think that was the show that they really had in mind. A lot of the obsession with whoâ€™s dying was more fan-pushed than anything. I could be wrong, but I donâ€™t think the creative team ever really pushed that the main characters wouldnâ€™t make it out alive. And I think that ultimately ended up being a really great way to define what the show was about. Itâ€™s about persevering through unimaginable odds. I think thereâ€™s something special there. The point is that the kids make it through, so I was never really scared. Also, if one of us was dying, I feel like they would have told us before the writing process even started. Itâ€™s not something they would have sprung on us in the table read. They would have told us individually if it was coming.

What was your reaction to finding out where Dustin ends up at the end of the series?

Itâ€™s such a relief. Theyâ€™ve all been through so much, so to see him going forward and taking a breath and finally having a shred of normalcy â€” itâ€™s all he really could have asked for. And thatâ€™s whatâ€™s so tragic about the end of Elevenâ€™s story. Normalcy would never be guaranteed for the people that she loves if she was there. She didnâ€™t see it as fair, and I think it was a beautiful choice to end her story the way that they did.

Do you have a personal belief in whether or not Eleven is alive?

I do, but I want to keep that private. I donâ€™t know if others will, but I think that whatever works for you and makes the show wrap up better for you is correct. You have the right to debate it, but whatever you want it to be for you is great. I think they teeter that line very well, because Iâ€™ve already noticed a kind of 50/50 split amongst fans about whether they believe.

How was it preparing and delivering Dustinâ€™s graduation speech where he gets to sum up the point of the show, but also stick it to the principal one last time?

Oh, it was fun. It was a really special opportunity to be given that monologue. It can be a bit stressful to say all those words, especially in front of such a large audience, but a lot of shows donâ€™t really give characters the opportunity to kind of just, for lack of a better word, talk shit and air everything out and speak unapologetically about the way they feel. I didnâ€™t take for granted how special that opportunity was. It also shows that Dustin is in a vastly better place from the start of the season.

Courtesy of Netflix

Dustin has a lot of really emotional scenes in Season 5. How did it feel to tap into the darker, sadder sides of this typically optimistic character?

It was weird. It was definitely on the scarier side. I love the show so much, and I was really excited to jump back into what I did in the previous four seasons, so the change was kind of a curve ball thrown out of nowhere and nerve-racking, but I understood it. I was a little anxious, but I felt very honored that Matt and Ross trusted me to approach Dustin differently and give me what I saw as a challenge. Iâ€™m always up for a tone shift, and it was a kind of performance that Matt and Ross had never seen me do. There are worlds where actors excel in different genres and styles, but when called upon to jump into something tonally different, it can feel clunky. I wanted to try giving everything I got to be as truthful as I could and service the story the way it deserves. So there was a little bit more pressure, but I was super up for the opportunity. I found it really cool, cathartic and sometimes very fun.

Because Dustin sort of inherits Eddieâ€™s persona in Hawkins for Season 5, Iâ€™m curious if you ever reconnected with Joseph Quinn and discussed your characters going into the final season?

Not much. I think it was kind of the point that Dustin didnâ€™t get to talk to him as much as he wanted. I had to be as truthful as I could and not ask him too much, because Dustin doesnâ€™t have the opportunity to ask Eddie very much. He has to learn as he goes. The one thing I did ask is if there was any music he listened to to prep, because Eddieâ€™s uncle gave Dustin Eddieâ€™s tapes. It was a great playlist, and I listened to a good chunk of that. I donâ€™t know if thatâ€™s something he likes to keep private or not, but it was a lot of good stuff. It actually ended up shifting my taste in music for the year quite a bit.

Dustin and Steve have become one of the showâ€™s most iconic duos. Did you ever anticipate this for the characters in the early seasons? How has your relationship with Joe Keery developed over the years? Joe is the absolute best. Heâ€™s the MVP of every room he walks into, and I donâ€™t think he even knows it. He has a leadership quality that he doesnâ€™t demand, but commands, seemingly without trying. Heâ€™s a strong actor, a very thoughtful actor, very grounded, a good friend and a tremendously funny guy. It was something that I was so excited to approach when Season 2 started when we had a few scenes together. Before that I didnâ€™t think Iâ€™d ever get to work with him, so I was excited to take the opportunity while it was there. Thankfully, it just clicked. I think itâ€™s because these characters were at a crossroads, and we were trying to figure out what to do with them. No one really knew what was next for them. They attempted a bit of a tug-of-war, will-they-wonâ€™t-they thing with both Dustin and Lucas [Caleb McLaughlin] having crushes on Max [Sadie Sink], but it was so clear that Caleb and Sadie just had such incredible chemistry and those characters just worked so well together that they ditched the rivalry. That was the train-track scene, Dustin trying to figure out how he can approach telling Max that he likes her and then itâ€™s so funny how literally they drop it instantly after that. Lucas and Max end up together because it just wasnâ€™t clunky and keeping Dustin in that plot would have been weird and bloated. Similarly, Nancy and Jonathan were clearly the couple that were going to be working consistently as the season went on, so it was like â€œWhat the fuck do we do with Dustin and Steve right now?â€ Because they were both kind of dealing with similar predicaments in their love lives and they kind of had something to relate to there. Thankfully, there was a quality that worked between us and we locked into it.

Courtesy of Netflix

Season 5 also introduces a slew of younger characters. What was it like to no longer be the youngest actors on set, and to have these kids around and probably looking up to you? Theyâ€™re the best, talented group of kids. I was so excited for them and their opportunity. They held it down so well, and they brought such a cool energy to such a cool plot line. Itâ€™s one of those things that Matt, Ross and Carmen [Cuba], the casting director, seem to have a gauge for and understanding of, because when it comes to casting kids in TV, itâ€™s not just what comes across off the page and whether something works, itâ€™s gauging whether or not thereâ€™s going to be an ease in a work environment. Itâ€™s hard to put the expectations of a very big show running smoothly in the hands of children. Thatâ€™s kind of what was thrusted upon us when we were quite young, but I think they found out how to do it properly and get the right people. These kids are so talented and so kind and I think they had a good time doing it. It was so nice to get to know them and see them experience the show the way that we did, but through a lens of a little more experience. That was really special.

Youâ€™ve basically spent your entire adolescence playing Dustin. How has growing up with this character affected you over the years?

Weirdly, itâ€™s basically shaped everything about me, but I donâ€™t think thereâ€™s any other way it could have happened. I spent so much of my time invested in trying to figure out who he was and I think I inevitably learned a lot about myself alongside him. Caleb has always said something really special and really interesting, which is that he knew Lucas before he knew himself, and thatâ€™s such an interesting perspective. I never thought of it that way, but heâ€™s right. So much of our time and energy is focused on figuring out somebody that we are not and, inevitably, you end up inadvertently learning about yourself through that. And thatâ€™s really cool, so I think that Iâ€™m a very different person because of Dustin. I think that I am shaped into a different type of guy because I spend so much of my time shaping who he was. I always consider what i would be like as a person without the show and Iâ€™m hyper-convinced that I would be a worse one. It helped me prioritize the people in my life, and I love them very, very much.

Do you have a favorite moment from the series as a whole, either on-screen or on set?

Thatâ€™s such a good question, because now I can finally put it all into perspective and figure out what that really is for me, but itâ€™s so tough. Seasons 4 and 5 feel like one chapter. It feels like one, very long season where they introduce Vecna and itâ€™s like, â€œOK, great. This is the show now and it feels like one big chapter.â€ And I had so much fun doing all of what we called the â€œScooby-Doo Group,â€ stuff with the Hawkins investigative crew in Season 4 in the Creel House, figuring out Henryâ€™s backstory and trying to save Max. That was really cool, so I think that was my favorite.

Who on the cast have you grown closest with over the years and who have you learned the most from?

Thatâ€™s so tough. I love everybody on the show so much. They are literally family, and I have such wonderful individual relationships with all of them. Theyâ€™re so distinct from each other and thatâ€™s whatâ€™s so special. You know how some friend groups feel like you canâ€™t imagine yourself hanging out with any of them individually? Like when work friends grab drinks, and itâ€™s like, â€œI donâ€™t think I can ever talk to any of these people by themselves.â€ Iâ€™m so happy that all of us have had the ability to maintain real friendships individually with each other throughout this process. Iâ€™m super grateful for that. I lived with Finn [Wolfhard] for about a year, and I think that cemented a cadence that you donâ€™t really get with a person until you spend your mornings and nights with them consistently. It almost sounds like a couple, but we had this very shared experience with the show and getting to see him finish his movie, sell his movie, write his album and watch it all get released was really cool. And Caleb, Iâ€™ve never been able to have a heart to heart with anybody as much as I have with Caleb. Thereâ€™s just a quality that he has. You just feel so safe with him and I just appreciate his candor and the level of respect he has for people. He shows what it means to be a really good friend and heâ€™s taught me a lot.

Now that the show is over, what do you hope Dustinâ€™s legacy is for fans of â€œStranger Thingsâ€?

Iâ€™m thinking of a word that might seem inconsequential, but I donâ€™t think that it is in the context of Dustin, and thatâ€™s â€œEnthusiasm.â€ I think something thatâ€™s so interesting about Dustin is that every time theyâ€™re in grave danger, heâ€™s always kind of smiling. I think that itâ€™s because heâ€™s fully aware and acknowledges how fucking cool everything is. Like, theyâ€™re gonna die, theyâ€™re literally saving the world, but heâ€™s still floored that he might be the first person to be in contact with exotic matter. Heâ€™s so excited and heâ€™s so unapologetically nerdy and so invested in his interests and excited to learn. Itâ€™s very Mr. Clarke [Randy Havens]-esque. Heâ€™s so excited to learn about what he doesnâ€™t know. A lot of people approach what they donâ€™t know with angst or anxiety because the unknown is scary, but to Dustin, the unknown is the most exhilarating feeling in the world, because he has nothing but a drive to learn more about it. Itâ€™s really fun and itâ€™s something that I strive to embody myself.
