content:
â€‹The investigative docuseries â€œThe Cult of the Real Housewifeâ€ has arrived on TLC, and the three-episode exposÃ© unpacks allegations of cult behavior surrounding â€œThe Real Housewives of Salt Lake Cityâ€ reality star Mary Cosby and her church.â€‹

From first-hand accounts from ex-congregants to family members diving into Cosbyâ€™s turbulent childhood and her highly criticized marriage to her step-grandfather, the three-hour documentary reveals much more than the rumored cult leader accusations happening at Faith Temple Pentecostal Church, the church Cosby shares with her husband, Robert Cosby Sr., in Salt Lake City.

â€‹With appearances from investigative journalists and bloggers who have covered the story, as well as a leading cult expert, the docuseries features clips of recordings of controversial sermons preached by Mary and Robert, along with historical information about the rise of Faith Temple.â€‹

Popular on Variety

â€œThe Cult of the Real Housewifeâ€ is directed and produced by Elli Hakami and Julian P. Hobbs, a directing duo who also led Discovery+â€™s â€œHouse of Hammer,â€ which chronicled sexual abuse allegations and the checkered family history of actor Armie Hammer.â€‹

Below, we broke down the biggest revelations from the docuseries.

Cosbyâ€™s ex-boyfriend claims she was a childhood bullyâ€‹

Michael Enoch, a former member of Faith Temple Church and Cosbyâ€™s self-proclaimed childhood boyfriend, describes the reality star as having a mean streak as a kid: â€œMary was a bully. I remember Mary picking on certain girls and controlling them. When youâ€™re kids, you see these things and donâ€™t think much of it. But as an adult, you look back on it. And she wasnâ€™t a nice person.â€

Cosby marries her step-grandfather after her grandmother died

In Season 1 of â€œThe Real Housewives of Salt Lake City,â€ Cosby appeared with her husband, Robert Sr., discussing how her late grandmother arranged for her to marry her step-grandfather as expressed in her will. â€œShe said if anything ever happens to me, I want you to marry one of my girls because theyâ€™ll look out for you,â€ Robert Sr. said during their confessional. The two, married since 1998 when Mary was in her early 20s, and Robert Sr. was 20 years her senior, share a son named Robert Jr.

Audio leaks of Cosby berating her congregationâ€‹

In an audio clip that was allegedly obtained from someone inside the church, the documentary includes a resurfaced sound bite of Cosby speaking to members of her church, in which she called them â€œpoorâ€ and â€œstingyâ€ for giving her only 14 birthday cards and not contributing enough with their tithes. Former church member and organist Ernest Enoch says he was present during the incident, and claims he gave her a birthday card with $1,000 inside.

Former members claim they felt forced to pay large payments in offerings

â€‹In addition to tithing, former churchgoers allege that the Cosbys would have six-month heave offerings, in which they would pressure members to make large financial sacrifices for the advancement of the church. Ex-church member Rosalind Enoch also claims that a week in between their heave offerings, they would also be told the church needed urgent financial assistance with offering requests up to $100,000 within a few days.

Rosalind also says members cashed out their 401Ks and mortgaged their homes in order to pay large sums to the church. â€œWe would have these meetings after church, and Robert would instruct ushers to stand at the doors. Youâ€™re barricaded in there,â€ she says. â€œDuring this meeting, everyone put their name and amount on the list. If you didnâ€™t have a certain amount, Robert would say, â€˜And thatâ€™s all you have.â€™â€

Cosbyâ€™s first cousin accuses her of having an affairâ€‹

Dan Cosby said ex-congregant Cameron Williams â€” who died after his appearance on â€œRHOSLCâ€ in 2021 from complications after a brain tumor â€” talks about having an intimate relationship with Cosby. During a phone call, Dan says that Cameron told him Mary went to his house and requested that he put on music. After sitting beside her, Cameron allegedly told Dan, Mary grabbed his hand and started â€œrubbing her.â€

Dan recalls, â€œAccording to Cameron, he put his hand in her vagina.â€ Dan continues, saying Cameron told him, â€œThen, we had sex.â€ In an audio clip with Dan, Cameron says, â€œWe had the affair and all that, but that was me being victimized. It had to take therapy for me to get out of that.â€ Ernest also reveals that Cameron told him about the affair.

Family members claim Robert Sr. was abusive

â€‹In the documentary, Sam Kelly, Cosbyâ€™s uncle, describes Robert Sr. as having a two-faced personality and exhibiting cruel behavior toward him as a child. Growing up, Kelly recalls having meetings with Robert Sr. and other church elders where they would gather the young men of the church over the weekend for lessons designed for their personal development.

During those lessons, Dan and Kelly allege that Robert Sr. would force them to do pushups, sprint around the church, hold books while running in place, among other tasks. â€œHe and some of the older elders were in the military, and they were putting that in us as kids,â€ Dan says while holding back tears. â€œFor example, taking a pin and putting it under your knees so you wouldnâ€™t hit the pin or it wouldnâ€™t stick to you. I remember a kid couldnâ€™t do a pushup or a sit up, and one of the elders kicked him.â€

Cosby was excommunicated from the church as a young adult

According to family members, Cosby had a difficult childhood where she allegedly would run away from home several times, skip school and frequently clash with her mother. Their strained relationship led to her grandmother stepping in to help take care of Cosby. Her troubled behavior reached a point where she was disfellowshipped from Faith Temple Church. While shunned, Cosbyâ€™s grandmother died.

Cosby allegedly divorced her first husband to marry Robert Sr.

â€‹Investigative journalist Cheyenne Roundtree found Cosbyâ€™s divorce and marriage records, which reveal that she married Robert Sr. 19 days after her divorce was finalized. After Cosbyâ€™s grandmother died, her family wasnâ€™t supportive of her marriage to Robert Sr.

During a walkout service, Cosbyâ€™s mother stood in the pulpit and publicly rejected their marriage in front of the congregation. â€œAll these lies have been put out, that is not God,â€ she said in a video clip. â€œYou hear me today. If this is my last stand in the pulpit, that is not God whatâ€™s going on around here.â€

Financial abuse claims

According to Roundtree, several church members told her they were expected to run errands, clean and manage bills, among other responsibilities, for Cosby and Robert Sr., free of charge. For five years, Rosalind â€” who at one point lived with the couple â€” says she was responsible for housekeeping and running errands. â€œI was never paid,â€ she says in the documentary. â€œI was collecting unemployment. I guess thatâ€™s what they thought I would live on. It was more like a slave plantation.â€

title: Kate Winslet on Her Acting Career on Why She Directed â€˜Goodbye Juneâ€™: â€˜In My 50th Year, I Damn Well Have to Do Itâ€™
summary: Kate Winslet sits down with a mix of exhilaration and disbelief. She’s still processing the magnitude of what sheâ€™s just done. The Oscar-winning actress (2008’s “The Reader”) has delivered her directorial debut, â€œGoodbye June,â€ an intimate family drama written by her son, Joe Anders, and the reality of it hasnâ€™t quite settled in. â€œEven hearing […]
content:
Kate Winslet sits down with a mix of exhilaration and disbelief. Sheâ€™s still processing the magnitude of what sheâ€™s just done. The Oscar-winning actress (2008â€™s â€œThe Readerâ€) has delivered her directorial debut, â€œGoodbye June,â€ an intimate family drama written by her son, Joe Anders, and the reality of it hasnâ€™t quite settled in.

â€œEven hearing you say that Iâ€™ve directed a film, Iâ€™m almost experiencing the aftershocks,â€ Winslet says with a smile. â€œAs a woman, making films is hard, even as an actress. Women directors have to advocate for themselves so fiercely. Iâ€™ve spent years advocating for others, so suddenly finding myself in that community feels thrilling. I donâ€™t think I ever truly imagined Iâ€™d be here.â€

The moment arrived not through urgency, but timing. Winslet had always prioritized motherhood. Now, with her children grown â€” or growing â€” space finally opened. â€œDirecting is an end-to-end commitment of a year, sometimes more,â€ she says. â€œThatâ€™s enormous. But the stars aligned, and in my 50th year, I damn well have to do it â€” and I loved it.â€

Popular on Variety

â€œGoodbye Juneâ€ centers on a family gathering as its matriarch faces a terminal illness, a subject Winslet approaches with lived understanding after losing her own mother in 2017. The film boasts a formidable ensemble: Helen Mirren, Toni Collette, Timothy Spall, Andrea Riseborough and Winslet herself.

Winslet drew on decades in front of the camera to rethink how actors are supported on set. Overhead boom microphones were eliminated. Hidden mics replaced them. Cameras were locked off. For the most private scenes, the crew quietly stepped away.

â€œI wanted to disarm the space,â€ Winslet explains. â€œTo remove the things that pull actors out of themselves.â€

The result is a film that finds humor inside grief without softening its truth. â€œLife doesnâ€™t stop being funny just because itâ€™s painful,â€ Winslet shares. â€œSometimes laughter is the only way through.â€

For a first-time director, Winsletâ€™s approach feels both considered and instinctive, rooted in empathy and trust. Whether â€œGoodbye Juneâ€ marks the beginning of a new chapter or a singular act remains to be seen. But for now, Winslet is allowing herself a moment to acknowledge what sheâ€™s built.

â€œI really did it,â€ she says, still sounding slightly surprised.

On this episode of the Variety Awards Circuit Podcast, Winslet talks about preparing for this moment in her career, working with her son, and what she wants to do next.

â€œGoodbye Juneâ€ stars Helen Mirren and Kate Winslet. (Kimberley French / Netflix / Courtesy Everett Collection) Â©Netflix/Courtesy Everett Collection

Read excerpts from her interview below, which has been edited and condensed for clarity.

How did your experience as an actor shape the way you directed?

I knew immediately how to bypass things that wouldnâ€™t be helpful. What surprised me was how different every actorâ€™s needs were. Each person needed something specific from me, and adapting to that was wonderful. It meant learning who they were, what they needed to feel safe â€” and building trust. That trust was everything.

Talk about the choices to eliminate boom microphones on set.

As an actor, I find them incredibly distracting. They move, they hover, and I always feel bad for the person holding them. Boom operators are brilliant, but they anticipate movement â€” and if an actor changes their mind mid-take, it can throw you out of the moment. I wanted to remove that distraction. We also had children in the film, and little kids always look up at the big black thing waving above their heads. Without booms, that problem disappeared.

What led you to lock off cameras and clear the set for intimate scenes?

In the quietest scenes â€” between Helen Mirren and Timothy Spall, or Toni Collette and Helen in the hospital bathroom â€” the actors were completely alone. Cameras were rolling, but no one was operating them. Helen said to me, â€œIâ€™ve never had that in my life, and Iâ€™m so grateful.â€ That meant everything. It allowed a different emotional texture to emerge â€” something very real.

How did you balance grief with humor in the film?

That balance was essential. When youâ€™re facing tragedy, laughter still happens â€” sometimes at moments that feel inappropriate. When my own mother was five days from passing, she told my daughter she should take her bras because she wouldnâ€™t need them anymore. We laughed. That moment was how my daughter understood she was losing her grandmother. Thatâ€™s life. Humor is part of it.

How did you manage a 35-day shoot with Helen Mirren for only 16 days?

Iâ€™m a forward thinker. If youâ€™re number one on the call sheet and you slow things down, you jeopardize the entire day. With a schedule like that, you cannot afford to drop a scene â€” you may never get it back. My prep with my DP, Alvin KÃ¼chler, was incredibly detailed. He practically moved into my house for a week. We planned everything.

What was the biggest challenge about directing yourself?

That was the one thing I didnâ€™t know how Iâ€™d handle. I had to be ready with multiple choices for myself so that in the edit Iâ€™d have options. My instinct is never to put myself first, so Iâ€™d always prioritize coverage of the other actors â€” and then realize I had to rush my own. It was insane. But also exhilarating.

Did your photographic memory surprise you in the edit?

I could remember specific takesâ€”what worked, what didnâ€™t. Iâ€™d say to my editor, Lucia Zucchetti, â€œStay on take five.â€ Sheâ€™d question it, and Iâ€™d say, â€œNo, trust me.â€ And I was right. That helped us maintain a strong emotional through line.

What was it like collaborating with your son, Joe Anders, on the screenplay?

Joe doesnâ€™t know how I work on set, and I canâ€™t teach my children how to do this job. They have to find their own way. Iâ€™m incredibly proud of both my kids because theyâ€™re carving their own paths. Collaborating with your child â€” and having meaningful creative conversations â€” is very special.

What struck you most about Timothy Spallâ€™s performance?

Thereâ€™s a moment when his character is asked, â€œDo you still love her?â€ He says nothing. Itâ€™s all in his eyes. The hurt, the betrayal â€” you see his heart crack open. Itâ€™s some of the best acting Iâ€™ve ever witnessed.

How did you approach the filmâ€™s visual language?

This is a messy, complicated family living with long-term illness. I didnâ€™t want cancer to become the narrative. Thatâ€™s not the story. The story is how a family is pulled closer together. Early on, I hold back visually â€” itâ€™s the space between people that tells us how distant they are.

Do you want to direct again?

I would love to. I genuinely would. Iâ€™ve only just delivered the film, so I donâ€™t know yet â€” but yes, Iâ€™d love to.

What was it like returning to â€œAvatar: Fire and Ashâ€ and what did it remind you about acting?

I shot it years ago, but the experience was extraordinary. The training was intense. Jim Cameronâ€™s passion is unmatched. And as I get older, I realize how much I love being in a pack with other actors. That energy matters. I was fortunate to be part of it.

content:
Chevy Chase is again wading into the resurfaced controversy surrounding his alleged use of the N-word on the set of Community.

â€œIt was too great a misunderstanding of what I was saying and not saying,â€ Chase said in an interview published yesterday by the New York Times. â€œI thought that there was at least one person â€” and another who, for some ungodly reason, didnâ€™t get me, didnâ€™t know who I was, or didnâ€™t realize for one second Iâ€™m not racist. They were too young to be aware of my work. Instead, there was some sort of visceral reaction from them.â€

Watch on Deadline

In the doc, Community director Jay Chandrasekhar says that Chase had an on-set â€œmeltdownâ€ following the incident in which the former SNL cast member apparently used the N-word in a conversation with co-star Yvette Nicole Brown, who is Black.

While he didnâ€™t actually hear the conversation between the two actors, Chandrasekhar says in the doc that he â€œwas there, directing, the night that Chevy Chase got fired from Community.â€ Chandrasekhar says the event stemmed from a scripted â€œblackfaceâ€ hand puppet bit involving Chaseâ€™s Community character Pierce Hawthorne.

Chase, as detailed in a Deadline report at the time, was unhappy with his characterâ€™s racist development, and said something along the lines that soon the writers would be having him say the N-word. Only he didnâ€™t say â€œN-word.â€

Brown took to social media yesterday and emphasized that no one can speak for her or for her personal experiences on the show.

â€œThere are things Iâ€™ve never spoken of publicly and perhaps never will. Anyone currently speaking FOR or ABOUT me with perceived authority is speaking without EVER speaking to me about the things they claim to know about,â€ she wrote in a statement on Threads. â€œThey actually donâ€™t really know me â€” at all.â€

She continued, â€œThey also have no knowledge of my relationship with anyone lâ€™ve worked with & cannot credibly speak on any current or previous issues. I hate that all this had to be said. In East Cleveland speak: Keep my name out your mouth.â€

Chase, reflecting on his time on Community and departure from the show, said, â€œIt wasnâ€™t a bad experience. I just didnâ€™t think it was that good, the show.â€

On the topic of explaining himself and his past actions, Chase said, â€œI donâ€™t have any need to do that. The whole issue of them thinking Iâ€™m an [expletive], itâ€™s all junk. I donâ€™t care much about it. I have a great, great life, a wonderful family.â€

Asked if his actions hurt his career, the comedian responded, â€œI donâ€™t think I sabotaged my career. I think we go up and down and up and down, up and down. You make mistakes. You make mistakes. title: â€˜CBS Evening Newsâ€™ Unveils â€œFive Simple Principlesâ€ In Advance Of Tony Dokoupilâ€™s Debut As New Anchor
summary: CBS Evening News has unveiled “five simple principles” to guide the broadcast, as Tony Dokoupil prepares to take over as the new anchor of the broadcast on Monday. Dokoupil, who has been a co-host on CBS Mornings, will be the sixth anchor of the newscast in the past 10 years. A revamp of the CBS […]
content:
CBS Evening News has unveiled â€œfive simple principlesâ€ to guide the broadcast, as Tony Dokoupil prepares to take over as the new anchor of the broadcast on Monday.

Dokoupil, who has been a co-host on CBS Mornings, will be the sixth anchor of the newscast in the past 10 years. A revamp of the CBS Evening News has been one of the priorities of Bari Weiss, the founder of center-right opinion site The Free Press who was named in October to lead the news division.

The principles are:

We work for you. That means you come first. Not our advertisers. Not politicians. Not corporate interests, including the corporate owners of CBS News. We report on the world as it is. Weâ€™ll be honest and direct with you. That means no weasel words or padded landings. Weâ€™ll tell you what we know, when we know it. Well update our reporting when we uncover new facts. And weâ€™ll admit when we get it wrong. We respect you. We believe that our fellow Americans are smart and discerning. Itâ€™s our job to present you with the fullest picture â€” and the strongest voices on all sides of an issue. We trust you to make up your own minds, and to make the decisions that are best for you, your families and your communities. We love America. And we make no apologies for saying so. Our foundational values of liberty, equality and the rule of law make us the last best hope on Earth. We also believe in Franklinâ€™s famous line about America as a republic â€” if we can keep it. We aim to do our part every night: One way to think about our show is as a daily conversation about exactly where we are as a country and where we are going. We respect tradition, but we also believe in the future. We embrace the tools that allow us to reach you where you are. Some of you will watch this show on linear television. Others will increasingly watch it on social media. What we can guarantee is that the tools will continue to change â€” but some things never will. One of those things is honest journalism.

Some of the principles reflect remarks that Dokoupil made in a video that debuted on Thursday. In those comments, he also addressed the issue of trust, saying that â€œon too many stories the press has missed the story. Because weâ€™ve taken into account the perspective of advocates and not the average American. Or we put too much weight in the analysis of academics or elites and not enough on you. And I know this because, at certain points, I have been you. I have felt this way too. I have felt like what I was seeing and hearing on the news didnâ€™t reflect what I was seeing and hearing in my own life. And that the most urgent questions simply werenâ€™t being asked.â€



â€œSo hereâ€™s my promise to you today and every time you see me in this chair: you come first. Not advertisers. Not politicians. Not corporate interests. And, yes, that does include the corporate owners of CBS. I report for you.â€

Dokoupil is taking the network anchor chair at a time of intense scrutiny over Weiss and the motives of new Paramount CEO David Ellison. It comes at a time when the corporate parent is making a hostile bid for Warner Bros. Discovery, a massive transaction that will need Trump administration approval.

Watch on Deadline

Some moves have fed suspicions that the Paramount owners are moving the news division rightward, in ways that will ultimately please Trump. As it sought the Trump FCC approval of its acquisition of Paramount, Ellisonâ€™s Skydance committed to hiring an ombudsman to take complaints about news coverage. The person selected, Kenneth R. Weinstein, is the former president and CEO of the Hudson Institute, a right-leaning think tank.

Weiss, meanwhile, generated a recent furor among some staffers at CBS News when she ordered a 60 Minutes segment on Trumpâ€™s deportations pulled, even though it had already been completed and promoted. Among other things, Weiss said that the segment was â€œnot readyâ€ and that it needed to â€œget the principals on the record and on camera.â€ The segment, which was mistakenly posted online by one of the networkâ€™s Canadian partners, noted that they had sought an interview with Trump Department of Homeland Security officials but were declined.

Correspondent Sharyn Alfonsi said in a memo to colleagues that they â€œrequested responses to questions and/or interviews with DHS, the White House and the State Department. Government silence is a statement, not a VETO. Their refusal to be interviewed is a tactical maneuver designed to kill the story.â€

She wrote that â€œif the administrationâ€™s refusal to participate becomes a valid reason to spike a story, we have effectively handed them a â€˜kill switchâ€™ for any reporting they find inconvenient.â€ She wrote that the pulling of the story was â€œpoliticalâ€ and a case of corporate interference.

title: How â€˜We Bury the Deadâ€™ Finds a Fresh Take on Zombies With Stomach-Churning Sounds and a Daisy Ridley Role Far Away From â€˜Star Warsâ€™
summary: No sound effect makes people squirm quite like grinding teeth. content:
No sound effect makes people squirm quite like grinding teeth. Zak Hilditch, who wrote and directed the new zombie feature â€œWe Bury the Dead,â€ out today via Vertical, has seen the noise make audiences shudder in real time, as itâ€™s the signature of the undead in his film.

â€œWhen I was delving into the zombie world, we didnâ€™t have all the money in the world, so how do I make these things unique?â€ Hilditch says. â€œThis idea of growing agitation, what does that look and sound like? It sounds like teeth grinding to me. So that was something even I was milking as much as I possibly could, wherever I could, as it was going to be a really interesting thing to have echo throughout the film. That particular sound was something that the sound team, before we even shot the movie, was most excited about delving into because they could see the possibilities there.

â€œItâ€™s been interesting watching the film internationally this year, on the festival junket,â€ he continues. â€œWhen we hit that sound, itâ€™s aching, like nails on a chalkboard. There were versions where it was even more extreme, and we had to pull it back a little bit to make it palatable for an audience. That was just one example of how this isnâ€™t a big studio film at all, yet we did everything we could to put you in that headspace. The sound was so important in helping guide that through.â€

Popular on Variety

In the film, Ava Newman (â€œStar Warsâ€ alum Daisy Ridley) heads to Australia to find and recover her husband after a military accident. Unfortunately, the dead are rising after the incident, and Ava must avoid the teeth-grinding zombies.

â€œDeadâ€ is the Australia-based auteurâ€™s eighth feature, and Hilditch was inspired to write it by the passing of his mother.

â€œIt was a personal initial kernel of an idea,â€ he says. â€œWhen it comes to grief, realizing there is no silver bullet or a special guidebook to get you through. When my mum passed, it was my job to pack down the family house that I grew up in, which she died in. It was weirdly cathartic having something physical to do. As a filmmaker, there was a part of me thinking, â€˜Iâ€™m going room to room and making these discoveries.â€™ Thereâ€™s something quite intimate yet surreal about it. I thought that there was something worth mining in terms of grief.â€

Hilditch says that Ridley signing on for the project added an essential layer of humanity to the film.

â€œIt was just unbelievable,â€ he says. â€œShe was the very first actress we sent the script to, and within one week, we were Zooming. She was absolutely perfect for the role: Right time, right place. When she arrived on set, seeing that side of her and how she was all-in on this character and my words that I had spewed out on the page â€¦ You see her taking that and turning it into a living, breathing entity that goes far beyond your wildest expectations of what this was going to be.â€

Hilditch says â€œthe whole movie rests on Ridleyâ€™s shoulders, and she absolutely crushed it.â€

â€œI canâ€™t wait for people to see her in this light. I donâ€™t think sheâ€™s done something quite like this before,â€ he adds. â€œTo be plucked from the millions of people who would have died to play Rey, and get through all those three films, and then moving on to the next phase of your filmmaking life as an actor â€¦ Sheâ€™s got a very eclectic bunch of tastes. Iâ€™m just really lucky that she saw something in my pages.â€

As for the future, Hilditch loves working in horror but is most drawn in to stories led by dynamic characters, no matter the genre.

â€œI just love ordinary people caught in extraordinary situations,â€ he says. â€œThis is exactly an example of that. I definitely wonâ€™t be going back into zombie tales anytime soon. I never thought I was going to make a zombie movie until I made â€˜We Bury the Dead.â€™ I only wanted to do it if I was able to say something new or interesting. I think I managed to find a fresh enough way to give people the zombie lore that they all have come to expect, but to really pull the rug on your expectations at the same time. If it can still do that, thatâ€™s an amazing thing in this modern age.â€

title: Global Box OfficeÂ Estimated At $33.5B; Anime Explodes In Up-And-Down Year: Studio Report Cards
summary: The global box office in 2025 is estimated to close out at $33.5B, per Gower Street Analytics, repping a nearly 12% increase on 2024, but thatâ€™s including a unique phenomenon in China where one local production did over $2B. Strip out China, and the global hike is about 8%, much better than the roughly 11% […]
content:
The global box office in 2025 is estimated to close out at $33.5B, per Gower Street Analytics, repping a nearly 12% increase on 2024, but thatâ€™s including a unique phenomenon in China where one local production did over $2B. Strip out China, and the global hike is about 8%, much better than the roughly 11% decrease we saw from the end of 2023 through 2024. The international box office, sans China, is forecast at $17.2B, also a 12% jump over last year. With China factored in, overseas is looking at $24.6B (+16%).

In general, when we sum up 2025, thereâ€™s good and not-so-hot news at the global and international box office but also optimism amid some uncertainty on the horizon. Windows remain a talking point â€” particularly amid a potential acquisition of a legacy studio by a streamer â€” as does volume and the shifting of moviegoing habits. And, though they may seem way in the past, the 2023 strikes also ended up impacting 2025 and the sequencing of when films could be finished. The year ahead should help to mitigate more of the impact.

One international distribution executive characterized 2025 as â€œa little disappointingâ€ but also noted: â€œI think you can look forward to â€™26 with some optimism that things are going to turn around. â€¦ Everybody measures this industry against 2019, which was pre-Covid, but that was also the all-time record year. Certainly at some point weâ€™ll get back to those box office levels, just through inflation and more premium screens and currency. But I donâ€™t know if we ever get back to those admission levels, just because I think consumer habits might have changed.â€

RELATED: 2025 Moviegoer Attendance Hits 780M, -5% From â€™24; Majority Went To Cinemas During Picsâ€™ First 30 Days Of Release

Like every year, there were ups and downs in 2025, but itâ€™s clear that there is still an audience for a theatrical event and the continuation of beloved franchises. The year started off slowly for Hollywood, with the first real breakout, Warner Brosâ€™ A Minecraft Movie, catapulting us into the spring. It was followed by Disneyâ€™s Lilo & Stitch, which became the first billion-dollar movie for the studios in 2025, with 59.2% of business from overseas. Just last month, Disneyâ€™s Zootopia 2 exceeded that film as Dis reached an estimated $6.58B worldwide ($4.08B from the international space). Thatâ€™s the biggest year for any studio since 2019. Also contributing, 20th Centuryâ€™s Avatar: Fire and Ash will cross $1B this week.

See below for the global/international studio rankings chart.

After Minecraft got the ball rolling, Paramountâ€™s Mission: Impossible â€” The Final Reckoning did 67% of its nearly $600M global business in offshore markets â€” making it the No. 9 title on the overseas chart â€” and played at the same time as Lilo & Stitch. Then Universal returned to How to Train Your Dragon (58.7% from overseas) and Jurassic World with Rebirth (61% internationally), and Appleâ€™s F1 (via WB) roared with 70% of its haul from offshore.

RELATED: Deadlineâ€™s Critics Pick Their Top 10 Films Of 2025

Japan got a jolt in midsummer with Demon Slayer: Kimetsu no Yaiba â€“ Infinity Castle, which carried into the fall as the movie released in markets outside Asia via Sony and Crunchyroll and including domestic, ultimately landing in the Top 10 worldwide. The early autumn, arguably apart from WBâ€™s The Conjuring: Last Rites, was somewhat quiet, but things ramped up again with Universalâ€™s Wicked: For Good, followed by Zoo 2 and Avatar.

Itâ€™s worth noting that there also were a number of bright spots for WB with titles including Final Destination Bloodlines, One Battle After Another, Sinners and Weapons. Although the latter two were bigger domestic plays, the studio reached nearly $4.4B on just 11 titles versus 20 the previous year.

International Swings

China, still the top overseas market, was heavily weighted by one movie: Ne Zha 2. The animated sensation released locally in late January and went on to become the highest-grossing title in the marketâ€™s history at 15.44B RMB ($2.2B+) as well as the biggest movie of the year worldwide and the No. 5 movie ever globally.

RELATED: The 25 Highest-Grossing Animated Films Of All Time At The Global Box Office

Chinaâ€™s final box office for 2025 is estimated at roughly 51.8B RMB ($7.4B), per Maoyan, a more than 20% increase on 2024, though nearly 30% of grosses were from just that one film. Most agree that the market struggled in 2025, getting a boost of adrenaline from Disneyâ€™s Zootopia 2 in November, with Maoyan noting repeat viewings and â€œfan engagement and loyalty.â€ While Hollywood doesnâ€™t really expect China to return to the pre-pandemic heyday, Zootopia demonstrated that audiences will turn out for event films and franchises for which they have an affinity.

Local midrange Chinese films saw a notable decline in numbers, â€œunderscoring the marketâ€™s increasing concentration on blockbuster projects,â€ Maoyan said. However, the traditional â€œblockbuster model is no longer a guaranteed formula for box office success,â€ it cautioned.

Of the Top 10 international markets, Japan, at No. 2, was a standout with a roughly 35% increase over 2024 in local currency and up 33% in U.S. dollars, according to comScore figures through December 28. This was amid the success of Demon Slayer, Kokuho, the latest Detective Conan, Chainsaw Man â€” The Movie: Reze Arc and Zootopia 2.

RELATED: From James Gray, Ruben Ã–stlund & PaweÅ‚ Pawlikowski To IÃ±Ã¡rrituâ€™s Tom Cruise-Starrer, â€˜Cliff Boothâ€™ & Judith GodrÃ¨cheâ€™s Directorial Debut: 79 Films That Could Light Up Festivals In 202

Indeed, anime really spread its wings in 2025, including Demon Slayer and Chainsaw Man. This is a growing medium that is expanding globally and resonates with an underserved audience while also drawing new customers â€” there was so much heat around these movies that they became must-sees in all regions.

In the UK, the No. 3 market internationally, Uniâ€™s Bridget Jones: Mad About the Boy was huge, becoming the No. 3 movie of the year there with about $63M, whereas it went straight to Peacock in the U.S. It was a smart bet to release it theatrically overseas, particularly in the UK. Overall, the market essentially was flat with 2024, up a slight 2% in U.S. dollars.

At No. 4 on the international chart, Franceâ€™s cinema admissions dropped 13.6% year-on-year in 2025, for a rough gross of $1.36B, according to figures released by Franceâ€™s National Cinema Center. A lack of local drivers compared to last year was part of the issue.

RELATED: Casting Conundrums: From Bond To Voldemort, Doctor Who To â€˜White Lotusâ€™, The Biggest Movie & TV Roles To Be Filled In 2026

And the No. 5 market, Germany, was up 6% in local currency (+10% in U.S. dollars). Whereas 2024â€™s Top 5 movies were Hollywood titles, the No. 1 movie in the market in 2025, per comScore, was Das Kanu des Manitu (Manitouâ€™s Canoe).

Windows

Although it has improved to a degree, France still has a fairly arcane windowing system. But globally, windows are on everyoneâ€™s minds, an issue which Deadlineâ€™s Anthony Dâ€™Alessandro already has written about extensively.

Internationally, some execs contend that itâ€™s not always a one-size-fits-all approach because habits are different in myriad overseas markets. Said one: â€œHabits, good or bad, can change within weeks, and when they do, they can settle in as the new normal. The new windowing patterns have changed the audienceâ€™s habit from going to â€˜The Moviesâ€™ to going to â€˜A Movie.â€™ International markets have had varying degrees of impact from this.â€

Also stressed by an international exec is that the impact of shorter, inconsistent windowing ultimately is what has negatively changed audience moviegoing habits, putting the impetus on every movie to create a cultural moment. If, for whatever reason, audiences donâ€™t go to the cinema on opening weekend, their mindset shifts, focusing on the conveniences of home viewing with the assumption that the movie will be imminently available, doing so with little knowledge of when each movie actually will be available outside cinemas.

RELATED: 2026 Awards Season Calendar: Dates For Oscars, Guilds, Grammys, Tonys & More

Yet another international distribution maven said: â€œWindowing has always been a hot button in the industry, but windowing is not a bad thing. â€¦ Part of the issue is that the intense competition has increased the price of content. So how do you maximize the gross? And when we talk about windows, what we donâ€™t do adequately is talk about what the consumer wants. â€¦ We have to make those decisions in a way thatâ€™s smart.â€

One person, however, took issue with exhibition already accepting Netflix movies on a condensed run. â€œI donâ€™t understand why a lot of these exhibitors around the world are playing Netflix content on these short windows. Windows are important to protect the theatrical experience, and they need to think about the long-term health of the business. I donâ€™t think you can have it both ways.â€

Problem Areas

Asia remains a concern for the studios, with some markets losing per-capita moviegoing and Korea notably suffering amid lots of in-home competition from local series. In 2024, four of the Top 5 films in the market were local, while in 2025, only one was Korean.

Elsewhere in Asia, local product tends to be working better â€” think Indonesia and its horror titles. For Hollywood, however, weâ€™re told that some markets are still off more than 50% from 2019. Said an international distribution exec: â€œWe had a region that was in consistent growth for years, and then as soon as we came out of the pandemic, it went backwards fairly quickly. â€¦ Local-market audience tastes have changed. Theyâ€™ve leaned into local filmmaking, which makes sense as those are relatable local stories.â€

RELATED: Horror Moviesâ€™ Next Wave: Whatâ€™s Coming In 2026, From Auteur Nightmares To Indie Breakouts

The studios and local exhibition are working together to try and reverse this downward trend as everyone is striving toward a healthier overall market.

Final Thoughts

Some folks wonder about continuing to leverage popular IP in a surprising way. Itâ€™s key to deliver content that is relevant but also to take swings. When it comes to international, it can be a challenge to have product that resonates across a multitude of markets. Choice and more volume also are necessary, as are the collaboration between studios and exhibitors and spreading out the calendar.

As noted above, audiences still come out for the big blockbusters, but there were some disappointments, particularly for superhero films. 2025 was the first year since 2020 that the Top 10 worldwide chart did not include a Marvel title. WB/DCâ€™s Superman did rank No. 10 but skewed heavily domestic. Upcoming this year, thereâ€™s plenty of reason to hope Spider-Man: Brand New Day and Avengers: Doomsday will perform strongly around the world.

Although itâ€™s expensive and logistically challenging, we saw more talent travel internationally in 2025, and that can pay dividends as it brings the audience in on the experience and drives awareness and want-to-see.

An annual refrain in the post-pandemic years has been that the industry could do a better job of spreading some of the wealth across 12 months so there are no significant fallow periods.

RELATED: 35 Of The Most Anticipated Movies Of 2026

While thereâ€™s a lot of content in summer, 2026â€™s Q1 does look better leveled out including Sonyâ€™s 28 Years Later: The Bone Temple and Amazon MGMâ€™s Mercy in January; WBâ€™s Wuthering Heights,Sonyâ€™s GOAT and Paramountâ€™s Scream 7 in February; then Amazon MGMâ€™s Ryan Gosling starrer Project Hail Mary and Disneyâ€™s Hoppers in March.

The rest of the year is well-stacked.

Look for Universal/Illuminationâ€™s The Super Mario Galaxy Movie and Lionsgateâ€™s Michael (which Universal has internationally) to light up April; followed by Disneyâ€™s The Devil Wears Prada 2 and Star Wars: The Mandalorian and Grogu in May. The next month marks the return of Steven Spielberg with Disclosure Day from Uni, then Dis/Pixarâ€™s Toy Story 5 and WB/DCâ€™s Supergirl. July trots out Uni/Illuminationâ€™s Minions 3, then Disâ€™ live-action Moana and Christopher Nolanâ€™s The Odyssey from Uni â€” and at the end of the month, Spidey swings in with Brand New Day from Sony/Marvel. August gets Parâ€™s PAW Patrol: The Dino Movie and Blumhouse/Sonyâ€™s Insidious: The Bleeding World. September brings a new Resident Evil from Sony and WBâ€™s Practical Magic 2. In October, Tom Cruise no doubt will be out in support of Alejandro GonzÃ¡lez IÃ±Ã¡rrituâ€™s Digger from WB. November rhymes in with WBâ€™s The Cat in the Hat, then Lionsgateâ€™s The Hunger Games: Sunrise on the Reaping and Parâ€™s Focker-In-Law. The year closes out with Sonyâ€™s Jumanji 3, WB/Legendaryâ€™s Dune: Part Three and Disney/Marvelâ€™s Avengers: Doomsday in December.

And thatâ€™s just the major titles â€” thereâ€™s a lot to look forward to from Hollywood in 26. Happy new year, indeed!

title: How â€˜Hamnet,â€™ â€˜If I Had Legs Iâ€™d Kick Youâ€™ and More Films Explore Modern Anxieties Around Parenthood and Raising Kids
summary: What does it mean to bring a child into todayâ€™s world? Based on some of this yearâ€™s buzziest films, that question is on the minds of contemporary directors and writers. From the postpartum loneliness and depression that many mothers face depicted in Lynne Ramsayâ€™s â€œDie My Love,â€ the multi-generational fight for meaningful change in Paul […]
content:
What does it mean to bring a child into todayâ€™s world? Based on some of this yearâ€™s buzziest films, that question is on the minds of contemporary directors and writers.

From the postpartum loneliness and depression that many mothers face depicted in Lynne Ramsayâ€™s â€œDie My Love,â€ the multi-generational fight for meaningful change in Paul Thomas Andersonâ€™s â€œOne Battle After Anotherâ€ to the never-ending economic stresses placed on family in Park Chan-wookâ€™s â€œNo Other Choice,â€ many of this yearâ€™s films take an unflinching look at the anxiety parents â€” and, in turn, their children â€” face in todayâ€™s increasingly politically volatile world.

In appreciating the links between these different stories, â€œTrain Dreamsâ€ director and co-writer Clint Bentley says: â€œThe world, for most of us, feels like itâ€™s turning on its axis a bit. Whether we live in Des Moines or Dubai, we feel like the world is changing in a way we canâ€™t quite understand, and that there might be a kind of end-of-the-world feeling even as weâ€™re all going on. Part of that is through, â€˜What do I give to the next generation? How do I take care of my kids and give them something when everything seems like itâ€™s fucked up, and that we all kind of fucked it up?â€™â€

Popular on Variety

In tackling grief, Oscar winner ChloÃ© Zhaoâ€™s (â€œNomadlandâ€) period piece â€œHamnetâ€ explores how the death of William Shakespeare (Paul Mescal) and Agnes Shakespeareâ€™s (Jessie Buckley) son led to the creation of the much-studied play â€œHamlet.â€ When author and co-writer Maggie Oâ€™Farrell, herself a student of English literature, read large Shakespeare biographies, she found herself â€œreally angeredâ€ at scholars who claimed it was â€œimpossibleâ€ to know whether the revered playwright grieved or not.

â€œI threw the book across the room because you just think, â€˜What are you talking about? Of course he grieved.â€™ And even if child mortality was high in the 16th century, which of course it was, it doesnâ€™t make it any less devastating when your child dies,â€ Oâ€™Farrell says. â€œI refuse to believe that anywhere in the world at any point in time, itâ€™s anything less than catastrophic to lose a child. In a way, I wanted to put Hamnet center stage and say to people, â€˜We owe this child so much.â€™â€

Beyond some of the filmâ€™s brutally devastating scenes, which feature Agnes fighting to cure her children of the plague, Zhao and Oâ€™Farrell tap into how art can serve as a transcendent, cathartic force, as Shakespeareâ€™s writing ensures Hamnet isnâ€™t forgotten. Oâ€™Farrell says: â€œThatâ€™s why the line â€˜Remember me,â€™ which the book ends with, has always been very important because I just wonder if thatâ€™s why Shakespeare wrote it. But obviously, Agnes and him had no idea for how many hundreds of years Hamnet would [actually] be remembered.â€

â€œTrain Dreams,â€ which follows the life of an ordinary man (Joel Edgerton) in the early 20th century across the Pacific Northwest, serves as a great companion piece to â€œHamnetâ€ for its meditative exploration of grief. However, Bentley also wrestles with â€œthe real tragedyâ€ of parents having to spend long periods of time away for work: â€œYouâ€™re always kind of catching up and just when it feels youâ€™re getting used to being back home, youâ€™re leaving again. A lot of people experience that whether youâ€™re a filmmaker, truck driver or somebody needing to leave their country.â€

Some directors, including Cherien Dabis, found the process of making their films cathartic and inspirational in their own right. For Dabis, writing, directing and acting in â€œAll Thatâ€™s Left of You,â€ a decades-spanning personal tale of a Palestinian familyâ€™s fight for survival, became a way to understand her own intergenerational trauma.

â€œI definitely wanted to draw attention to the struggles of families under occupation, but especially parents who donâ€™t really have the ability to protect their kids anymore,â€ Dabis says. â€œOften, what we see in Palestine is kids who, at some point, realize, â€˜Well, my parents canâ€™t protect me, so what use are they?â€™ Itâ€™s like parents lose all authority. I think thatâ€™s a problem; thatâ€™s something that we need to take a look at.â€

The film, which is Jordanâ€™s Oscar entry for Best International Feature, also deals with the loss of childhood innocence, as the young child Noor watches his father being stripped naked by Israeli soldiers. The father-son relationship quickly deteriorates in the years following the humiliation, and the scene was inspired by Dabisâ€™ own experience â€” her first memory of traveling to Palestine.

â€œMy family was held at the border between Jordan and the West Bank for 12 hours; my parents were interrogated multiple times. The soldiers searched through all the contents of our suitcases and then ordered all of us to be strip searched, including myself and my baby sisters, who were age three and one,â€ Dabis recalls. â€œIt was one of the first moments in my life where I really understood, viscerally, what it meant to be Palestinian.â€

In varying ways, political pressures around the world have found their way into these films. Bentley, himself a father, explains how parents have to reckon with not just what it means to bring a child into the world, but how to prepare them for its realities: â€œ[For example], how do I prepare them for the fact that itâ€™s going to be hard to find a job with AI taking everything over? What do you do? The powerlessness of a parent really feeds into that.â€

As many of these directors have traveled around the world with their films â€” both â€œTrain Dreamsâ€ and â€œAll Thatâ€™s Left of Youâ€ started their campaigns at Sundance, and â€œHamnetâ€ bowed in Telluride and Toronto â€” theyâ€™ve realized how universal these stories can be in their specificity.

â€œIâ€™m always so excited when it feels like thereâ€™s something in the zeitgeist and filmmakers are capturing it. Theyâ€™ve come together and made films at a similar moment in time, therefore creating a cultural dialogue â€” itâ€™s almost proof that weâ€™re all connected somehow,â€ Dabis says. â€œEven prior to this year, there have been trends toward really talking honestly and openly about motherhood in a way that empowers women.â€

To unpack the unspoken pressures of motherhood, Mary Bronsteinâ€™s anxiety-including â€œIf I Had Legs Iâ€™d Kick Youâ€ situates the viewer in the subjective experience of one motherâ€™s (Rose Byrne) life as she struggles to care for her child suffering from a mysterious illness. Whatâ€™s inventive about the craft, here, is Bronstein choosing to have the childâ€™s face be off-screen for most of the runtime, allowing the sound design to put viewers on edge.

â€œI couldnâ€™t think of another film that really reflected the feelings and experience I was having that got into the existential confusion of identity,â€ Bronstein says. â€œMy film can be abstracted out to the feeling of disappearing into a care-taking role and how to hold onto your identity. Can you be an individual and a mother at the same time?â€

While Bronstein has received positive feedback from mothers feeling seen for the first time watching the film, especially in todayâ€™s climate with rights for women being taken away, what has pleasantly surprised her is hearing from young people who are finally understanding what their mother went through in raising them.

â€œIt can feel like a betrayal to the love of your child, and what Iâ€™m expressing in the movie is that itâ€™s not. We should be able to talk about these difficult things and the loss of identity that women feel, and the scary parts of being in charge of another living human,â€ she says. â€œFor women, thereâ€™s a freedom in seeing somebody finally express that to you.â€

title: Chevy Chase Says His Mom Physically Abused Him: She Woke Him Up â€˜Slappingâ€™ Him and Locked Him in a Cellar
summary: In a revealing new documentary about his life and career, Chevy Chase alleges that he suffered physical abuse as a child at the hands of his mother and stepfather. In “I’m Chevy Chase and You’re Not,” which debuted Jan. 1 on CNN, Chase and his family and friends said he was beaten, locked in a […]
content:
In a revealing new documentary about his life and career, Chevy Chase alleges that he suffered physical abuse as a child at the hands of his mother and stepfather.

In â€œIâ€™m Chevy Chase and Youâ€™re Not,â€ which debuted Jan. 1 on CNN, Chase and his family and friends said he was beaten, locked in a closet and continually woken up with violence.

Chaseâ€™s parents divorced when he was about 4 years old, and both of them quickly remarried. He described his stepfather, John Cederquist, as â€œhumorless.â€ Chaseâ€™s half-brother, also named John Cederquist, said, â€œMy father had a flash anger, and he could lash out with a single blowâ€¦He did not take to anything that he perceived as insolence. Chevy was insolent.â€

Chaseâ€™s wife, Jayni, said the first time she stayed overnight with Chase and woke him up, he â€œshuddered.â€ â€œHe explained, â€˜Well, my mother would wake me up slapping me.â€™ From the time he was a little guy, wham!â€ she said.

Popular on Variety

Chaseâ€™s mother, Cathalene Browning, is described in the documentary as â€œa bag of cats, certainly on the schizoid spectrum.â€

â€œThis was an out-of-control woman who I look back on and I say I feel sorry for her,â€ Chase said. â€œShe had her own issues â€” bad ones. But, she was physically abusive to me.â€

Peter Aaron, a friend of the comedianâ€™s, said Chase told him stories about the â€œterrible things that would happen to him as a young man â€” things like being locked in the closet.â€ Chaseâ€™s brother, Ned, added, â€œThere was a cellar, and he was sent down there because of really messing up in school.â€

In an interview with The New York Times published Friday, Chase alluded to being â€œslapped with a yardstick on your bare ass and on the backs of your legs until theyâ€™re so bruised that somebody else notices.â€

Chase would get punished for receiving poor grades in school, but, ironically, he said he was failing academically because of the abuse. â€œWhereas others would concentrate on their homework, I didnâ€™t have a chance at that,â€ he said. â€œI was always worried about one thing or another that had to do with my own health.â€

Chase detailed one incident in which he and Ned were eating breakfast, and their stepfather came downstairs â€œand started slapping me across the back of the head.â€ Ned recalled, â€œI stood up and made it clear I didnâ€™t think this was a time for corporal punishment. And John Cederquist sat down, and I sat down.â€

â€œI knew at that time that Ned was there for me,â€ Chase said. â€œThat was a big moment for us.â€

When asked by director Marina Zenovich if there was a time when Chase walked away from his mother and stepfather and never saw them again, Chase pretended to swat a fly on his forehead, then licked his fingers as if eating the imaginary bug. â€œSorry?â€ he asked, half-smiling.

Chaseâ€™s family and friends described how his trauma informed his comedy â€” a â€œcoping mechanismâ€ â€” and how it may have contributed to his struggles with depression in his later life. â€œIt shaped him. He used comedy, he used humor as a way to mask what was going on inside. And thatâ€™s continued. It continues to this day,â€ said Emily Chase, his youngest daughter. â€œHe will joke around from morning until night, and you wonâ€™t know whatâ€™s going on. â€¦ Thatâ€™s how he always dealt with problems in his life.â€

â€œIâ€™m Chevy Chase and Youâ€™re Notâ€ is now available to watch on CNNâ€™s streaming platforms.

title: How Awards Season Contenders Dare to Get Real About the Struggles of Motherhood
summary: Parenting doesnâ€™t come with a user manual and thereâ€™s never going to be a perfect solution to every situation. But this award season is full of films with mothers who make decisions and sacrifices that will be debated well beyond WhatsApp chats, school drop offs and personal therapy sessions. Is the decision that Teyana Taylorâ€™s […]
content:
Parenting doesnâ€™t come with a user manual and thereâ€™s never going to be a perfect solution to every situation. But this award season is full of films with mothers who make decisions and sacrifices that will be debated well beyond WhatsApp chats, school drop offs and personal therapy sessions.

Is the decision that Teyana Taylorâ€™s â€œOne Battle After Anotherâ€ revolutionary activist Perfidia Beverly Hills makes to go on the lam and abandon her young child an act of selfishness and self-preservation? Or is it a means of saving her daughter from the dangers of growing up with her, someone who regrets becoming a parent? Is it right for â€œSinnersâ€™â€ Grace (Li Jun Li) to sacrifice the last surviving humans at a juke joint to a swarm of vampires if it means she may be able to save the child she has back at home? Is Rose Byrneâ€™s Linda in â€œIf I Had Legs Iâ€™d Kick Youâ€ acting on the best interest of her daughterâ€™s medical care? Or is she burned out and drowning in the exhaustiveness of feeding tubes, doctorâ€™s appointments and everything else life throws at her?

Mary Bronstein, who wrote and directed â€œLegsâ€ based on her own experiences (and who appears in the film as a doctor unsympathetic to Lindaâ€™s plight), says that â€œthereâ€™s a fantasy fulfillmentâ€ to her film; that she couldnâ€™t speak out in parenting support sessions or leave her child at a hotel unsupervisedâ€¦ but Linda can.

Popular on Variety

â€œWhen you have a child with special needs, or when youâ€™re in a crisis situation with your child, everybody is placating you and trying to make you feel better by saying, â€˜Itâ€™s not your fault,â€™â€ she says.

She describes these feelings as both confusing and guilt-inducing because â€œyouâ€™re also positioned as the main person thatâ€™s in charge of helping your child.â€

Told from Lindaâ€™s point of view, â€œLegsâ€ shows a caretaker unraveling. The disorder the characterâ€™s daughter has is deliberately never named. Bronstein says that choice was made because, if it was named, then it becomes a movie â€œabout a specific illness that a mother is trying to fix or find a cure for.â€ The daughterâ€™s face is also hidden for most of the movie, and much screentime is fixated on Linda, with her increasingly greasy hair and dark shadows under her eyes. Bronstein also added the sly twist that Linda is a therapist, meaning her entire world is supposed to be about caring for other people.

â€œA big part of this movie centers on the trauma that Linda is experiencing, that Linda holds within her body,â€ Bronstein says. â€œThe trauma of different things that have happened with the daughter, those are things that she has hidden away in the back of her mind. And one very major one reveals itself to her and slaps her in the face.â€

Bronstein says that â€œwith trauma, I believe that you do hold it in your body somewhere and, if you donâ€™t deal with it, itâ€™s going to get you at some point. And you canâ€™t run away from it, because itâ€™s not external; itâ€™s internal.â€

Whatever audiences might think of Linda and her decisions, the concept of parental trauma is also seen on film this year in mothers who adhere closer to the textbook definition of â€œgoodâ€ parents. Jessie Buckleyâ€™s Agnes in â€œHamnetâ€ is angry at herself as much as she is guilt-ridden that she couldnâ€™t save one child because she was so fixated on protecting another. Kate Hudsonâ€™s wounded musician Claire in â€œSong Sung Blueâ€ can only see to help her daughter Rachel (Ella Anderson) after she puts on her own oxygen mask and gets sober. â€œKPop Demon Huntersâ€™â€ Celine (Yunjin Kim) teaches her adoptive daughter to feel shame and hide her true self rather than discuss her otherness.

In director Eric Lin and screenwriter Marilyn Fuâ€™s â€œRosemead,â€ which is based on a true story covered in a 2017 Los Angeles Times piece, Lucy Liuâ€™s Irene must weigh how her own terminal cancer diagnosis will impact her teenage son Joeâ€™s (Lawrence Shou) newly diagnosed schizophrenia. Coping with all of this, as well as the recent loss of her husband to cancer and cultural stigmas toward therapy, Western medicine and mental disorders, Irene uses stoicism to hide her own fears. She both supports her son by joining him in his therapy sessions, even if they make her uncomfortable, and attempts to protect him from ostracization within the community by lying about why heâ€™s there when heâ€™s seen going into these sessions.

â€œI think thereâ€™s a shame behind it [and] I donâ€™t think itâ€™s just solely the Asian community,â€ she says of reaction to Joeâ€™s diagnosis and treatment. â€œItâ€™s a stigma that everyone holds that therapy is for someone who really has a problem, and nobody wants to be known as somebody who has a problem or an issue.â€

The reality, she continues, â€œis that we all have to process something that happens to us, whether itâ€™s severe or not.â€

In fact, the movie centers so much on Ireneâ€™s dedication and concern for her son that itâ€™s easy to forget just how sick she is until her doctor gives her the final diagnosis.

Liu thinks Ireneâ€™s grief over the loss of her husband plus â€œthe secrecy and the hiding and the stories she made up to try to fit into society, and to also make sure that her son was not sequestered from the community or from other kids â€¦ that struggle already was so difficult on top of the physical illness that she was experiencing.â€

â€œThe corporal body was weak, but her inner willpower and her courage and her love for her son was really strong,â€ Liu says. â€œThat dynamic tension [and] that urgency sort of fills the time on screen. Her personality comes through with the urgency of trying to save her son because sheâ€™s losing her son even though heâ€™s right there in the house.â€

The movie ends with Irene making the only decision she deems possible, a parental act of both love and fear.

â€œItâ€™s definitely going to spark conversation, and it should really create a comfortable, safe place for discussion and reaction because it is such a powerful moment of choice for her,â€ Liu says of the finale. â€œItâ€™s obviously not for everyone, but itâ€™s a haunting reality that that if it werenâ€™t true, nobody would believe it. I think the legacy that she left behind is something to hold up in our community and others to say that things can become like this if you donâ€™t take these simple steps.â€

Liu says that parents are taught to be present and work with their children in their current situations, but they also inevitably â€œfuturize or try to live in another fantasy world.â€ She says she thinks Ireneâ€™s decision is â€œsymbolic of how lonely she was and how isolated she was, and how real it was to her.â€

She doesnâ€™t know if her own family has experiences with mental disorders, saying, â€œI donâ€™t know enough about my history because there has been so much secrecy in our own family.â€ But she says she has seen in society that â€œeveryone wants to solve the puzzle â€” and itâ€™s not a puzzle to be solved. Itâ€™s a puzzle to be lived. And thatâ€™s something that people just donâ€™t want to believe because theyâ€™re not really living it the way that you are.â€

title: CBS Evening News Says â€˜We Love Americaâ€™ Is Now One of Its Guiding Principles
summary: Under the oversight of Bari Weiss, CBS’s newly revamped weeknight news program is waving the American flag — and it’s not apologizing for its pro-U.S. editorial stance. On Friday, the program released a statement outlining “five simple principles” that will inform the show’s presentation of the news under anchor Tony Dokoupil, who was previously a […]
content:
Under the oversight of Bari Weiss, CBSâ€™s newly revamped weeknight news program is waving the American flag â€” and itâ€™s not apologizing for its pro-U.S. editorial stance.

On Friday, the program released a statement outlining â€œfive simple principlesâ€ that will inform the showâ€™s presentation of the news under anchor Tony Dokoupil, who was previously a morning news anchor on CBS. According to CBS News, what had formerly been a â€œ38-page handbookâ€ is now â€œ5 simple values.â€

Dokoupil was appointed to the anchor chair of â€œCBS Evening Newsâ€ last month by Weiss, the editor in chief of CBS News and founder of The Free Press, which describes itself as â€œa new media company built on the ideals that were once the bedrock of American journalism.â€ Paramount Skydance CEO David Ellison acquired The Free Press in a reported $150 million deal and installed Weiss to oversee CBS Newsâ€™ editorial operations in what he said was an effort to restore viewersâ€™ trust in the outlet.

Popular on Variety

â€œWhen the new â€˜CBS Evening Newsâ€™ kicks off on Monday, we promise to live by these five simple principles â€“ from our very first show on the road, to our first broadcast on the new set in New York, and every one after that,â€ the show said in a series of posts on social media.

One of the principles outlined by â€œCBS Evening Newsâ€ was this: â€œWe love America. And we make no apologies for saying so. Our foundational values of liberty, equality and the rule of law make us the last best hope on Earth.â€ The news show said that â€œWe aim to do our part every night: One way to think about our show is as a daily conversation about exactly where we are as a country and where we are going.â€

On Thursday, Jan. 1, Dokoupil shared his thoughts on the state of journalism in the U.S. ahead of his taking over as â€œCBS Evening Newsâ€ anchor.

â€œPeople do not trust us like they used to,â€ Dokoupil said in a video shared on CBSNews.com. He continued: â€œOn too many stories, the press has missed the story. And itâ€™s not just us. Itâ€™s all of legacy media. Because weâ€™ve taken into account the perspective of advocates, and not the average American. Or, we put too much weight in the analysis of academics, or elites, and not enough on you.â€

Here are the â€œfive simple principlesâ€ that â€œCBS Evening Newsâ€ says it will be guided by with Dokoupil as the anchor:

We work for you. That means you come first. Not our advertisers. Not politicians. Not corporate interests, including the corporate owners of CBS News. We report on the world as it is. Weâ€™ll be honest and direct with you. That means no weasel words or padded landings. Weâ€™ll tell you what we know, when we know it. Well update our reporting when we uncover new facts. And weâ€™ll admit when we get it wrong. We respect you. We believe that our fellow Americans are smart and discerning. Itâ€™s our job to present you with the fullest picture â€” and the strongest voices on all sides of an issue. We trust you to make up your own minds, and to make the decisions that are best for you, your families and your communities. We love America. And we make no apologies for saying so. Our foundational values of liberty, equality and the rule of law make us the last best hope on Earth. We also believe in Franklinâ€™s famous line about America as a republic â€” if we can keep it. We aim to do our part every night: One way to think about our show is as a daily conversation about exactly where we are as a country and where we are going. We respect tradition, but we also believe in the future. We embrace the tools that allow us to reach you where you are. Some of you will watch this show on linear television. Others will increasingly watch it on social media. What we can guarantee is that the tools will continue to change â€” but some things never will. One of those things is honest journalism.

â€œCBS Evening Newsâ€ with Tony Dokoupil premieres Monday, Jan. 5, at 6:30 p.m. ET.

title: â€˜Stranger Thingsâ€™ and Prince: The Complicated Road to Bringing â€˜When Doves Cryâ€™ and â€˜Purple Rainâ€™ to the Showâ€™s Finale
summary: Securing the rights to use a song in film or TV is a challenging and expensive task â€” and the more iconic the song, the more challenging and expensive the clearance is likely to be. So when two of Princeâ€™s most legendary songs, â€œWhen Doves Cryâ€ and â€œPurple Rain,â€ appeared in the finale of â€œStranger […]
content:
Securing the rights to use a song in film or TV is a challenging and expensive task â€” and the more iconic the song, the more challenging and expensive the clearance is likely to be.

So when two of Princeâ€™s most legendary songs, â€œWhen Doves Cryâ€ and â€œPurple Rain,â€ appeared in the finale of â€œStranger Things,â€ it was obvious that therein lay a tale. And the tale is even more complicated than virtually anyone would have thought.

Why? Not only because of the challenges in clearing the songs with the Prince estate â€” but because of the showâ€™s plot: The two songs required for that segment of the show had to be the first and last songs on one side of a single vinyl album, which, to use a reference from the show, is like a Rubikâ€™s Cube for the music supervisor, and much more challenging than selecting Kate Bushâ€™s â€œRunning Up That Hill,â€ Metallicaâ€™s â€œMaster of Puppetsâ€ or any of the showâ€™s many other iconic music moments.

Popular on Variety

The hard work paid off: Since the episode debuted on New Yearâ€™s Eve, â€œPurple Rainâ€ has seen a 243 percent increase in Spotify global streams and a 577 percent surge in global Gen-Z streams specifically, Variety can exclusively reveal. â€œWhen Doves Cryâ€ also saw a 200 percent boost in global streams, as well as a 128 percent increase in Gen Z streams.

And as youâ€™ll see below, Nora Felder, president of Picture Music Company and a veteran music supervisor who has been on board for the entirety of â€œStranger Things,â€ was more than up to the task â€” which doesnâ€™t mean it was easy! Variety caught up with Felder on Friday afternoon to find out how she got it done â€¦

Did you do anything special for the finale?

Yes, I saw it in a theater with my family â€” Iâ€™ve never seen â€œStranger Thingsâ€ like that, with an audience. It was the first time I was able to really experience how theyâ€™re so emotionally attached to the characters â€” they were cheering and shrieking, some of them were crying. I canâ€™t think of another way I would rather have seen it.

I think the music in the show does so well because it stems from the fans being so attached to the characters and the stories, and the music extends their journeys, so they naturally become attached to it as well.

Music plays a bigger role in â€œStranger Thingsâ€ than a lot of similar episodic shows or films. Was that intentional from the jump?

I think the intention was just to find songs to push the narrative of the story, and rolling up our sleeves and keying in on â€œWhat is the right song for this character?â€ and â€œWhat is the right song for each moment? Should this be score or a song?â€ I canâ€™t speak on behalf of the Duffers, but I donâ€™t think there was an overall sense of â€œWeâ€™re going to create something thatâ€™s going to make music such a main character that itâ€™s going to blow up all over their world!â€ No, they just wanted songs that accented their characters, pushed the narrative, and showed the attachment of music to the characters â€” and how music can sometimes save you.

Did we know the Clash was going to have a moment? Or Kate Bush or Metallica, or possibly whatâ€™s going on now? No, itâ€™s always been about what is the most effective choice to either move this narrative or represent the true essence of this character. And I think that because we always constantly stayed true to that, the show became what it was.

Those two Prince songs were a surprise, and Iâ€™m sure it was a challenge clearing them. Why those songs? And how do you think they spoke to those moments in the show?

Iâ€™m glad you say â€œdo you thinkâ€ because songs can be interpreted in so many different ways. But they came about in a similar way to Kate Bush and â€œRunning Up That Hillâ€: They were not scripted. They were â€œTBDâ€ moments in the two spots in the script where a song needed to play: [SPOILER ALERT] for the scene when Hopper and Murray set off the bomb detonation to collapse the Upside Down gate, which was set off from the record player. So it needed to be the first song from one side of a [vinyl album], and then it needed to segue to the last song on that same side of the [same album], to play through Elevenâ€™s emotional stand against that leads into the collapsing dimension of the Upside Down. So they needed to hit those two spots.

The Duffers reached out to me about this before the scene was shot â€” I didnâ€™t even have a shooting schedule, I think they had just written the script and only the cast had seen it. Theyâ€™d been going through songs, I think they were asking for ideas from the cast. And they said, â€œThis one is a little more tricky because of the way the scenes are going to be set up: We need something preferably from 1987 â€” but it could be from before â€” the songs have to be from the same artist; and the first song has to start the A or B-side of an album by that artist, and the second song has to end the A or B side of that album.

That is an incredibly narrow window!

Exactly! So my heart stopped, like, ooh, thatâ€™s a tough one. And remember, the sceneâ€™s not shot yet, so I havenâ€™t seen the footage and this is just me imagining it in my head â€” and itâ€™s got to play through this big, emotional, sad scene thatâ€™ll lead into a dimension collapsing! Iâ€™ve been doing this for 20 years, but thereâ€™s still always a first.

Obviously I have various ways of finding music: Sometimes songs just pop into my head â€” and I know the â€˜80s quite well â€” sometimes itâ€™s just e-surfing, Spotify or streaming this or that; sometimes itâ€™s just driving in a car and somebody drives by with a song playing; and I also have 15,000 or 20,000 CDs and albums. But for this one, I needed to go to my research books. I found a couple that listed the albums [by side], and I literally had to go and flip through the book for ideas and then see if the first and last tracks on a side could line up to our needs. And in a lot of cases, they just didnâ€™t. I mean, I stayed up all night, and I think I came up with just two ideas.

Just to step away from Prince for a second, in these situations, I like to give the Duffers a lot of different flavors to choose from to find what works best. Like in the scene where [SPOILER ALERT] Karen is fighting the monster to save Holly, I tried all kinds of songs, from Frank Sinatra to you name it, and they fell in love with the ABBA song, â€œFernando,â€ which was actually the first song I sent them.

So what was the other album you sent them, along with Princeâ€™s â€œPurple Rainâ€?

Part of me doesnâ€™t want to say what it is, because I donâ€™t want people to feel bad. But I did send a classic artist from the â€˜70s, big artists, and I said, â€œWe could end it with this, but Iâ€™m not sure about the starting song â€” and honestly, I donâ€™t even know if those guys will clear it, and itâ€™s going to cost megabucks.â€

Or, I said, â€œWe could end it with â€˜Purple Rainâ€™ and start with â€˜When Doves Cryâ€™ â€” but honestly, I donâ€™t even know if I can clear it.â€ I mean, I had not heard of [â€œPurple Rainâ€] clearing before, although I know now that it did clear for something right after Prince died [in 2016] â€” there was a relationship with someone who did a [â€œBlack-ishâ€] series episode about a character mourning Princeâ€™s death, but that was a one-off situation.

So the Duffers wrote back to me and said, â€œDo you think we could get this cleared?â€ And Iâ€™m like gulp, â€œIâ€™m really not sure, but Iâ€™d be willing to try.â€ And they said, letâ€™s try. Double gulp! Because this means they really want it â€” they werenâ€™t having me clear anything else.

The good news is, I majored in English in college, and that helped with creating what I call â€œthesesâ€: where you give the rights owners all the information of how the songâ€™s going to be used, and the backstory of it, the meaning of it â€” Jennifer Barron, my clearance coordinator, and I went deep on this one. So we spoke to Marty Silverstone at Primary Wave. He goes, â€œWell, we all know itâ€™s a tough one, but letâ€™s try.â€ I said, â€œIf thereâ€™s anything that they might clear it for, it would be â€˜Stranger Things,â€™ right?â€ He goes, â€œLetâ€™s hope!,â€ because the estate has so many approvals.

Then I talked to Joy Murphy at Universal Music Publishing [which administers the songsâ€™ publishing], and she said the same thing â€” â€œNora, letâ€™s give it a try, weâ€™ll do everything we can to position this in the right way.â€ So that was two. Then I had Thuy Lam at Warner Records â€” which controls the master [recording] â€” who Iâ€™d been down this road before with Kate Bush, and she said, â€œWe support this.â€ And then we waited â€” that was grueling, and it took a few weeks â€” we were getting closer to shooting and so the Duffers made a plan to shoot the scenes in a way where the song could be added later. But shortly after that, I got the answer that [the Prince tracks were approved.]

Now, I know the Duffers feel that Princeâ€™s estate cleared the songs because of Kate Bush, and Iâ€™m sure that had something to do with it, as the parties reminded them of the impact the show had with â€œRunning Up That Hill.â€ And I did tell them I thought this was going to be one of the most significant moments in the season, although no one has a crystall ball. But still, for the rights owners, itâ€™s not just about the money, itâ€™s about what lines up with what Prince would have wanted, and to do it in the most respectful manner possible. And I donâ€™t want to discount all the hard work we put into the â€œtheses,â€ making sure everyone fully understood these uses and what they meant to the characters.

For â€œRunning Up That Hill,â€ though, there were hundreds of other songs that could have worked, you didnâ€™t need songs that began and ended an album side.

Yeah, for [the Kate Bush slot], I had 9 or 10 other songs in my pocket â€” but I said, â€œThis is the best one. This does everything we want it to do.â€ I donâ€™t think it could have been [as good with] anything else â€” because the lyrical content lined up so perfectly with what the characters were going through and needed to do. You know, they needed to step outside of their own world and step into someone elseâ€™s shoes to truly understand and reconnect. Iâ€™m not saying we couldnâ€™t have gotten something else, but I donâ€™t know if it would have lined up as perfectly, not only with the melodic structure in the building, but also with the intricate message that seemed to speak on a deeper level and relate to our characters.

Also, those two Prince songs are so heavily associated with the â€œPurple Rainâ€ film and the emotions and visuals that go with it â€” was that a concern?

No, not for me, and the Duffers never mentioned that. Weâ€™ve never been against using songs that have been tied to other stories because this is a completely different, unique story. And again, going back to the special relationship that the fans have with this show, once you attach it to their characters and this story, itâ€™s almost as if it takes on a different meaning. And remember, a lot of the young people are not going to have that association. Even the older people that knew and grew up with these songs, theyâ€™re listening to it in a different way.

They kind of line up in that way as well, because â€œPurple Rainâ€ is obviously the climax of that film, and here itâ€™s part of the climax.

Yeah, when things are beginning to be resolved and [SPOILER ALERT] Eleven has made her decision that she needs to cease existing in order to save them. And â€œWhen Doves Cryâ€ â€” doves have always represented love and peace, right? And in this case, theyâ€™re crying because theyâ€™re sorrowful â€” if we want to get heavy here, and pretend we just smoked some pot together (laughter).

But from what Iâ€™ve always understood, the song is about the conflicts that exist within relationships, right? So to me, it was interesting to put the song in that spot, because theyâ€™re feeling hopeful, but things arenâ€™t resolved â€” their mission is not done; thereâ€™s still people in danger; the world is not one. So even though the song has a kind of a lightness to it, I think thatâ€™s why it worked well. And â€œPurple Rainâ€ has always symbolized the chaotic, sad world that we live in, but itâ€™s also ultimately about redemption, love, and transformation.

[Marty Silverstone, President of Global Sync at Primary Wave Music, tells Variety: â€œWeâ€™re thrilled that we could play a part in bringing these very special uses to life and have Princeâ€™s music included in the phenomenon that is â€˜Stranger Things.â€™ You have to admire the unique connection the show has with its fanbase, its brilliant music curation over its entire run, and its spotlight on the cosmic importance of music in the lives of young people, and all people!â€]

OK, can I guess the other one you considered? Led Zeppelin? The Eagles?

No, it wasnâ€™t the Eagles. And Iâ€™m not going to say Led Zeppelin didnâ€™t come up â€” I tried Led Zeppelin, but it didnâ€™t work because I was thinking â€œStairway to Heavenâ€ and it wasnâ€™t a first [song on album side] and a last situation. And I thought maybe Pink Floyd with â€œThe Wall,â€ but I canâ€™t remember if the right song was an ending or not. I donâ€™t know how many times I went through this: One song would work and the other one wouldnâ€™t. I mean, thatâ€™s why I stayed up all night with my books!

Are you having separation anxiety now that the show is over?

Iâ€™m sad, but Iâ€™m about to go into â€œYellowjacketsâ€ right now, literally on Monday. And I love that show. And Iâ€™m working on the Duffer Brothersâ€™ other project that theyâ€™re executive-producing, â€œThe Boroughs,â€ thatâ€™s coming out this year. And then weâ€™ll see about after that! I really want to take some time and find something really special to work on.
