title: â€˜Top Gun: Maverickâ€™ Copyright Suit Gets Its Wings Clipped By Appeals Court In Win For Paramount
summary: Tom Cruise and Paramount are cleared for takeoff on more Top Gun thanks to a trio of federal judges. Three and a half years after the now David Ellison-owned studio was first buzzsawed by a Top Gun: Maverick copyright infringement from the estate of the journalist who penned the piece the original flyboy flick was […]
content:
Tom Cruise and Paramount are cleared for takeoff on more Top Gun thanks to a trio of federal judges.

Three and a half years after the now David Ellison-owned studio was first buzzsawed by a Top Gun: Maverick copyright infringement from the estate of the journalist who penned the piece the original flyboy flick was based on, an appeals court has shut the whole thing down â€” at least for now.

â€œThe question under the extrinsic test is whether the expression in Maverick is substantially similar

to the original expression in â€œTop Guns,â€ and it is not,â€ writes Judge Eric D. Miller of the US Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.

Reconfirming the April 2024 decision of U.S. District Judge Percy Anderson, the unreserved January 2 opinion ruled against the widow and son of Ehud Yonay, who penned â€œTop Gunsâ€ from the now-defunct California magazineâ€™s May 1983 edition. Having sold his work to producers back in the day, Yonay, who died in 2012, was credited in the Reagan Era Top Gun. Common in the Ninth Circuit, the extrinsic test looks at comparison, context and, in a case like this, specific plot elements.

Watch on Deadline

â€œThe panel affirmed the district courtâ€™s conclusion that Maverick did not share substantial

amounts of the original expression of â€œTop Guns,â€ and plaintiffs therefore failed to establish a triable issue as to substantial similarity, as required to establish copyright infringement, Judge Miller also stated, writing for a trio that heard the appeal last year. â€œThe panel concluded that there was a lack of similarity in protectable elements of the article, and plaintiffs did not establish an original and protectable selection and arrangement of elements.â€

The aforementioned panel of three judges included Trump appointee Miller, as well as Andrew D. Hurwitz, and Jennifer Sung. With the likes of thorn-in-many-a-studio-paw Marc Taboroff and studio go to lawyer Daniel Petrocelli arguing for their respective clients, the trio of Pasadena-based judges heard arguments back in early June.

Additionally, Judge Miller noted that â€œthe panel held that the district court properly granted summary judgment for Paramount on plaintiffsâ€™ claim that Paramount breached its 1983 agreement with

Ehud Yonay by not crediting him in the 2022 movie.â€

Tom Cruise in Top Gun: Maverick (Photo: Paramount Pictures / Courtesy Everett Collection)

One of a couple of suits that the Joseph Kosinski directed blockbuster has faced since its 2022 release, Shosh Yonay and Yuval Yonayâ€™s breach of contract, declaratory relief, and copyright infringement action claimed â€œTop Gunsâ€ rights reverted to them in January 2020 under copyright statutes. They alleged the $1.5 billion box office hit violated termination rights and Paramount, Cruise and producers like Jerry Bruckheimer and now Par owner David Ellison had no standing to make the sequel to 1986â€™s Top Gun.

While there is still a path for the Yonays to request a to stay the mandate and seek a petition for rehearing, it will be a dog fight. To that, Toberoff did not respond to request from Deadline on the Appellate opinion and his next move, if any.

Sounding a lot like they did in 2024 when Judge Anderson found in their favor, Paramount kept it short and sweet. â€œWe are pleased that the Ninth Circuit recognized that plaintiffsâ€™ claims were completely without merit, a spokesperson for the WBD bidding company said.

As for the next move for Paramount, a Top Gun 3 is getting primed for takeoff.

The Palm Springs International Film Awards gala delivered its annual blend of star wattage and Oscar-season momentum on Jan. 3, with candid speeches, emotional reveals and a last-minute reshuffling prompted by an absent honoree.

One of the nightâ€™s most buzzy moments came from Miley Cyrus, who accepted the Outstanding Artistic Achievement Award for the original song â€œDream as Oneâ€ from James Cameronâ€™s blockbuster â€œAvatar: Fire and Ash.â€ Presented by one of the filmâ€™s star Jack Champion, Cyrus spoke openly about reinvention, and her desire for Oscar recognition.

â€œReinvention is something I continuously strive for in my music,â€ she said, drawing loud applause as she acknowledged her ambitions beyond the recording studio.

Popular on Variety

The evening had an interesting blend of standout moments. One belonged to TimothÃ©e Chalamet, who was a constant presence throughout the ceremony and earned the Spotlight Award for his performance as table tennis phenom Marty Mauser in A24â€™s â€œMarty Supreme.â€ Introduced earlier in the night by host Nischelle Turner, Chalamet later took the stage, after being presented by director and co-writer Josh Safdie, reflecting on the privilege of working at this stage of his career.

â€œEvery day, to wake up in good health and have the opportunity to create things for the world is truly a gift,â€ Chalamet said. His girlfriend, Kylie Jenner, watched from his table, cheering him on.

Also among the nightâ€™s emotional high points was Ethan Hawke, who received the Career Achievement Award, presented by Mahershala Ali and delivered a rousing speech recalling his early friendship with River Phoenix. The eveningâ€™s biggest logistical surprise involved Leonardo DiCaprio, who was slated to receive the Desert Palm Achievement Award for â€œOne Battle After Anotherâ€ but was unable to travel from St. Barts due to air restrictions following an international conflict. â€œMovies are still meant to be experienced together in a theater,â€ DiCaprio said in a pre-recorded message. â€œRight now, that belief matters more than ever.â€

Continuing: â€œOriginal films are harder to make and harder to protect, but movies still matter. Not content â€” but cinema. Stories made by people are meant to be shared in a dark room in a communal experience.â€

Amanda Seyfried, also honored with the Desert Palm Achievement Award, followed DiCaprioâ€™s remarks and credited him with inspiring her own path into acting.

Michael B. Jordan, presented by Colman Domingo for his performance in â€œSinners,â€ and was the first honoree to acknowledge a medical emergency that was taking place in the lobby.

â€œJay Kellyâ€ star Adam Sandler, who received the Chairmanâ€™s Award, delivered the nightâ€™s most entertaining and hilarious speech, joking about how his life would be if he hadnâ€™t made it as an actor: an electrical contractor, like his Dad.

The night closed with Kate Hudson, who received the Icon Award for â€œSong Sung Blue.â€ Introduced by director Rob Marshall, Hudson capped an evening that doubled as both celebration and campaign launchpad.The Palm Springs International Film Festival runs Jan. 2â€“12, showcasing 168 films from 72 countries, including 53 premieres and 44 submissions for the Academy Award for international feature.

The speech closed on a characteristically sincere note, with Sandler thanking his wife â€” â€œmy forever girlâ€ â€” and promising the audience heâ€™s not done yet.

title: CES Ups Its Entertainment Game, As Cannes Market And Netflix Join Disney, Amazon, NBCUniversal & More At Tech Confab
summary: The entertainment community has kept tabs on CES for decades, monitoring the giant Las Vegas tech confab and fitting in semi-regular trips there. The timing, though, coincides with a busy stretch spanning the Palm Springs and Sundance film festivals, the Golden Globes and the ramp-up of Oscar season. This year, organizers at the Consumer Technology […]
content:
The entertainment community has kept tabs on CES for decades, monitoring the giant Las Vegas tech confab and fitting in semi-regular trips there.

The timing, though, coincides with a busy stretch spanning the Palm Springs and Sundance film festivals, the Golden Globes and the ramp-up of Oscar season.

This year, organizers at the Consumer Technology Association have upped the showâ€™s entertainment factor. CES this year is inaugurating a partnership with the Cannes MarchÃ© du Film and will see an expanded presence for Netflix alongside recent regulars like Disney, Amazon and NBCUniversal.

A tumultuous 2025, which was punctuated by Netflixâ€™s $82.7 billion proposal to acquire the studios-and-streaming division of Warner Bros. Discovery, the ultimate collision of tech and Hollywood, proved that being fluent in tech talk isnâ€™t just a laudable goal. For those in traditional media roles, it could be a survival tactic. And survival is the word when weâ€™re talking about a convention that last year hosted 142,465 attendees.

Watch on Deadline

Paramount Skydance, which is pursuing its own hostile bid for WBD, is backed by Oracle, one of the main combatants in the global AI race. The latest AI wares will be exhibited in Las Vegas, as usual, but there could be a more tangible wow factor this year given that heavy spending by major companies is starting to reach fruition. Analyst Dan Ives of Wedbush Securities expects tangible effects of companiesâ€™ massive investments in AI to be on vivid display.

â€œThe vibe of CES this year is around new chip announcements, AI driven products on the consumer ecosystem, and in essence a new era opening up for companies around the world set to capitalize on $3 trillion to $4 trillion of AI Cap Ex hitting the market over the next 3 years,â€ Ives wrote in a recent note to clients. â€œWe also expect a growing China tech presence at the show with robotics and smart vehicles (Xpeng-flying car, etc.) some key highlights on the floor. With AI demand accelerating globally and our recent Asia supply chain checks continuing to show unprecedented demand, we view CES this year as kicking off a new AI consumer age as the masses now start to head down this AI Revolution golden path.â€

Jensen Huang, founder and CEO of Nvidia and a Pied Piper of AI, will deliver his annual keynote on Monday, which is technically the day before the show officially opens. (It wraps up Thursday.)

Huangâ€™s comments are apt to move the market, Ives believes, and Nvidiaâ€™s stock (up more than 1,300% in the past five years) attests to his potency as a prognosticator. Nvidia aside, this yearâ€™s CES will be â€œone of the most important momentsâ€ for AI of late, in Ivesâ€™ view, with recognition now fairly universal that the arrival of AI is a â€œparadigm shift that is still in the early days of playing out.â€

One new initiative that attests to how the paradigm shift is affecting the film community is a new venture announced last May by Cannesâ€™ MarchÃ© du Film and the CTA. They are launching a new innovation award for or companies, startups, entrepreneurs and filmmakers developing transformative tech in filmmaking, production, and distribution.

While the creative community is grappling with the implications of AI, advertising has fully embraced the technology.

Netflixâ€™s larger profile at CES, which will see the company host a â€œspeakeasyâ€ happy hour event for advertisers, tech vendors, media members and others, stems from its push into advertising over the past three-plus years. Traditionally, certain highly successful tech companies like Netflix, Apple and others, have eschewed the trappings of giant booths spanning tens of thousands of square feet, leaving that practice to Sony Corp., Samsung, Panasonic and other gadget makers. But as the WBD deal has shown, Netflix is a nearly 30-year-old leopard that is more than willing to change its spots.

Many upfront conversations take root at CES, a fact that has motivated Disney to host a â€œtech and data showcaseâ€ at the show. Amazon Ads, meanwhile, has a large footprint inside the Aria Resort & Casino, which is home base for a range of stakeholders in the ad business. Fox Corp., WBD, NBCU and other sellers of both linear and streaming ads are leaning into tech, with execs speaking on panels before wining and dining clients at night.

Also inside the Aria, Medialink parent United Talent Agency has a stake in the ground at CES, convening a series of panels about the collision of entertainment and technology under the â€œFuture Decodedâ€ banner.

The march of technology gives a lot of writers, directors and actors in Hollywood reason for concern, especially with the major above-the-line unions set to start contract negotiations with studios and streamers in the coming weeks. SAG-AFTRA, which has prioritized CES in recent years, co-hosting the Labor, Innovation and Technology Summit with other unions during the Las Vegas show, is recalibrating this year. In place of its Las Vegas presence, the union plans to take other opportunities later in the year to get its message out, along with preparing for the contract talks, which are likely to be as thorny as they were in 2023, when both SAG-AFTRA and the Writers Guild of America went on strike.

Elsewhere on the CES docket, FTC Chair Andrew Ferguson and FCC Chair Brendan Carr will conduct â€œfireside chatsâ€ on Thursday morning. Both should be closely tracked given the scrutiny of pending mergers like WBDâ€™s with Netflix or Paramount, as well as Nexstar and Tegna. plus the state of play of a long-discussed breakup of Big Tech titans.

title: Amazon Will Tout New Focus on Helping Advertisers Reach Live Viewers at CES
summary: Amazon thinks it can do more for TV advertisers than traditional TV. The digital giant is preparing to meet with marketers during the annual Consumer Electronics Show, which gets underway on Tuesday. And when the company does, executives plan to tout not only its ability to help sell goods and services via its large e-commerce […]
content:
Amazon thinks it can do more for TV advertisers than traditional TV.

The digital giant is preparing to meet with marketers during the annual Consumer Electronics Show, which gets underway on Tuesday. And when the company does, executives plan to tout not only its ability to help sell goods and services via its large e-commerce portal, but to gain significant reach among consumers, thanks to its streaming content and a growing spate of programmatic alliances it has struck with rivals including Disney, Roku and Netflix, among others.

â€œAt some level, you want to be the â€˜everything storeâ€™ for advertising,â€ says Alan Moss, vice president of global sales for Amazon Ads, during a recent interview.

Popular on Variety

Mossâ€™ willingness to preview Amazonâ€™s plans for CES suggests the company continues to have confidence in its ability to lure new support from Madison Avenue as most video companies move earlier into negotiations ahead of the â€œupfront,â€ the annual sales market during which the bulk of TV ad inventory is sold. â€œWe will expand beyond traditional channels and bring more advertisers, especially non-endemics, into our fold,â€ he says.

Asked what categories of advertisers Amazon need to secure more dollars from, Moss replies: â€œThe simple definition is: those that donâ€™t sell on Amazon.â€

Amazon seems poised to put a bigger spotlight on its ability to connect advertisers with bigger audiences. The company has created an enviable suite of DSP agreements that can help advertisers reach both video and audio users of content tied to other companies. The hope is that giving marketers the chance to buy a broader set of programmatic inventory from a single venue might reduce the number of commercials they show to the same consumer and improve the effectiveness of commercials by distributing them with more precision.

â€œWe can now connect advertisers to 90% of all US households, giving us a broad, deterministic reach,â€ says Moss.

Amazonâ€™s ability to extend reach beyond its own content led it to launch a new â€œlive events optimizerâ€ that enables programmatic advertisers to connect with audiences during heavily watched live moments. These are fast becoming like gold for Madison Avenue stalwarts, who are grappling with a growing number of TV viewers who watch programs at times of their own choosing â€” in a splintered mass that is harder to reach in an efficient manner. A good chunk of Amazonâ€™s content is watched in such disaggregated fashion, but the company continues to sink millions into sports rights. After winning â€œThursday Night Football,â€ Amazon has now moved on to the NBA, with a new rights deal.

Rivals have their own big-ticket events to sell. Disney is expected to use its scheduled telecast of the 2027 Super Bowl to tout a broader series of live events against which it hopes to sell advertising packages. NBCUniversal has a new rights pact with Major League Baseball that will help extend its Sunday-night sports franchise, as well as a bigger celebration tied to the 100th anniversary of its broadcast network.

Amazon has raised eyebrows in recent months among sales executives at many traditional advertisers after its use of sharp elbows in last yearâ€™s sales market. Amazon opted to hold a showcase last year on the first night of the industryâ€™s mid-May â€œupfront weekâ€ â€” a slot that has been used for years by rivals NBCUniversal and Fox for events and meetings with advertisers and buyers.

The strategy didnâ€™t appear to crimp Amazonâ€™s sales efforts. â€œWe exceeded our own expectations in upfront commitments year over year with new and existing advertisers,â€ Amazon said in a statement in August, nodding to interest in a new NBA rights pact and series including â€œFalloutâ€ and â€œBeast Games.â€

Amazon will also spotlight new capabilities powered via A.I. One analyzes a brandâ€™s presence across Amazonâ€™s properties, then â€œgenerates creative briefs and storyboards for campaigns,â€ says Moss.

There is also a new effort to combine ads that generate awareness and those that help lead to a sale, in a new â€œfull funnelâ€ product expected to debut in the first quarter of 2026. Such an effort might start with â€œpremium streaming TV, audio, then reinforces brand message with display and online video across Amazon in the open internet and completes the conversion, whether itâ€™s on a brand site or with sponsored ads,â€ Moss explains.

The economic outlook in recent months has been foggy, with concern about tariffs creating an overhang of sorts on optimistic sentiment. Recent forecasts have called for new reasons for hope in 2026. WPP Media has called for global ad spend in 2026 to increase 7.1%, compared with a previous estimate of 6.1%. One of the factors cited is a raft of new products and services created by A.I., leading to new firms that need to advertise.

â€œTo some extent the uncertainty is a little bit of the new normal,â€ Moss says, adding: â€œNo matter the economic climate, advertisers are focused on using advertising where itâ€™s most likely to achieve their desired business goals, whether thatâ€™s awareness, consideration, or diversion.â€

title: Showbiz Leaders Take AI Deep Dive at Variety Entertainment Summit at CES 2026
summary: Launched in 1967, the Consumer Electronics Show bounced around cities and spots on the calendar before finally settling down in 1998 as an event held every January in Las Vegas. For more than half of those years, the Variety Entertainment Summit has been a fixture of that New Yearâ€™s tradition, bringing together leaders from various […]
content:
Launched in 1967, the Consumer Electronics Show bounced around cities and spots on the calendar before finally settling down in 1998 as an event held every January in Las Vegas. For more than half of those years, the Variety Entertainment Summit has been a fixture of that New Yearâ€™s tradition, bringing together leaders from various media verticals for onstage discussions about how bleeding-edge technologies are transforming entertainment and shaping the culture.

This year, Varietyâ€™s CES offering comes in two parts, both held at C-Space Studio at the Aria: the Variety Entertainment Summit on Jan. 7 from 9 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. and the Variety Business of Creators Summit, presented by Samsung Ads, on Jan. 8 from 9 a.m. to 1 p.m.

Popular on Variety

Participants will include everyone from Disney president of global advertising Rita Ferro and Hasbro president of licensing and entertainment Kim Boyd to actors Joseph Gordon-Levitt and Simon Helberg.

This year, there will be added urgency to the conversations brought on by the lightning-fast emergence of AI, which is viewed by many as an existential threat.

But Jon Liebman, chairman and CEO of Brillstein Entertainment Partners, points out that AI is just the latest in a long line of tech disruptors that were supposed to spell doom for the biz, from the arrival of sound movies in the 1920s to home video in the 1980s and the internet in the 1990s.

â€œI would say Hollywood has cried wolf a lot about technology destroying its business, and actually, the opposite has probably occurred,â€ says Liebman, who will appear on â€œThe Future of Contentâ€ panel, moderated by Variety co-editor-in-chief Cynthia Littleton on Jan. 7. â€œThe technology, when harnessed appropriately, has become a tool for what we now have, which is global distribution of content. And so while I donâ€™t think anyone really knows what it will do to our business, I think that the fear that we have has to be tempered by the reality of what technology has actually historically done for the entertainment business, which is fuel its growth in era after era.â€

Liebman will get no argument from Jonathan Yunger, co-founder and CEO of AI-powered content production platform and studio Arcana, who will join actor-producer Breckin Meyer (who stars in Arcanaâ€™s AI short â€œEcho Hunterâ€) and Luminate chief analyst and president Andrew Wallenstein for a conversation on AI storytelling on Jan. 7.

â€œThe [AI] toolset can really make a difference and help with being able to maintain or raise production value, but lower costs,â€ says Yunger, adding, â€œAI doesnâ€™t work without the creative, without the storyteller.â€

Other panels at the Variety Entertainment Summit on Jan. 7 include â€œThe New Business of Entertainment,â€ moderated by Danny Ledger, telecom, media & entertainment leader for consulting services, Deloitte; â€œExperience This! Whatâ€™s Next in Events Across Platformsâ€ and â€œFandom in the Zeitgeist,â€ moderated by Variety business editor Todd Spangler; â€œAI in Overdriveâ€ and â€œThe Big Picture Outlook â€” What Trends Will Shape 2026?â€ moderated by Littleton; and â€œHarnessing Fandom Through Live Sports Content Featuring Amazon Ads & WPP Media.â€ There will also be a â€œBrandmakers Elite Roundtableâ€ and a headliner conversation with Anthony Wood, founder, chairman and CEO of Roku.

The Variety Business of Creators Summit on Jan. 8 will feature such panels as â€œThe State of the Creator Economy in Media and Entertainment,â€ moderated Wallenstein; â€œNew Hollywood Power Players: The Rise of Creators on TVâ€ and â€œThe Power of the Creator Brand,â€ moderated by Littleton; â€œThe Live Shopping Era Has Arrivedâ€ and â€œAudiences Unlocked â€” The Future of Creator Marketing,â€ moderated by Spangler, as well as fireside chats with â€œmedia cartographerâ€ Evan Shapiro and Substack co-founder Hamish McKenzie.

title: Josh Charles Charms as a Cantankerous Small Town Doctor in Foxâ€™s Cutesy â€˜Best Medicineâ€™: TV Review
summary: The protagonist of the lighthearted new Fox series â€œBest Medicineâ€ may be a doctor, but the hourlong show isnâ€™t really a medical procedural. Instead, the series borrows a time-honored setup from â€œSchittâ€™s Creek,â€ infinite Hallmark movies and its own source material, the long running British series â€œDoc Martinâ€: uptight big city professional gets reluctantly acquainted […]
content:
The protagonist of the lighthearted new Fox series â€œBest Medicineâ€ may be a doctor, but the hourlong show isnâ€™t really a medical procedural. Instead, the series borrows a time-honored setup from â€œSchittâ€™s Creek,â€ infinite Hallmark movies and its own source material, the long running British series â€œDoc Martinâ€: uptight big city professional gets reluctantly acquainted with the charms of small-town life. In this case, the titular curmudgeon â€” yes, the name is a pun and the character is called Doctor Best â€” is played by erstwhile â€œThe Good Wifeâ€ star Josh Charles, whose cantankerous charm keeps the sometimes forced-feeling zaniness in check through the first four episodes.

â€œBest Medicineâ€ takes place in a corner of coastal Maine currently best known to outsiders from Graham Platner campaign ads. (Ironically, this celebration of the countryâ€™s quieter corners was developed by Liz Tuccillo, an alumna of the quintessentially urban â€œSex and the Cityâ€ and co-author of the hit self-help book â€œHeâ€™s Just Not That Into You.â€) Charlesâ€™ Boston heart surgeon used to vacation there as a kid, and returns when a childhood trauma-triggering incident at work gives him an occupationally hazardous fear of blood. Conveniently, the town doctor has just passed away, giving Martin â€” inheriting a first name from his English predecessor â€” a new job and a chance to work on his abysmal bedside manner.

Popular on Variety

Martin wants nothing more than to diagnose his patients, treat their illnesses and move on with his day. Unfortunately for him, thatâ€™s not really the gig, as he learns the hard way when one womanâ€™s use of estrogen cream to treat symptoms of perimenopause accidentally reveals her infidelity. (Both her male partners develop breasts due to estrogen contact. Itâ€™s called gynecomastia!) Dr. Best is more like a communal therapist, expected to be on call at all times to consult whatever minor problems his new neighbors may be working through, strictly medical in nature or not â€” â€œlike the world is one giant doctorâ€™s office,â€ he laments.

Every episode of â€œBest Medicineâ€ establishes a new yet equally beloved local tradition to confound the fiercely anti-sentimental doctor: a baked bean dinner; a high-school baseball game against archrivals Bar Harbor; a handsome hermit who comes out of the woods once a year to teach the local ladies wilderness survival skills. Martinâ€™s no-nonsense aunt Joan (Annie Potts), incompetent assistant Elaine (the mononymous actor Cree) and partner in will-they-wonâ€™t-they flirtation Louisa (Abigail Spencer), a teacher, serve as his guides through these local rituals. These women are flanked by an ever-expanding cast of quirk-forward local characters, from the gay couple who own a local restaurant and let their pet pig wander the kitchen to a father-and-son handyman duo who like to make unsolicited repairs.

On the one hand, itâ€™s a relief that â€œBest Medicineâ€ feels like the first rural-set story in half a decade to make no mention of the opioid crisis. But as endearing as these Maine denizens may be â€” like Louisaâ€™s ex-fiancÃ© Mark, played by Hollywoodâ€™s go-to funny himbo Josh Segarra â€” they collectively lack edge in a way thatâ€™s less than convincing. Lip service is paid to the decline of small towns, yet any contributing factors to that shift are ignored in the name of an insistently sunny (literally; no snow here!) disposition. Martinâ€™s former bully Glen (Patch Darragh) has the makings of a villain before heâ€™s swiftly reformed. Mark briefly flirts with manosphere-style aggrievement, but anger doesnâ€™t suit him.

Any hint of acid comes from Martin himself, a necessary counterpoint to the sugar in such abundant supply. â€œIâ€™m not meant to be a town doctor because I donâ€™t like people,â€ he complains, but Charles doesnâ€™t play the physician as mean-spirited or even especially irritable. Martin just has little patience or understanding of social niceties, which happen to be the stock and trade of his new home: â€œI find the people demanding, irrational and far too chatty at supermarkets,â€ he sighs. To invoke another iconic TV doctor from the same network, Martinâ€™s like a less gleefully bitchy Dr. House, a parallel that extends to his penchant for solving diagnostic mysteries like the source of a seemingly foodborne illness.

Martin will doubtless have his edges sanded down over time, though hopefully later rather than sooner. For now, the contrast between Martin and his patients has a productive friction that gives Charles plenty of grouchy misanthropy to work with. Amid so much communitarian sweetness, a spoonful of bitter helps â€œBest Medicineâ€ go down.

â€œBest Medicineâ€ premieres on Fox on Jan. 4 at 8 p.m. ET, with remaining episodes airing Tuesdays at 8 p.m. ET starting on Jan. 6.

Following U.S.â€™ military strike that led to the deposition and capture of Venezuelan President NicolÃ¡s Maduro, a clip from Season 2 of the Prime Video political action thriller, originally released in 2019, has gone viral. It features the eponymous CIA analyst Jack Ryan (John Krasinski) breaking down why Venezuela should be considered â€œa major threat on the world stageâ€ alongside â€” and even over â€” usual suspects such as Russia, China and North Korea.

â€œThe fact is that Venezuela is arguably the single greatest resource of oil and minerals on the planet,â€ Ryan says in the scene after listing the Latin American country as having the largest oil deposit in the world as well as more gold than all the mines in Africa combined. â€œSo why is this country in the midst of one of the greatest humanitarian crises in modern history?â€

Watch on Deadline

He focuses on the countryâ€™s fictional President who â€œhas crippled the national economy by halfâ€ and â€œhas raised the poverty rate by almost 400%.â€

Ryan also points out that, unlike other countries that have faced economic collapse such as Yemen and Iraq, Venezuela is â€œwithin 30-minute range from the US of next-gen nuclear missiles.â€

Social media users have praised the six-year-old clip, which you can watch below, for explaining well the current Venezuela situation.

The parallels are not lost on Carlton Cuse, who co-created Jack Ryan with Graham Roland and served as showrunner for the first two seasons.

â€œWhat always surprises you as a storyteller is how often real-world events catch up to fiction,â€ he told Deadlime. â€œThe goal of that season wasnâ€™t prophecy â€” it was plausibility. When you ground a story in real geopolitical dynamics, reality has a way of making it rhyme.

He spoke about the choice of Venezuela as the subject of the seriesâ€™ second season, which was conceived more than seven years ago.

â€œGraham Roland and I werenâ€™t making a statement â€” we were telling a fictional character-driven thriller rooted in Venezuelaâ€™s long-standing strategic relevance,â€ he said. â€œOur job was to make the situation feel credible. We approached Venezuela as a country where democratic ideals, economic reality, and geopolitical interests have been in tension for a long time â€” and where choices are never simple.â€

As for potentially looking into the future, â€œthe season came from our desire to tell a fictional story about the forces at play, not from imagining an outcome,â€ Cuse said.

Speaking of the outcome, there are some similarities between the culmination of Jack Ryanâ€˜s second season and the real-live events of this weekend as the fictional Venezuelan president on the show also gets removed after Ryan and the Venezuela CIA Station Chief fly a helicopter into the Presidential Palace.

But in the series, they confront the corrupt President who is exposed, with the opposition winning the election. The reality involved a military operation by U.S. special forces.

â€œAny time the United States uses force abroad, itâ€™s a moment that deserves reflection,â€ Cuse said. â€œThe consequences are born most significantly by people who have very little control over events. I can only hope things move toward stability and peace for the people living there.â€

content:
As the sun started peeking through the clouds after a sudden desert deluge, the stars and filmmakers turned out for Varietyâ€˜s 10 Directors to Watch and Creative Impact Awards brunch at the Parker Hotel in Palm Springs on Sunday morning.

The annual event, held the day after the Palm Springs International Film Awards, honored Dwayne Johnson with the Creative Impact in Acting Award, Teyana Taylor with the Creative Impact in Breakthrough Performance Award and Guillermo del Toro with the Creative Impact in Directing Award.

Colman Domingo presented the award to Dwayne Johnson, saying, â€œCongratulations, my friend, you are a rock!â€

Popular on Variety

Johnson then told a story about his fellow honoree, del Toro, and when he attended his first Golden Globes ceremony as a presenter the year â€œThe Shape of Waterâ€ was nominated.

Johnson was surprised to be seated up front at â€œThe Shape of Waterâ€ table, where he met del Toro, who was â€œso kind to me,â€ Johnson said. After del Toro won the Golden Globe for best director, he came straight to Johnson, hugged him and exclaimed, â€œWe did it!â€

â€œAnd I went, â€˜We did do it!â€™ and Iâ€™ll never forget that, and everyone after that was coming up to me and congratulating me,â€ Johnson laughed.

Johnson was honored for playing MMA fighter Mark Kerr in â€œThe Smashing Machine,â€ saying, â€œIt changed my life in ways that I didnâ€™t anticipate, discovering things about myself.â€

Johnson spoke about Kerr, who had overdosed twice, the toll of drug addiction and dealing with pressure. He counts 15 friends he has lost who died from drugs or suicide. He said. â€œThis role gave me a greater level of empathyâ€¦and the realization that, you know who is really going through something right now? Everyone. Weâ€™re all going through it.â€

â€œThis one goes out to everyone whoâ€™s going through it and whoâ€™s fighting,â€ Johnson concluded.

Teyana Taylor and Chase Infiniti at Varietyâ€˜s Creative Impact Awards and 10 Directors to Watch Brunch. Michael Buckner/Variety

Teyana Taylor was introduced by her â€œOne Battle After Anotherâ€ co-star Chase Infiniti, who said her role as Perfidia Beverly Hills â€œtruly burned a hole through the screen.â€

Taylor said that 20 years into her career, being celebrated as a breakthrough â€œfeels a little ironic.â€ She gave a shoutout to her two young daughters at her table, exclaiming, â€œAre you on your phone?â€

Speaking about her decision to retire from music five years ago because she felt boxed in, she compared herself to a Glade plug-in scent. â€œWhy only plug me in a bathroom, when I can make the whole room smell good?â€

â€œYouâ€™re going to plug me in every single outlet! I want to take up every square foot!,â€ she said. â€œThere have been so many incredible directors Iâ€™ve been fortunate to work with, but none as impactful as Paul Thomas Anderson.â€ Taylor is preparing to direct her first feature film, she said.

Oscar Isaac introduced del Toro, saying in Guillermoâ€™s cinema, â€œtransformation is constant,â€ adding he has â€œredefined what genre cinema can beâ€ and brings â€œpoetry to horror.â€

Del Toro spoke about his â€œreligious experienceâ€ as a child when he first saw James Whaleâ€™s â€œFrankenstein,â€ and then said he was very grateful to have Sara Karloff, daughter of the iconic â€œFrankensteinâ€ star, as his guest at the brunch.

â€œSometimes the world gets so complicated, you can only explain it with the power of monsters,â€ he said. â€œWe are in a time like that right now.â€

â€œA director has to have two skins â€” a thick one for the business and the world, and a thin one for their collaborators and their heart,â€ del Toro said, lobbing pithy quotes one after another.

â€œItâ€™s not just the size of the screens, itâ€™s the size of the idea,â€ he continued. â€œAmbition includes failure â€“ itâ€™s right next door to success. There are no numbers on the door. Youâ€™re going to knock on that door, and itâ€™s going to open, and itâ€™s either a supermodel of your dreams or your mom in curlers.â€

He directed his next remarks to the Variety 10 Directors to Watch table, saying, â€œBe kind, be involved, believe in your art. At a time when people tell you art is not important, that is always a prelude to fascism. They think they can debase everything that makes us a little better, a little more human. And that, in my book, and in my life, includes monsters.â€

Variety chief film critic Peter Debruge introduced this yearâ€™s 10 Directors to Watch, explaining that honoree Dave Green is stuck in Puerto Rico due to flight restrictions. All the filmmakers except Green and Harry Lighton were present at the brunch.

The directors to watch are Akinola Davies Jr. (â€œMy Fatherâ€™s Shadowâ€); Beth de Araujo (â€œJosephineâ€); Jan-Ole Gerster (â€œIslandsâ€); Sarah Goher (â€œHappy Birthdayâ€); Dave Green (â€œCoyote vs. Acmeâ€); Chandler Levack (â€œMile End Kicksâ€); Harry Lighton (â€œPillionâ€); NB Mager (â€œRun Amokâ€); Kristen Stewart (â€œThe Chronology of Waterâ€) and Walter Thompson-HernÃ¡ndez (â€œIf I Go Will They Miss Meâ€).

While accepting the directing honor at Varietyâ€™s 10 Directors to Watch and Creative Impact Awards brunch during the Palm Springs International Film Festival, Guillermo del Toro told the up-and-coming filmmakers to never listen when â€œpeople tell you art is not important,â€ because that is â€œalways a prelude to fascism.â€

â€œBe kind, be involved, believe in your art,â€ he said. â€œAt a time when people tell you art is not important, that is always the prelude to fascism. When they tell you it doesnâ€™t matter, when they tell you a fucking app can do art you say, if itâ€™s that important, why the fuck do they want it so bad? The answer is because they think they can debase everything that makes us a little better, a little more human. And that, in my book, and in my life, includes monsters.â€

Along with del Toro, who received the Directing Award for his work on â€œFrankenstein,â€ other honorees included Dwayne Johnson, who received the Creative Impact in Acting Award for â€œThe Smashing Machine,â€ and Teyana Taylor, who received the Creative Impact in Breakthrough Performance Award for â€œOne Battle After Another.â€

Popular on Variety

Elsewhere in his speech, del Toro spoke about the â€œreligious experienceâ€ of watching James Whaleâ€™s 1931 â€œFrankensteinâ€ for the first time. Sara Karloff, the daughter of the original â€œFrankensteinâ€ star Boris Karloff, was his guest at the event.

â€œSometimes the world gets so complicated, you can only explain it with the power of monsters,â€ he said. â€œWe are in a time like that right now.â€

He later added, â€œItâ€™s not just the size of the screens, itâ€™s the size of the idea. Ambition includes failure â€“ itâ€™s right next door to success. There are no numbers on the door. Youâ€™re going to knock on that door, and itâ€™s going to open, and itâ€™s either a supermodel of your dreams or your mom in curlers.â€

â€œFrankensteinâ€ was released on Netflix on Oct. 17, 2025. The film stars Jacob Elordi, Oscar Isaac and Mia Goth.

title: John Mayer and McG on Buying the Henson/A&M Lot and Preserving It as Chaplin Studios: â€˜This Is One of Those Times in Life Where You Throw Down for What Mattersâ€™
summary: John Mayer and McG have both spent a lot of time thinking about what is inherently special about the Chaplin Studios, the lot that previously was home to A&M Records, Henson Studios and, in its earliest decades, Charlie Chaplinâ€™s production company. Between the two of them, Mayer may have spent the greatest amount of time […]
content:
John Mayer and McG have both spent a lot of time thinking about what is inherently special about the Chaplin Studios, the lot that previously was home to A&M Records, Henson Studios and, in its earliest decades, Charlie Chaplinâ€™s production company. Between the two of them, Mayer may have spent the greatest amount of time thinking about the scents associated with the landmark Hollywood property, which they jointly purchased for a reported $44 million just over a year ago.

â€œIâ€™ve asked a lot over the years about this: I donâ€™t know what makes an old California studio smell like an old California studio,â€ Mayer says. â€œYou cannot fake the smell. Ocean Way [the classic Hollywood recording studio] had it. The medical buildings in Beverly Hills, those green-carpet kind of medical buildings, have it. You walk in and you go, â€œI donâ€™t know why Mickey Fine smells like thatâ€™,â€ he says, referring to the historic pharmacy. â€œI donâ€™t know why the Beverly Hills Polo Lounge smells like it does. But if you have that classic California smell, keep it! Because you cannot buy it. There is no candle.â€

Popular on Variety

Mayerâ€™s attention to the aromatic qualities of a historic property has apparently made an impression on McG, too, because even he raises the issue, when he discusses the day-to-day decisions that have been made over the last 10 months about what to renovate and what to leave alone for fear of affecting the all-important vibes that have accumulated over the last 110 years.

â€œItâ€™s still a work in progress,â€ says McG, the filmmaker behind â€œCharlieâ€™s Angelsâ€ and â€œTerminator Salvation,â€ who is especially in charge of the parts of the lot that involve film/TV production and offices. â€œI was telling John a lot of the buildings are built like film sets. I remember getting the reports, where there would be gaps in a window where the breeze will come in, and someone is like, â€˜For Godâ€™s sake, a spider could crawl through! You gotta seal those windows.â€™ And Iâ€™m just like, if I seal it, that California smell might be erased. I canâ€™t do that. So youâ€™ve gotta lean into the Wabi-sabi funk of this place, or youâ€™re in the wrong place.â€

â€œI think thatâ€™s a great point,â€ agrees Mayer. â€œHow do you thread the needle between that lived-in thing and looking forward and acknowledging modern-day? Thatâ€™s something I try to do all the time. What are the best of both worlds, and what is great and sturdy about the past? What can you interlace in a way that doesnâ€™t hold back the future and just gives it a little more strength and durability? And thatâ€™s what weâ€™re having fun doing.â€

Sentiments like these will be music to the ears of the many Southern Californians who look to Chaplin â€” or to A&M, or Henson, or however they grew up knowing it best â€” as a hopefully immutable touchstone of both the city of Los Angeles and its entertainment community. Whether youâ€™re a historic preservationist or just a nostalgist, chances are you have some strong feelings about the lot, especially if youâ€™ve worked or frequently visited there. Mayer and McG have not talked openly about their plans until now, but they met with a small group of journalists last month to first tour the lot, then sit down in Studio B talk at length about the propertyâ€™s history and possibilities.

One of the things they are discussing for the first time publicly is how the sale came to be, and how they came to be in on it together, not having previously been buddies or even acquaintances up until this became a joint mission. They also addressed the widespread reports that Scientology was set to acquire the property, which did not sit entirely well with an entertainment community that had become accustomed to the lot being open for a wide variety of usages over the decades.

â€œJohn and I strangely donâ€™t know each other all that well prior to our arranged marriage,â€ acknowledges McG. â€œI was sort of trying to take a run at it. Iâ€™d gotten to know Faryal (Ganjehei, the lotâ€™s president and studio manager since 2000], and John kicked the tires for his purposes and tried to figure it out. And I just didnâ€™t have enough dough, and I donâ€™t think he wanted to deal with the headache. Then we finally got together and I was like, â€˜Iâ€™m equipped to deal with the headacheâ€™ [of overseeing the entire lot]. Heâ€™s like, â€˜Good. I want to tunnel into the [recording] studio and tunnel back out.â€™ And I go, â€˜Perfect!â€™ And Irving Azoff gave me my first record deal in the â€˜90sâ€ â€” (McG was one of Sugar Rayâ€™s primary instigators and had his own imprint before becoming one of the top musid video directors of that decade) â€” â€œand we had a very good experience with that, and he obviously manages John. So Irving vouched for both of us: Chocolate, meet peanut butter. Reeseâ€™s, knock yourself out.â€

But McG approached the possibility of a deal first as a solo act. â€œI even got it into escrow,â€ he reveals, â€œbut I couldnâ€™t close it; I didnâ€™t have enough dough. This is before John. And I donâ€™t know if we should talk about our competitionâ€¦,â€ he wonders aloud. â€œI think [Henson] got way downstream with a family with deep ties to the Church of Scientology, and then that got out in public, and people were concerned about the manner in which it was going to be deployed. Iâ€™ll leave it at that. And then we got our foot back in the door and got our financial ducks in a row, and we were fortunate enough to make it happen.â€

McG and John Mayer at Chaplin Studios Brecht Vanâ€™t Hof

Mayer was coming from a place of having recorded at the A&M studios going back to 2005, and having locked in Studio C for his own purposes in 2018, getting to know the people who worked there. â€œIâ€™ll piggyback off what McG said. It was in the press; itâ€™s known. But it wasnâ€™t necessarily about anyone else who was in the running. For me, this was about keeping the band together And all I really cared about was in my sort of near view, which is: This is a gang you can spend another 30 years working with. It wouldâ€™ve really upset me deeply if everyone who comes to work every day and sees one another â€” itâ€™s a very tightknit family â€” had to separate and dissipate, and I went and worked at one studio, and Faryal went and started somewhere in the middle of the ladder at another studio. I did not want to see all of us go different places. Thatâ€™s it.

â€œThis was not about outsmarting anybody. This is about caring about so many people who see each other every day â€¦. especially if youâ€™re me and youâ€™re an artist, and you donâ€™t have any semblance of routine in your life, and I found it, like other artists find it here. â€¦ This is one of those times in life where you throw down for what matters, not for what you can brag about you were able to corner someone onâ€¦ At a certain pointâ€¦ I know I said to the previous owners, â€˜You have my attention, and Iâ€™m not here to play games anymore. And what does it take?â€™ And to have an emotional asset in your life is a really good thing. I think everyoneâ€™s always looking at assets from a very objective, hardcore, empirical value level. This is something I wake up and go to sleep every day knowing in my heart that I have a piece of in some way, or Iâ€™m responsible for other peopleâ€™s piece of it.â€

Says McG: â€œIâ€™m old enough to have seen the exodus of aerospace out of Southern California â€” [it] broke my heart â€” and old enough to have seen the exodus of Hollywood out of Southern California. So if we could take a small step in the direction of planting a flag and saying, â€˜Hey, weâ€™re trying to do the right thing and protect the people of the city that we care about, trying to show that you can make a film or television show or record and do it here with extraordinary people and extraordinary facilitiesâ€™ â€” why not?â€

With an estimated $9 million going into renovating the property and its facilities, on top of the substantial purchase price, no one is expecting it to be a profitable investment soon. Theyâ€™re fine with that.

â€œJohn makes a really good point about the dough,â€ McG says, â€œbecause I think a lot of financial people kicked us in the shins and said, â€˜Not such a hot financial idea.â€™ And we just kind of shrugged because it was always emotional. Itâ€™s well-known that John is a premiere watch collector and a giant voice in that community. And I kind of wrapped my head around, if John buys a very interesting watch, it doesnâ€™t pay a dividend; Iâ€™m sure his business manager told him he overpaid for it, all those thingsâ€¦ But he gets to live with the watch, enjoy the watch, take it out for a test spin, do the thing, enjoy it. And itâ€™s very likely to go from the value of one to the value of two over the course of time, even in the absence of making prudent financial sense. So I think that youâ€™ve gotta look at it like one of Johnâ€™s watches, if you will.â€

â€œYeah, it would be one of my watches that I love wearing more than I care about the P&L or what the books say it is,â€ agrees Mayer. â€œYou donâ€™t hear, as youâ€™re scrolling through on line, about making a contribution in some way â€” having something in your name that is less about a portfolio and more about having a piece of something and having a part in preserving something. There are people in L.A. who have never needed a recording studio and will never need to come here, who are going to be very happy that a building in L.A. that was known as one thing has changed hands and will continue to be known as the same thing.â€

Chaplin Studios, formerly A&M and Henson Studios Brecht Vanâ€™t Hof

Are there other major investors that McG and Mayor will need to answer to as they steer the lot toward a hoped-for profit someday?

â€œWe didnâ€™t really look up each otherâ€™s pant leg,â€ says McG. â€œWe split it right down the middle. I brought in a couple of friends to help offset [some of the down payment]. My nephew gave me a couple bucksâ€¦ It was a lot of money for me. We had to put down a lot cash to make the deal workâ€¦ We all became sort of blinded with desire just to get it done at the end there. But we got it done and, at the end of the day, what matters most is, itâ€™s dually John and McG.â€

â€œYeah, I mean, I think itâ€™s just you and I on the paperwork,â€ says Mayer.

â€œYeah, thereâ€™s no â€˜And therefore we also have to check with the big Daddy Warbucks character.â€™ Itâ€™s truly just us,â€ McG says.

â€œI have a food truck business,â€ adds Mayer. â€œI just went into that â€¦ used my profits from the food truck.â€ As is sometimes the case with him, it takes a couple of beats to realize heâ€™s kidding.

The two co-owners got almost everything they wanted in procuring the lot â€” with a couple of symbolic exceptions that were denied by the propertyâ€™s last two sets of owners. They were not allowed to use the A&M name, and the statue of Kermit dressed as Charlie Chaplin that had towered over the LaBrea front entrance for 25 years was carted off to go to a museum, despite a vociferous case being made to leave the frog where he stood.

â€œThe Hensons took the Kermit dressed as the Tramp and put it in a museum in Atlanta thatâ€™s dedicated to Jim Henson, which I think is terribly sad for the people of Los Angeles,â€ McG says. â€œIâ€™ve always made it analogous to, like, if we all owned Randyâ€™s Donuts, but we sold it to the barbecue place, I think between us and the barbecue person, just leave the donut up thereâ€¦ Griffith Park Observatory, Formosa Cafe, the Hollywood sign â€” we donâ€™t have that much, so donâ€™t keep cannibalizing and chipping away. A woman I work with takes her kids to school every day on this road, and she says, â€˜My kids every day would say, â€œWhatâ€™s up, Kerms?â€ Now, they donâ€™t.â€™ And it breaks my heart, and I think that itâ€™s an opportunity missed. I think it transcends the Henson family, respectfully, and transcends John or McG or anybody. I feel like at a certain point it belongs to the city, and Iâ€™m very sad to see it go. Oh well.â€

When it came to renaming the facility from Henson Studios, there were issues of whether to go back in time and, if so, how far back.

Says McG, â€œMy companyâ€™s called Wonderland Sound and Vision, and of course, Johnâ€™s breakout hit is â€˜Your Body Is a Wonderlandâ€™â€¦â€

â€œAnd my best song to date, by the way,â€ interjects Mayer, tongue firmly in cheek.

McG: â€œSo a woman I work a lot with goes, â€˜Are you guys gonna call it Your Body Is a Wonderland Sound and Vision? And Iâ€™m like, no.â€

Another idea: â€œPeople for a long time were saying, just call it J&M,â€ Mayer notes. Another immediate no.

â€œBut we even took a run at just, â€˜Hey, should we call it A&M?â€™â€ says McG. â€œBecause Iâ€™m of a generation where I just regard this as A&M. I used to hang out on the docks begging everybody for CDs, so I associate it with that period. But there were problems with Universal Music Group being proprietary about this, that and the other.â€ Technically, A&M is part of a current label name â€” Interscope Geffen A&M â€” which represents some of the imprints that Universal bought and absorbed, although at this point the A&M part is more of a faintly nostalgic technicality than a distinct entity with any connection to the house that Herb Alpert and Jerry Moss built. â€œThey just couldnâ€™t see it,â€ says a frustrated Mayer. â€œThey had A&M Records. This wouldâ€™ve been A&M Studios. Two nodesâ€¦ They couldnâ€™t get it.â€

But sometimes simpler is better (as anyone who has ever had to wrap their tongues around Interscope Geffen A&M can attest), and â€œChaplinâ€ is pretty simple.

â€œItâ€™s difficult to correctly launch the narrative of a new brand in 2026,â€ Mayer says. â€œAnd if you take any name you have in mind for a studio and put the word â€˜studioâ€™ after it, it exists onlineâ€¦ Itâ€™s very hard to find a (new) name for a studio that still has vowels in itâ€¦ What I liked about Chaplin is, it is a 100-year-old brand, and thereâ€™s this second life to it. I thought this could be really interesting, to have people in their twenties who are working on their first album go to a place called Chaplin, even if theyâ€™re not aware of what the connection is. How can you get those who understand the legendary contributions Charlie Chaplin made to film understand it, and have a new cohort of artists just see a name that looks and sounds good, hoping that at some point people go, â€˜I didnâ€™t know there was a person behind Chaplinâ€™? You donâ€™t go to buy a Ford Raptor and interface so much with Henry Ford and his legacy. But itâ€™s important to keep legacies alive. I think itâ€™s cooler to have it exist in a constant but very low-grade way, so that you have just kind of a pinky locked on it, but move forward.â€

A tour of the facility establishes that everything still around on the lot that has any connection to Chaplinâ€™s era, which extended from 1917 through 1953, is being carefully preservedâ€¦ except in cases of pure dry rot being uncovered.

Standing out in front of the La Brea entrance on the exterior sidewalk, McG says, â€œWe started to redo everything in the spirit of getting it exactly like it was when Chaplin built it. We did the research with the width of the strip oak that he put in for the hardwood floors and replaced them.â€ In front, â€œWe chipped off the paint and we got the original colors from when Chaplin did it and did the analytics, so it was the exact brown and the exact white. We did all the landscaping to make it more beautiful for the forward-facing part of La Brea, just trying to give back to the city, since thereâ€™s a lot of blight around here, and weâ€™re just trying to be a moment of light in that. And these wooden buildings are historically protectedâ€ â€” but not necessarily in the exact spots they were in the 1910s. â€œWhen they widened La Brea, they had to put â€™em on logs and push â€™em back.â€

McG points out features on a vintage overhead view of the A&M/Henson lot, now Chaplin Studios Chris Willman/Variety

Signs of Chaplinâ€™s reign remain within. On a tour of the buildings, for instance, Ganjehei shows off a furnace where the silent film legend used to burn outtakes, after examining dailies in his screening room right across the front entrance. Some of Chaplinâ€™s footprints remain in cement in an inner courtyard. In McGâ€™s own office, there are stained glass windows that apparently date back to when Chaplin held court there. â€œA few years back, there was a really bad car accident on LaBrea, and the fire hydrant went up and the water destroyed the wall, and when we knocked down the wall for the repair work, these windows were discovered. So itâ€™s so beautiful that Mc G is now including it in his office,â€ Ganjehei says. The director says that other glass windows will be replaced with Mondrian-style glass to match the original.

There are other artifacts or entire buildings that remain from the silent era. On the slightly tawdry side, the studio overseer points to a mostly out-of-sight loft where â€œrumor has it that thatâ€™s where Chaplin would keep his concubines of sorts.â€ Chaplinâ€™s original grooming and makeup chair sits near the entrance to Studio A. Down the hall, there is a table with books perched on it that propped up a studio saw a hundred years ago, still branded with the â€œC.C. Film Co.â€ logo. In the building still called â€œthe mill,â€ is â€œapparently the oldest standing saw, minus the blades, in the West,â€ Ganjehei says. All this woodworking talk leads to anecdotes about how, in the A&M era, there would be shout-outs about â€œneeding the carpenters,â€ only for Richard and Karen Carpenter to answer the call.

Detail of Charlie Chaplin-era woodsaw table at the Chaplin Studios Chris Willman/Variety

Charlie Chaplinâ€™s makeup chair, on display at the Chaplin Studios Chris Willman/Variety

Most of the footprint of the lot remains as it has been since the late â€˜60s, when Jerry Moss and Herb Alpert bought it and transformed two of the three soundstages to five recording studios. Each of these six spaces where music or video productions are made has its own history.

The recording studios continued to be made available to outsiders during the quarter-century Henson had the place, while the soundstage was mostly utilized for Hensonâ€™s own kidsâ€™ shows, with exceptions.

Lately, the giant stage has been used for everything from â€œKnives Out: Wake Up Dead Manâ€ pickup shots to a Stella McCartney fashion show to a benefit concert Mayer and his band did for a veteransâ€™ charity. They have been looking at what kind of event should be held there during Grammy Week.

â€œI want it to be the kind of place where, if the event is happening here, the address is the pull to go,â€ says Mayer. â€œThat might sound a little superficial, but I think thatâ€™s an interesting way to create a goal. Can the address become â€˜Ooh, thereâ€™s a thing at Chaplin. It doesnâ€™t matter what it is. Thatâ€™s a cool place to go hang.â€™â€

Chaplin Studios Brecht Vanâ€™t Hof

There are more outdoor chairs and tables, and more greenery and fountains, to â€œsoftenâ€ the facilityâ€¦ not that everyone didnâ€™t already just dig a nice bungalow. McG has gotten down into the dirt to do some of the planting himself,

â€œWhat you see with these gardens and stuffâ€¦ for me, the whole impetus of this place was, everywhere we shoot, literally around the world, when itâ€™s wrapped, youâ€™re like,â€™How fast can we get the fuck outta here?â€™â€ says the filmmaker. â€œHere, when you finish your work, itâ€™s like, â€˜Do you want a glass of wine? Do you wanna hang out and talk a little bit?â€™ And I find that so magical.â€

You will not find Mayer literally getting into the dirt, himself. Although if you are in one of the studios and you happen to need a guitar part, and you come across Mayer in the hallway, he might oblige you, without getting bogged down in whatever is involved in taking a credit.

As for whether there is a need for this kind of advanced studio anymore, when home studios are capable of so much in the 2020s, Mayer has an answer: â€œItâ€™s work from home versus working from the office. And I think itâ€™s cool to hedge your bet on the side of humanity.â€

Thatâ€™s why they havenâ€™t made any major renovations to the structure or look, especially, of the recording studios, knowing that part of the appeal is being able to go into the exact room â€” Studio C â€” where Joni Mitchell recorded â€œBlueâ€ and several other albums. Mitchell came by the studio last month, to revisit the scene of the crime at a holiday party, and was no doubt pleased to see that itâ€™s Henry Diltz photos of her that everyone who comes in first sees, establishing a Laurel Canyon vibe.

â€œIf artists walked in and immediately everything was LED back-litâ€¦â€ says Mayer, letting that distasteful thought trail off. â€œThereâ€™s a nomenclature to being in the studio that lives in its own timeframe, and you just let people relate to that still. Even the tapestriesâ€¦ thereâ€™s just something about tapestries and string lights that make people want to write songs, even if itâ€™s not the most modern, Tesla-fied thing.â€

Ganjehel, the studio manager, will happily reel off past recordings of yore: The largest studio, A, can handle a 45-piece orchestra, and has been home to everything from vintage Burt Bacharach, Alpert and Sergio Mendes recordings to Guns Nâ€™ Rosesâ€™ â€œUse Your Illusionsâ€ projects to five out of the last six Paul McCartney albums to Justin Bieberâ€™s recent â€œSwagâ€ (volumes one and two). The smaller Studio D, on the other end of the hallway, has hosted the Doors, U2, Fleetwood Mac, Pearl Jam, Rage Against the Machine, Miley Cyrus and the last two Harry Styles albums.

But donâ€™t ever imagine the studio manager is ever going to give up who is currently woriing in the studio. â€œWe donâ€™t kiss and tell,â€ she says. Not even to major rock stars or a co-owner.

â€œLady Gaga a couple years ago was recording in Studio B, and the Stones were in studio A and D,â€ she recalls. â€œMick Jagger comes up and says, â€˜I hear Lady Gagaâ€™s here.â€™ And we respond with, â€˜We donâ€™t discuss whoâ€™s here.â€™ But the bodyguards made it happen. Lady Gaga was sitting on this couch and I said, â€˜Mick asked if you were here, but everything is so private and confidential and we really, really value that.â€™ And she said, â€˜You can always tell Mick Jagger when Iâ€™m here.â€™ She recorded that duet with them [â€œSweet Sounds of Heaven,â€ from their 2023 â€œHackney Diamondsâ€ album] two hours later.â€

Says Mayer, talking about the years before he bought the lot, â€œFaryal never let me know who else was here. And you might say that my half of this place was worth paying just to get the calendar every day, being let behind that very iron curtain of who was in the building every day, Iâ€™m still not over it, I donâ€™t think.â€

â€œMay I add, Iâ€™m not behind that iron curtain,â€ McG protests. â€œAs recently as yesterday, Faryal was chewing my ear off because there was a truck loading in something, and she goes, â€˜I have an artist comingâ€™,â€ but she wouldnâ€™t say who. â€œIâ€™m shooting a fucking nude scene with Reese Witherspoon and Tom Hardy â€” I can handle the discretion of who the artist is! But I donâ€™t say anything and I honor the code. So when Iâ€™ve earned it, thatâ€™ll be a hell of a day and Iâ€™ll definitely elbow John, like, â€˜She let me in, dude.â€™â€

Chaplin Studiosâ€™ soundstage Brecht Vanâ€™t Hof

With Bieber no longer on the premises, they can acknowledge press reports of an unusual recent request that made use of the large soundstage for a non-filming purpose.

Says Mayer, â€œFaryal wrote me one Saturday morning: â€˜Hey, Justinâ€™s gonna be in the studio. He mentioned wanting a basketball court. What do you think about turning the soundstage into a basketball court for him?â€ I said, â€˜Great, but I donâ€™t know that you can do that.â€™ Two or three hours later on that night, I get an image of what looks like a perfect basketball court with a three-point line and a foul line and everything, all done with tape. The runners had figured out how to do it.â€

As for whether whims like that need to be indulged, Mayer, perhaps not surprisingly, is on the side of the talent. â€œI staunchly defend artists both as being more normal than you think and way more screwed up than you think. And I try to protect the best parts of both of â€™em. So if Justin Bieber had something that you could hear on â€˜Swagâ€™ that was nominated for Album of the Year at the Grammys because he was able to shoot a little hoops on a break, then weâ€™ve done our job.â€

The match of personalities between Mayer and McG has been a good one, they avow, after 10 months of working together tightly, as two guys who both talk very fast and who can both use big words like â€œnomenclatureâ€ while talking that fast. To say nothing of shared ambitions.

â€œI like high-octane personalities,â€ says Mayer. â€œI think itâ€™s fair to say, McG, you have a high-octane personality. I have somewhat of a high-octane personality. And I know how to weave in and out of that, and I know how to let someone else rip when itâ€™s time to rip.â€

McG and John Mayer at the Chaplin Studios Chris Willman/Variety

Preservation was far from their only reason for acquiring the Chaplin Studios, but itâ€™s neither negligible nor ignoble as a factor.

Says McG, â€œI hope that organically it will be revealed: Oh, that was the tenure where John and McG were the torch bearers and hopefully will be regarded as they did a good job and they threw down for Los Angeles. They put their money where their mouth was. I love what Jason Reitman did with the Village Westwood theater, where he got a consortium of superheroes to kind of come in and save it. Itâ€™s like, we donâ€™t need another six-story mixed-use. Theyâ€™re not coolâ€¦ We really should take a look at what made Los Angeles great and be of a mind that those things donâ€™t grow on trees and not everything is disposable.â€

Mayer has his own take on that. â€œI wonder if at some point, like 10 years from now, someone whoâ€™s gonna be 30 will stand outside of Supreme [the clothing store that moved into Tower Recordsâ€™ old Sunset building] as itâ€™s being closed down and go, â€˜You just canâ€™t keep anything good these days.â€™ They probably will, because I do think that probably every generation thinks that their thing is the thing that matters the most â€” except this building has five generations. So I think if you can [hold onto it], you should, right?â€

(More details about the lot can be found here, with specific information about the soundstage here and the recording studios here.)

â€œWe won, the President lost and now Iâ€™m back on the air every night givinâ€™ the most powerful politician on earth a right and richly deserved bollocking. Thatâ€™s a word, right? I used it properly?â€ Kimmel added.

Universal Music Groupâ€™s Indian division has secured a significant minority stake in one of Bollywoodâ€™s leading production houses, gaining global soundtrack rights in the process, it was confirmed on Monday.

Universal Music India has entered into a definitive agreement to acquire a 30% equity stake in Excel Entertainment, valuing the Mumbai-based film and digital content studio at INR2,400 crores ($267 million). Founded in 1999 by producers Ritesh Sidhwani and Farhan Akhtar, Excel Entertainment has established itself as a major force in Indian cinema and streaming content. The studioâ€™s slate includes critically acclaimed titles such as â€œGully Boyâ€ (Indiaâ€™s 2019 Academy Awards submission), â€œZindagi Na Milegi Dobara,â€ and â€œDil Chahta Hai,â€ as well as Prime Videoâ€™s Emmy-nominated series â€œInside Edgeâ€ and popular shows â€œMirzapurâ€ and â€œMade in Heaven.â€

Under the agreement, UMG will launch a dedicated Excel music label with global distribution, while Universal Music Publishing Group becomes Excelâ€™s exclusive music publishing partner. The arrangement creates opportunities for UMGâ€™s existing artist roster to be featured in Excelâ€™s future productions.

Devraj Sanyal, chairman and CEO of Universal Music India and South Asia and senior VP of strategy for Africa, Middle East and Asia, will join Excel Entertainmentâ€™s board of directors. Sidhwani and Akhtar will continue overseeing creative direction and content decisions.

â€œIndiaâ€™s entertainment landscape continues to grow from strength to strength, and this is the perfect moment to build meaningful global collaborations,â€ Sidhwani and Akhtar said in a joint statement. â€œWeâ€™re excited to partner with UMG in what we believe will be a truly creative and transformative alliance â€“ one that unlocks fresh opportunities for artists and repertoire across music, film, and emerging formats. Together, we aim to take culturally rooted stories to the world.â€

Vishal Ramchandani, Excel Entertainmentâ€™s CEO, added: â€œThis partnership with UMG marks a pivotal step in our journey to broaden creative opportunities and tell Indian stories with a global lens. With a shared vision for innovation and excellence, we aim to transform Excel into a creative global studio â€“ one that brings clutter-breaking, original content to audiences across platforms and geographies.â€

The deal strengthens UMGâ€™s position in India, currently the worldâ€™s 15th-largest recorded music market by revenue according to IFPI data. Original soundtracks remain central to Indiaâ€™s music consumption, with the genre showing continued growth among local listeners.

Adam Granite, UMGâ€™s CEO of Africa, Middle East and Asia, said: â€œTodayâ€™s announcement further strengthens UMGâ€™s position in India, a dynamic and strategically important music market for the group globally. Original soundtracks remain at the heart of Indiaâ€™s fast-growing music market, with Indian listeners showing a growing desire to access more music in that genre. By investing in and partnering with Excel Entertainment, UMG will be uniquely positioned to contribute from the earliest stage to Excelâ€™s future endeavours and throughout the creative process, providing huge benefits to both parties.â€

Sanyal added: â€œFarhan and Ritesh have built an exceptionally impressive business, and weâ€™re thrilled to be working with them on the next phase of their journey. The Indian film scene presents a hugely exciting opportunity for music and the music-led entertainment business, and Excel is the perfect partner for us to work with going forward.â€

Indiaâ€™s digital entertainment sector presents significant growth opportunities, with more than 375 million over-the-top viewers and 650 million smartphone users consuming content across multiple platforms.

summary: One Cool Groupâ€™s Back To The Past, starring Louis Koo and Raymond Lam, brought some much-needed cheer to the Hong Kong box office on New Yearâ€™s Eve, grossing a record-breaking $1.48m (HK$11.54m) on its opening day.
