content:
One Cool Groupâ€™s Back To The Past, starring Louis Koo and Raymond Lam, brought some much-needed cheer to the Hong Kong box office on New Yearâ€™s Eve, grossing a record-breaking $1.48m (HK$11.54m) on its opening day.

The strong opening placed the film at number seven in the year-end chart of Hong Kong films, according to local industry body Hong Kong Box Office, just on the strength of a single dayâ€™s release (December 31).

The film went on to gross $5.4m (HK$42.36m) over its opening weekend, which would have made it the biggest local film of 2025 if the Hong Kong Box Office chart included revenue from 2026. It also grossed $24m (RMB78.6m) on its opening weekend in mainland China, according to Artisan Gateway figures.

Continuing the story from a top-rating 2001 TV series, the film follows a modern-day cop (Koo) who is pulled back to the Qin Dynasty to help the Emperor (Lam) defeat another time-travelling usurper.

Watch on Deadline

The film is directed by Ng Yuen-fai and Jack Lai with VFX carried out by the same team that worked on 2022 sci-fi hit Warriors Of Future, also directed by Ng and starring Koo.

Hong Kong Box Office reported that the film scored the biggest opening day of all time for a Hong Kong film, ahead of The Last Dance ($958,000) and Cold War 2 ($700,000). It was also the biggest opening day for a Chinese-language film, ahead of The Last Dance ($958,000) and Ne Zha 2 ($856,000). It also scored the highest opening day in 2025 amongst both local and foreign movies.

The film brought a long overdue boost to the Hong Kong and Macau box office, which was down 15% in 2025 to $155m (HK$1.21bn) after a slide of 6% the previous year, according to Hong Kong Box Office figures. Japanese anime Demon Slayer: Kimetsu No Yaiba The Movie was the highest-grossing film overall last year, pulling in $13.94m, followed by F1: The Movie and Zootopia 2. The release of Avatar: Fire And Ash has been postponed in Hong Kong due to the Tai Po fire tragedy.

Looking at figures between January 1 to December 31, 2025, local animation Another World was the highest grossing local film with box office of $1.97m (HK$15.36m). By comparison, local film The Last Dance was the highest-grossing film overall in 2024, grossing more than $18m.

title: Critics Choice to Oscars: Does â€˜One Battle After Anotherâ€™ Need Acting or Tech Wins? Is Jacob Elordi the New Frontrunner?
summary: The 31st Critics Choice Awards winners both reflected where much of the industry sees the Oscar race â€” and, in key ways, upended it. With the Golden Globes arriving next Sunday night and Oscar nomination voting opening the next day on Monday morning, the CCA ceremony served as one of the final, meaningful data points […]
content:
The 31st Critics Choice Awards winners both reflected where much of the industry sees the Oscar race â€” and, in key ways, upended it.

With the Golden Globes arriving next Sunday night and Oscar nomination voting opening the next day on Monday morning, the CCA ceremony served as one of the final, meaningful data points before Academy members begin filling out ballots. In that context, Paul Thomas Andersonâ€™s â€œOne Battle After Anotherâ€ sweeping best picture, director and adapted screenplay sends an unmistakable message to the rest of the field: this is the film to beat. Historically, that combination is Oscar catnip â€” a filmmaker-driven vision paired with broad, cross-branch support.

In the preferential-ballot era, breadth routinely defeats intensity, and â€œOne Battle After Anotherâ€ now looks like the title most capable of surviving every round of redistribution.

Popular on Variety

And yet, the sweep also comes with a built-in asterisk. Critics donâ€™t vote for the Oscars. That has long been my No. 1 rule of awards prognosticating, and it still applies. But when a film satisfies critics while simultaneously delivering craft-forward storytelling that appeals to Academy voters across demographics, it becomes exceedingly difficult to dislodge. Expect â€œOne Battle After Anotherâ€ to gain real momentum as Oscar nominations approach, particularly in the crafts categories â€” and if it can retain some traction for its acting contenders, including Chase Infiniti and possibly tack on an additional piece of recognition like Regina Hall.

A central question emerging now is whether â€œOne Battle After Anotherâ€ can complete Paul Thomas Andersonâ€™s trifecta without also winning an acting or craft category. Historically, that path is rare. The last two films to win best picture without at least acting or crafts attached â€” â€œThe Greatest Show on Earthâ€ (1952) and â€œSpotlightâ€ (2015). With Variety projecting â€œOne Battle After Anotherâ€ to approach the upper tier of all-time nomination totals, a scenario in which it converts so lightly on Oscar night would feel counterintuitive for a film that currently reads as inevitable. A more plausible outcome may resemble â€œThe Shape of Waterâ€ (2017), which paired picture and director wins with selective below-the-line support.

Still, this race is far from settled. Warner Bros. led all studios overall, thanks in large part to â€œSinners,â€ which co-led all films with four wins: original screenplay for Ryan Coogler, best young actor for Miles Caton, best casting and ensemble, and best score for Ludwig GÃ¶ransson. That package suggests something a bit more than passion â€” it hints at a possible coalition. If â€œSinnersâ€ can carry this momentum through the Golden Globes and convert it into support from SAG, the Writers Guild and other major guilds, it could emerge as the seasonâ€™s late-breaking spoiler.

Academy voters have repeatedly shown a willingness to reward bold originality when paired with technical achievement, and â€œSinnersâ€ is beginning to look like this yearâ€™s version of that formula. The original screenplay win is particularly notable. This is a category where the Academy frequently diverges from critics, often favoring dialogue-driven work over structural innovation. Cooglerâ€™s win shows the film has broken through in ways that could translate directly onto Oscar ballots, especially within the writers branch, which consistently punches above its weight in the best picture race.

Jacob Elordi , winner of the Best Supporting Actor Award for â€œFrankensteinâ€ Getty Images for Critics Choice

Netflixâ€™s â€œFrankensteinâ€ also walked away with four prizes, highlighted by a surprising best supporting actor win for Jacob Elordi as the Creature in Guillermo del Toroâ€™s gothic epic. Until now, Elordi had claimed only two critics prizes this season â€” from the New York Film Critics Online and the Oklahoma Film Critics Circle â€” raising two immediate questions. Did he just solidify a nomination slot after weeks of being viewed as fringe behind Benicio Del Toro, Sean Penn, Stellan SkarsgÃ¥rd and Paul Mescal? Or did we witness the Critics Choice version of the Aaron Taylor-Johnson effect, referencing his Golden Globe win for â€œNocturnal Animalsâ€ that ultimately failed to translate to an Oscar nomination?

The major difference here is meaningful. â€œFrankensteinâ€ is far more firmly embedded in the best picture conversation than â€œNocturnal Animalsâ€ ever was. And crucially, no Critics Choice winner for best supporting actor has ever gone on to miss an Oscar nomination. On that basis alone, Elordi now looks safely in the lineup (at least pending SAG noms next week). Whether he becomes a serious win threat is a separate discussion â€” one that hinges on follow-through at the Golden Globes and BAFTA. Should that happen, the race will recalibrate quickly.

The acting races elsewhere remain fluid. Jessie Buckleyâ€™s win for portraying Agnes Shakespeare in ChloÃ© Zhaoâ€™s grief-soaked drama â€œHamnetâ€ came with the most emotionally resonant speech of the night and offers voters a clear, focused way to reward a film that may come up short in best picture, given Buckley was the sole win for the movie. Her two closest competitors â€” Renate Reinsve and Rose Byrne â€” will have to play major catch up down the road if they want to catch Buckley.

TimothÃ©e Chalametâ€™s best actor win for â€œMarty Supremeâ€ further strengthens his frontrunner status heading into the Globes, where the organizationâ€™s genre-friendly body could amplify his lead.

But it is never that simple. At 30, Chalamet would become the second youngest best actor winner in Oscar history â€” and now, heâ€™s the youngest ever to win Critics Choice. Remember, this is the same Academy that made Leonardo DiCaprio wait until 41 to decide to throw him a bone for climbing into a dead carcass in â€œThe Revenantâ€ (2015). This race has been tightly contested all season, with Chalamet trading critics wins with Michael B. Jordan for â€œSinners,â€ while Ethan Hawke remains a serious factor for â€œBlue Moonâ€ and DiCaprio stars in the best picture frontrunner. CCA history offers some cautionary tales: Critics Choice winners Chadwick Boseman (â€œMa Raineyâ€™s Black Bottomâ€), Christian Bale (â€œViceâ€) and Michael Keaton (â€œBirdmanâ€) are among those who lost their Oscars despite entering as perceived â€œno brainers.â€

Amy Madiganâ€™s supporting actress win for â€œWeaponsâ€ was expected by many pundits, but questions remain about whether the Oscars are willing to reward a genre performance (especially one this cool) â€” and particularly if she emerges as the filmâ€™s sole nominee. If â€œWeaponsâ€ fails to land any additional noms such as casting or original screenplay, history can be unforgiving to those performers. PenÃ©lope Cruzâ€™s win for â€œVicky Cristina Barcelonaâ€ (2008) is the most recent example of a sole nominee winning in the supporting actress category, and that required a rare category switcharoo by Kate Winslet from supporting to lead for â€œThe Reader,â€ who swept all the precursors. Before that, one has to look back to Marisa Tomei in â€œMy Cousin Vinnyâ€ (1992), who was a surprise nominee on the day (and even more shocking winner on Oscar night). These are the exceptions, not the norms.

By all these somewhat vague measurements, there is still room for another contender (or two) to emerge. And with Oscar voting opening Monday morning, the next week may matter more than any ceremony that comes before.

title: Ahn Sung-ki, Veteran Korean Actor of â€˜Silmidoâ€™ and â€˜Radio Star,â€™ Dies at 74
summary: Ahn Sung-ki, one of South Korean cinemaâ€™s most enduring and respected screen actors, whose six-decade career spanned more than 130 films and included landmark hits such as â€œSilmidoâ€ and â€œRadio Star,â€ has died. He was 74. His death was confirmed by his agency, Artist Company, and Seoulâ€™s Soonchunhyang University Hospital, which said Ahn had been […]
content:
Ahn Sung-ki, one of South Korean cinemaâ€™s most enduring and respected screen actors, whose six-decade career spanned more than 130 films and included landmark hits such as â€œSilmidoâ€ and â€œRadio Star,â€ has died. He was 74.

His death was confirmed by his agency, Artist Company, and Seoulâ€™s Soonchunhyang University Hospital, which said Ahn had been battling blood cancer, according to the Associated Press.

Ahn entered the film industry as a child actor at age five, debuting in 1957â€™s â€œThe Twilight Train.â€ He went on to appear in roughly 70 films as a child before stepping away from acting during his teenage years, AP reported.

Popular on Variety

After studying Vietnamese at Hankuk University of Foreign Studies â€“ where he graduated with top honors â€“ Ahn initially struggled to re-establish himself in the industry. He returned to acting in 1977, with his adult breakthrough coming in Lee Jang-hoâ€™s â€œGood, Windy Daysâ€ (1980), a generational drama that earned him the Grand Bell Award for best new actor.

Over the decades that followed, Ahn became a central presence in modern Korean cinema, known for performances marked by restraint, authority and emotional clarity. His filmography included roles in â€œMandara,â€ â€œWhale Hunting,â€ â€œWhite Badge,â€ â€œTwo Cops,â€ the blockbuster military drama â€œSilmido,â€ and the music-industry drama â€œRadio Star,â€ in which he played the devoted manager of an aging singer.

Ahn won five Grand Bell Awards for best actor, a record, and was widely admired for a career defined by consistency and an absence of scandal. His steady public image and long-term credibility earned him a level of trust rare in the industry, according to AP.

In a 2023 interview cited by AP, Ahn said the expectations placed on him motivated him to live and work in a way that justified the publicâ€™s respect. He also said he avoided romantic scenes when he felt they were included only for effect, explaining that he was uncomfortable performing them without narrative necessity.

Beyond his screen work, Ahn played an active role in Koreaâ€™s film community, serving as chair of the Korean Film Actors Association and advocating for performers during periods of industry change.

He is survived by his wife, Oh So-yeong, and their two sons.

title: Critics Choice Analysis: It Is One Win After Another For â€˜One Battle After Anotherâ€™ As It Continues Steam-Rolling Through Awards Season
summary: The now four-time host for the just concluded 31st Annual Critics Choice Awards, Chelsea Handler might have meant her opening monologue line as a joke, but it certainly has a ring of truth to it. “This is the first awards show of the season so we are going to kick things off with the right […]
content:
The now four-time host for the just concluded 31st Annual Critics Choice Awards, Chelsea Handler might have meant her opening monologue line as a joke, but it certainly has a ring of truth to it. â€œThis is the first awards show of the season so we are going to kick things off with the right vibes, â€ Handler told the very starry packed-to-the-rafters of the Barker Hangar at Santa Monica Airport Sunday night. â€œYou guys are all going to be spending the next three months together so whoever wins tonight get used to seeing them win, and whoever doesnâ€™t win Quentin Tarantino will come up here and tell you what you did wrong.â€





Watch on Deadline

Chelsea Handler hosted the 31st Critics Choice Awards on Sunday at Barker Hangar in Santa Monica Kevin Winter/Getty Images

The part about â€œget used to seeing them winâ€ has the ring of truth based on my experiences covering numerous awards seasons over the decades. There can be a clinging hope of changing fortunes as the season rolls along for those who keep losing precursor awards to the same people, but for some eventual Oscar winners the dye can be cast right from the first of many of these ceremonies since other voting groups including the all-important industry awards sometimes follow right in unison. Everyone loves the smell of a winner and getting to go on stage and give inspiational acceptances can really build momentum.

Kicking off the actual televised awards-giving portion of the loooooong season that wonâ€™t end until March 15 at the Dolby Theatre, this is the first time in my memory the Critics Choice Awards voted on by some 500+ critics and film and tv writers/reporters (FULL DISCLOSURE: I am President of the Film Branch of CCA and vote in both movie and tv ballots), has actually been the lead horse, but this organization has traditionally been a reliable bellwether in crowning eventual Oscar winners no matter where it has landed on the calendar. Last year the Best Picture victory of Anora at the fires-delayed CCA ceremony, followed the next night by both key PGA and DGA victories, sealed the deal for that movie just as final Oscar voting was about to start. CCA also correctly forcast three of the four Oscar acting winners too. Past years have a consistent track record.

Photo by Kevin Winter/Getty Images

If tradition holds up we may be able to look back and say this was not just a good night, but a very prescient one, for Timorthee Chalamet (Marty Supreme), Jessie Buckley (Hamnet), Amy Madigan (Weapons) , and Jacob Elordi (Frankenstein). This quartet managed the neat trick of scoring key acting triumphs in four different movies, none of which were the Best Picture winner. That honor went to Paul Thomas Andersonâ€™s juggernaut, One Battle After Another which has a perfect track record on the critics circuit so far this year by always coming up at the end and being named Best Picture. Every single time. That has now happened at the Gothams, LA, NY, London, Chicago, Toronto, San Francisco Film Critics, countless other regional groups, National Board Of Review, and now this weekend at both the National Society of Film Critics and Critics Choice Awards.

Photo by Kevin Winter/Getty Images

This kind of run is quite rare these days and can have a strong effect on Oscar voters, no question about it. And it is not as if the industry has to be convinced about Andersonâ€™s film. It has been rapturously received wherever it has screened around town starting with its turnaway official Academy screening in September. Plus Anderson is considered way overdue with 11 previous Oscar nominations including three for Best Picture. We had to wait until the end of the three hour CCA show for its three victories including Adapted Screenplay and Director, but it is now clear OBAA is the one to beat, putting it in prime position as all the guild nominations begin unspooling including SAG on Wednesday, and then DGA, PGA, WGA, BAFTA, Oscars etc in the next three weeks.

(L-R) Owen Cooper and Jacob Elordi (Photo by Kevin Mazur/Getty Images

What was refreshing though about the CCA show was the way it spread the love around . OBAA had 14 nominations but only those three (albeit key) wins. Sinners had 17 nominations and led with 11-time nominated Frankenstein with four each. The lead acting wins for Chalamet and Buckley (whose acceptance was especially good and makes me look forward to the next twelve times she has to give one) werenâ€™t surprising, and veteran Madiganâ€™s popular Supporting Actress win was something you could feel might happen. She was a charmer. Many might have been surpised at Elordiâ€™s Supporting Actor triumph as the Creature in Frankenstein but voters clearly recognized the degree of difficulty and this is a major boost for his Oscar nomination chances eight days before that balloting begins in the uber competitive Supporting Actor category. I sat at the front Netflix table with the Frankenstein group and Elordi who was enthusiastically standing (at 6â€™6 he canâ€™t be missed in the room) and cheering on everyone including his young Wuthering Heights co-star Owen Cooper who followed his Emmy win with another here for Adolescence. When the artisans behind the hair and makeup , as well as production design of Frankenstein were all also announced as winners, they came over from Table 58 and the group hugs were palpable. I also noticed during commercial breaks the inevitable seat fillers would come and sit at the empty chairs at the table with Elordi affably engaging in conversation with all of them. Nice guy .

With Sound and Editing wins for F1, that Apple Original Films production looks to follow in the Oscar trajectory of one of its inspirations, 1966â€™s Grand Prix, another racing classic that earned three Oscars for its Sound and Editing. And with Song and Animated Feature for KPOP: Demon Hunters, plus Cinematorgraphy for the gorgeous Train Dreams you could easily see those two Netflix films doing the same thing at the Oscars. CCA just annointed them front runner status in those categories in a night that was very big for the streamer when you also consider the four wins for Frankenstein, as well as a sweep in the Limited Series TV categories for Adolescence. And hey, throw in those big Warner Bros wins for OBAA and Sinners, and wellâ€¦. Okay maybe we are getting ahead of ourselves I guess.

Rhea Seehorn, winner of the Best Actress in a Drama Series Award for â€œPluribus â€ Photo by Kevin Winter/Getty Images

And speaking of Adolescence the Critics Choice Awards, like the Globes and SAG also mix up film and TV. This year it was clear that it was the Emmys that made a major impact on CCA voters with not just Adolescence sweeping up four wins, but also Appleâ€™s The Studio with three, and HBO Maxâ€™s The Pitt also with three. Though CCA nominated a lot of fresh shows like Alien: Earth, Chief Of War, Death By Lightning, Landman, Murderbot, Task, The Beast In Me, The Girlfriend, and other acclaimed newbies, it stuck with the tried and Emmy-true for the most part (and that includes Jean Smart again for Hacks).

(L-R) Noah Wyle accepts the Best Actor in a Drama Series Award for â€œThe Pittâ€ from Jean Smart (Photo by Kevin Winter/Getty Images)

Only Sarah Snookâ€™s Lead Actress win in the Peacock limited series All Her Fault, and Rhea Seehornâ€™s well-deserved win for Lead Actress in the freshman Apple series, Pluribus waved the flag for newer entries, although it was nice to see perrenial nominee Janelle James finally take the prize on her fourth go round in Abbott Elementary. I also loved (and voted for) Jimmy Kimmelâ€™s talk show win and his thank you to Donald Trump for making it possible.

But like Handler said, this is just the first big show of the season, with so many more to go, including the Golden Globes next weekend (and SAG and DGA nominations plus the AFI Awards Lunch and Movies For Grownups Awards show before we get to even that). Momentum is everything so letâ€™s see where we are a week from now.

content:
Ahn Sung-ki, star of more than 100 Korean movies who was dubbed â€œthe nationâ€™s actor,â€ has died aged 74. After suffering from blood cancer for years, he died at Seoulâ€™s Soonchunhyang University Hospital, his agency, the Artist Company, said in a social media post.

â€œSung-gi Ahn [Ahn Sung-ki] was a person who has been with the history of popular culture in Korea with a deep sense of mission and consistent dedication to acting,â€ said a statement from his agency, which has been translated into English by Deadline. â€œHis acting has always been towards people and life, and through his countless works, he has conveyed deep resonance and comfort across ages and generations.â€

Ahn starred in well over 100 films during a 60-year career.

Watch on Deadline

Born in Daegu, he started his career as a child actor aged just six in 1957â€™s Twilight Train. Over the following decades, he went on to star in big successes like Silmido, Radio Star, Mandala and A Fine, Windy Day. The latter won him the best new actor gong at the Grand Bell Awards in 1980, which is the Korean equivalent of the Oscars. His latest film was Birth in 2022.

Ahn won numerous awards throughout his career and was beloved in his home nation. He was dubbed â€œthe nationâ€™s actorâ€ by the press, although he had previously said in interviews that he was not overly enthused by this nickname and preferred to simply be referred to as another film actor.

Tributes came in from the likes of Korean President Lee Jae Myung, who wrote on Facebook that Ahn has â€œleft a big footprint on Korean film history and cultural arts.â€ â€œI already miss his warm smile and gentle voice,â€ he added.

The Artist Company said Ahnâ€™s funeral will take place on Friday at Seoul St. Maryâ€™s Hospital Funeral Hall. Ahn is survived by his wife and two children.

title: Universal Music Buying 30% Stake In Indiaâ€™s Excel Entertainment
summary: Universal Music India (UMI) is set to take a minority stake in Excel Entertainment, the Bollywood movie and digital studio behind films such as Dil Chahta Hai and Don. The definitive agreement hands Universal Music Group (UMG)-owned UMI a 30% shareholding in Mumbai-based Excel, valuing the company at â‚¹2,400 crores ($300M). Though the value of […]
content:
Universal Music India (UMI) is set to take a minority stake in Excel Entertainment, the Bollywood movie and digital studio behind films such as Dil Chahta Hai and Don.

The definitive agreement hands Universal Music Group (UMG)-owned UMI a 30% shareholding in Mumbai-based Excel, valuing the company at â‚¹2,400 crores ($300M). Though the value of the transaction was not officially disclosed, its stake is worth $90M at current currency conversion rates.

UMI will gain global distribution for all future soundtracks from Excel-owned or -controlled projects, and will see the launch of a dedicated Excel music label, which UMG will distribute globally. Universal Music Publishing Group will also become exclusive music publishing partner to Excel.

Devraj Sanyal, Chairman and CEO of Universal Music India & South Asia and SVP of Strategy, Africa, Middle East and Asia â€“ will join Excelâ€™s board, with Excel founders Ritesh Sidhwani and Farhan Akhtar remaining in control of creative direction and content.

Watch on Deadline

Founded in 1999, Excel has made more than 40 films and scripted TV shows. It is known for a string of Indian box office hits such as Dil Chahta Hai, Don, Zindagi Na Milegi Dobara and Talaash. It also makes more avant-garde features such as Gully Boy, Indiaâ€™s first hip-hop film and the countryâ€™s Oscars entry in 2019, and TV shows such as the 2019 International Emmy-nominated drama Inside Edge, Indiaâ€™s first original series on Prime Video.

More recently, its drama series Dahaad took a nomination at the Berlinale, and last yearâ€™s Superboys of Malegaon, co-produced with Tiger Baby, premiered in Toronto. Streaming series have included Prime Videoâ€™s Mirzapur and Netflixâ€™s Dabba Cartel.

The deal is the first major Indian industry talking point of 2026, and comes as the countryâ€™s streaming market continues apace.

â€œIndiaâ€™s entertainment landscape continues to grow from strength to strength, and this is the perfect moment to build meaningful global collaborations,â€ said Sidhwani and Akhtar in a statement. â€œWeâ€™re excited to partner with UMG in what we believe will be a truly creative and transformative alliance â€“ one that unlocks fresh opportunities for artists and repertoire across music, film, and emerging formats. Together, we aim to take culturally rooted stories to the world.â€

Excel CEO Vishal Ramchandani added the deal marked â€œa pivotal step in our journey to broaden creative opportunities and tell Indian stories with a global lens.â€

Adam Granite, UMGâ€™s CEO of Africa, Middle East and Asia, explained the rationale behind the investment. â€œOriginal soundtracks remain at the heart of Indiaâ€™s fast-growing music market, with Indian listeners showing a growing desire to access more music in that genre,â€ he said. â€œBy investing in and partnering with Excel Entertainment, UMG will be uniquely positioned to contribute from the earliest stage to Excelâ€™s future endeavours and throughout the creative process, providing huge benefits to both parties.â€

AZB & Partners acted as legal counsel to UMG, while Ernst & Young and KPMG served as transaction advisors to Excel and UMG, respectively. Morgan Stanley acted as financial advisors to Excel, with Khaitan & Co serving as legal counsel.

title: Four Video Games That Could Become The Next Big TV Or Movie Franchise
summary: After the runaway success of The Last of Us and A Minecraft Movie, the studios have been aggressive with video game IP, but there is plenty more out there. British research firm Ampere Analysis has dug deep into the world of gaming to come up with what it believes are the four next titles ripe […]
content:
After the runaway success of The Last of Us and A Minecraft Movie, the studios have been aggressive with video game IP, but there is plenty more out there.

British research firm Ampere Analysis has dug deep into the world of gaming to come up with what it believes are the four next titles ripe for adaptation.

Ampere floated BAFTA 2024 best game winner Baldurâ€™s Gate III, Black Myth: Wu Kong, Hollow Knight: Silksong, and Sons of the Forest as the quad of video games that could be coming to a big or small screen next, noting that they each have â€œstrong popularity,â€ are â€œrecent releases,â€ and contain â€œdistinctive worlds.â€

Off the back of a super five years for video game IP, Ampere searched through the gaming archives leading on eight key characteristics to come up with its list. Characteristics included a defined narrative, adaptation style, franchise popularity and addressable audience.

Watch on Deadline

â€œStudios have moved quickly to secure the biggest and most obvious game franchises, but our research shows there is still significant untapped potential in the market,â€ said Ronald Santa-Cruz, Research Manager and Games Subject Matter Expert at Ampere Analysis. â€œFor studios willing to look beyond the usual suspects, there remains a strong pipeline of game IP that could translate into the next major transmedia success.â€

Some of the biggest shows and movies of the previous few years started life as video games and Ampere said commissions of IP have increased by an average 30% since 2019. Major studios, including Warner Bros. Discovery, Paramount, Netflix, Comcast, and Amazon have already secured rights to 10 marquee game franchises, with the likes of Mortal Kombat, Street Fighter and Legend of Zelda all coming up.

Driven by the recent success of high-profile titles such as The Last of Us and A Minecraft Movie, the market has shifted decisively towards live-action adaptations and away from animation, added the research firm. In 2025, 69% of commissioned adaptations were live action, more than double the share from the previous year. In the second half of 2025 alone, 18 new game adaptations were commissioned, with 78% of these live action.

Alyson Gorske (Obliterated) stars as â€œa young woman trapped in a macabre fever dream, ruthlessly exploring the cages we create for ourselves and others in complex human relationshipsâ€. She will be joined onscreen by genre vet Thomas Dekker (Terminator: The Sarah Connor Chronicles).

Amir Moini, a former comms manager at Netflix, Chief Marketing Officer at Fangoria and current Tubi Director of Executive Communications, is directing the short, his second after Screamfest film Slashr.

Writer is Adam Van Dyke of Skull Globe Productions. Bria Oâ€™Brien and Sam Van Dyke will produce for Skull Globe Productions. Prince Chenoa will serve as executive producer for Galore. Production is due to begin in early 2026 in Castroville, California, known for its large artichokes.

Watch on Deadline

The full synopsis reads: â€œHeld captive in a violent relationship, a woman named Cynara (Gorske) discovers a phoropter that opens a portal to another world. In a terrifying cat and mouse chase between worlds, Cynara finally comes face to face with The Man (Dekker) and must decide what sheâ€™s willing to destroy, in order to survive.â€

â€œIâ€™m thrilled to be partnering with Skull Globe Productions, Galore, Anna, Thomas and Alyson to create Artichoke,â€ said Moini. â€œAs a lover of the visceral style of giallo and art-house cinema, we are excited to join together to create something that is both ethereal and haunting.â€

Dekker added: â€œArtichoke is pure cinema. An abstract peek into a thematically complex space where sensation and visual provocation reign and narrative questions are boldly asked and then left to hang in the ripe and dazzling air of its world.â€

title: Italy 2025 Box Office Holds Firm as Local Movies Rise, Led by Checco Zalone Hit â€˜Buen Caminoâ€™
summary: Italyâ€™s box office remained basically stable in 2025, totaling roughly â‚¬496 million ($576 million) in grosses and 68 million admissions â€” which is slightly above the countryâ€™s 2024 intake of â‚¬494 million ($577 million).Â  But the year marked a major shift, with Italians flocking to see more homegrown movies, starting with local box office sensation […]
content:
Italyâ€™s box office remained basically stable in 2025, totaling roughly â‚¬496 million ($576 million) in grosses and 68 million admissions â€” which is slightly above the countryâ€™s 2024 intake of â‚¬494 million ($577 million).

But the year marked a major shift, with Italians flocking to see more homegrown movies, starting with local box office sensation Checco Zaloneâ€™s new smash hit â€œBuen Camino.â€ The film easily conquered the 2025 top spot, scoring more than â‚¬36 million ($42 million) in just one week following its Dec. 25 release, according to figures from national box office compiler Cinetel.

The latest comedy by Zalone â€” in which he plays a rich and debauched 50-something father who zips around in a red Ferrari searching for his runaway teenage daughter along the path of Spainâ€™s world famous Camino de Santiago spiritual pilgrimage â€” has now pulled more than â‚¬53 million ($61 million) via Italyâ€™s Medusa, and counting.

Popular on Variety

But unlike other years in which a single Zalone hit accounted for most of the domestic slice of Italyâ€™s box office pie, the year 2025 saw three Italian titles ensconced among the countryâ€™s top 10. Besides â€œBuen Camino,â€ the other two movies are concept comedy â€œMadlyâ€ by director Paolo Genovese (â€œPerfect Strangersâ€), which pulled $21 million via 01 Distribution â€” landing at No. 3 on the 2025 chart â€” and Ferzan Ozpetekâ€™s female-centric ensemble drama â€œDiamonds,â€ which weighed in at No. 8 with a $19 million take via Vision Distribution.

During 2025, homegrown titles in Italy enjoyed the best box office level of the past decade, Cinetel underlined in a statement. Italian movies, including co-productions, generated more than â‚¬160 million ($187 million) in grosses last year, scoring more than 22.5 million admissions and a roughly 33% admissions share, up from 25.7% in 2024.

Meanwhile, Hollywood still accounted for more than 50% of the Italian market share, with Disney continuing to be the countryâ€™s dominant distributor thanks mainly to animated titles â€œLilo & Stitchâ€ and â€œZootopia 2â€ as well as James Cameronâ€™s â€œAvatar: Fire and Ash.â€

Cinetel, in its preliminary 2025 analysis, noted that the country saw relatively robust moviegoing figures in the summer â€” which is historically a sore spot as millions of Italians hit the beach â€” and that moviegoing gained plenty of momentum toward the end of the year. December 2025, which saw the releases of both â€œAvatar: Fire and Ashâ€ and Zaloneâ€™s â€œBuen Camino,â€ marked Italyâ€™s strongest box office month since 1995, which is the year that Cinetel began collecting data, â€œconfirming the central role that holidays play in supporting overall results,â€ the statement said.

Though Italian moviegoing remains well below pre-pandemic levels â€” when admissions hovered around 100 million â€” the countryâ€™s current box office stability is encouraging compared to the moviegoing crisis looming in some other European countries, especially Spain, which in 2025 saw an 8% decline to 65 million admissions. January Italian releases expected to keep the momentum going include Paolo Sorrentinoâ€™s Venice 2025 opener â€œLa Graziaâ€ and Josh Safdieâ€™s TimothÃ©e Chalamet-starrer â€œMarty Supreme.â€

content:
Comcast has officially completed its separation from the new Versant Media, ending Comcastâ€™s ownership of a wealth of news and cable networks.

After being confirmed by the board late last year, Comcast said this morning that Versant had become a separate public company effective 11.59 p.m. ET (8.59 p.m. PT) on January 2. Comcast shareholders received one share of Versant Class A common stock or Versant Class B common stock for every 25 shares of Comcast Class A common stock or Comcast Class B common stock, respectively, held at the close of business on December 16, 2025, while the distribution of Versant shares occurred after the close of trading on Nasdaq on January 2, 2026, Comcast said.

Versant immediately sent out a release saying that the new company had commence trading on the Nasdaq under the ticker symbol VSNT.

title: â€˜Stranger Thingsâ€™ Documentary Sets Netflix Release Date; Trailer Takes Fans Inside the Making of the Final Season and Last Day on Set
summary: Netflix has set the premiere date and released a trailer for its previously unannounced documentary that followed the making of the final season of “Stranger Things,” directed by Martina Radwan. “One Last Adventure: The Making of Stranger Things 5” will drop on Jan. 12, and according to its logline it will provide, “An inside look […]
content:
Netflix has set the premiere date and released a trailer for its previously unannounced documentary that followed the making of the final season of â€œStranger Things,â€ directed by Martina Radwan. â€œOne Last Adventure: The Making of Stranger Things 5â€ will drop on Jan. 12, and according to its logline it will provide, â€œAn inside look at the years of effort and craft that went into the final installment of the Duffer Brothersâ€˜ generation-defining series.â€

Being able to get close and watching them bring this beloved show to life in real time, was pure joy. I only wish I could travel back and document Seasons 1 through 4. From the cast to their long-time collaborators, everyone welcomed me with remarkable generosity, openly sharing their personal and collective experiences from a decade of creative filmmaking, always pushing the boundaries. The Duffers inspire everyone to be better, including myself, their process and the show represents everything I love about filmmaking.â€

Ross Duffer and Jamie Campbell Bower Courtesy of Niko Tavernise/Netflix

The trailer for the documentary begins by showing snippets from the final table read of â€œStranger Things,â€ as Ross Duffer says in voiceover, â€œWriting the last lines these characters would ever say, it was really hard to do.â€ Matt Duffer adds, â€œI remember more than anything just writing â€˜End Series.â€™ Writing those two words having the biggest impactâ€ as Noah Schnapp and Millie Bobby Brown cry on a couch during the table read, and Schnapp nuzzles into Cara Buono (who plays Karen Wheeler). The trailer then shows stills of the young cast from the showâ€™s earliest days. David Bowieâ€™s â€œHeroes,â€ which â€œStranger Thingsâ€ used more than once, including over the end credit in the series finale, plays as the trailer continues. The documentary also goes inside the writersâ€™ room, as Duffers discuss the fate of Eleven (Brown). Later, Brown in voiceover says, â€œIâ€™m not ready to let go.â€

Popular on Variety

The trailer ends with Ross Duffer, on the final day of filming, saying, â€œAnd that is a wrap on â€˜Stranger Things,'â€ as confetti falls from the ceiling. (Do read Varietyâ€˜s oral history of the last days of â€œStranger Things.â€)

In a statement accompanying the announcement, the Duffer brothers said: â€œGrowing up in Durham, North Carolina, we dreamed of becoming filmmakers â€” but Hollywood felt impossibly far away. Everything changed when we watched the behind-the-scenes documentaries for â€˜The Lord of the Ringsâ€™ â€” on-the-ground films that showed the real nuts and bolts of how a massive production actually gets made. We saw how stressed Peter Jackson was and thought: yep, thatâ€™s the dream. With the decline of physical media, that kind of behind-the-scenes storytelling has largely disappeared. We wanted to bring it back. â€˜One Last Adventure: The Making of Stranger Things Season 5â€™ â€” beautifully captured and directed by Martina Radwan â€” is our attempt to do just that. If you love â€˜Stranger Things,â€™ or if youâ€™re simply curious how a major Hollywood production comes to life, this oneâ€™s for you.â€

â€œOne Last Adventure: The Making of Stranger Things 5â€ is a MakeMake Production, produced by Angus Wall, Terry Leonard and Kent Kubena.

content:
Tim Walz, the Democratic vice presidential nominee in 2024, abandoned his campaign for a third term as governor of Minnesota.

Walz had announced last fall his plans to seek another term.

But a fraud scandal over the stateâ€™s welfare reemerged as a primary election issue in recent weeks, after a conservative influencerâ€™s video went viral with claims that Somali run day care centers were illegally taking money.

Even though local outlets have countered with their own fact checks of the viral video, it has led to federal funding for child care in the state being frozen. Donald Trump and Republicans have sought to pin the blame for the scandal on Walz, even though he has not been accused of wrongdoing.

â€œFor the last several years, an organized group of criminals have sought to take advantage of the stateâ€™s generosity. And even as we make progress in the fight against the fraudsters, we now see an organized group of political actors seeking to take advantage of this crisis,â€ Walz said in a statement.

Watch on Deadline

Walz said that as he reflected on the race over the holidays, he â€œcame to the conclusion that I canâ€™t give a political campaign my all.â€

â€œEvery minute I spend defending my own political interests would be a minute I canâ€™t spend defending the people of Minnesota against the criminals who prey on our generosity and the cynics who prey on our differences.â€

Walz was a relative unknown on the national stage when Kamala Harris picked him to be her running mate in the last presidential election. Unlike Harris, who decided against a bid for California governor this year, Walz decided to forge ahead on his own political career. The last figure to seek more than two terms, Rudy Perpich, was defeated in 1990 by Arne Carlson, who was designated as the replacement candidate just days before the election after the Republican nominee dropped out due to a scandal. Democrats have held the governorship in the state since 2011.

In addition, Dish asserts that Disneyâ€™s acquisition of Fubo (which it has merged with Huluâ€™s live TV business) and the introduction of the ESPN-Fox One bundle violate antitrust laws by â€œeliminating competition.â€ By buying Fubo, Disney â€œeffectively hoards consumer-friendly sports options for itself and blocks alternative skinny bundles,â€ according to a Dish rep.

Furthermore, Dish alleges that Disney is attempting to corner the â€œskinny sports bundle marketâ€ through the launch of the ESPN Unlimited stand-alone streaming service, as well as by acquiring Fubo and enforcing â€œrestrictive contracts.â€ Through those actions, Dishâ€™s legal filings claim, Disney is attempting to ensure it is the only provider of â€œflexibleâ€ sports packages, which artificially inflate consumer prices.

title: Evangeline Lilly Says She Has Brain Damage After Traumatic Fall: â€˜Almost Every Area in My Brain Is Functioning at a Decreased Capacityâ€™

content:
Evangeline Lilly revealed on social media that she has brain damage after suffering a concussion last year when she fell into a boulder. The â€œLostâ€ and â€œAnt-Manâ€ star said that â€œalmost every area in my brain is functioning at a decreased capacity.â€

â€œIâ€™m entering into this new year, the Year of the Horse, with some bad news about my concussion,â€ the Marvel actor said in an Instagram video. â€œA lot of you asked how Iâ€™m doing. A lot of you have inquired about the brain scans that you heard I got. And the results came back from the scans [and] showed that almost every area in my brain is functioning at a decreased capacity.â€

â€œBut now my job is to get to the bottom of that with doctors and then embark on the hard work of fixing it, which I donâ€™t look forward to because I feel like hard work is all I do,â€ Lilly added. â€œBut thatâ€™s okay. My cognitive decline since I smashed my face open has helped me to slow down and helped me to have a more restful finish to my 2025.â€

Popular on Variety

Lilly wrote in the caption to her post: â€œVerdictâ€™s inâ€¦ I do have brain damage from my [traumatic brain injury]. Comforting to know my cognitive decline isnâ€™t just peri-menopause, discomforting to know what an uphill battle it will be to try to reverse the deficiencies. Thank you all for always asking, for always caring, and for your continued prayers.â€

Lilly starred as Kate Bishop on all six seasons of â€œLost,â€ which ran from 2004 to 2010. Her performance earned her a nomination for the Golden Globe Award for best actress in a drama series. Sheâ€™s also well known for playing Hope van Dyne/Wasp in the Marvel Cinematic Universe, debuting as the character in 2015â€™s â€œAnt-Manâ€ and reprising her in 2018â€™s â€œAnt-Man and the Wasp,â€ 2019â€™s â€œAvengers: Endgame,â€ and 2023â€™s â€œAnt-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania.â€ Lilly also played Tauriel in Peter Jacksonâ€™s â€œThe Hobbitâ€ trilogy, appearing in the latter two films â€œThe Desolation of Smaugâ€ and â€œThe Battle of the Five Armies.â€

In a social media post last June, Lilly revealed she was stepping away from acting for the foreseeable future and wrote: â€œStepping away from what seems like the obvious choice (wealth and fame) can feel scary at times, but stepping into your dharma replaces the fear with fulfillment. I might return to Hollywood one day, but, for now, this is where I belong.â€

Lilly added in a statement to Variety at the time: â€œI have actually been on a hiatus from acting for the past three years already (since finishing work on â€˜Quantumaniaâ€™). This time outside of the business has brought me a grounding sense of fulfillment and joy. I could return tomorrow, two years from now or never, but at the moment I am not actively pursuing any work in the industry and am not under any contractual obligations to anybody. I am devoting my time to my humanitarian work and my writing.â€

content:
Dionne Warwick, Saweetie and Mya have joined forces to record a new version of the Diane Warren-penned song â€œOne Heart (Can Change The World)â€ as title song from the forthcoming film, â€œOZi: Voice of the Forest,â€ both of which are intended to raise awareness of the dangers of climate change, focusing on last yearâ€™s Los Angeles wildfires. The song was produced by Grammy-winner Damon Elliott and the film by Mike Medavoy, in conjunction with Leonard DiCaprioâ€™s Appian Way Productions and GCI Film. Elliott and Warren both lost their homes in the fires last January. This music will be released in the spring.

â€œOZi: Voice of the Forestâ€ is a family film that focuses on the story of an orangutan who is separated from her parents. OZi grows up in an animal sanctuary and uses her influencer skills to save her parents and forest home from deforestation. The film aims to raise awareness around the issues faced by rainforests due to the growing levels of deforestation, and how this affects ecosystems and climate change.

Popular on Variety

The film features the voices of Laura Dern, Amandla Stenberg, Donald Sutherland, Djimon Hounsou, RuPaul Charles, Dean Charles Chapman and Urzila Carlson.

â€œI am honored to have produced this song, and have it support this cause, as I was personally affected by these tragic fires a year ago,â€ Elliott says. â€œI lost my home and literally everything in it. â€˜Oziâ€™ definitely tugs at my heartstring as it deals with fires caused by climate change.â€

â€œWarren says, â€œI was inspired to write the song by watching the movie which so beautifully illustrates that Ozi and all of us, with our one heart, can truly change the world.â€

Medavoy adds, â€œWe are proud to support this initiative. The story of Ozi has such strong links with the LA fires, homes being lost due to fire all driven by climate change.â€

The proceeds from the sales of the music and film will be donated to the charities International Animal Rescue and Sumatran Orangutan.

title: Amazonâ€™s Fire TV Getting Major User Interface Upgrade
summary: Amazon is rolling out the biggest update to its Fire TV user interface in years — designed to help you find something to watch even faster. The new UI will start rolling out in February, initially in the U.S. on the most recent Fire TV devices, and Amazon will be demo’ing it at 2026 CES […]
content:
Amazon is rolling out the biggest update to its Fire TV user interface in years â€” designed to help you find something to watch even faster.

The new UI will start rolling out in February, initially in the U.S. on the most recent Fire TV devices, and Amazon will be demoâ€™ing it at 2026 CES in Las Vegas this week. Along with the UI redesign, the company is prepping the release of a new Fire TV mobile app that adds content discovery and management tools, and itâ€™s introducing our first-ever lifestyle TV, the Amazon Ember Artline.

According to Joshua Danovitz, Amazonâ€™s VP of Fire TV, the new UI is overall more â€œmodernâ€ â€” cleaner, faster and better organized. The interface displays movies, TV shows, sports, news and live content across all your subscriptions, so that when you browse the UI you will see titles and programming from all the apps you use.

Popular on Variety

The new Fire TV UI features rounded corners, redesigned color gradients, updated typography and more optimized spacing. Beyond the aesthetics, the underlying code was rebuilt to make the experience faster: Danovitz said in some cases the new UI is up to 30% faster.

The redesign also increases the number of apps users can pin to the Fire TV home screen, from six to 20. The Menu button on the Fire TV remote lets you access Games, Art & Photos, and the Ambient Experience with a few clicks. Thereâ€™s also a shortcut panel on the right rail you can access by long-pressing the Home button on the remote, to let you add shortcuts the controls including audio and display settings and smart-home device management.

Fire TV will continue to include Alexa+, Amazonâ€™s generative AI-powered agent, to let you ask to watch something based on the mood youâ€™re in, who youâ€™re with, or actors or directors you like. Alexa on Fire TV also recently added to ability for you to ask to jump straight to a specific movie scene.

The new Fire TV UI will launch starting in February on the Fire TV Stick 4K Plus, Fire TV Stick 4K Max (2nd generation), and Fire TV Omni Mini-LED Series in the U.S. Later this spring, Amazon plans to expand the new UI design to more countries and more devices, including the latest-generation Fire TV 4K streaming media players and TVs including the Fire TV 2-Series, Fire TV 4-Series, Fire TV Omni QLED Series as well as TVs from partners like Hisense, Insignia, Panasonic and TCL.

Updated Fire TV mobile app

Also launching in February is a redesigned Fire TV mobile app â€” which until now has essentially functioned as a backup remote control.

The redesigned Fire TV mobile app (which will be available as a free download) adds the ability to browse content, manage your watchlist, and play titles on your TV, with a look and feel that matches the new Fire TV design, according to Danovitz. Now Fire TV customers can use their phone as a second screen to discover what to watch next or add a friendâ€™s show recommendation to your watchlist when youâ€™re away from home.

Also at CES, Amazon will show off its first lifestyle TV, under the new brand name Amazon Ember. The Amazon Ember Artline is a 4K QLED TV designed to be hung on the wall like a piece of artwork.

The Amazon Ember Artline is the companyâ€™s thinnest TV to date, measuring just 1.5 inches deep, and will be available 10 different frame colors (walnut, ash, teak, black oak, matte white, midnight blue, fig, pale gold, graphite and silver). The TVs have a matte screen (to reduce glare) and will be available in 55- or 65-inch screen sizes, priced starting at $899. Itâ€™s scheduled to go on sale this spring in the U.S., Canada, Germany, and the U.K.

As with its previous-generation TVs, the Amazon Ember Artline comes with far-field microphones to support Alexa+ and includes its Omnisense technology that automatically turns the ambient experience on and off when people enter or leave the room. The Ember Artline is integrated with Amazon Photos and offers more than 2,000 pieces of free art. It also has an AI-powered feature that lets you take up to four photos of the room where you plan to hang the TV and get personalized recommendations on the best artworks to show on-screen to match the dÃ©cor.

title: â€˜The Singersâ€™ Filmmaker Sam Davis On Making A â€œSneaky Crowd-Pleaserâ€Â That Landed The Oscars Shortlist
summary: Sometimes inspiration can come from the most unlikely of places. In the case of the Oscar-nominated, multi-hyphenate filmmaker Sam Davis, motivation came from an old Russian short story and the social media juggernauts Instagram and TikTok. Davisâ€™s short film, The Singers, based on the Ivan Turgenev story of the same name, follows a varied group […]
content:
Sometimes inspiration can come from the most unlikely of places. In the case of the Oscar-nominated, multi-hyphenate filmmaker Sam Davis, motivation came from an old Russian short story and the social media juggernauts Instagram and TikTok. Davisâ€™s short film, The Singers, based on the Ivan Turgenev story of the same name, follows a varied group of down-on-their-luck men who find themselves making a connection with one another through an impromptu singing competition.

The 17-minute short has garnered wins for Best Director and Best International Film at HollyShorts London, the Grand Prize for Best Narrative Short and Audience Choice Award for Narrative at the Indy Shorts International Film Festival and Best Cinematography in the Professional Competition at SCAD Film Festival.

Here, Davis talks to Deadline about the vulnerability of men and the fun, creative challenge of turning talented buskers into lowkey film stars.

Watch on Deadline

DEADLINE: What compelled you to adapt Ivan Turgenevâ€™s story? And what themes were you trying to convey to the audience?

SAM DAVIS: There were a few things that sparked for me when I read the short story. Initially, I wasnâ€™t thinking about adapting it, and I even fell asleep a couple of times while reading it because itâ€™s dense and tough to get through [laughs]. But by the time I did, I was so taken by this unexpected testament to the power of connection through singing. You could extend the bookâ€™s ideation to art of any kind or the concept of vulnerability. The characters in the story are these crusty, hard-shell underdogs who reminded me a lot of the people I grew up around, in particular. Iâ€™m from a small town in Michigan, and there were a lot of these people who were really soulful and complete with talents and passions, but you wouldnâ€™t know it at first glance.

Then, I saw this project as a unique opportunity for me as a filmmaker to apply my background in documentary work in a fiction piece that could be a hat tip to Robert Altman and some of my other favorite filmmakers like ChloÃ© Zhao, Sean Baker and the Safdie brothers, who are modern examples of people synthesizing narrative and documentary in their own way.

DEADLINE: You found your singers on Instagram and TikTok? Walk us through that.

DAVIS: As I mentioned earlier, I enjoyed the short story the first time I read it, but I didnâ€™t close the book and think, â€œThis is for me. The next three years, Iâ€™m dedicated to making this, a film adaptation of this story.â€ That moment didnâ€™t come until a few minutes later when I opened my phone and looked at Instagram. The first video was a viral clip of this incredible New York City busker, Mike Yung. It was an unbelievable performance [of â€œUnchained Melodyâ€] that I was watching and so moved by. I saw people passing by without paying much attention to him, and I also read a story about all these modern-day viral-video singing sensations who, for whatever reason, had never really broken through. So, thatâ€™s where the idea came from. This was the idea of basically filling a bar with these unexpected geniuses, letting them shine, and giving them a stage theyâ€™ve never had but always deserved.

DEADLINE: How did you end up pitching these guys?

DAVIS: When I reached out, most of them thought they were being scammed. I would reach out and tell them, â€œHey, Iâ€™m an Oscar-nominated filmmaker in LA trying to do this new project.â€ And they were like, â€œGo to Hell.â€ Itâ€™s a long story, but basically, my documentary background came into play. Docs are about, at least in the development and pre-production stages, building relationships with people before a camera is even turned on and gaining a sense of mutual trust. I have to trust that theyâ€™ll be able to deliver on some level and be vulnerable on camera. They have to trust that theyâ€™re not being scammed and that theyâ€™ll be represented with respect. So, getting everyone together was this long, arduous, and clumsy process of scrolling whenever I had an opportunity, leaving comments, sending DMs, and eventually it all just came together into this eclectic group of guys from all over the world who had never been on camera before. And who were all willing to take a leap after getting to know each other a bit via Zoom and phone calls.

DEADLINE: When did you know which songs you were going to feature in the short film?

DAVIS: Not until the day before we filmed. The whole process was radical: we just went all in on spontaneity and having real people in one room and took a documentary approach to a narrative film. Because of that, I didnâ€™t feel I could commit to a specific song until I heard it from the singerâ€™s voice in the space where we were going to film. Unfortunately, with the tiny, short-film budget, we couldnâ€™t get them in that space until the day before the shoot. It was impractical because these guys were all coming from all over the place to LA to film. Thereâ€™s an exception with Mike Yung, the bartender, who was the first [cast], he sang â€œUnchained Melodyâ€ in that viral video and in the short film. That was always going to be his performance. But for the rest of them, it was just a conversation. We sat together in the bar the day before the shoot and talked until we eventually landed on these songs you hear in the film.

DEADLINE: What was the most challenging thing to adapt?

DAVIS: Iâ€™ll talk about the bar first. I like that the bar in the story is this one building, and the opening shot is this dark void next to the railroad tracks. In a way, the bar is a visual metaphor for each of the guys in the bar. These are all these unsuspecting little containers for so much story. And in that bar, little do you know in the opening, but thereâ€™s a huge world of lived experience, possibilities, song, and connection that will come out of that little room, and thatâ€™s what each of the characters is about. When we were casting, we didnâ€™t just want people who could sing. We wanted people who would bring real-life experience that would enhance their characters, like an ingredient that could explode outward and affect the story in different ways. For example, two war veterans could talk to each other, which was an idea that we didnâ€™t have until we found ourselves there. These two guys were genuinely sharing their experiences: one in Vietnam and the other in Afghanistan.

The idea of the bar we ended up filming in was inspired by a [place I grew up near] in Michigan, where I always imagined shooting [a film]. However, it became impractical to get everyone to this small town in Michigan, so we ultimately decided to do it in LA and just fake the exteriors. We spent a lot of time hunting for the right bar, because we didnâ€™t want anything too precious and cute. Just like the guys in the film, I didnâ€™t want to cast people who were going to get right back to me or those with websites and managers; I wanted to hunt and chase. I wanted the type of person who maybe didnâ€™t want to be found. My ideology was the same as finding this bar. I knew this bar wasnâ€™t going to show up on Eaterâ€™s list of coolest dive bars in LA [laughs]. We eventually found it after exhausting hundreds of bars in LA and the surrounding areas â€“ Moose Lodge. Itâ€™s a non-commercial, private, members-only bar in La Habra, and it just had the right vibe.

Secondly, pulling this cast together and getting all of these guys under one roof felt like a mini miracle by the time we were there at the Moose Lodge. Iâ€™ll never forget walking in and seeing all these faces. We spent a year and a half handpicking from all over the internet to find them. It was this really jovial and strange bringing together of different people, and like in the film, there was this evolution from a group of 20 to 30 strangers, plus our crew, into a little family by the end.

DEADLINE: Whatâ€™s your musical style?

DAVIS: Keeping in line with The Singers, I think the film has the spirit of John Prine and Leonard Cohen. Thereâ€™s a Leonard Cohen song [â€œClosing Timeâ€] in the end credits, which I am so thrilled that we were able to get.

DEADLINE: Youâ€™ve made the rounds at SXSW, Hollyshorts, AFI and SCAD, to name a few. Now youâ€™ve landed the Oscar shortlist. What do you think people are responding to?

DAVIS: The film is a sneaky crowd-pleaser. It starts rather calmly, but by the end of it, maybe youâ€™ve cried a bit, or have been touched by it or laughed. Itâ€™s a full meal of emotion. I hope people are enjoying it in that sense. Also, I donâ€™t think itâ€™s a political film. A lot of Oscar films, docs and narratives tend to be political. This film is more soulful than political. Of course, though, we can unpack it and talk about vulnerability and masculinity. All those things are real, and those themes are in there. Thereâ€™s a David Lynch quote that I love, where he says, â€œThe film is the talking,â€ which is this thing of, after watching something, we talk about this and that and beat things to death. But I think those themes are important. Growing up in a small town in Michigan, where we werenâ€™t really taught how to process, men especially, our emotions in a healthy way â€“ thatâ€™s something I still work through to this day. And for me, the art of filmmaking is a great outlet. In a lot of ways, thatâ€™s whatâ€™s happening in the story, the beautiful act of being vulnerable and connecting with a stranger next to you, who, 10 minutes ago, you thought had nothing in common with you. I think that message has a universal application.

[This interview has been edited for length and clarity]

As the epidemic spreads, Jeremy (Jeremy Pope), a desperate outsider, is caught in the chaos, searching for purpose as the agents race across Paris, Venice, Rome and New York to stop a threat that could alter the future of humanity.

title: Box Office 2026 Predictions: Will â€˜The Odyssey,â€™ â€˜Avengers: Doomsdayâ€™ and a New â€˜Star Warsâ€™ Finally Propel Grosses Above $9 Billion?
summary: For long-suffering movie theaters, salvation always seems to be just around the corner.   In 2026, many of the biggest film franchises in history are returning to screens. Itâ€™s a squadron of high- profile spinoffs and sequels to everything from â€œThe Avengersâ€ (with Robert Downey Jr. and Chris Evans back in spandex) to â€œStar Wars,â€ with a smattering of Mario and Luigi and Buzz and Woody in between.   But since […]
content:
For long-suffering movie theaters, salvation always seems to be just around the corner.



In 2026, many of the biggest film franchises in history are returning to screens. Itâ€™s a squadron of high- profile spinoffs and sequels to everything from â€œThe Avengersâ€ (with Robert Downey Jr. and Chris Evans back in spandex) to â€œStar Wars,â€ with a smattering of Mario and Luigi and Buzz and Woody in between.



But since COVID upended the movie business, the box office has never been harder to predict. Last year, Marvel, once the most consistent hit â€“ maker in Hollywood, saw one hyped-up superhero movie after another fail to connect with audiences, while auteur-driven films like â€œSinnersâ€ and anime offerings like â€œDemon Slayer: Kimetsu no Yaiba Infinity Castleâ€ became some of 2025â€™s most unlikely successes.



So , with that caveat out of the way, weâ€™re staring into our crystal ball and going out on a limb to predict the movies that will struggle or soar over the next 12 months.

Sure Things

Matt Damon in â€œ The Odyssey Universal Pictures

The Super Mario Galaxy Movie (Universal)

Release date: April 3

Thrill factor: Generations of gamers have traveled to the Mushroom Kingdom, a familiarity that helped turn â€œThe Super Mario Bros. Movieâ€ into a billion-dollar smash. The follow-up should get a similar reception, particularly as it has the spring box office more or less to itself.

Chill factor: Video game adaptations like â€œA Minecraft Movieâ€ and â€œSonic the Hedgehogâ€ have been one of the only genres that have reliably worked. Could we be nearing oversaturation?

Verdict: Who are we kidding? The Nintendo brand is king, and those mustachioed siblings are its most beloved ambassadors.

Popular on Variety

Toy Story 5 (Disney)

Release date: June 19

Thrill factor: â€œToy Storyâ€ represents Pixar at its best, and this installment â€” which confronts the reality that children would rather play with screens than dolls â€” feels like a timely reason to revisit the animated world of talking toys.

Chill factor: Maybe the tech-forward premise will hit too close to home for parents who prefer to park their kids in front of iPads at restaurants?

Verdict: Woody and Buzz might be afraid of smart tablets, but they neednâ€™t worry about box office grosses. â€œToy Story 5â€ will be the biggest family film of the year.

The Odyssey (Universal)

Release date: July 17

Thrill factor: Christopher Nolan turned the life story of J. Robert Oppenheimer into a silver-screen sensation. The Trojan War sounds a lot more commercial, and it helps that the actors filling out the tunics include A-listers like Matt Damon, Tom Holland and Zendaya.

Chill factor: Homer? During the summer? Sounds like homework.

Verdict: July belongs to Nolan, who has debuted blockbusters such as â€œThe Dark Knightâ€ and â€œDunkirkâ€ at the height of popcorn season. â€œThe Odysseyâ€ will join the club.

Spider-Man: Brand New Day (Sony)

Release date: July 31

Thrill factor: Tom Holland is dusting off his Spidey suit for the first time since 2021â€™s â€œNo Way Homeâ€ became a bonanza with $1.9 billion. That film ended on a massive cliff-hanger, meaning a lot of people have been waiting to see what happens after Peter Parker makes the difficult decision to erase his identity from the world.

Chill factor: â€œNo Way Homeâ€ became a cinematic event in part because multiversal shenanigans allowed two prior Spider-Men, Andrew Garfield and Tobey Maguire, to save the day with Holland. Will hype be as high with just one Spidey on-screen?

Verdict: Marvel might be waning in box office popularity, but Spider-Man remains on the comic book A-list.

Safe Bets

Baby Yoda in â€œThe Mandalorian and Groguâ€ LUCASFILM

The Mandalorian and Grogu (Disney)

The Mandalorian and Grogu â€” Disney

Release date: May 22

Thrill factor: The last â€œStar Warsâ€ movie, 2019â€™s billion-dollar blockbuster â€œThe Rise of Skywalker,â€ was released seven long years ago. In the time since, Baby Yoda (nÃ© the Child nÃ© Grogu) has become a household name through the very popular Disney+ series â€œThe Mandalorian.â€

Chill factor: Lucasfilm has struggled for what feels like eons to get a theatrical release off the ground. Meanwhile, Disney+ has become the go-to destination for all things set in a galaxy far, far away with shows ranging from â€œThe Book of Boba Fettâ€ and â€œAhsokaâ€ to â€œAndor.â€ Do audiences still associate â€œStar Warsâ€ with the cinematic experience, or is it a franchise they now prefer to watch at home?

Verdict: â€œThe Mandalorian and Groguâ€ will benefit from goodwill and brand recognition. However, not every â€œStar Warsâ€ spinoff will feel the box office Force.

Avengers: Doomsday (Disney)

Release date: Dec. 18

Thrill factor: Downey and Evans return to the MCU, bringing the two mightiest heroes back into the fold. Theyâ€™re joined by fan-favorite characters from â€œThe X-Menâ€ and â€œThe Fantastic Fourâ€ in a true â€œthe gangâ€™s all hereâ€ extravaganza.

Chill factor: Superhero fatigue is real, and Marvel canâ€™t seem to shake it. The studioâ€™s last few films â€” â€œThunderbolts,â€ â€œCaptain America: Brave New Worldâ€ and â€œThe Fantastic Four: First Stepsâ€ â€” all disappointed at the box office.

Verdict: Absence makes the heart grow fonder. Itâ€™s been six years since the last â€œAvengersâ€ adventures, and Evans and Downeyâ€™s presence will make this sequel a bona fide event.

Verity (Amazon MGM)

Release date: Oct. 2

Thrill factor: Colleen Hoover might be the new box office whisperer after â€œIt Ends With Usâ€ became a sleeper success for Sony, and â€œRegretting Youâ€ was one of Paramountâ€™s only 2025 releases to turn a theatrical profit. â€œVerity,â€ which follows a struggling writer hired to complete a popular book series after the potentially unhinged author becomes injured, promises deliciously campy performances from stars Dakota Johnson and Anne Hathaway.

Chill factor: Adult-oriented fare is, alas, always a risk in post-pandemic times.

Verdict: Twisty thrillers are fun to watch with crowds, so â€œVerityâ€ will become a breakout with women in the vein of â€œThe Housemaidâ€ or â€œA Simple Favor.â€

Question Marks

Ryan Gosling in â€œProject Hail Maryâ€ Screenshot courtesy YouTube/Amazon MGM

Project Hail Mary (Amazon MGM)

Release date: March 20

Thrill factor: Phil Lord and Christopher Miller are returning to the directorâ€™s chair for the first time since 2014â€™s â€œ22 Jump Street.â€ With â€œProject Hail Mary,â€ the very funny filmmakers team up with the endlessly charming Ryan Gosling on a sci-fi adventure about an amnesiac astronaut tasked with saving the world from Armageddon.

Chill factor: Amazon MGM doesnâ€™t have a track record of launching original properties, and with a hefty $150 million budget, â€œProject Hail Maryâ€ needs to pack â€™em in to justify its price tag.

Verdict: Gosling, a versatile actor who should have won an Oscar for his performance of â€œIâ€™m Just Kenâ€ at the Academy Awards ceremony, isnâ€™t a bankable star. After all, his 2024 action comedy â€œThe Fall Guyâ€ misfired theatrically despite great reviews. That means quality wonâ€™t be enough to get people to multiplexes. Itâ€™s up to the studioâ€™s marketing department to turn the film into a must-see cinematic event.

Disclosure Day (Universal)

Release date: June 12

Thrill factor: For decades, Steven Spielberg has been synonymous with blockbuster entertainment. Now, the man who made â€œIndiana Jonesâ€ and â€œE.T.â€ returns to spectacle-style filmmaking with an alien-invasion adventure.

Chill factor: Does the old master still have it? Spielbergâ€™s spent most of the past 20 years directing Oscar bait like â€œBridge of Spiesâ€ and â€œLincoln.â€ Has he outgrown his populist roots?

Verdict: The title sounds like a bad airplane novel, but the trailer delivers plenty of thrills. Itâ€™s just hard to convince people to turn out for something that isnâ€™t based on a game or a known property.

Clayface (Warner Bros.)

Release date: Sept. 11

Thrill factor: With comic book adaptations, audiences are fine with familiar faces but clearly arenâ€™t settling for more of the same story. In that respect, â€œClayface,â€ a body-horror film about a struggling actor with a disfigured face who takes drastic measures to transform his body into clay, feels vastly different from â€œBrave New World,â€ â€œThunderboltsâ€ and the family-friendly â€œSuperman.â€

Chill factor: Has anyone, on this planet or any other, ever heard of Clayface?

Verdict: James Gunn and Peter Safran may have revived the DCU with â€œSuperman,â€ but not every comic book character is worthy of the big-screen treatment.

Practical Magic 2 (Warner Bros)

Release date: Sept. 18

Thrill factor: Nearly 30 years after the first â€œPractical Magicâ€ became a cult hit on home entertainment â€” remember VHS? â€” Sandra Bullock and Nicole Kidman reunite for another supernatural rom-com.

Chill factor: Itâ€™s worth noting that â€œPractical Magicâ€ flopped when it was released in 1998. Given Bullock and Kidmanâ€™s price tags, Warners is probably banking on them casting a stronger spell on moviegoers in 2025.

Verdict: Nostalgia is powerful â€” just look at other long-gestating sequels like â€œTop Gun: Maverickâ€ and â€œBeetlejuice, Beetlejuice.â€ But this follow-up feels random. Besides Bullock and Kidmanâ€™s agents, whoâ€™s asking for this?

Biggest Risks

Jessie Buckley as Frankensteinâ€™s monsterâ€™s betrothed in â€œThe Brideâ€ Â©Warner Bros/Courtesy Everett Collection

The Bride! (Warner Bros.)

Release date: March 6

Thrill factor: Audiences have been flipping for auteur-driven horror films such as Ryan Cooglerâ€™s â€œSinnersâ€ and Robert Eggersâ€™ â€œNosferatu.â€ Maggie Gyllenhaal, who impressed with her directorial debut, â€œThe Lost Daughter,â€ is offering up a bold vision with her steampunk take on â€œFrankenstein.â€

Chill factor: Guillermo del Toro just did his own thing with Mary Shelley with last fallâ€™s â€œFrankenstein.â€ Some stories donâ€™t need to be revived again and again.

Verdict: The buzz on the $80 million production has been frightful. Unless critics swoon, audiences arenâ€™t showing up to see this undead couple in action.

Hoppers (Disney)

Release date: March 6

Thrill factor: Family films have, for the most part, been all the rage. And the most recent animated adventure was Decemberâ€™s â€œSpongeBobâ€ sequel, so â€œHoppersâ€ should benefit from pent-up demand.

Chill factor: Pixar hasnâ€™t successfully launched a new animated film since 2017â€™s musical hit â€œCoco.â€ Even last yearâ€™s positively reviewed â€œElioâ€ cratered at the box office. Plus, the plot â€” revolving around scientists who can transfer human consciousness to robotic animals â€” sounds kind of confusing.

Verdict: â€œHoppersâ€ needs to be undeniably great and marketable to parents of youngsters. Otherwise, Pixar is doomed to retreat into the world of sequels and possibly forced to send anything new to streaming.

Digger (Warner Bros.)

Release date: Oct. 2

Thrill factor: Itâ€™s been a while since Tom Cruise, who once worked with Spielberg and Scorsese, put himself in the hands of a true master. Heâ€™s got one of the greatest who ever slid behind a camera in Alejandro G. IÃ±Ã¡rritu.

Chill factor: These two are partnering on the story of a powerful man who tries to save humanity from a disaster heâ€™s unleashed. We just lived through Elon Musk and DOGE. Oh, and itâ€™s a comedy.

Verdict: Execution dependent. Cruiseâ€™s movies are pricey, so unless he gave WB a big bargain, he and IÃ±Ã¡rritu better deliver the next â€œTropic Thunder.â€
