title: â€˜This Show Is Whatever the Fâ€” We Want It to Beâ€™: How â€˜Industryâ€™ Expands the Sex, Drugs and Capitalist Debauchery in Season 4
summary: The actors are perched on red stoolsÂ at the dark mahogany bar in a 1920s-themed restaurant in Cardiff, Wales. Marisa Abela and Myhaâ€™la â€” who star in HBOâ€™s steamy, propulsive finance drama â€œIndustryâ€ â€” are filming a key scene for the showâ€™s upcoming season in which their characters, Yasmin Kara-Hanani and Harper Stern, are having an […]
content:
The actors are perched on red stools at the dark mahogany bar in a 1920s-themed restaurant in Cardiff, Wales. Marisa Abela and Myhaâ€™la â€” who star in HBOâ€™s steamy, propulsive finance drama â€œIndustryâ€ â€” are filming a key scene for the showâ€™s upcoming season in which their characters, Yasmin Kara-Hanani and Harper Stern, are having an uncharacteristic heart-to-heart. While barely touching the Negronis in front of them (itâ€™s actually watery tea, so itâ€™s understandable), the frenemies are almost competing to reveal their own deep, painful vulnerabilities. At one point, after telling Harper how â€œfucking jealousâ€ she is of her â€” and for the first time in five or six takes of this scene â€” Yasmin starts to cry. The tears are not in the script, but for creators, writers, showrunners and, now, directors Mickey Down and Konrad Kay, sitting behind monitors about 10 feet away, itâ€™s just the emotional ad-lib they were looking for. Kay vigorously fist-pumps the air while Down, sporting a blue â€œIndustry Writers Roomâ€ cap, jabs enthusiastically at the screen. â€œThatâ€™s it â€” thatâ€™s the shot,â€ he eagerly whispers to Down, his close friend since they met at Oxford University almost 20 years ago. â€œCut! Beautiful!â€ For all the sex, drugs, widespread debauchery and unintelligible financial jargon that has defined â€œIndustryâ€ since it launched in late 2020, itâ€™s the twisty-turny, sometimes-supportive, sometimes-backstabbing dynamic between damaged British heiress Yasmin and ruthless American overachiever Harper that has become the showâ€™s central axis. The two â€” who Abela likens to â€œsiblings in how they get away with saying so much to one anotherâ€ â€” are the sole survivors from the five fresh-faced would-be traders who arrived at fictitious bank Pierpoint & Co. in Season 1. Their diverging journeys since have effectively reflected the growing ambition and confidence of â€œIndustryâ€ itself. In the explosive Season 3 finale, which aired in September 2024, Yasmin opted for supposed stability, choosing a privileged life of grouse hunts and tweed jodhpurs on the vast country estate of aristocratic posho and failed entrepreneur Henry Muck (Kit Harington). Harper, meanwhile, agreed to become the Gen Z successor to a shadowy old money head of a bearish investment fund. Their arcs would appear to have been completed, as had Pierpointâ€™s. Its trading floor â€” the setting for most of the hostile financial bedlam â€” was last seen smothered in tarpaulin while awaiting closure after the bank was acquired by an Egyptian sovereign wealth fund. It looked like the perfect series closure for â€œIndustry.â€

â€œI could think of five different reasons why Yasmin and Harper should never speak to each other again â€” I would never talk to this bitch if it was me in real life!,â€ says Myhaâ€™la. Courtesy of HBO

â€œWriting yourself out of a corner is a great creative challenge,â€ Down says with a smile, speaking earlier in the day over coffee at a Cardiff restaurant. Adds Kay: â€œBut thereâ€™s no corner you canâ€™t write yourself out of, especially in our world, because itâ€™s mine and his brainchild.â€

For Myhaâ€™la, even though the last episode of Season 3 was â€œwritten as though it was the end,â€ she always thought theyâ€™d be coming back. â€œIâ€™m sure the second they finished that finale, they were like, â€˜What else can I write?,â€ she says. â€œJust for the sheer joy of competing with themselves, and because they love to make art â€” they love the challenge.â€

As brazenly highlighted by Season 4 (which premieres on Jan. 11 in HBOâ€™s vaunted Sunday, 9 p.m., time slot), Down and Kayâ€™s solution to cornering themselves so exquisitely has been to blow everything up and throw the pieces back together again. But this time without the constraints of Pierpointâ€™s walls.

Popular on Variety

â€œIn a way, that creative freedom has been amazing,â€ Kay says. â€œWe were writing about one world, and at the edges of that world were other worlds, like media and politics. With Season 4, we were like, now we donâ€™t have a trading floor, we can actually just go into those spaces.â€

From those spaces have emerged new characters (Max Minghella, Kiernan Shipka and Charlie Heaton are among the additions), all very â€œIndustryâ€ in being deeply troubled, unlikable and compelling. Thereâ€™s a new company at the showâ€™s center in Tender, a fintech startup looking to buy and bully its way into monopolistic dominance. Opportunistic politicians and investigative reporters swing by, as do fascist dynasties and some sinister Jeffrey Epstein undertones. Even the sex and drugs have been turned up a notch, this time with a bleaker, more manipulative edge (but not always: Henry snorting a line off a harpsichord in his manor as a group of kids on a school trip walks by is one of many comedic moments).

Season 4 also throws wholly new genres into the mix, with one particularly dark episode Kay describes as a â€œneo-Gothic period drama in a big house.â€

In a show all about risk-taking and its (mostly destructive) consequences, both admit that making such a detour from its origins is itself a high-stakes gamble.

â€œBut I honestly think thereâ€™s no point in doing anything if youâ€™re not going to take a risk,â€ says Down. â€œIâ€™m sure some people will be like, â€˜What the fuck are they doing? Itâ€™s supposed to be set in a bank!â€™ But this show is whatever the fuck we want it to be.â€

â€œIndustryâ€ was always destined to be the â€œlittle engine that could,â€ says Jane Tranter, an executive producer and co-founder of Bad Wolf, the production company and physical studio in South Wales where the show has mostly shot (as have, among other things, â€œHis Dark Materialsâ€ and â€œDoctor Whoâ€). A former senior BBC exec, Tranter was already thinking about a drama set in the world of finance when, in late 2015, just after she returned to the U.K. from a stint in L.A., HBOâ€™s Casey Bloys, now the companyâ€™s CEO, approached her about doing a series.

â€œI was absolutely fascinated as to why, after the crash of 2008, when the banks and everything theyâ€™d been doing were exposed, young people â€” who were meant to be the generation thinking differently about the world â€” were still going in their droves to work in the city,â€ she says. Struck by the real-life tragedy of an intern who died of exhaustion (a story that wound up being in the very first episode), Tranter realized the way in would be these entry-level recruits. As it happened, a colleague had just met budding scribes Down and Kay about a different project, and theyâ€™d mentioned theyâ€™d both previously worked in banks. Tranter persuaded them to start writing. But there was one minor hitch: Theyâ€™d never written for a network.

â€œHBO originally promoted this as â€˜Two ex-bankers have written a show about finance and itâ€™s going to blow the lid off the industry,â€™ not knowing that weâ€™d spent our time sat behind desks with no power for a year,â€ says Konrad Kay (left).

The first script they based on their own miserable experiences on bankingâ€™s lowest rungs. It was, as Kay freely says now, â€œreally dourâ€ and â€œglacially slow,â€ prompting Bloys to ask whether theyâ€™d actually â€œhad any fun when you were in this job?â€ They started again, this time trying to bottle some of the â€œanticipatory energyâ€ they had going into the workplace for the first time. There was still a lengthy process of endless rewrites â€” that first episode would go through roughly 60 iterations â€” and what Down describes as â€œthree years of development hell.â€ As it happens, â€œIndustryâ€ getting the eventual green light was one of the final acts of HBO boss Richard Plepler before he exited in February 2019.

With the BBC on board as a co-producer, the first season started shooting that summer, boasting a lead cast of first-timers practically as new to TV as the showâ€™s creators.

Alongside Abela and the now mononymic Myhaâ€™la were Harry Lawtey, David Jonsson and Nabhaan Rizwan (all now names very much in the ascendancy â€” and in the case of Jonsson, a BAFTA rising star winner). The only recognizable actor was â€œLostâ€ alumni Ken Leung, playing the fiery baseball bat-swinging Pierpoint vet Eric Tao. Lena Dunham directed the pilot episode and warned Leung that heâ€™d probably have to play mentor. â€œShe was like, theyâ€™re just out of drama school â€” they might be looking at you in a certain way, so be prepared,â€ Leung says. They didnâ€™t need any help. â€œThey are incredible actors, as you can see from the get-go.â€

But Season 1 was not a hit. Despite solid reviews praising its fast pace style and the performances and numerous column inches dedicated to the raucous levels of nihilistic behavior on display (â€œMillennium Mad Men,â€ claimed one headline), ratings were fractional. While the show developed a passionate, if tiny, audience, â€œwe had to really push to get a second season and had to really push again to get a third,â€ says Tranter. (She also notes that, at around $2 million an episode, â€œIndustryâ€ was cheap to make, at least by HBO standards.)

It was Season 3, the one that wrapped the story up in a bow (almost), that would become â€œIndustryâ€â€™s breakout. Sensing it might be their last, Down and Kay went for it. â€œWe said to each other, letâ€™s just swing as hard as we can for the fences and if it blows up, who cares?â€ recalls Kay. But audiences and critics alike loved the swing (which included, amid a kaleidoscope of depraved mayhem, disastrous IPOs, a brawl in a kidsâ€™ soft play area, abusive billionaire parents and two sudden deaths â€” one shockingly violent).

One of the showâ€™s side characters, the foulmouthed and near-comically amoral Pierpoint VP Rishi Ramdani (Sagar Radia), was even given his own episode, a high-intensity coke-addled descent into chaos as he tries to recoup spiraling gambling debts. The Safdie brothers â€” and Down and Kayâ€™s love for â€œUncut Gemsâ€ â€” can take credit for inspiring that one.

Thankfully, with HBO having promoted â€œIndustryâ€ from a Monday slot to Sunday, more people watched Season 3 than ever. The premiere debuted with a live audience of 300,000 and would surpass 1.6 million with delayed viewing. Season 4 was by far the quickest green light in the showâ€™s history. HBOâ€™s VP of drama programming, Cela Sutton, says the network realized it now â€œhad a hit on our handsâ€ and knew the drill. â€œWe were excited to renew it as quickly as possible.â€

â€œI love the way they get away with those names,â€ says Kit Harington, who joined â€œIndustryâ€ in Season 3 as spoiled aristocrat and entrepreneur Henry Muck alongside fellow show newcomer Miriam Petche, playing Pierpoint intern Sweetpea Golightly. Both have much bigger roles in Season 4.

While the scope of â€œIndustryâ€ has grown with each renewal, the confidence of the team putting it together has evolved with it. Down and Kay, showrunners since the start, marked their directorial debuts with the final two episodes of Season 3, but have helmed four of eight episodes in Season 4 (including the one they admit is the â€œmost out thereâ€).

When cinematographer Federico Cesca joined â€œIndustryâ€ in Season 2, he was almost entirely shooting on shoulders, the camera effectively behaving as it was were a character in itself. â€œIt was unpredictable and with plenty of agency to look away from people and find something else,â€ he says. But alongside Down and Kay, the Europe-based Argentine has broadened the showâ€™s cinematic language, often with inspiration from their favorite directors and films. In Season 3, thereâ€™s a flashback sequence during an ayahuasca trip that Cesca describes as â€œalmost Kubrickian,â€ and another (perhaps actually Kubrickian) scene he bills as â€œâ€˜Barry Lyndonâ€™ meets â€˜A Clockwork Orange.â€™â€ In Season 4, he says there are notes of â€œMagnoliaâ€ and â€œThe Brutalist,â€ plus â€” in keeping with the financial-thriller themes â€” â€œMichael Claytonâ€ and â€œMargin Call.â€

Casting, too, has graduated. Landing â€œGame of Thronesâ€ star Harington for Season 3 was a serious statement of intent â€” the showâ€™s first major signing. But it was helped by the fact that he was already a fan. â€œMickey and Konrad are quite disparaging about their first season, but I donâ€™t feel that at all,â€ says the actor. â€œFor me, it stood out as a piece of TV that was unlike any any other and theyâ€™d written characters that were fully realized and rich.â€

Another Season 3 arrival was newcomer Miriam Petche, playing Pierpoint intern Sweetpea Golightly, a name she admits thinking was â€œinsaneâ€ at first â€” â€œI thought it was a â€˜Breakfast at Tiffanyâ€™sâ€ referenceâ€ â€” but is now its â€œfiercest defender.â€

But the â€œIndustryâ€ additions last time around are nothing compared to the latest offering. Alongside Minghella (â€œThe Handmaidâ€™s Taleâ€), Shipka (â€œMad Menâ€) and Heaton (â€œStranger Thingsâ€), â€œTed Lassoâ€ breakout Toheeb Jimoh joins the ensemble in a sizable role, while Kal Penn appears early on.

Casting director Julie Harkin had worked with Minghella on his 2018 directorial debut, â€œTeen Spirit,â€ and says she â€œchuckled to myselfâ€ when she read the role of Whitney Halberstram, the self-assured co-founder of Tender and a man whose snake-oil-salesman qualities â€” and some considerably shadier elements â€” slowly rise to the surface. â€œMax is playful and subtle and has all the dexterity to go to the different places Whitney needs to go â€” and heâ€™s kind of fearless as well,â€ she says. Unlike Harington, Minghella hadnâ€™t watch much â€œIndustryâ€ when he signed up, but says it was â€œmassively, massively popularâ€ in his social circle â€” â€œmy friends are sort of religious about the show, which was terrifying to me.â€

For the character Haley Clay, a doting assistant with more than a provocative edge (and a backstory that emerges later in the season), Harkin says she turned to Shipka because there was â€œsomething so incredibly interesting in bringing her a role that goes completely against what audiences have seen her in.â€ Indeed, anyone who last watched her play Don Draperâ€™s little daughter may well be shocked by where â€œIndustryâ€ takes her (the most recent trailer gives much away).

Thanks to the showâ€™s growing status, Harkin says they not only landed all the top casting choices, but sheâ€™s now fielding regular pitches from agents eager to get their clients on board.

â€œYou get the U.K. agents ringing you all day, and then as soon as teatime hits, itâ€™s the U.S. Itâ€™s hard to keep up with it,â€ she says. â€œBut yeah, weâ€™ve had a lot of incoming for the show.â€

â€œWhitney is an enigma to everybody, including myself,â€ says Max Minghella of fintech startup CEO and Season 4 addition Whitney Halberstram. â€œWe continue to figure him out, even after we finished shooting, and figure out where the truth lies, whatâ€™s authentic and whatâ€™s manipulation. I feel like the lines are so blurred with this character â€” so much of his desire is tied to some kind of business or strategic warfare.â€

Even the music â€” credited by many to be a core element of the â€œIndustryâ€ DNA â€” has benefited from the rising popularity. Music supervisor Oliver White, a friend of Down and Kayâ€™s for years, says that in Season 4 theyâ€™ve been able to license tracks from top artists that were previously unavailable. â€œA lot of them have seen the show and have been fans,â€ he says. Among them is Daft Punk, whose baroque-inspired disco track â€œVeridis Quoâ€ plays over a nightclub scene with Harper and Yasmin. (White also recalls how the Donna Summer estate was so enthused by how the show deployed â€œState of Independenceâ€ in a Season 2 episode that they sent a note saying it was â€œone of the best uses theyâ€™d seen for the song.â€)

But licensed tracks play second fiddle to the â€œIndustryâ€ score, which is littered with the showâ€™s now near-iconic euphoric and floaty electro, composed by the Berlin-based Canadian Nathan Micay (hired largely because so many of his tracks found their way onto an early Spotify playlist White put together with Down and Kay). Micayâ€™s ability to, as White says, â€œmake the trading floor sound like a dance floor,â€ meant there were few notes from the showrunners at first, but now he says theyâ€™re coming through with suggestions.

â€œOn the last season, the common note Iâ€™d get would be â€˜Make this sick,â€™ and on Season 4 itâ€™s been â€˜Make me touch God,â€™â€ he says. And how does one touch God with the score? â€œWith them at this point I know it just means: Channel the movie â€˜Heat.â€™ Just channel all of â€˜Heatâ€™ into a 30-second TV cue.â€

With a three-year exclusive TV deal Down and Kay signed with HBO only 12 months old, it feels like a safe investment â€” even in the volatile entertainment market â€” to bet on them coming back for â€œIndustryâ€ Season 5. Kay admits they have an â€œending in sight,â€ and are â€œstarting to write towards the bullâ€™s-eye.â€

But where in the upper echelons of wealth and power they take their hedonistic adventure to reach this conclusion is anyoneâ€™s guess â€” even theirs.

â€œWe donâ€™t know what the fuck is going to happen. Weâ€™re constantly making it up as we go along,â€ says Down. â€œWe never had a big thesis statement about the world or capitalism; we just write what we think is interesting at the time. And that sometimes manifests in weird fucking things.â€

title: â€˜The Pittâ€™ Makes Its Triumphant Return in Season 2 With an Even Bigger Cast and the Same Social Conscience: TV Review
summary: When â€œThe Pittâ€ premiered on HBO Max almost exactly a year ago, it was an unflashy medical drama without the boost of preexisting IP (though the Michael Crichton estate, which claims the project is an unauthorized reboot of â€œER,â€ would disagree) or major stars. The show returns for Season 2 a conquering hero, the incumbent […]
content:
When â€œThe Pittâ€ premiered on HBO Max almost exactly a year ago, it was an unflashy medical drama without the boost of preexisting IP (though the Michael Crichton estate, which claims the project is an unauthorized reboot of â€œER,â€ would disagree) or major stars. The show returns for Season 2 a conquering hero, the incumbent winner of the Emmy for outstanding drama series along with a quartet of additional trophies. The awards only cemented a rapturous celebration of â€œThe Pittâ€ as a return to TV classicism amid the streaming revolutionâ€™s upheavals: a 15-episode season, a weekly release and a cast of largely unknowns catapulted to fame by sheer collective chemistry. Katherine LaNasa, Shawn Hatosy and Isa Briones â€” to name just three standouts from a massive and uniformly excellent cast, with LaNasa and Hatosy Emmy winners alongside star and executive producer Noah Wyle â€” may not be household names, but theyâ€™re now beloved by millions for bringing their characters to beleaguered, adrenalized life over a single shift in a fictionalized emergency room.

You wouldnâ€™t know any of this from Season 2, though not because the show takes some steep decline in quality. Quite the opposite, in fact: Under the steady leadership of Wyle, creator R. Scott Gemmill and producing director John Wells, â€œThe Pittâ€ drops us right back into the fray of Pittsburgh Trauma Medical Center, where each season unfolds hour by hour in close to real time. For the doctors, nurses, social workers and EMTs who make up the staff, itâ€™s just another day at work, which means â€œThe Pittâ€ doesnâ€™t need to generate new storylines from whole cloth to explain its continued existence. Nor do the unglamorous environs of an overcrowded hospital facilitate a â€œStranger Thingsâ€-like boost in production value that might wink at the showâ€™s real-world acclaim.

Popular on Variety

Changes to the status quo of â€œThe Pittâ€ are subtle, but theyâ€™re apparent to an audience deeply attuned to its workplace dynamics. Wyleâ€™s attending physician Michael â€œRobbyâ€ Rabinovich comes into work on the Fourth of July via motorcycle, a new hobby his colleagues roundly mock him for with good-natured ribbing about midlife crisis. Theyâ€™d be more harsh if they knew he was lying to them about wearing a helmet, a perfect and passing detail that tells us all we need to know about Robbyâ€™s mental state almost a year after the mass shooting at a music festival that spurred the climax of Season 1. (Thereâ€™s now a memorial plaque in the lobby.) The Fourth is set to be Robbyâ€™s final shift before a three-month sabbatical, and the laws of television dictate it canâ€™t be an easy one.

Robby isnâ€™t the only ER staffer at a crossroads. Dr. Frank Langdon (Patrick Ball) is back after a forced hiatus to treat a prescription-pill addiction that emerged in highly dramatic fashion last season, and you could cut the tension between him and now-estranged mentor Robby with a scalpel. Dr. Samira Mohan (Supriya Ganesh) is contemplating her personal and professional future at the end of her residency. Once a neophyte student doctor, Dennis Whitaker (Gerran Howell) is now training new pupils himself. Those med students, cocky know-it-all Ogilvy (Lucas Iverson) and acerbic, perceptive Joy (Irene Choi), are drops in a flood of new faces that mark one of the few ways a show set in a single place can meaningfully scale up. Robby clashes with his soon-to-be-replacement, tech evangelist Dr. Al-Hashimi (Sepideh Moafi); case manager Noelle (Meta Golding) consults on how to navigate the labyrinth of Medicare, Medicaid and private insurance; psychiatrist Caleb (Christopher Thornton) sees to patientsâ€™ mental health as best he can in an emergency context.

This being â€œThe Pitt,â€ however, health care providers and the relationships among them exist only in the context of the people they treat. Just as Noelle and Caleb act as windows into facets of a dysfunctional, patchwork system â€œThe Pittâ€ didnâ€™t address as directly in Season 1, the cases in Season 2 continue to highlight social issues that inevitably arise from a cross-section of humanity at their lowest moments. A proudly progressive show that serves as a counterpoint to our archconservative political moment, â€œThe Pittâ€ addresses ICE deportations, fatphobia in medicine, palliative care for terminal cancer, homelessness, the pitfalls of generative AI and the need for ASL interpreters to assist unhearing patients in its new episodes. (Both seasons of â€œThe Pittâ€ will be available to stream in ASL.) Comic relief is interspersed via drunken injuries and Viagra mishaps, but â€œThe Pittâ€ remains unabashed in its earnest social consciousness. Thereâ€™s also a palpable push to up the Pittsburgh-specific material that honors the real place outside the hospital doors, from somber reminders of the Tree of Life synagogue shooting to lighthearted traditions like an annual furry convention.

Such a wellspring of material is seemingly inexhaustible, though the show strains a bit when working to match the festival shooting as a crucible that pushes its cast to the breaking point. (All the old â€œ24â€ jokes about how many terrible days Jack Bauer can have still apply.) â€œThe Pittâ€ instead thrives in quieter moments, especially as the actors ever so slightly modulate their performances to reflect the evolution of their characters. Typically calm Robby is notably snippier and in need of his impending break; veteran charge nurse Dana (LaNasa) is less tolerant of disruption after she was assaulted by a patient in Season 1. Trinity Santos (Briones) hasnâ€™t lost her abrasive edge, but a year of residency has given her real confidence instead of forced bravado. â€œThe Pittâ€ doesnâ€™t need to show us the months of grind that produced these changes, only their cumulative effect â€” an act of trust in both the performers and the audience that makes reciprocating easy. It feels good to put oneself back in â€œThe Pittâ€â€™s capable hands.

content:
The end is near for The Upshaws. Netflix has released the official trailer for Part 7 of The Upshaws, the final season of the series starring Mike Epps, Kim Fields and Wanda Sykes.

The Upshaws was created by Regina Hicks and Sykes who serve as showrunners. In it, Bennie Upshaw (Epps), the head of a Black working-class family in Indianapolis, is a charming, well-intentioned mechanic and lifelong mess just trying his best to step up and care for his family â€” wife Regina (Fields), their two young daughters (Khali Spraggins, Journey Christine) and firstborn son (Jermelle Simon), the teenage son (Diamond Lyons) he fathered with another woman (Gabrielle Dennis) â€” and tolerate his sardonic sister-in-law (Sykes), all without a blueprint for success. But the Upshaws are determined to make it work, and make it to the next level, together.

In the final episodes, the Upshaws continue to ride lifeâ€™s ups and downs, including new jobs, bigger dreams, health struggles and some major life surprises but still hanging on with the love that comes with family.

Watch on Deadline

The Upshaws will wrap with 60 episodes, the third longest run for a Netflix original multi-cam comedy behind The Ranch (80) and Fuller House (75). The final installment consists of 12 episodes.

Hicks, Sykes and Epps executive produce with Page Hurwitz, Niles Kirchner, Annie Levine & Jon Emerson and Mark Alton Brown.

The Upshaws Part 7 premieres Jan. 15 on Netflix.

title: â€˜Butcherâ€™s Stainâ€™ Filmmaker Meyer Levinson-Blount On Creating â€œRespectful Dialogueâ€ Surrounding Israeli & Palestinian Discrimination In Oscar Shortlist Short Film
summary: Meyer Levinson-Blount is already having an impactful new year. The 24-year-old New York native, now a decade-long resident of Israel, has finished up film school at Tel Aviv University, created his first short film, won a silver medal for narrative film at the competitive Student Academy Awards for said short film, and recently, that same […]
content:
Meyer Levinson-Blount is already having an impactful new year. The 24-year-old New York native, now a decade-long resident of Israel, has finished up film school at Tel Aviv University, created his first short film, won a silver medal for narrative film at the competitive Student Academy Awards for said short film, and recently, that same short film landed a spot on the 2026 Oscars shortlist.

What is the name of the short film garnering attention from the industry? Butcherâ€™s Stain. Produced by Oron Caspi and the Steve Tisch School of Film and Television at Tel Aviv University, the 14-minute film set, after the Oct. 7, 2023, terror attacks in Israel and Palestine, follows Samir (Omar Sameer Mahamid), an Arab butcher who finds himself falsely accused of tearing down hostage posters in his companyâ€™s breakroom. Under scrutiny and discrimination, Samir tries to prove his innocence and keep the job that he desperately needs to provide for himself and his child.

Here, Levinson-Blount speaks with Deadline about the complications of war and the need for empathy in todayâ€™s society.

Watch on Deadline

DEADLINE: Where did this idea come from?

MEYER LEVINSON-BLOUNT: I went to work at a supermarket after the 7th of October. I had just finished my first year of film school [at Tel Aviv University], and I went to work at the supermarket because everything else was closed, so I had to find something to do. During that time, I basically witnessed all of the effects of the war within the supermarket itself, because that place is a microcosm of Israeli society as it has people from different backgrounds [working and shopping inside]. I felt like I witnessed the way that all of Israeli society reacted to the traumatic events of the 7th of October.

What really bothered me the most was the reaction that was pointed at the Palestinians who were in Israel. Thereâ€™s a lot of racism and discrimination from people who donâ€™t want anything to do with Palestinians who are here in Israel. So, I wanted to talk about two things that are sometimes discussed separately for political reasons. Sometimes people talk about the 7th of October. Sometimes people talk about the discrimination against Palestinians. And I really wanted to talk about both of them. As obviously these events transpired and they were awful, but also, that doesnâ€™t justify racism and discrimination against an individual who really had nothing to do with this whole conflict.

DEADLINE: Why was it important to tell the story through the lens of the butcher profession?

LEVINSON-BLOUNT: Itâ€™s an obvious choice when you see the film. I think that the important thing to think about when answering this type of question is to think about the contrast between what the butcher character does in physically watching [everyone around him], cutting meat, putting meat away, and the person that he actually is. Heâ€™s a very gentle, nice, polite, smart human being, and the idea is to put the stereotype in your face for a second, then show you that itâ€™s absolutely false and has nothing to do with the person. Itâ€™s almost like meeting the viewer where he is with what he thinks about a certain group of people, then bursting that bubble. But itâ€™s not only the stereotypes around Palestinians, but itâ€™s also about stereotypes around all types of people. Itâ€™s showing you that there are different groups of people trying to make a living and trying to look after their family, and a lot of the time, there really is no basis for all these racist stereotypes that we have in our system.

DEADLINE: How did you find Omar Sameer Mahamid to play Samir?

LEVINSON-BLOUNT: Originally, I contacted my lecturer, who was helping me out, and she set me up with this agent for Palestinian actors. I sent the agent the script, and he read it and showed me Omar. He was like, â€œThis is your guy, do an audition with him.â€ So, I set up an audition with Omar, and he came in, and that agent was right [laughs]. Initially, Omar had an issue with the filming schedule because he was going to be on vacation during some of the production dates. So, we moved the entire production a month or so, to accommodate him, because it was just that important for me to have him as an actor. There was no one else we saw who was even close to acting on his level or encompassing this character as well as he did. Heâ€™s an amazing actor, a very professional person, and a pleasure to work with. He also really taught me a lot about the script.

DEADLINE: What did he teach you about the script? And were there any other logistical challenges for the short?

LEVINSON-BLOUNT: There were lots of challenges. There was still a war going on at the time, so production would stop and start whenever [something happened]. Then there was the challenge of me being a Jewish director and telling this story about a Palestinian within Israel. And even though I had written this script and had the actors read it and really like it, I also had to listen to what the Palestinian actors had to say to direct in a way that authentically respects their story and narrative. We were able to overcome this, though, because the actors were very professional and nice and would explain things to me. For example, in their Arabic scenes, I gave them some text, but they were responsible for making sure everything was said correctly, because I had no idea what they were saying. They had to explain it to me afterwards.

DEADLINE: Itâ€™s delicately handled in the film, but youâ€™re still talking about the Gaza War situation. Was there fear in covering this topic at any point along the way?

LEVINSON-BLOUNT: Itâ€™s a very controversial issue thatâ€™s still talked about worldwide. What bothers me is that itâ€™s so hard to talk about these things on social media, where everyone is just very on edge all the time and at each otherâ€™s throats. I wanted to create a respectful dialogue about some of these issues. This was a way to connect with Palestinian Israeli actors and have people meet and talk about things in a way that is actually productive.

DEADLINE: You won the silver medal for best narrative at the 2025 Student Academy Awards and landed the Oscars shortlist. What do you think people are tapping into with your short?

LEVINSON-BLOUNT: I donâ€™t know. This is a very surreal experience for me, as this is my first serious film. Every single step of the way, Iâ€™m more excited and more surprised that weâ€™re able to have people like the film so much that theyâ€™re voting for it. Thatâ€™s really an exciting and fantastic experience for me. If I were to guess why it is that we have been able to get to where we are, I think that itâ€™s, as I said, itâ€™s really about talking about an issue in a delicate, emotional, and humane way and not in a political way. I think that when youâ€™re watching a film, you really want to connect with it as a human being. We have politicians and social media for those kinds of conversations, arguments, and all that, and thatâ€™s fine. Thereâ€™s no issue with that. But I think what I wanted to do was really connect the audience on a human level to that community, put you in their shoes, and have the viewer experience that in a humane way, which isnâ€™t supposed to make you uncomfortable. It isnâ€™t supposed to provoke you or get you angry. Itâ€™s really only supposed to connect you on a human, emotional level.

[This interview has been edited for length and clarity]

title: British TVâ€™s Most-Watched In 2025: â€˜Celebrity Traitorsâ€™ Imperious; â€˜Adolescenceâ€™ Tops Streaming; Plus â€˜KPop Demon Huntersâ€™ Monster Success
summary: The Celebrity Traitors was comfortably the most-watched show on British television in 2025, marking an imperious year for the Claudia Winkleman-hosted reality series, according to analysis from Deadline. The BBC show inspired watch parties and was the talk of the nation for weeks, as comedian Alan Carr went undetected as a traitor and ultimately triumphed […]
content:
The Celebrity Traitors was comfortably the most-watched show on British television in 2025, marking an imperious year for the Claudia Winkleman-hosted reality series, according to analysis from Deadline.

The BBC show inspired watch parties and was the talk of the nation for weeks, as comedian Alan Carr went undetected as a traitor and ultimately triumphed in a thrilling final episode in November.

The Season 1 finale was watched by an audience of 15.4M, according to 28-day viewing figures published by Barb, the UKâ€™s official television ratings body.

This made it the highest-rated episode of the season and the biggest single title on British television in 2025. Although 28-day viewing figures are not yet available for the full year, no other show is likely to come close to The Celebrity Traitors.

Watch on Deadline

Below is a run-down of the 10 best-performing titles on TV and streaming in 2025. It does not contain the final six weeks of the year, but is unlikely to change much. The most plausible entrant may be a late-season episode of Strictly Come Dancing, which could creep into the lower echelons of the top 10.

Top 10 Series & Films On British TV

RANK TITLE RATING SERVICE 1 The Celebrity Traitors (E9) 15.4M BBC 2 New Yearâ€™s Eve Fireworks 13.3M BBC 3 Adolescence (E1) 13.2M Netflix 4 The Traitors (S3, E1) 10.8M BBC 5 Iâ€™m a Celebrityâ€¦ Get Me Out of Here! (S25, E1) 10.6M ITV 6 The Thursday Murder Club 10M Netflix 7 The Great British Bake Off (S16, E1) 8.72M Channel 4 8 Gavin & Stacey: A Fond Farewell 8.7M BBC 9 Race Across The World (S5, E1) 8.3M BBC 10 Unforgotten (S6, E1) 8.1M ITV

The ranking reveals that not only did The Celebrity Traitors perform strongly, but its civilian sister show The Traitors also figured, with its highest-rated episode attracting 10.8M viewers early in the year.

Impressively, a single production company, Studio Lambert, clinched three spots in the top 10 as Race Across The World (also produced for the BBC) snatched ninth place with 8.3M viewers. The reality formatâ€™s celebrity version also performed well, premiering with 7.9M viewers, putting it just outside the top 10.

The BBC laid claim to half the titles in the table, with Netflix and ITV each picking up two places apiece. Channel 4 managed a single spot, thanks to the enduring popularity of The Great British Bake Off, which cooked up an audience of 8.72M for the first instalment in Season 16.

For all the talk of U.S. streamers unsettling the natural order of UK television, the table provides a timely reminder that traditional networks still have the power to gather huge audiences with the right shows.

â€˜Adolescenceâ€™ Netflix

Adolescence was, perhaps unsurprisingly, the highest-rated title in streaming in 2025. The four-part knife crime dramaâ€™s opening episode was watched by 13.2M viewers after 28 days, according to Barb, making it the breakout hit of the year.

Globally, the story of a British teenager radicalized by the manosphere became Netflixâ€™s second most-watched series of all time. It went on to win eight Emmys and will likely dominate the BAFTA TV Awards when the event rolls around in May.

Top 10 Series In Streaming

RANK TITLE RATING STREAMER 1 Adolescence (E1) 13.2M Netflix 2 Clarksonâ€™s Farm (S4, E2) 7.5M Amazon Prime Video 3 Harlan Cobenâ€™s Missing You (E1) 7.1M Netflix 4 Wednesday (S2, E1) 6.8M Netflix 5 LOL: Last One Laughing UK (E1) 6.2M Amazon Prime Video 6 Hostage (E1) 5.9M Netflix 7 Dept. Q (E1) 5.8M Netflix 8 Monster: The Ed Gein Story (E1) 5.3M Netflix 9 Untamed (E1) 4.6M Netflix 10 Stranger Things (S5, E1)* 4.5M Netflix *Seven-day viewing figure

Elsewhere in streaming, Netflix dominated the top 10 series with eight entries. British shows, including Harlan Cobenâ€™s Missing You, Hostage, and Dept. Q, featured heavily. Stranger Thingsâ€˜ final season also appeared, even though this was only a seven-day viewing figure. The drama will rise up the ranking when the 28-day figure is published.

Amazonâ€™s Prime Video grabbed two places. Clarksonâ€™s Farm remained hugely popular with British viewers, while the streamer had a fresh hit in the shape of comedy competition show LOL: Last One Laughing UK. Both series will return in 2026.

Other points of order: there was no place for the final season of Squid Game in the top 10, despite the Korean drama being Netflixâ€™s most-watched franchise in recent years. Disney+ failed to register a single series in the top 20, let alone the top 10.

Over in films, The Thursday Murder Club topped the ranking with 10M viewers, which also bagged the Richard Osman adaptation sixth-place in the top 10 titles on British TV last year. With four other books in the series, it would be a surprise if Netflix does not revisit the cosy crime world of Coopers Chase.

Top 10 Films In Streaming

RANK TITLE RATING STREAMER 1 The Thursday Murder Club 10M Netflix 2 Happy Gilmore 2 6.7M Netflix 3 Moana 2 5.4M Disney+ 4 Back in Action 5.3M Netflix 5 The Super Mario Bros. Movie 4.9M Netflix 6 Paddington in Peru 4.3M Netflix 7 The Woman in Cabin 10 4M Netflix 8 Unknown Number: The High School Catfish 3.7M Netflix 9 A House of Dynamite 3.6M Netflix 10 The Twits 3.6M Netflix

Netflix dominated the ranking, thanks in part to savvy acquisitions like The Super Mario Bros. Movie and Paddington in Peru. Disney+ managed one spot in the shape of Moana 2.

Not featured is Wake Up Dead Man: A Knives Out Mystery, which premiered in late November and had 3.6M viewers after seven days of viewing. The Rian Johnson-directed franchise will almost certainly force its way into the top 10 once 28-day viewing is counted.

KPop Demon Huntersâ€˜ Netflix

Another film not in the top 10 is KPop Demon Hunters, but donâ€™t let that fool you about the success of the Sony Pictures Animation title in the UK. The feature managed 3.2M viewers in its first week on Netflix, but its longevity was astonishing.

KPop Demon Hunters appeared in Barbâ€™s weekly list of the top 50 titles on British TV for 19 consecutive weeks, an achievement that is almost certainly unprecedented. The movieâ€™s best week came nearly two months after it was first released, when it was watched by 5.5M viewers.

title: â€˜Mayor Of Kingstownâ€™ To End: Taylor Sheridan Drama Starring Jeremy Renner Renewed For Fifth & Final Season By Paramount+ With Shorter Order
summary: On the heels of Mayor of Kingstown‘s bloody Season 4 finale, the Paramount+ crime drama starring Jeremy Renner has been renewed for a fifth. It will be the final installment of the series, created by Taylor Sheridan and Hugh Dillon, and will consist of 8 episodes, down from 10 for Seasons 1-4, with recent cast […]
content:
On the heels of Mayor of Kingstownâ€˜s bloody Season 4 finale, the Paramount+ crime drama starring Jeremy Renner has been renewed for a fifth. It will be the final installment of the series, created by Taylor Sheridan and Hugh Dillon, and will consist of 8 episodes, down from 10 for Seasons 1-4, with recent cast addition Edie Falco returning alongside Renner.

This is the first ongoing Sheridan series to set an end date since the regime change at Paramount+. In the months following Skydanceâ€™s acquisition of the streamerâ€™s parent Paramount Global in August, Paramount+ has ordered new seasons of Sherdianâ€™s Landman, Tulsa King and Lioness. (Paramountâ€™s new streaming chief Cindy Holland in August called the the Taylor Sheridan universe â€œa really great foundationâ€ for Paramount+; in October, the prolific creator set a 2029 move to NBCUniversal.)

Mayor of Kingstown has been a solid draw on Paramount+. It also has steadily improved its standing with critics, going from 33% on Rotten Tomatoes for Season 1 to 100% for the most recent fourth season featuring Emmy winner Falco as a new lead opposite Oscar nominee Renner.

Watch on Deadline

Still, Mayor of Kingstownâ€˜s ratings performance has not been on the level of other Sheridan dramas, especially recently. Season 4 of Mayor of Kingstown overlapped with new seasons of Landman (Season 2) and Tulsa King (Season 3) being released on Paramount+. Both Landman and Tulsa King have charted on Nielsenâ€™s weekly Top 10 of streaming originals, with Landman also making waves as a Top 3 series on the overall Nielsen chart.

Meanwhile, Mayor of Kingstown, which â€” like most Sheridan series â€” is expensive to make, has not broken into Nielsenâ€™s originals Top 10 with its fourth season having done so with previous installments.

Still, it is a Paramount+ legacy show being part of the Taylor Sheridan universe, which led to the decision to pick up a final season, with a six-episode order reportedly discussed before the two sides settled on eight installments.

In Season 4 of Mayor of Kingstown, Mikeâ€™s (Renner) control over Kingstown is threatened as new players compete to fill the power vacuum left in the Russiansâ€™ wake, compelling him to confront the resulting gang war and stop them from swallowing the town. Meanwhile, with those he loves in more danger than ever before, Mike must contend with a headstrong new Warden (Falco) to protect his own while grappling with demons from his past.

The season ended with the gang war in Kingstown escalating to a violent climax in the finale. Sheridan and Dillon will now have eight more episodes to examine the aftermath and tell the rest of the story, which Dillon previously shared they had been prepared to take to seven seasons.

â€œ[Sheridan] has an ending for it in Season 7. Whether it goes that far or thatâ€™s where we get [who knows], but he has an ending, and everyone knows about it,â€ Dillon said in a Screen Rant interview last year. â€œOur goal is to get to that Season 7, because thatâ€™s as far as we can get, because thatâ€™s where heâ€™s always had it. 15 years ago, he had it. 15 years ago, â€˜So, hereâ€™s how itâ€™s starting, Mitch is going to get killed off in the first 10 pages, and season 7, episode 10, this is where Mikeâ€™s going to be.â€

Mitch, played by Kyle Chandler, was Mikeâ€™s (Renner) older brother who was famously shot dead in the seriesâ€™ opening episode.

In addition to Renner and Falco, the latest season stars Lennie James, Laura Benanti, Dillon, Taylor Handley, Tobi Bamtefa, Derek Webster, Hamish Allan-Headley and Nishi Munshi.

Mayor of Kingstown is produced by Paramount Television Studios, 101 Studios and Bosque Ranch Productions. Sheridan executive produces with Dillon, Renner, Antoine Fuqua, David C. Glasser, Ron Burkle, David Hutkin, Bob Yari, Michael Friedman, Dave Erickson, Christoph Schrewe, Wendy Riss, Evan Perazzo and Keith Cox. Erickson also serves as showrunner. The series is distributed by Paramount Global Content Distribution.

title: CrimeConâ€™s Clue Awards Open Submissions for 2026 Ceremony (EXCLUSIVE)
summary: CrimeConâ€™s Clue Awards, an awards program dedicated to true crime storytelling, is now accepting submissions for its 2026 ceremony. The ceremony will be presented during CrimeConâ€™s annual flagship event for true crime fans, creators and industry professionals on Saturday, May 30, in Las Vegas.Â  Dedicated to celebrating excellence across true crime content, The Clue Awards […]
content:
CrimeConâ€™s Clue Awards, an awards program dedicated to true crime storytelling, is now accepting submissions for its 2026 ceremony. The ceremony will be presented during CrimeConâ€™s annual flagship event for true crime fans, creators and industry professionals on Saturday, May 30, in Las Vegas.

Dedicated to celebrating excellence across true crime content, The Clue Awards honor projects across television, podcasting, film and publishing. Television categories include outstanding episodic series, outstanding docuseries and outstanding scripted series or film, which was previously added in 2025. The podcast category will recognize outstanding episodic series and outstanding docuseries. Outstanding documentary film and true crime book of the year will also be awarded, in addition to individual achievement honors. Entries can be submitted at ClueAwards.com.

Early submissions for the 2026 awards will be accepted at a discounted rate through the Feb. 15 deadline. Regular submissions will be accepted until March 21, and April 1 is the cut-off for final submissions. To be eligible for consideration, projects must have been released between May 31, 2025 and March 31 and be available in the United States.

Popular on Variety

A third-party committee of true crime content producers, executives and creatives will select the nominees and winners of the Clue Awards. Last yearâ€™s panel included professionals from Inside Crime, Campfire Studios, National Center for Victims of Crime, Law&Crime Network, CourtTV and more.

Last yearâ€™s awards were hosted by Grammy-award winning hip hop artist and award-winning actor Ice-T, who stars on â€œLaw & Order: Special Victims Unit.â€ Netflixâ€™s â€œAmerican Murder: Gabby Petito,â€ ABC Newsâ€™ â€œThe Girl Who Looked Like Meâ€ and MGM+â€™s â€œGodfather of Harlemâ€ were amongst the winners at the 2025 awards, and the families of Liberty German and Abigail Williams, Lead Investigator Lt. Jerry Holeman of the Indiana State Police (â€œCrimefighter of the Yearâ€) and â€œCrime Weeklyâ€ hosts Derrick Levasseur and Stephanie Harlowe (â€œPeopleâ€™s Choice: Creator of the Yearâ€) received individual achievement awards.

content:
Big news for popcorn enthusiasts: In celebration of National Popcorn Day on Monday, Jan. 19, participating movie theaters nationwide will feature one-day-only promotions, discounts and offers on the famed movie theater snack in an initiative with Cinema United and The Cinema Foundation. Fandango has joined the campaign as its presenting sponsor.

â€œNational Popcorn Day is one of those moments that reminds us why people love going to the movies,â€ said Michael Oâ€™Leary, President and CEO of Cinema United, in a statement. â€œItâ€™s about sharing a big screen experience and enjoying the amazing combination of movies and popcorn together that you simply canâ€™t replicate anywhere else.â€

Concessions are a core part of the moviegoing experience, according to a Fandango study of more than 6,000 moviegoers: 96% of general ticket buyers said they purchased concessions during their trip to the movies and 61% of participants said they like to order a variety of concessions. Of the many refreshments offered in theaters, popcorn remains one of the most popular picks.

Popular on Variety

title: Ireland Introduces Europeâ€™s First Unscripted Tax Credit
summary: Ireland is launching Europe’s first tax credit for unscripted shows, offering a rebate of up to 20% of expenditure. The Irish government is introducing the credit as a means of supporting Irish and European culture and will use a cultural test to assess whether programs qualify for support. Shows such as The Traitors Ireland and […]
content:
Ireland is launching Europeâ€™s first tax credit for unscripted shows, offering a rebate of up to 20% of expenditure.

The Irish government is introducing the credit as a means of supporting Irish and European culture and will use a cultural test to assess whether programs qualify for support. Shows such as The Traitors Ireland and Dancing with the Stars Ireland will likely benefit.

Fox Entertainment Studios, in particular, will be tracking the system, as it produces unscripted shows such as Beat Shazam, Name That Tune and The Floor out of Irish studios. Weâ€™ve asked the Irish government and Fox for comment on whether they will qualify.

In its announcement, Irelandâ€™s Department of Finance noted the tax credit was being introduced â€œto support the expression of Irish and European culture in the fast-growing unscripted sector and to grow Irelandâ€™s audio-visual industry by attracting international investment as well as encouraging increased activity in the domestic space.â€

Watch on Deadline

The system has been given European Commission approval to run until December 31, 2028. It will relate to expenditure incurred during program development and be available at a rate of 20% of the lowest eligible expenditure or 80% of the total cost of production. The credit is capped at â‚¬15M ($17.5M) per production.

To be eligible, a production must not cost less than â‚¬250,000 and eligible expenditure not fall below â‚¬125,000. The production company will have to first apply for an interim cultural certificate, which will confirm the production â€œis genuinely seeking to promote Irish and European culture.â€

The certificate will allow production companies to claim during the making of a show, not at the end â€“ helping overcome an often-cited criticism of tax relief systems. Once a show is made, the producer will apply for final certification from Irelandâ€™s Minister of Culture, Communication and Sport. This will allow them to make a final claim, which is limited to one season of a project during a 12-month period.

â€œUnscripted programming is one of the most dynamic and internationally successful parts of the global audio-visual industry, and Ireland has the talent, creativity and production expertise to lead in this space,â€ said Minister Patrick Oâ€™Donovan.

â€œThis new tax credit is about backing Irish storytellers, producers and crews, while ensuring that Irish and European culture is clearly reflected on screens at home and around the world. By being the first in Europe to introduce a dedicated incentive for unscripted production, we are sending a strong signal that Ireland is open, competitive and ambitious when it comes to creative investment and cultural expression.â€

Simon Harris, Irelandâ€™s TÃ¡naiste (effectively second-in-command to the Prime Minister), added: â€œThe Tax Credit for Unscripted Production is a natural addition to this and ensures that Ireland remains an extremely competitive location for audio-visual production now and into the future.â€

Unscripted production has been challenged around the world. As such, cost efficiencies in Ireland have made it a desirable hub for international productions over the past few years, with Fox among those taking advantage. In the neighboring UK, there have been calls for an unscripted credit for at least the past 18 months, but little movement as of yet.

title: â€˜One Battle After Anotherâ€™ Producer & Editor On Getting PTA Epic Across The Line; Budget Was â€œNot Wastefulâ€ â€“ Crew Call Podcast
summary: On today’s Crew Call we talk with One Battle After Another producer Sara Murphy and editor Andy Jurgensen, both longtime Paul Thomas Anderson collaborators, hot off the film’s three Critics Choice Awards wins Sunday night including for Best Picture. There’s been a lot of noise over One Battle After Another‘s reported $140 million production cost, […]
content:
On todayâ€™s Crew Call we talk with One Battle After Another producer Sara Murphy and editor Andy Jurgensen, both longtime Paul Thomas Anderson collaborators, hot off the filmâ€™s three Critics Choice Awards wins Sunday night including for Best Picture.

Thereâ€™s been a lot of noise over One Battle After Anotherâ€˜s reported $140 million production cost, its P&L, despite the film being Andersonâ€™s highest-grossing title at $205M-plus worldwide. Cynics wonder whether the car chase really needed to cost that much. But a reality check is needed for those: One Battle After Another was a star-driven project shot in California, a state in dire need of keeping Hollywood production at home. That privilege comes with a cost, as opposed to shooting elsewhere. With the pic inspired by Thomas Pynchonâ€™s Vineland, there was no other place to shoot, for as Murphy says, â€œitâ€™s a California story.â€

Says Murphy about the budget that Warner Bros gave the production, â€œWe were not wasteful about it.â€

Watch on Deadline

Murphy tells Crew Call, â€œI feel good about the budget that we had in order to gain the scope that we brought to this film, thatâ€™s what makes it feel big and entertaining and unpredictable and unique.â€

â€œWe had a good production plan, but it did require a lot of people in California,â€ says the producer, adding, â€œI hope that we continue to expand the tax credit here so that we can keep work here.â€

Anderson spent several years scouting locations from Eureka to San Diego with his production designer and location manager to find places that organically infiltrated the narrative of the script.

Jurgensen shares with us how he stitched together a 2-hour and 40-minute contemporary action comedy, lengthy by all other film standards, into a breathless, snappy, rapid-running movie. He also expounds on Andersonâ€™s decision to shoot in VistaVision and Super 35 as well as the filmmakerâ€™s cinematic references, i.e., The French Connection and Gillo Pontecorvoâ€™s three-time Oscar-nominated The Battle of Algiers. The most intense sequence to edit wasnâ€™t the car chase scenes but rather when Chase Infinitiâ€™s Willa comes face to face with Sean Pennâ€™s Col. Steven J. Lockjaw.

title: Bella At The Italian Box Office: Checco Zalone Comedy â€˜Buen Caminoâ€™ Poised To Become Countryâ€™s Highest Grossing Local Pic
summary: Exhibitors in the U.S. like to cry about the encroachment of streaming on theatrical attendance, but they’ve never been to Italy where moviegoing has more or less been in a funk post Covid sans any multi-national circuits in the country. content:
Exhibitors in the U.S. like to cry about the encroachment of streaming on theatrical attendance, but theyâ€™ve never been to Italy where moviegoing has more or less been in a funk post Covid sans any multi-national circuits in the country. Which is what makes the latest success of the Checco Zalone starring, and co-written comedy Buen Camino all the more amazing; the pic headed to become the highest grossing local language film in Italy overtaking the comedy starâ€™s 2016 comedy Quo Vado? (65.3M Euros/$72.6M).

The Medusa theatrical release Buen Camino opened over the four-day Christmas holiday (Dec. 25-28) to a record $31.6M, the biggest opening ever for an Italian film. Not only did that amount bonk the James Cameronâ€™s Naâ€™vi folk over the head, Avatar: Fire and Ash, which posted a $6.3M second weekend then, but it also made Buen Camino the highest grossing movie in Italy for calendar year 2025 besting Disneyâ€™s Lilo & Stitchâ€˜s $25.2M.

This past weekend, Comscore reports that Buen Camino posted a second weekend of $18.3M, sending its running cume in the land of Vittoria De Sica and Federico Fellini to $66.7M (57M Euros). At that cume, Buen Camino is currently the second highest grossing local language movie in Italy behind Quo Vado? and the third highest grossing overall in a market thatâ€™s led by 2009â€™s Avatar ($68.6M unadjusted for inflation/currency swings). Against all global Hollywood releases for the first weekend of 2026, Buen Camino ranked second in a frame led by Disney/20th Century Studiosâ€™ Avatar: Fire and Ash which did $170M WW in 51 material territories. In Italy alone, Avatar: Fire and Ashâ€˜s running total stands at $24.3M.

Watch on Deadline

Buen Camino follows a father who leaves his comfort zone to search for his missing daughter on the Camino de Santiago. During his pilgrimage, amid blisters and unexpected encounters, he discovers much more than mere clues: he rediscovers himself.

The movie was co-written and directed by Gennaro Nunziante who also helmed the other Italian Zalone hits Quo Vado?, Solo A Catinelle and What A Beautiful Day.

Bari-born Zalone owns five of the biggest Italian local blockbusters including Quo Vado? ($72.6M), Buen Camino), 2013â€™s Solo A Catinelle ($69.9M), 2020â€™s Tolo Tolo ($52.2M, which Zalone directed and co-wrote with Paolo Virzi) and 2011â€™s What A Beautiful Day ($59.4M)

Whatâ€™s the secret to Buen Caminoâ€˜s success? Per sources on the ground, absence makes the heart grow fonder for the multi-hyphenate comedy star and singer. Zalone makes movies about every five years, hence ratcheting up anticipation among fans. His comedies are known to be simple with some political incorrectness and a good tone. Couple this with a year-end release date when holiday moviegoing is active and you have an ideal recipe for success.

The Italian box office for all films for Jan. 1-Dec. 28, 2025 per Comescore grossed $517.7M, -1% from the same range a year ago. The fourth highest grossing film for 2025 in Italy, and the second-highest local language film for the year was Paolo Genoveseâ€™s Madly with $21.9M from February.

title: Dish Countersues Disney In Fight Over Sling  TV Passes

content:
Dish Network has filed a counterclaim against Disney in the ongoing battle over temporary Sling Passes, the day, week and weekend passes that include live and on-demand access to networks including ESPN.

They launched in August. Disney sued in U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York requesting a temporary injunction, which the judge rejected in a November ruling. Disney amended and refiled the suit. Sling has just escalated the fight in two filings late Friday, Jan. 2, one asking the court to dismiss the two key counts of the amended complaint, and the other bringing federal antitrust and breach of contract claims against Disney.

For a one-time fee, Sling Passes provide access to the Sling Orange service for defined time periods on a non-renewing basis. Disney claimed that its Dish agreement requires monthly subscriptions. It also alleged that Sling Pass prices violate the â€œimplied covenantâ€ of the contract.

Watch on Deadline

Dish contended that the license agreement does not impose any minimum subscription length, and that Sling Pass prices â€œare objectively reasonable in relation to the monthly rates for Sling TV.â€

Denying Disneyâ€™s motion for the injunction, Judge Arun Subramanian said Disney had not made the case that the passes are not subscriptions nor proven that they threaten the ESPN streaming app in a quantifiable way.

Disney reps did not immediately respond to request for comment on Slingâ€™s countersuit, which accuses Disney of abusing its its dominant market power. It claims Disney gave competitors favorable terms but refused to extend those same terms to Dish and Sling, despite Most Favored Nation clauses in their carriage agreement. The suit cited alleged anti-competitive conduct including violating the Sherman Act by conditioning access to ESPN on the purchase of lower value channels.

Dish takes a swing at Disneyâ€™s recent acquisition of Fubo and creation of the ESPN/Fox One bundle, which it claims violate the Clayton and Sherman Acts by eliminating competition. â€œDisney is attempting to corner the Skinny Sports Bundle Market. By launching ESPN Unlimited, acquiring Fubo and enforcing restrictive contracts, Disney ensures it is the only provider of flexible sports packages, keeping prices artificially high for consumers,â€ said Dish.

Weâ€™ve seen movie stars dismantle their personas, character actors seize once-in-a-lifetime spotlights, international performers redefine what Hollywood deems â€œuniversalâ€ and first-timers arrive fully formed, carrying entire films on instinct rather than rÃ©sumÃ©.

What binds the most inspiring acting nominees of this century is not merely garnering rave reviews. Itâ€™s also about risk, and these performances often challenged voter comfort, resisted sentimentality or refused to explain themselves. Inspiration, in this context, isnâ€™t limited to victory speeches or cultural firsts, although those do matter. Itâ€™s found in the way Ellen Burstyn aged in real time on-screen without vanity, or how Riz Ahmed turned silence into a language or in how QuvenzhanÃ© Wallis used childhood imagination against despair.

This list isnâ€™t about the â€œbest actingâ€ in the clinical sense. Itâ€™s about performances that expanded the vocabulary of mainstream cinema, redefined what Oscar recognition could look like in the modern era and have made an indelible impression. Some won, some lost, but none faded.

From 2000 until now, these are the coolest and most inspiring picks by the Actors Branch.

Popular on Variety

Seventeen seasons and five Emmys later, â€œShark Tankâ€ has spawned nearly 45 international spinoffs and struck hundreds of deals. According to Oâ€™Leary, the show â€œchanged the elevator pitch forever.â€ It also made him a celebrity whose blunt ruthlessness cemented him as the Simon Cowell of capitalism.

Oâ€™Leary was not an actor, and he insists Mr. Wonderful is not a character. (Yes, itâ€™s really him when he tells an aspiring business owner, â€œYouâ€™re dead to me,â€ or berates them as a â€œgreedy pigâ€ or â€œvampire cockroach.â€) So, it came as a surprise when, two decades after that breakfast in L.A., he got a call from director Josh Safdie, who was casting â€œMarty Supreme,â€ an A24 film centered around a ping pong star played by TimothÃ©e Chalamet. Safdie uttered the same magic words as Burnett: â€œWeâ€™re looking for a real asshole.â€

Â©ABC/Courtesy Everett Collection

Despite his lack of acting experience, the â€œUncut Gemsâ€ auteur envisioned Oâ€™Leary as the central foe in the movie, a pen-hawking millionaire WASP named Milton Rockwell who spars with Chalametâ€™s hustler athlete. Safdie asked Oâ€™Leary to come to New York to read for the part, but Oâ€™Leary refused. â€œI canâ€™t do it. Itâ€™s the middle of summer. Iâ€™m sitting on my dock,â€ he told the director. â€œIâ€™ll send a plane for you. You come see me.â€ Oâ€™Leary surmised that if Safdie was willing to jet to his lake house in Muskoka just to hear him read for the part, the opportunity must be serious.

Safdie and his co-writer Ronald Bronstein obliged and sent Oâ€™Leary the script, which he printed out and left on his home bar. The next morning, Oâ€™Learyâ€™s friend, the investment banker Gene McBurney, was outside on his dock, reading the screenplay as the sun peeked over the water. â€œHave you read this fucking thing?â€ McBurney asked Oâ€™Leary. â€œWhoever wrote this is a very sick puppy, but you canâ€™t stop turning the pages.â€

Oâ€™Leary was sold. He read for the part, and his agent soon began negotiating the deal. The â€œregular Hollywood bullshitâ€ ensued. But Oâ€™Learyâ€™s rep wasnâ€™t so sure it was a good career move for him: â€œHe said, â€˜I have to be transparent with you. Some of us at UTA are nervous that youâ€™ve never acted before. What happens if you shit the bed?â€™â€

â€œMarty Supremeâ€ opened wide on Christmas, quickly becoming A24â€™s second-biggest opening weekend and generating Oscar buzz. Most important for Oâ€™Leary, his performance has received raves from critics. â€œThis asshole thing is starting to work for me a little bit,â€ he smiles.

I first meet Oâ€™Leary on an icy morning in Midtown, where heâ€™s just arrived, suitcase in hand, after a weather-delayed flight. Heâ€™s wearing a black suit with cufflinks in the shape of skulls, and he shows me a prototype earpiece that translates his texts from five languages, gifted to him by â€œShark Tankâ€ co-star Mark Cuban. As Oâ€™Leary checks in at the front desk, I offer to grab us a table in the half-vacant hotel restaurant. He shrugs me off with a grin and suggests, â€œLetâ€™s just do it in the penthouse.â€

In the hotel suite, Oâ€™Learyâ€™s wife, Linda, insists I order a coffee and a bite to eat as Oâ€™Leary sets up a small camera on a tripod. He films every interview and clips them for his social media pages, he says, pegging a microphone on my jacket. Itâ€™s an unusual move that speaks to his passion for video production and also, perhaps, a desire for control.

He struggles to explain his acting process other than to say he didnâ€™t feel like he was acting at all. When he stepped onto the set with his hairpiece and glasses and red watches â€” which heâ€™s wearing now, one on each wrist â€” he simply was Milton. â€œI just breathed the 1952 air,â€ he says.

The first scene he filmed was opposite Chalamet. â€œWe talked about the scene for a couple of minutes, then heâ€™d get up, walk around the camera for a second and come back as Marty Supreme. Sparks are flying off his fingertips,â€ he says. â€œThe first time we shot, that freaked me out. It never freaked me out again. I knew exactly how he worked, and it was marvelous.â€ Oâ€™Leary is confident that Chalamet will win the Academy Award for best actor.

In the film, Milton mocks and marvels at Marty. In one particularly memorable scene, Oâ€™Leary smacks Chalametâ€™s bare ass with a ping pong paddle. Oâ€™Leary says the scene required 40 takes and shot until 4 a.m., and Chalamet refused to use a butt double because â€œhe didnâ€™t want some other ass immortalizedâ€ on screen. When the prop paddle broke after one hit, Chalamet insisted Oâ€™Leary use a real one, which left indents on his tush.

â€œIt was easy to beat him up because he was that arrogant little bastard right out of the gate â€” that assumptive little prick. It was amazing,â€ Oâ€™Leary says.

Courtesy Everett Collection

In another threatening speech, Milton sneers at Marty, â€œIâ€™m a vampire,â€ a line Oâ€™Leary came up with himself. He pulls up his texts with Safdie and shows me a video he sent the director of him getting into character. â€œWe have a contract â€¦ and we sealed it with a paddle,â€ Oâ€™Leary improvises, looking at the iPhone camera. â€œI was born in 1601 â€¦ and Iâ€™ve met many Marty Mausers over the centuries.â€ Safdie and Bronstein loved the immortality quip and worked it into the script.

But Oâ€™Leary and the writers didnâ€™t agree on everything, and he still gripes about the ending of the film, which sees Marty holding his newborn child, tears streaming down his face, overwhelmed, terrified, euphoric. Heâ€™s come straight off the plane from Japan, where he sabotaged Milton by refusing to lose an exhibition match against the countryâ€™s star table tennis player, Koto Endo (Koto Kawaguchi).

â€œI told them I was really unsatisfied with the ending, for my character to get fucked over like that. This kumbaya ending is absurd,â€ Oâ€™Leary says. (He circles back to this frustration five or six separate times throughout our conversations.) Oâ€™Leary feels that Marty â€œfucked everybodyâ€ in his relentless quest for ping pong success, and â€œwhy should he not live a life in misery in perpetuity after that?â€

Oâ€™Leary believes not only Marty should suffer but his love interest Rachel, played by Odessa Aâ€™Zion, should too. He pitched Safdie on an idea: â€œRachel has to die. She has to die in childbirth.â€ (Safdie allegedly considered the suggestion before deciding it was too â€œsick.â€) Oâ€™Leary also wanted the film to end with Milton literally biting Marty, and he says Safdie and Bronstein â€œwent as far as to make digital teethâ€ before nixing the vampiric twist. â€œI know that sounds nuts, but to me that would be the right punishment,â€ Oâ€™Leary says.

For Oâ€™Leary, â€œMarty Supremeâ€ marked the first time in decades he was an employee. â€œI learned my lesson that film sets are not democracies. Iâ€™m not used to being told what to do. I do the telling,â€ Oâ€™Leary says. â€œWe shot something 20 times and I said to Josh, â€˜OK, I think we got it. We can move on.â€™ He said, â€˜What the fuck are you talking about? Thereâ€™s no moving on until I say weâ€™re moving on.â€™â€

Before he built up his nine-figure net worth, Montreal-born Oâ€™Leary was a film editor who worked primarily in sports television. Photography is a lifelong passion of his, and he still edits one social media post per week on Premiere Pro, despite having a personal marketing team. (His online portfolio features a dramatic self-portrait in black and white, Canadian landscapes and behind-the-scenes shots of Chalamet.)

Watching Safdie and co. work with Aeroflex cameras, Panavision lenses and 35mm film was a fantasy for Oâ€™Leary. But it was also, at times, a pain in the ass.

â€œIâ€™d never seen such inefficiency. The cinematographer drove me nuts,â€ he says of Darius Khondji, who required flawless lighting for every scene. Shooting with one camera meant constantly resetting between two characters, and Safdie and Bronstein were â€œanally insane for perfection.â€

â€œThen I saw the movie and I realized the sheer fucking genius of this guy,â€ Oâ€™Leary says of the director. â€œEvery single frame was perfect. The lighting was perfect. The scenes were perfect.â€

In October, Oâ€™Leary suggested in a podcast interview that Safdie could have saved millions of dollars by replacing thousands of extras with artificial intelligence. He maintains that AI can be a useful tool in entertainment for backgrounds. â€œI used blow-up sex dolls in the stands of hockey arenas when we were shooting so that people didnâ€™t have to freeze for 16 hours,â€ he says of his TV editing days. â€œThey were slightly out of focus. You couldnâ€™t tell they were sex dolls.â€

Still, Oâ€™Leary, a bullish investor in AI, rejects that the technology will meaningfully encroach on the work of artists. â€œI donâ€™t think itâ€™s going to be anytime soon that itâ€™s integrated into filmmaking,â€ he says. â€œWhat makes an actor magic is their lives, who they are and what they mean to the fan base. Itâ€™s the same phobia we had when television hit radio. â€˜Oh, itâ€™s going to decimate radio!â€™ No itâ€™s not. The art form exists today, even bigger, terrestrial and in space. To me, AI is just a tool.â€

And while he says the growth of streaming and decline of theatrical distribution is â€œobviousâ€ â€” especially amid Netflixâ€™s impending acquisition of Warner Bros. â€” Oâ€™Leary doesnâ€™t think movie theaters will go away. â€œI go to these large-screen formats. Itâ€™s not just the images, itâ€™s the sound,â€ he says. â€œEven in the most expensive home theater â€” and Iâ€™ve got one â€” thereâ€™s no way you can get that same feel. As long as the experience is unique, particularly these new theaters with full bar service, food service, incredible sofa-like chairs in a giant room with perfect sound and 70mm size screen, you canâ€™t beat it.â€

Disney

Weâ€™re past our allotted time at the hotel, and Oâ€™Learyâ€™s phone wonâ€™t stop buzzing. â€œLetâ€™s keep going,â€ he says, flipping the device face-down on the coffee table. â€œWeâ€™re in a groove here.â€ But eventually, he hits the answer button. Itâ€™s his publicist, and heâ€™s late for other interviews. â€œOK, OK. OK,â€ he says, hurriedly. â€œGot it. Got it. OK. Iâ€™m going. Iâ€™m going. Iâ€™m going right now.â€ He looks at me, without cracking a smile, and says: â€œWeâ€™re fucked.â€

Linda brings over Oâ€™Learyâ€™s breakfast â€” scrambled eggs, smoked salmon and gluten free toast â€” and I wolf down some berries before scurrying out of the penthouse. As Oâ€™Leary preps for his junket interviews, I ask if doing press for a movie is a thrill or a chore. His wife answers for him: â€œHeâ€™s having the most fun of his life.â€

Oâ€™Leary is keen on growing his Hollywood career. Even before â€œMarty Supremeâ€ arrived in theaters, he had already received a couple of offers from directors and producers who saw early previews of the film. Heâ€™s going to wait until the promotional cycle ends before deciding what to do next. â€œIâ€™ve definitely caught the bug, and I want to see how diverse I can be in terms of what roles I play,â€ he says.

Still, thereâ€™s one part in particular he has his eyes on.

â€œMy whole life, since I was a teenager, Iâ€™ve wanted to be the bad guy in a Bond movie,â€ Oâ€™Leary says. â€œI want to blow shit up. I could blow a lot of shit up.â€

title: China 2025 Box Office At $7.4B, +20%, But That Comes With An Asterisk

content:
Research corp Maoyan Entertainment reports the China box office 2025 finaled at RMB 51.832 billion or $7.47 billion, +20% over 2024â€™s take, in a year largely driven by the highest grossing animated movie ever, Ne Zha 2 which minted $2.12 billion, but also Disneyâ€™s Zootopia 2 which recently became this morning the No. 1 MPA release in the Middle Kingdom with $601.6M, ahead of Avengers: Endgame.

Admissions came in at 1.24 billion.

Maoyan says that 57 animation titles generated RMB 25B, or $3.6 billion thanks to IP-driven titles.

The report also adds that top films dominated as mid-tier titles struggled. Four titles in the top 10 exceeded RMB 3B ($432.6M) and eight clicked past RMB 1B ($144M+). Local films drove the majority of the B.O. Titles grossing more than RMB 1B ($144M+) remain unchanged, but movies earning in mid-range box office brackets (RMB 100â€“500 million and RMB 500 millionâ€“1 billion) â€œsaw a marked decline in numbers, underscoring the marketâ€™s increasing concentration on blockbuster projectsâ€ per the report.

Watch on Deadline

Box office shares from third- and fourth-tier cities were up for three consecutive years, with 2025â€™s hitting a five-year high. â€œThe proportion of first-time and infrequent moviegoers also rose, expanding both the reach and depth of cinema consumption, making these markets a key source for incremental growth across the industry,â€ adds the reportâ€™s release which dinged superhero imports as waning. â€œSuperhero titles saw a notable decline, signaling that such IPs require fresh storytelling to sustain market appeal,â€ the report added.

Maoyan Entertainment market analyst Lai Li also added that the traditional â€œblockbuster model,â€, is no longer a guaranteed formula for box office success, offering new lessons for market participants.

Comscore reports that the top five movies in China for 2025 were Ne Zha 2, Zootopia 2 and local titles Detective Chinatown 1900 ($496M), Dead to Rights ($421M) and 731 ($273.1M).

But what Hollywood international distribution sources emphasize about China, is that sans Ne Zha 2, the China box office was actually down from 2024â€™s $5.9B, with $5.2 billion.

Shankman said that HeartRock Partners will have three primary areas of focus: representing â€œentrepreneurial-mindedâ€ talent, representing and building consumer products brands (Shankman oversaw Gershâ€™s brand consulting business including clients such as mobile dating brand First Roundâ€™s On Me) and working with â€œstorytellers and content owners to leverage new technologyâ€.
