title: Corporation for Public Broadcasting to Shut Down After 58 Years Due to Trump Eliminating Funding
summary: Less than a year after the Trump administration and Congress voted to defund the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, the entity â€” which helped fund the operations of local public TV and radio stations â€” has voted to shut down. The CPB announced Monday that its board of directors voted to close the organization after 58 […]
content:
Less than a year after the Trump administration and Congress voted to defund the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, the entity â€” which helped fund the operations of local public TV and radio stations â€” has voted to shut down. The CPB announced Monday that its board of directors voted to close the organization after 58 years, rather than continue to exist and potentially be â€œvulnerable to future political manipulation or misuse.â€

The CPB was created by Congress by the Public Broadcasting Act of 1967 to support the federal governmentâ€™s investment in public broadcasting. The org noted that the rescission of all of CPBâ€™s federal funding came after years of political attacks.

â€œFor more than half a century, CPB existed to ensure that all Americansâ€”regardless of geography, income, or backgroundâ€”had access to trusted news, educational programming, and local storytelling,â€ said CPB president/CEO Patricia Harrison. â€œWhen the Administration and Congress rescinded federal funding, our Board faced a profound responsibility: CPBâ€™s final act would be to protect the integrity of the public media system and the democratic values by dissolving, rather than allowing the organization to remain defunded and vulnerable to additional attacks.



CPB Board of Directors chair Ruby Calvert called the move â€” and what has happened to public media â€” â€œdevastating.â€



â€œAfter nearly six decades of innovative, educational public television and radio service, Congress eliminated all funding for CPB, leaving the Board with no way to continue the organization or support the public media system that depends on it,â€ Calvert said. â€œYet, even in this moment, I am convinced that public media will survive, and that a new Congress will address public mediaâ€™s role in our country because it is critical to our childrenâ€™s education, our history, culture and democracy to do so.â€

Popular on Variety

The news doesnâ€™t come as a surprise after the Republican Congress in July approved Trumpâ€™s rescission package, eliminating $1.1 billion in crucial funding for public broadcasting that had been approved for the next two years. Without that money, the Corporation for Public Broadcasting was set to shut down. And the fate of hundreds of TV and radio stations remains up in the air.



The funding was used to support both public radio and public television stations, directing over 70 percent of CPBâ€™s appropriation straight to local stations. The funds also supported independent filmmakers. Without the funds, PBS has been scrambling to support and protect some of its most vulnerable member stations. Some stations have announced plans to shut down; Arkansasâ€™ PBS stations disaffiliated with the service and went independent to save money.

â€œCPBâ€™s support extends to every corner of the countryâ€”urban, rural, tribal, and everywhere in between,â€ the org noted.â€ In many communities, public media stations are the only free source of trusted news, educational childrenâ€™s programming, and local and national cultural content.â€



The CPB said that without funding, its board determined that â€œmaintaining the corporation as a nonfunctional entity would not serve the public interest or advance the goals of public media. A dormant and defunded CPB could have become vulnerable to future political manipulation or misuse, threatening the independence of public media and the trust audiences place in it, and potentially subjecting staff and board members to legal exposure from bad-faith actors.â€

As it closes, CPB is distributing its remaining funds, and also supporting the American Archive of Public Broadcasting in digitizing and preserving historic content. The CPBâ€™s own archives will be preserved at the University of Maryland, which will make it accessible to the public.

In September, the Television Academy honored CPB with its Governors Award, presenting it to Harrison , who had led the organization since 2005, at the Creative Arts ceremony.

â€œPublic media remains essential to a healthy democracy,â€ Harrison added. â€œOur hope is that future leaders and generations will recognize its value, defend its independence, and continue the work of ensuring that trustworthy, educational, and community-centered media remains accessible to all Americans.â€

Savannah Guthrie is sharing a health update after undergoing vocal cord surgery that has kept her off the Today show.

In a post on social media, the morning talk show host shared an update on her recovery, captioning the post, â€œSee you soon!â€

Guthrie shared a picture of herself holding up a whiteboard that read, â€œAll good! Thanks for prayers and love.â€

Watch on Deadline

It was on December 19, 2025, when Guthrie revealed she would take some time off the Today show to undergo surgery.

â€œI am going to have a surgery real early in the new year and be off for a couple of weeks. So itâ€™s my last day for a little while. So I just want to let everyone know, and if youâ€™ve been wondering, do I have the worldâ€™s longest head cold? No, I donâ€™t,â€ Guthrie said.

â€œYouâ€™ll love this, guys. I have to be silent for a couple of weeks, totally silent,â€ she said, adding, â€œthe jokes write themselves.â€

Guthrie joined the Today show as co-host of the third hour in June 2011 and was elevated to co-anchor in 2012. Guthrie is a New York Times bestselling author for her book Princesses Wear Pants and the sequel Princesses Save the World. The book was adapted into a Netflix animated series, Princess Power, in 2023, which ran for three seasons.

title: Board Votes To Dissolve Corporation For Public Broadcasting After Loss Of Federal Funding
summary: The board of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting voted to dissolve the organization after Donald Trump’s successful effort last year to roll back federal funding. The move is not a surprise: After it became clear that the funding would not be restored, the CPB announced in August that it would be shutting down operations. It […]
content:
The board of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting voted to dissolve the organization after Donald Trumpâ€˜s successful effort last year to roll back federal funding.

The move is not a surprise: After it became clear that the funding would not be restored, the CPB announced in August that it would be shutting down operations. It had about 100 employees, and a transition team has been in place since the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30.

Patricia Harrison, the president and CEO of the CPB, said in a statement, â€œWhen the Administration and Congress rescinded federal funding, our Board faced a profound responsibility: CPBâ€™s final act would be to protect the integrity of the public media system and the democratic values by dissolving, rather than allowing the organization to remain defunded and vulnerable to additional attacks.â€

GOP lawmakers voted to rescind $1.1 billion in federal funding already allocated to the CPB for the next two fiscal years.

Watch on Deadline

The CPB was formed by an act of Congress in 1967 to distribute funds to public media outlets, including local stations and, through the years, NPR and PBS. The CPB has noted that the majority of its funding, about 70%, goes to local stations, not the national outlets.

As part of the closure, the CPB will distribute remaining funds and provide support to the American Archive of Public Broadcasting. CPBâ€™s own archives will be preerved in a partnership with the University of Maryland.

Ruby Calvert, chair of the CPB board of directors, said in a statement, â€œWhat has happened to public media is devastating. After nearly six decades of innovative, educational public television and radio service, Congress eliminated all funding for CPB, leaving the Board with no way to continue the organization or support the public media system that depends on it. Yet, even in this moment, I am convinced that public media will survive, and that a new Congress will address public mediaâ€™s role in our country because it is critical to our childrenâ€™s education, our history, culture and democracy to do so.â€

In November, the CPB and NPR reached a settlement over litigation over a contract to provide almost $36 million in interconnection funds. NPR had claimed that the CPB withheld the funds in response to a Trump executive order. That executive order is being challenged in court, and CPB agreed not to enforce it unless a judge directs them to do so.

title: â€˜The Testament Of Ann Leeâ€™: Read The Screenplay For Mona Fastvoldâ€™s Take On A Mover And A Shaker
summary: Deadlineâ€™s Read the Screenplay series spotlighting the scripts behind the awards seasonâ€™s most talked-about movies continues with The Testament of Ann Lee from Searchlight Pictures. Directed by Mona Fastvold, who co-wrote the script with Brady Corbet, her husband and filmmaker behind last year’s Oscar-nominated The Brutalist, Ann Lee won the Silver Lion for Best Director at the […]
content:
Deadlineâ€™s Read the Screenplay series spotlighting the scripts behind the awards seasonâ€™s most talked-about movies continues with The Testament of Ann Lee from Searchlight Pictures. Directed by Mona Fastvold, who co-wrote the script with Brady Corbet, her husband and filmmaker behind last yearâ€™s Oscar-nominated The Brutalist, Ann Lee won the Silver Lion for Best Director at the Venice Film Festival.

The Testament of Ann Lee, is an epic musical retelling of the life of the 18th century Shaker founder starring Amanda Seyfried as the religious leader. The film explores the radical origins of the devotional sect known for its ecstatic worship and egalitarian beliefs.

The pic had its world premiere at the Venice Film Festival and soon after was acquired by Searchlight. It was nominated for Best Feature at the Gotham Awards, while Seyfried scored Best Actress noms from the Gothams, Golden Globes and the Critics Choice awards. It hit theaters December 25.

Watch on Deadline

The filmâ€™s narrative is structured into three distinct acts that track the major transitions of Leeâ€™s life, beginning with her impoverished upbringing in pre-industrial Manchester, England. In this first chapter, the story depicts the personal tragedy of Lee losing her four children at a young age, a trauma that serves as the catalyst for her spiritual transformation. She begins preaching that holiness can only be attained through celibacy and the renunciation of traditional marriage, views that eventually lead to her being declared a heathen and confined to a mental asylum. While imprisoned, Lee experiences visions that lead her to believe she is the female reincarnation of Christ and Godâ€™s representative on Earth.

The filmâ€™s second act follows Lee and a small group of devoted followers â€” including her husband Abraham, brother William and the loyal Sister Mary â€” on a transatlantic journey to the New World in 1774. This transition from the claustrophobic reality of Manchester to the open air of the Atlantic sets the stage for the final chapter: the building of a utopian community in America. Settling in Albany County, New York, the Shakers establish the colony of Niskayuna, a society governed by rigid guidelines of celibacy, social equality and a pursuit of perfection through labor. The film culminates in 1784 with Leeâ€™s death at age 48, following a violent attack on the community by neighbors threatened by their radical lifestyle.

Central to the film is the theme of radical feminism, with Fastvold portraying Lee as a wild feminist leader who was overlooked by history despite her early advocacy for gender and social equality. By offering a way out of the restrictive Church of England, Leeâ€™s movement provided a sanctuary for those who did not fit into mainstream society. This quest for utopia is depicted as a yearning for communal grace and justice, which Fastvold likens to the creative impulse found in all artistic endeavors.

The film further explores the theme of spiritual ecstasy through movement and song, functioning as a full-on musical where worship is expressed through shaking, trembling and exuberant acts of devotion. These movements were not merely physical but also were intended as embodied expressions of faith and shared experience. Additionally, the rigidity and rules of Shaker life served as a form of redemption and safety for individuals like Lee who had endured profound grief. This connection between labor, craftsmanship and spirituality is woven throughout the film, reflecting the Shaker philosophy that shaping the world through work was itself a form of transcendence.

title: Aubrey Oâ€™Day on Participating in Netflixâ€™s Diddy Doc and Danity Kaneâ€™s Reunion: â€˜It Canâ€™t Just End Hereâ€™
summary: In Netflix’s documentary series “Sean Combs: The Reckoning,” close associates of Diddy share their various experiences working with the fallen mogul in a professional and personal capacity throughout the years. For Aubrey O’Day, who Diddy signed to his girl group Danity Kane as part of “Making the Band” in the early aughts, it was the […]
content:
In Netflixâ€™s documentary series â€œSean Combs: The Reckoning,â€ close associates of Diddy share their various experiences working with the fallen mogul in a professional and personal capacity throughout the years. For Aubrey Oâ€™Day, who Diddy signed to his girl group Danity Kane as part of â€œMaking the Bandâ€ in the early aughts, it was the culmination of years of speaking out about her former boss and the trauma sheâ€™s endured.

â€œToday, I have this fear of the grieving process or putting things together or living with the limited perspective I have now, understanding the full context through the documentary and with the world watching,â€ she tells Variety. â€œWhen I woke up early this morning, all of these thoughts were starting to consume my mind.â€

Popular on Variety

Oâ€™Day, 41, is discussing her participation in the documentary â€” which was directed by Alexandria Stapleton and executive produced by Curtis â€œ50 Centâ€ Jackson â€” just days after wrapping the 2025 dates of Danity Kaneâ€™s â€œThe Untold Chapter Tourâ€ in late December, a reunion that saw her taking the stage once again with D. Woods and Aundrea Fimbres. She explains that she didnâ€™t realize how overwhelming it would be to revisit the foundation of her music career amid the release of the documentary, in which she shares how Diddy fired her from the group for rebuffing his sexual advances and, in a shocking moment, reads an affidavit from a woman who claims she witnessed Diddy sexually assaulting her while she was inebriated.

But, as she says, Oâ€™Day is using her appearance on the documentary to open up conversations about abuse not just in the music industry, but beyond. â€œIâ€™m overall wanting the behavior to stop across the board,â€ she says. â€œWeâ€™re having open discussions to this day about behaviors that are very similar. And Iâ€™m wondering what we as a society are going to do about them.â€

You were one of the first people to be vocal publicly about Sean Combs. Itâ€™s been going on for years, and the reaction may not have always been as warm or supportive as it is now. Do you feel a sense of vindication in all of this?

You know, Iâ€™ve gone back to that so much and my answer is, yes, I have been speaking out for 20 years. I did it in ways that I could based on the things that I had to sign contractually to get out of my 360 deal. I did it a lot less then. I started over the years as I started to understand myself and build my own career away from â€œMaking the Bandâ€ and Danity Kane and Diddy. I started to understand the power of my voice differently, and so I spoke bigger about it.

But even when I look back at something like â€œCelebrity Apprentice,â€ this clip always comes back around during election time where Trump is praising Diddy and saying heâ€™s the greatest guy and encouraging me to say that as well â€” and I refuse to say it. And I noticed even then I wasnâ€™t so far removed from that situation, but I wasnâ€™t willing to compromise my integrity even in front of a man that had all the power. So I think itâ€™s been very consistent.

Watching your part of the docuseries was, frankly, very difficult, not only because of what youâ€™re talking about, but also watching you share that with the world. Why was it important for you to read the affidavit publicly?

So when this whole thing occurred, the very first thing that happened in my world is every single person that was making a documentary ran straight to me and offered me the world. And I would have conversations, and I would notice, â€œOh, these people are just wanting to make a hit piece on Diddy. These people seem interesting, but Iâ€™ve spoken with all the producers and Iâ€™ve asked to meet all of the editing bay and there is no Black representation here. How would they ever be able to tell a culture piece and not have any representation on the production side or the editing bay?â€ I didnâ€™t trust that.

I was talking with Alex a lot about everything, and she was kind of the last one that came through and had her deal with Netflix. And then she was the last person that got to me. But when I got on with her, sheâ€™s just such an incredible, incredible human. The way that she listened to me, the way that she validated the things that I said, the way that she listened to the things that had happened to me prior to doing the documentary and advised me that Iâ€™m not experiencing the way that doing a documentary on this project would look. It almost sounded like Iâ€™m experiencing what a reality TV version of this would look like, which Iâ€™m very used to.

So when I spoke with her, she had such patience, respect. She knew and understood. She knew all of the connections. She knew the world. And sheâ€™s a woman that has a lot of pressure on her being a mixed woman. She spends her life doing culture pieces and having people wonder if sheâ€™s the right person to do it. Sheâ€™s got a smaller production company. And so to put that much on her back and for her to be part of, I mean, youâ€™ve seen how huge this documentary has become. And it is a statement of the culture, of the industry, and of a time and place in which a lot of things were going unchecked. I just saw that Netflix was willing to take its time and that she was taking her job of telling this piece of history with a lot of integrity and she was being very careful. I wanted to be on a documentary that was going to tell a through story of a manâ€™s life, good and bad.

What was your reaction when you were first given the affidavit?

The first thing I did was verify everything that I was told that this woman was. Who she was, how many kids she had, or what she does for a living, or her degrees. I wanted to make sure, as the daughter of a lawyer â€” my stepdad was a lawyer too, so of lawyers â€” that I did my due diligence in understanding that this person is real. And when I got that concerned was right around the time that [the authorities] reached out to me and wanted to meet with me. So the problem was for me, when you speak with them, they tell you two things when they leave, which is, donâ€™t tell anyone that youâ€™ve met with us, obviously, until youâ€™ve been subpoenaed or youâ€™re not being subpoenaed and the trial is over. And two, canâ€™t speak to victims because you can drastically create errors in the case if youâ€™re talking with other victims. What if both of you need to take the stand? There can be no communication between two people or else you could have compromises to the actual trial. And so at that point it was, if you wanted to even investigate this, itâ€™s a non-starter.

So I just started reading every civil lawsuit. One thing I noticed in all of them is these instances in which they start feeling woozy. There were instances throughout all of them in which these details occurred and I just kept trying to find myself in any of them. Find anything in them that made sense to me like, oh, I had that feeling too. But it was very difficult to sift through a lot of those lawsuits. Some of them are so horrific. I would be feeling sick over it for days. And when the conversations that were had with this woman over a multiple-year period of time, her story never changed once, and she was speaking with people who did not discuss knowing me. And this is all happening as [Aundrea] called me and said she found me on â€œMasked Singerâ€ [in early 2025] and wants to sing again. So Iâ€™m trying to get an agent to put a tour together and bring all of these girls back. But Iâ€™m also secretly suffering in this whole world. And I didnâ€™t even realize when combining the worlds how absolutely horrific it would be for me, for my mental health.

What do you think is going to happen to Sean Combs once heâ€™s out of prison and this part of his life is behind him?

I am unsure that the amount of time that heâ€™s going to be in prison is enough to fully, solely do the type of work that you would need to become a better person and to â€” how do I say this? To heal into the type of person that could be effective and good going back into life, and Iâ€™m mostly worried that a lot of money and a great spin team could create the idea that he has once again recreated a new version of himself. And that worries me, because there are people that will always be around to be able to potentially be pulled into that.

You were saying how you didnâ€™t realize that doing this reunion and dealing with the docuseries rollout at the same time would be a lot to handle. Regarding the timing of the reunion, was it done with the intention of creating a new path forward following what youâ€™ve been through these past few years, or is it just that the timing worked out that way?

I was feeling like it canâ€™t just end here for all of the artists that went through so much. So my thought was being able to end the year on seeing the artists come back and shine, having nothing to do with him. He didnâ€™t build it. He didnâ€™t create it. He didnâ€™t put the show together. Like being able to still show resilience after such a traumatic period of time for so many people, whether you knew him or not, it was so palpable. The trial was so palpable. The behaviors were so palpable. So many people who have been abused in this world in any shape or form, they all were just feeling really heavy. So I thought that this tour would be a good way of closing out the year and really bringing it back to the music and to the reason why all of us showed up in the first place.

You teased the reunion with silhouettes. People were unsure of who was going to be on the actual stage. Dawn Richard said publicly that she didnâ€™t know about the reunion. What sort of conversations happened behind the scenes to get it into the formation that people have been seeing at these shows?

So I reached out to Dawn to come back. It originally started with an agent reaching out to everyone. When I saw her release that, I had reached out and said, â€œCome back.â€ The reason I donâ€™t post the receipts or get into it is that we go right back into that divisive Diddy mentality of chaos. And I donâ€™t want to revisit that. The whole point was to not revisit that. And so I just have always kind of let her know a few different times, you are welcome back. I kept the shadows on our initial announcement, because I hadnâ€™t even signed the contract at that point, let alone if any other girls wanted to come forward, we could make room and make it happen. There was a bandmate that did not want Dawn back. There was certain things that were occurring, but for me personally, the motto of Danity Kane is every single time, everyone is invited back. Iâ€™ll listen to everybody and Iâ€™ll hear them out, but I want everyone to come and speak to each other and where itâ€™s solved is where it should fall. And thatâ€™s how it should have been done. And it didnâ€™t get done that way. And thatâ€™s not anything that I had anything to do with.

But I have reached out to her multiple times. And of course, I mentioned her and Shannon on the stage. I was able to get Shannon to still be part of the show, even though sheâ€™s retired. But I just think that when youâ€™re made under Diddy, thereâ€™s just so much that he did to each individual person. Everybody experiences it in different ways, and certain people got it way heavier than others, as the documentary tells the world. And I think that when you build something in an unhealthy environment, that Iâ€™m not sure that it ever gets to a place where it isnâ€™t thick.

Now that the tour is coming to an end, have you discussed recording new music? Is that something thatâ€™s been on your mind?

No.

This interview has been edited and condensed.

title: Jeff Probst Breaks Down â€˜Survivorâ€™ 50â€™s Celeb Collabs, Promises They Donâ€™t â€˜Overshadowâ€™ the Game: â€˜Our Show Is Not Changingâ€™
summary: When Jeff Probst began planning â€œSurvivorâ€ 50, he knew he had to go big. As always, that began with the cast â€” sifting through the 700+ castaways who have competed over the last 25 years to find the most memorable and iconic ones to return. Then, Probst quickly moved onto designing the season’s theme. As […]
content:
When Jeff Probst began planning â€œSurvivorâ€ 50, he knew he had to go big. As always, that began with the cast â€” sifting through the 700+ castaways who have competed over the last 25 years to find the most memorable and iconic ones to return. Then, Probst quickly moved onto designing the seasonâ€™s theme.

As revealed in the first trailer for this season, â€œIn the Hands of the Fansâ€ will include twists featuring Billie Eilish and Jimmy Fallon, and cameos from Jimmy â€œMrBeastâ€ Donaldson and Zac Brown.

But donâ€™t fret, â€œSurvivorâ€ loyalists: Probst isnâ€™t losing the plot.

Popular on Variety

â€œOnce we committed to turning the game design over to the fans, the next question became: â€˜How far can we go with this idea!?â€™â€ the host and showrunner tells Variety. â€œWe knew some of â€˜Survivorâ€™sâ€™ biggest fans happen to be celebrities, so we thought sprinkling a few of them in with their own unique twists felt like a fun way to make the game even more unpredictable! It definitely caught the players off guard in some really exciting ways, and added another layer to this celebratory season.â€

This is the largest cast to ever play, and the castaways will, as always, be the real stars of the season â€” even when there are game-changing twists with celebrities attached. Variety was on set in Fiji for two of the collaborations, and can confirm that â€œSurvivorâ€ still feels like â€œSurvivor,â€ even when A-list names are attached.

â€œI think itâ€™s a legitimate concern when you start adding layers like celebrities, that they can overshadow the game and take it off course. Our job was to make sure that we stayed true to what weâ€™re doing on â€˜Survivor,â€™ which is exploring this continuous social experiment. And now weâ€™re adding another layer,â€ Probst says. â€œAnd when you bring in a celebrity like Zac Brown or MrBeast or Jimmy Fallon, you now add idolatry, and you add different perceptions and reputations. Suddenly, people can get off track a little bit, or they lean in, and they want something to do with Jimmy Fallon. A lot of the players said, â€˜Iâ€™ve always dreamed of being in a MrBeast video.â€™ So the twist is designed to see if you can stay on course with the thought process you should â€” or how is it going to shift your thought process, and will it do you in?â€

He also adds that he didnâ€™t go out to celebrities and ask who wanted to be involved â€” it was through his own friendships and relationships that each collaboration came about. And it was the celebrityâ€™s idea.

â€œWith Jimmy Fallon, it was on his show. Jimmy texts me ideas all the time about â€˜Survivor,â€™ and we put some of them in the show, and weâ€™ve always talked about this idea,â€ Probst says. That idea, for now, wonâ€™t be shared â€” but it is an exciting one, which is hinted at during the trailer, and didnâ€™t go at all how Probst thought it would. â€œI think people will see, when they see these play out, I think theyâ€™ll understand these are legit â€˜Survivorâ€™ fans who wanted to be a part of 50.â€

The biggest collab of the season, however, will be the one with MrBeast; Probst appears on Season 2 of â€œBeast Gamesâ€ and Donaldson shows up for something on Season 50 of â€œSurvivor.â€ The cameos were filmed days apart from each other in June in Fiji.

The crossover conversation began when Lori DelliColli, VP of communications at CBS, was eating breakfast, and her kids showed her a MrBeast video. One of his team members, Karl Jacobs, was wearing a â€œSurvivorâ€ buff and talking about the show. She flagged to the marketing team, who invited Jacobs, along with â€œBeast Gamesâ€ co-creator Sean Klitzner, to participate in the influencer experience filmed ahead of Season 49.

No one knew at the time just how big of fans they were of the franchise. Executive producer Matt Van Wagenen recalls Klitzner applying and getting close to being cast on an earlier season. In 2020, Jacobs DMâ€™d Van Wagenen on Twitter (as it was then), raving about the show. Van Wagenen mailed him a crew T-shirt and when Jacobs posted it on social media, the producer started hearing from friends and family. He had no idea how big Jacobsâ€™ following was. Once they re-met in Fiji, â€œit felt like this was a conversation we never finished,â€ Van Wagenen says.

During the influencer experience, Klitzner pitched Probst on some sort of collaboration â€” and â€œthe camaraderie was instant; my respect for them was instant,â€ says Probst. â€œAnd then it was Loriâ€™s idea to say, â€˜That felt like some synergy there.â€™ Weâ€™ve never said, â€˜Letâ€™s collaborate with another show.â€™ Ever. We are our own tiny little world trying to just stay out of the way, and do our show.â€

A main part of the crossover, though, was logistics; the calendar for â€œSurvivorâ€ Season 50 and â€œBeast Gamesâ€ Season 2 were already set. But the Prime Video reality competition series was willing to bend: They all wanted to make it work.

â€œI said, â€˜Jeff, if you really want to do this, â€˜Iâ€™ll push my entire shoot. Iâ€™ll fit your dates no matter what,â€™â€ says Klitzner. â€œWe had a kick-off meeting where they pitched us what we should do for our show. They said, â€˜We donâ€™t want to overstep.â€™ We said, â€˜We want you to overstep in every sense of the word.â€™ They said they could shoot it with their crew and could build challenges. They came in, designed everything from soup to nuts. And of course, then our team came in, and we put â€˜Beastâ€™ into itâ€¦ There was not one moment that Jeff went, â€˜I donâ€™t know if we can do this.'â€

Jeff Probst on â€œBeast Gamesâ€ Season 2

Though â€œBeast Gamesâ€ and â€œSurvivorâ€ are both reality competition shows, they have very little in common.

â€œThey have a chaotic approach. They have cameras everywhere; they break the fourth wall all the time. They talk to players whenever they want. Itâ€™s a completely different form of storytelling, and it works,â€ Probst says. And Donaldson is a very different type of host from Probst. â€œHeâ€™s not focused on a longer-term story. He seems more focused on an in-the-moment reaction, and they bounce from one reaction to another, to another. Itâ€™s similar to his online environment, which is this constant hit of another moment, another event, one after another. â€œOn â€˜Survivor,â€™ weâ€™re looking at the long game. We want to introduce you to somebody, let you know who they are, where theyâ€™re from, what their vulnerabilities are, and then we add things to the game to exacerbate that uncertainty and force adaptability.â€

And Donaldsonâ€™s style was â€œexhilaratingâ€ for Probst to see, allowing him a look into such a different production than heâ€™s used to. â€œWho knows what influence I will take from that?â€ Probst says. â€œIâ€™m sure in some ways, I will take things from my time with Jimmy and go, â€˜I could use some elements of that in â€˜Survivor.â€™â€

In a way, it was â€œlike I was in a video game and just trying to keep up,â€ Probst says of being part of the â€œBeast Gamesâ€ episode. â€œHe just goes wherever he wants. He, like me, is the producer of his show. He can decide to do whatever he wants, and he does. He doesnâ€™t hesitate to say, â€˜I think Iâ€™ll just bribe you with money right now.â€™ It was fascinating to be inside their world and watch them.â€

Of course, having Probst by his side was a huge learning experience for Donaldson â€” both as a host and as a producer. After the first part of the collab is filmed, Donaldson says: â€œIâ€™m a little more monotone. Jeff projects his voice, and has a swag with certain things â€” like Island swag! I would love to have more presence with my voice like he does.â€

From a producerâ€™s standpoint, Donaldson realized while in Fiji that maybe â€œBeast Gamesâ€ has â€œover-indexed on changing things. Heâ€™s essentially done similar vibes for 25 years, and itâ€™s still cool. People like familiarity, and I usually try to mix things up, but that makes the production way harder,â€ says Donaldson. â€œItâ€™s helped me realize that not everything has to be fresh, because sometimes fans just like things, and if they like it, do it over and over again.â€

But after figuring out how â€œSurvivorâ€ would be incorporated into â€œBeast Games,â€ it came time for Probst to figure out how to mix MrBeast into his show.

â€œThe key point for me was, our show is not changing. Jimmy will come in, and weâ€™ll bring the aspects of â€˜Beast Gamesâ€™ that we want to explore on our show,â€ says Probst. â€œIf you look at the two shows, â€˜Beast Gamesâ€™ asks one question: What will people do for money? â€˜Survivorâ€™ asks a different question: Who are you when youâ€™re stripped of everything?â€

What Donaldsonâ€™s role is in â€œSurvivorâ€ 50 needs to stay secret for now, other than whatâ€™s shown in the trailer: He shows up with his briefcase. Letâ€™s just say, whatâ€™s inside has major potential to change the game.

â€œWhen you take people who are being stripped of everything,â€ Probst says, â€œand then you bring in maybe the most well-known person for unpredictable moments, it took the uncertainty to another level.â€

â€œSurvivorâ€ premieres on CBS Feb. 25 at 8 p.m. ET.

title: NBCUniversal, AWS, Adobe & WPP Execs On Balancing AI Ad Innovation With IP Protection
summary: Senior execs from NBCUniversal, Amazon’s AWS, Adobe and ad agency WPP discussed the tricky balance between embracing AI and safeguarding IP during a panel discussion Monday at CES. “We’ve been talking about personalization for decades,” said Hannah Elsakr, VP of GenAI New Business Ventures at Adobe. To that point, she continued, “Nobody wants to see […]
content:
Senior execs from NBCUniversal, Amazonâ€˜s AWS, Adobe and ad agency WPP discussed the tricky balance between embracing AI and safeguarding IP during a panel discussion Monday at CES.

â€œWeâ€™ve been talking about personalization for decades,â€ said Hannah Elsakr, VP of GenAI New Business Ventures at Adobe. To that point, she continued, â€œNobody wants to see the same ad three times.â€ Most ad content, she added, â€œis dead on arrival after a week, maybe two weeks. â€¦ Weâ€™ve talked about a promo taking two-plus weeks to execute. Now with AI â€“ and with I want to put the word â€˜responsible AIâ€™ out there â€“ you can do it in hours.

Programmers and advertisers are â€œin a fight for attention,â€ Elsakr said. â€œSo, being able to be relevant and let the fan drive the narrative, that, to me, is the new definition of personalization of the brand.â€

Watch on Deadline

Kristina Shepard, EVP of Streaming & Performance Sales & Partnerships at NBCU cited a number of initiative at the media giant that are designed to take advantage of the speed of AI tools.

Buyers and sellers of ad time can now use AI â€œto get down, not just to a show or an episode, but to a scene level,â€ Shepard said. â€œContextual targeting in some regard has gotten a bad rap because it has seemed very basic, right? An advertiser would say, â€˜I want to reach women 25 to 54, give me the top 100 shows.â€™ Now, AI can allow us to actually identify scenes. For example, there might be an advertiser who wants to be the first ad in an ad pod right after a holiday kiss. How do we make that advertiser really, really relevant in that moment?â€

AI can create â€œa great marriage between the viewer and the advertiser experience,â€ Shepard added. â€œWe basically beta-tested this with a luxury brand, you know, doing contextual targeting in VOD content in 2026, youâ€™ll see this in liveâ€ at upcoming NBCU events like the Super Bowl, the Winter Olympics.

One scenario, she said, would be enabling creative messages to allude to what is happening in a live sporting event. â€œImagine a touchdown happens in the third quarter of a game and that next ad pod says, â€˜Congratulations for the touchdown brought you by said brand.'â€

In the case of the luxury brand, she added, NBCU research found that viewers got 27% more enjoyment from that experience, and search engagement jumped 56% for the brand. Search and purchase intent, the so-called â€œlower funnelâ€ parts of the advertising experience (as opposed to upper-funnel efforts to create awareness), are â€œthe holy grail for all advertisers,â€ Shepard said. NBCUâ€™s experience â€œshows the benefit that television can be both an upper and lower funnel medium.â€

Samira Panah Bakhtiar, General Manager of Media & Entertainment, Games, and Sports at AWS, pointed to the larger context in which all viewing and advertising is occurring.

â€œI think we have to think about where the audiences are,â€ she said. â€œGen Z right now is spending 54% more time on social and theyâ€™re spending 26% less time on traditional viewing experiences. And if you look at some of the creators right now who are really able to capitalize themselves in a marvelous way.â€ She cited Dude Perfect or Mr. Beast, whose valuations are â€œrivaling more traditional brands.â€

The emergence of creators â€œisnâ€™t just an anomaly. These are creators who have very, very loyal fan bases who have learned how to be able to really cultivate production level content and higher media executives and get institutional investment and have figured out ways to be able to only create that content, but distribute that content at scale.â€

Any companies â€œseeking this to reinvent themselves, or be able to capitalize on this moment,â€ she said, need to â€œreally pay attention to the multi-generational preferences that exist in the viewing sphere right now.â€

title: Guillermo del Toro Tells Bradley Cooper â€˜Iâ€™ve Written 42 Screenplaysâ€™ but Only â€˜Made 13 Moviesâ€™ as They Discuss Directing Struggles, â€˜Frankensteinâ€™ and â€˜Is This Thing On?â€™
summary: Guillermo del Toro is known for his painstakingly crafted tales of monsters and ghosts. But the Oscar-winning filmmaker recoils at being called a visionary. â€œItâ€™s not like youâ€™re in a recliner with somebody feeding you grapes, going, â€˜I see a castle,â€™â€ del Toro tells his friend Bradley Cooper when they meet in Varietyâ€™s midtown Manhattan […]
content:
Guillermo del Toro is known for his painstakingly crafted tales of monsters and ghosts. But the Oscar-winning filmmaker recoils at being called a visionary. â€œItâ€™s not like youâ€™re in a recliner with somebody feeding you grapes, going, â€˜I see a castle,â€™â€ del Toro tells his friend Bradley Cooper when they meet in Varietyâ€™s midtown Manhattan studio.

The point del Toro is making is thereâ€™s a lot of hard, unglamorous work that goes into bringing movies to life â€” from hiring the right actors to making decisions on the fly when budgets are tight and time is running short. His latest sumptuously produced epic, â€œFrankenstein,â€ is a project he struggled for decades to bring to the screen before Netflix agreed to greenlight a $130 million horror film where the creature (Jacob Elordi) is more sympathetic than his creator (Oscar Isaac). Itâ€™s a film that reflects del Toroâ€™s own turmoil and pain.

Cooper, who starred in del Toroâ€™s 2021 film â€œNightmare Alley,â€ sees his latest directorial effort, â€œIs This Thing On?,â€ as a similarly personal project. Itâ€™s the story of a middle-aged man (Will Arnett) who discovers a love for stand-up when his marriage collapses. It also gave Cooper a chance to show a deeper, more sensitive side of Arnett, a close friend famous for broadly comedic turns in â€œArrested Developmentâ€ and â€œThe Lego Movie.â€

Bradley Cooper: I think Warren Beatty said this: Casting is plot.

Guillermo del Toro: Thatâ€™s a great way of putting it. I was talking about that the other day with Al Pacino. If you do Shakespeare and all of a sudden you cast a Hamlet in his 50s, that changes everything.

Cooper: Youâ€™ve been obsessed with â€œFrankensteinâ€ since you were a kid. These characters have been gestating inside you. This idea of casting is plot â€” how does that relate to finding Oscar Isaac?

Del Toro: When you read the book, Victor is a young, brilliant student. But I was fascinated by this idea of a person in their 30s who was stuck in their teens. The point of the character for me is that after his mother died when he was a child, he grew intellectually, he grew socially, but he stopped growing emotionally. Also, I wanted Oscar to not belong completely to the family of his father; I wanted him to be frowned upon because his skin was darker, his hair was unruly, and he had this fiery temperament. I wrote it for him.

You came to â€œIs This Thing On?â€ after it was developed?

Cooper: But I rewrote it. And much like you, I wrote it for Will Arnett and Laura Dern and where they are in their lives.

Del Toro: Both movies are strangely autoÂ­Â­biographical.

Cooper: Donâ€™t you think if weâ€™re doing our jobs properly, everythingâ€™s autobiographical?

Benedict Evans for Variety

Del Toro: People say, â€œOh, you identify with the creature.â€ In the past, yes. Now I identify with the creator. Iâ€™m the antagonist of my own story, as well as the protagonist.

Cooper: I know you, so I identify you throughout the film.

Del Toro: Thatâ€™s the biography.

You operated the camera on your film?

Cooper: I did wind up operating the camera for the lionâ€™s share of filming, which created an environment with the actors that was special. I was able to keep the flow going.

Del Toro: Did you talk to them from behind the camera?

Cooper: I would shout lines or ask them to explore something.

Del Toro: You were like David O. Russell?

Cooper: I learned so much from him [on â€œSilver Linings Playbook,â€ â€œAmerican Hustleâ€ and â€œJoyâ€]. He expanded my horizons about what it can be like in a creative environment on a set. I took to that way of making movies.

What [you and I] share is that we love this so much. We love every aspect.

Del Toro: When people talk about filmmaking visionaries, I go, â€œWell, itâ€™s hard work and itâ€™s hardware.â€ You have to build it; you have to film it with a certain lens. You have to decide between a Steadicam or a handheld. The decision is precision.

Cooper: Both of our movies take chances structurally and trust the audience. Where the camera is has everything to do with how the viewer relates to the story. In â€œIs This Thing On?â€ you donâ€™t see a full shot of our main characterâ€™s face until about 20 minutes into the movie. Itâ€™s all profiles or three-quarter shots until he gets up on that stage, finally turns and says, â€œIâ€™m getting a divorce.â€ I wrote it into the script, and the studio was trepidatious about the idea of not seeing your main character. And I said, â€œIt will work because hopefully the audience wonâ€™t know it cerebrally, but theyâ€™ll feel like all of a sudden there he is.â€

I love the scene in â€œFrankensteinâ€ where you have the monster hiding behind this wall, looking at the blind manâ€™s house.

Del Toro: The moment where he crosses from his hiding place into the house, the camera crosses with him through the set. All of a sudden, heâ€™s in a completely different environment. Itâ€™s the widest shot of the scene, so that when we enter the house, itâ€™s magical.

That happened to me at the Academy Awards. When I got the Oscar for â€œShape of Water,â€ people asked, â€œHow does it feel?â€ I said, â€œWell, youâ€™re in your seat and then you climb up to the stage and turn around and go, â€˜What is this?â€™â€ All of a sudden, youâ€™re in your dream moment in the shower as a kid rehearsing your speech with the shampoo bottle.

The monster needed to feel like that. He enters the house, and it needs to feel like a palace. Everything we did is 99% anchored in practical elements. We wanted to build giant sets. We wanted to build a massive ship on real motors.

Cooper: Which is incredible.

Del Toro: You want to stage everything so that that world exists in a way that feels natural. [But] you have to be able to adapt to unforeseen circumstances.

Benedict Evans for Variety

Cooper: Things can just pass you by â€” these wonderful gifts â€” and if youâ€™re not looking, youâ€™re not going to see them.

Del Toro: One detail can change everything, and you have to identify those accidents. I ordered oversized irises for Jacob Elordi to make his eyes more animalistic. So those are scleral contact lenses; theyâ€™re large and troublesome. He put one on and the other hurt, and he says, â€œI canâ€™t put in the two lenses. Letâ€™s do it digitally.â€ And I said, â€œNo, letâ€™s keep two different sizes of eyes, and the bigger eye is going to reflect back the light, and Iâ€™m going to use it to show when heâ€™s angry.â€

Cooper: It wound up being an incredible story weapon.

Del Toro: If youâ€™re playing chess with reality, you will lose. Thatâ€™s true of every filmmaker that has ever lived, even when they create their entire world, like Jim Cameron. What was fascinating about the â€œAvatarâ€ [movies] is the more control he has over the world, the more he can be loose with the actors. On the most recent movie, you see how much heâ€™s improvising.

Cooper: Yes, 100%. Itâ€™s funny, the more structured I am, the freer the actors feel.

Del Toro: How do you choose the movies you direct?

Cooper: It sounds hokey, but they choose me. It takes so much work and energy; it has to be something that feels slightly otherworldly to harness what it takes to see it through. For each movie that Iâ€™ve directed, I asked, â€œWhatâ€™s the nuclear weapon?â€ With â€œA Star Is Born,â€ thereâ€™s no better way to tell a love story than two people singing, because you cannot hide your emotions. And then Gaga was the nuclear weapon. For â€œMaestro,â€ it was being obsessed with conducting since I was a kid. But then the nuclear power was finding Leonard Bernstein.

Del Toro: And for â€œIs This Thing On?â€

Cooper: It was Will Arnett. Here is this guy who is like Robert Mitchum. Heâ€™s 6â€™4â€. His voice is what you would dream of having. To see him on a nightclub stage â€” knowing where he is right now in his life â€” I knew he could open up.

Del Toro: And you could push him where he has not gone, because you know him?

Cooper: Every day was a struggle. Every day he was uncomfortable. It was about trusting me.

Del Toro: People say, â€œWhy did you choose this movie?â€ I say, â€œListen, Iâ€™ve written 42 screenplays; Iâ€™ve made 13 movies.â€ Itâ€™s not like I said, â€œOh, no, Iâ€™ll do that one now.â€ Itâ€™s which project can I get produced.

Cooper: When we made â€œNightmare Alley,â€ we both had other obsessions.

Del Toro: But because we made it, I got to make â€œFrankensteinâ€ and you made â€œMaestro.â€ We approached the character that you played in â€œNightmare Alleyâ€ as being the worst and the best of us, [which helped me on â€œFrankensteinâ€]. I did that with Jacob Elordi and Oscar Isaac. I said, â€œLet us not be the actor and the director; let us be flawed human beings and confess to each other our shortcomings and come to these characters through that pain.â€

If I had done â€œFrankensteinâ€ 20 years ago, it would have been about my father and me as a child. Now itâ€™s too late for that. It needed to be about me as a father and my fear of repeating mistakes through generations with my children.

title: Versant Shares Dip On Day One As Comcast Spinoff Settles Into NYC Headquarters, Looks To Future
summary: Shares of newly public Versant Media fell on the first day of trading as an independent public company, closing down 13% at $40.57. Executives led by CEO Mark Lazarus were on hand at the Nasdaq market for the debut of the newly standalone entity that houses TV networks and complementary digital businesses, including CNBC, MS […]
content:
Shares of newly public Versant Media fell on the first day of trading as an independent public company, closing down 13% at $40.57.

Executives led by CEO Mark Lazarus were on hand at the Nasdaq market for the debut of the newly standalone entity that houses TV networks and complementary digital businesses, including CNBC, MS NOW formerly MSNBC), USA Network, Golf Channel, Oxygen, E!, SYFY, Fandango, Rotten Tomatoes, GolfNow, GolfPass and SportsEngine. Comcast announced about a year ago plans to separate declining linear cable assets its core broadband business and the rest of NBCUniversal.

The spinoff delivered Comcast stockholders with 1 share of Versant for every 25 shares of Comcast in hand. A downturn in Versant stock was expected as index funds and other investors primarily interested in holding Comcast cycle out and it could take a few weeks or more for the shares to settle with a true read on investor sentiment.

Watch on Deadline

At a recent investor day, CEO Mark Lazarus and his team described plans to grow the new company beyond cable. Versant initially expects to generate $6.7 billion in revenue with 62% coming from linear distribution, 23% from advertising, 13% from its digital platforms and 3% from content licensing and other. It also expects $2.3 billion in EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization) and $1.5 billion in free cash flow

It debuts with $3 billion in gross debt, $750 million in cash on hand and 1.5 billion in total liquidity.

The spin is being closely watched as a statement on the future of cable, which throws off significant cash but has been in rapid decline as viewers migrate to streaming. Versant is also particularly interesting as a proxy for Discovery Global, another new linear television company Warner Bros. Discovery is planning to cut loose in the third quarter of 2026 as it sells its Warner Bros. studios and streaming assets to Netflix. David Ellisonâ€™s Paramount is attempting to derail that deal, announced late last year, and acquire all of WBD.

A takeover battle between the two bidders has largely come down to Discovery Global, which Par values at about $1 a share but WBD and some Wall Streeters say is worth significantly more.

Share price is a function of multiples of projected future revenue and other metrics based on financials, which, for Discovery Global, have not yet been nailed down, including the precise amount of debt that will be layered on the new company.

Meanwhile, Versant has settled on its new digs and unveiled in late December that it is making the historic New York Times building its permanent home. It had settled temporarily into three floors there but Lazarus told staff in a memo that it is taking another three and renovating all six as well as a lobby and cafeteria at 229 West 43rd Street.

â€œAfter careful consideration and hearing from many of you about how this location makes your commute more manageable, we have decided to remain here. We are excited to become a fixture in this hub of media, entertainment and finance,joining our neighbors â€“ Paramount Global, Snap Inc., TikTok, Roku, Nasdaq, Morgan Stanley and Bank of America,â€ he wrote.

â€œLeaving 30 Rock and settling into this unique space was not always easy, but it has also become a special moment in our companyâ€™s history. Now, we look forward to setting down roots and transforming this space into our own permanent VERSANT New York Headquarters together.â€

content:
Signed. Sealed. Delivered.

Deadline first told you in November that John Mayer and McG were closing in on buying the famed Jim Henson Studio lot and the Charlie Chaplin Studios at 1416 N. La Brea in Los Angeles. Now comes word that the deal is done.

The duo announced today that the historic property will continue â€œoperating as a major working studio in the heart of Los Angeles.â€

The seven-time Grammy winner and Charlieâ€™s Angels director announced the facility, where Mayer records and has offices, is open for business.

Watch on Deadline

â€œNow renamed Chaplin Studios, the property will continue to operate as a fully staffed, fully functioning production and recording facility â€” open immediately and actively booking projects across music, film, television, and digital media.â€

Despite owning The Muppets IP, Disney didnâ€™t own the Jim Henson lot. The Henson family did. There was buzz that the Church of Scientology was circling to buy the property in early October, but Deadline learned and reported that that wasnâ€™t true.

A spokesperson for the Jim Henson family said then: â€œIn regards to recent rumors about the sale of the La Brea studio lot, the Henson family is not in any business dealings with the Church of Scientology, and that organization is not in consideration as a potential buyer of the property. It is still the familyâ€™s intention to move The Jim Henson Company to a new location it can share with Jim Hensonâ€™s Creature Shop, but at this time the family is not in escrow with any buyer.â€

The 80,000-square-foot facility included recording studios and, at the time of the Henson family purchase in 2000, it contained Chaplinâ€™s 10,000-square-foot sound stage and original woodworking shop.

The Jim Henson Company put the lot on the sale block in an effort to put the production company and its Burbank-based Jim Hensonâ€™s Creature Shop in one facility, which the space at La Brea could not accommodate. Chaplin shot cinema classics such as The Kid, The Gold Rush, Modern Times and The Great Dictator at the studio.

â€œThis studio has stood at the center of Hollywoodâ€™s history for generations, and itâ€™s a privilege to help shepherd it into its next chapter,â€ said Mayer. â€œBeyond its film legacy, the musical history here is extraordinary â€” from the A&M years and being home to A&M Records to landmark albums recorded on this campus to â€˜We Are the Worldâ€™ being captured inside Studio A. The Chaplin lot has given the world some of its most enduring art, and our goal is to honor that legacy by keeping it working, open, and accessible to the creative community.â€



McG added, â€œYou can feel the spirit of Hollywoodâ€™s past the moment you set foot on this lot. From Chaplin to Superman, to Soul Train, this place is a cornerstone of our industryâ€™s history. John and I are committed to respecting that heritage while ensuring the studios remain a vibrant, fully operational home for filmmakers, musicians, and creators. We want artists to walk through these gates and immediately feel that spark of possibility.â€

In 1952, Chaplin sold the property to real estate development firm Webb and Knapp, who ultimately rented to feature productions like George Reevesâ€™ Adventures of Superman. Red Skelton purchased the lot in 1960, and it was owned by CBS from 1962-1966. By1966, it was in the hands of Herb Alpert and Jerry Mossâ€™ A&M Records. Most recently, the lot served as headquarters for The Jim Henson Company.

So itâ€™s [one thing] me saying that the showâ€™s over, and then [another] that itâ€™s actually over. Those were the circumstances; it wasnâ€™t me,â€ Jackson told me in late November.

With that clarification, whether The BMF Documentary: Blowing Money Fast will continue beyond Season 2 is as yet unknown. Regarding the future of the franchise, Jackson has reiterated his intentions to continue via spinoffs, both before BMF was cancelled and after. However, he has yet to elaborate on what storylines or timelines heâ€™s interested in expanding on.

Jackson is also executive producer of the â€œPowerâ€ franchise on Starz, which has successfully found new life beyond the mothership series Power with spinoffs Ghost, Raising Kanan, Force, and the new prequel project Origins. Ghost concluded its run after four seasons in 2024, prequel Raising Kanan will end following its upcoming fifth season, and Force will wrap up Tommyâ€™s (Joseph Sikora) Chicago adventures after three seasons on January 16. Origins is currently in production on its freshman season in New York/New Jersey.

All that to say that BMFâ€˜s ending after four seasons doesnâ€™t signify that the Black Family Mafiaâ€™s stories canâ€™t continue.

In addition to Jackson, The BMF Documentary: Blowing Money Fast is also executive produced by Shan Nicholson (Jerusalem: City of Faith and Fury, Rubble Kings), who will also serve as the seriesâ€™s showrunner, as well as Razan Ghalayini, Richard Perello, and Stacey Offman. Khidija Rivera and Jessica Vale co-executive produce, and the supervising producer is Kenyatta Steans. The documentary series is produced for Starz by Jigsaw Productions and G-Unit Film & Television.

Gwyneth Paltrow in â€˜Marty Supremeâ€™

Oscars Best Film Editing Commentary (Updated Jan. 5, 2026): Since film editing became an Oscar category in 1934, its connection to the best picture race has been unmistakable. From 1981 through 2013, every best picture winner was also nominated for film editing, a remarkable 33-year streak that helped cement the category as one of the Academyâ€™s most reliable predictors. Roughly two-thirds of best picture winners have gone on to win the editing Oscar.

That pattern has cracked only twice in the expanded best picture era. â€œBirdmanâ€ (2014) and â€œCODAâ€ (2021) both won best picture without editing nominations.

This yearâ€™s editing race showcases radically different philosophies of cinematic rhythm.

â€œHamnetâ€ and â€œMarty Supremeâ€ represent one of the seasonâ€™s most intriguing case studies, particularly because of the filmmakersâ€™ hands-on approach. Josh Safdie and ChloÃ© Zhao co-editing their own films places them in exceedingly rare company. Only three directors have ever won the Oscar for film editing â€” James Cameron for â€œTitanic,â€ Alfonso CuarÃ³n for â€œGravityâ€ and Sean Baker for â€œAnora.â€ Others, including David Lean, the Coen brothers (working under the alias Roderick Jaynes) and Zhao herself, have previously earned editing nominations for films they directed.

Another crucial factor shaping the race is the long-standing bond between film editing and sound. Since 2013, no two Oscar categories have demonstrated a stronger statistical relationship, regardless of whether sound was split into editing and mixing or combined into a single award. During the split-sound era, films such as â€œGravity,â€ â€œMad Max: Fury Road,â€ â€œDunkirkâ€ and â€œBohemian Rhapsodyâ€ swept both editing and sound. Even when the overlap was partial, the connection held. â€œHacksaw Ridgeâ€ won editing and sound mixing in 2016, while â€œFord v Ferrariâ€ took editing and sound editing in 2019.

That relationship has loosened in recent years. â€œEverything Everywhere All at Onceâ€ (2022) won editing without a sound nom. â€œOppenheimerâ€ (2023) claimed editing but lost sound to â€œThe Zone of Interest.â€ Last year, â€œAnoraâ€ won editing without a sound nod, while â€œDune: Part Twoâ€ took home the statue.

Against that backdrop, â€œF1â€ vrooms into the conversation as a potential disruptor. Fresh off a Critics Choice Award win for editing and powered by its commercial success and broad appeal, the high-octane racing drama has been registering beyond the craft branches. If its momentum carries through the guild phase, â€œF1â€ could position itself as a film testing the edges of a best picture nom as well.

This is the first year that cinematography has been included in the Oscar shortlist, and on the list are such familiar names as Dan Laustsen, Guillermo del Toroâ€™s go-to DP, and Robbie Ryan, who works regularly with Yorgos Lanthimos.

But thereâ€™s a trend: three women made the cut: Autumn Durald Arkapaw (â€œSinnersâ€), Alice Brooks (â€œWicked: For Goodâ€) and Amy Vincent (â€œSong Sung Blueâ€).

In the history of the category, no woman has ever won the Oscar for cinematography, and only three women have ever been nominated: Rachel Morrison in 2018 for â€œMudbound,â€ Ari Wegner in 2021 for â€œThe Power of the Dogâ€ and Mandy Walker in 2022 for â€œElvis.â€

Popular on Variety

This year, Arkapaw made history as the first female cinematographer to shoot on Imax 65mm and Ultra Panavision for â€œSinners,â€ and looks like a front-runner. With a win, she would not only be the first woman

to win the category, she would also be the first Filipina/African American to win an Oscar for cinematography.

Arkapaw and Coogler went out to the desert near Lancaster, Calif., and tested IMAX 35mm and 65mm, with Coogler showing a keen interest in showcasing the landscape â€” an idea inspired by Quentin Tarantinoâ€˜s â€œThe Hateful Eight,â€ which was shot on 65mm film using Ultra Panavision 70mm. â€œWe screened those tests at FotoKem and the headquarters of IMAX. After you see what you created, you canâ€™t unsee that stuff,â€ Arkapaw said.

Emotions were key to â€œWickedâ€ and its conclusion, â€œWicked: For Good.â€ â€œThe first movie would live in this effervescent daylight and the second film would be steeped in maturity and density and have a weight to it,â€ Brooks says. â€œAs we were designing it, â€˜Wicked: For Goodâ€™ has this handmade feel to it, but it also feels textured and raw and edgy.â€

Brooks used every color of the rainbow to light the movie. Each scene, color meant something. â€œRed is when you make the wrong choice. You see that in a lot in the governorâ€™s mansion. Orange is the color of Elphabaâ€™s transformation, and you see it with the flames and with â€˜No Dood Deed.'â€ And blue, Brooks says is the color of love between the two. You first see in the Ozdust Ballroom surrounding and then you see it for the color of the moonlight in â€˜For Good.â€

But, itâ€™s going to be a tough choice for voters to whittle down the field, given the levels of achievement on display. Among the familiar artisans on the shortlist are two-time Oscar nominee Seamus McGarvey for â€œDie My Loveâ€; Åukasz Å»al, also a two-time nominee, for â€œHamnetâ€; Darius Khondji returns to the race looking for a third nomination with â€œMarty Supremeâ€; â€œOne Battle After Anotherâ€™sâ€ Michael Bauman, who looks to be a front-runner for a nom, as does Oscar-winner Claudio Miranda for his work on â€œF1.â€ â€œAll Quiet on the Western Frontâ€ Oscar-winner James Friend returns to the race with â€œBallad of a Small Player.â€

New to the Oscar campaign are David Chambille, who shot â€œNouvelle Vagueâ€ in black and white on the streets of Paris; Kasper Tuxenâ€™s interiors for â€œSentimental Value,â€ which added to the secrets and untold emotions of the filmâ€™s main family; â€œSirÃ¢t,â€ in which Mauro Herce shot raves and majestic landscapes in the North African desert; Fabian Gamperâ€™s work on â€œSound of Falling,â€ which translates the generational trauma in the film; and â€œTrain Dreams,â€ in which Adolpho Veloso, who just won the Critics Choice Award for best cinematography, let the magnificent landscape of the Pacific Northwest speak for itself.

content:
Disney fans behold: â€œDisneyland Handcrafted,â€ a new feature documentary from producer and director Leslie Iwerks, will premiere â€” and be available to stream â€” on Disney+ and Disney YouTube on Jan. 22. Built from rare archival footage and original audio recordings, the film will give viewers an inside look into the magic of Walt Disneyâ€™s dream and the extraordinary artistry and grit it took to create The Happiest Place on Earth.

Disneyland has been operating for more than 70 years. But Disney wasnâ€™t built in a day, and â€œDisneyland Handcraftedâ€ tells the tale of how the park came to be the iconic spot it is today ahead of its opening on July 17, 1955. Through newly unearthed materials from the Walt Disney Archives, Iwerks and her team uncovered previously forgotten 16mm film reels and audio recordings that aim to bring audiences along for the tumultuous year ahead of the parkâ€™s creation, capturing both the legacy and nostalgia leading up to the creation of the Disneyland Resort.

Firsthand accounts from the artists, craftsmen and Imagineers who were there also provide insights into the parkâ€™s creation, creating a fly-on-the-wall perspective aimed to capture what was truly happening behind the scenes.

Popular on Variety

Iwerks herself also has a special connection to Disney; sheâ€™s the daughter of Don Iwerks, a former Disney executive, and the granddaughter of Ub Iwerks, the animator and co-creator behind Mickey Mouse. Her previous projects include â€œThe Imagineering Story,â€ â€œThe Pixar Storyâ€ and â€œLeague of Legends: Origins.â€

The ABC News year-end special â€œWhat You Need to Know: 2025â€ has premiered exclusively on Disney+.

Hosted by correspondents James Longman and Rachel Scott, the special episode will highlight memorable stories that defined the year.

â€œIn under 15 minutes, we took the stories that people couldnâ€™t escape and brought them together in a way that is uniquely â€˜What You Need to Know,â€™â€ Longman and Scott said in a joint statement. â€œWhen we sign off, our hope is that viewers feel a little more informed, a little more hopeful, and reminded that even in a whirlwind of headlines, weâ€™re all sharing this story together.â€

From global reporting and politics to pop culture headlines and viral videos, â€œWhat You Need to Know: 2025â€³ will unpack the biggest moments in under 15 minutes.

â€œWhat You Need to Knowâ€ launched in July 2025 with morning episodes streaming exclusively on Disney+ and expanded in July to twice-daily episodes so viewers can follow the top stories and headlines as they continue to develop. It is ABC Newsâ€™ first daily streaming news series exclusive to Disney+.

Turner Classic Movies will honor the life and career of filmmaker Rob Reiner with a programming tribute of his most popular films on Jan. 28, 2026.

â€œThe profound sense of loss weâ€™re all feeling is heightened by Robâ€™s lofty standing in Hollywood; he was universally loved inside the entertainment industry,â€ Ben Mankiewicz, TCM host, said in a statement.

He continued, â€œI did not know him as well as I would have liked, but he always made me feel like we had been pals for decades. Robâ€™s character was defined by the qualities we see in those films: kindness, decency, humor, compassion, and most of all, a belief in humanity.â€

The tribute will be headlined by a special premiere presentation of â€œThe Princess Brideâ€ with â€œWhen Harry Met Sally,â€ â€œStand By Meâ€ and â€œThis Is Spinal Tapâ€ to follow.

Directed by Nathaniel Lezra, â€œRoads of Fireâ€ provides a look into human smuggling and migration, following three different stories of individuals and groups on perilous journeys towards prospective freedom.

The film won Best Documentary at the 2025 Santa Barbara International Film Festival, the Audience Award at the Brooklyn Film Festival and Best Cinematography at the Pacific Northwest Documentary Showcase.

The TVOD release marks the filmâ€™s first nationwide digital availability following its limited theatrical and festival runs.

Through exclusive access, in-depth reporting and behind-the-scenes content from events, Fox 11 will provide Angelenos with compelling content across digital, broadcast and social platforms, with a special focus on showcasing the ways Los Angeles locals can be part of the major events coming to their city.

title: Final Actor Awards Predictions: â€˜One Battle After Anotherâ€™ Poised to Break the All-Time SAG Nomination Record With 7

content:
The actors are about to have their say.

The Screen Actors Guild Awards may have a new name, but their importance in the Oscar race is as vital as ever. Now called the Actor Awards, nominations will be announced Jan. 7. With more than 122,000 SAG-AFTRA performers eligible to vote â€” the largest voting body of any major awards show â€” the results often reflect populist tastes and broad mainstream appeal.

This yearâ€™s eligibility window covers performances released between Jan. 1 and Dec. 31, 2025, setting up what appears to be a competitive field across all categories.

Popular on Variety

Since the ensemble category was introduced in 1995, only four films â€” â€œBraveheartâ€ (1995), â€œThe Shape of Waterâ€ (2017), â€œGreen Bookâ€ (2018) and â€œNomadlandâ€ (2020) â€” have gone on to win best picture at the Academy Awards without earning a SAG ensemble nomination. Since the Academy expanded the best picture field in 2009, 61 of the 80 films nominated for SAG ensemble â€” a 76% success rate â€” have also received best picture nominations, underscoring the categoryâ€™s value as a reliable Oscar indicator.

The ensemble race is as crowded as ever.

Warner Bros.â€™ â€œOne Battle After Anotherâ€ is entering as an early frontrunner with a star-studded cast led by Leonardo DiCaprio and Sean Penn, and a lineup that fits the guildâ€™s well-established preference for recognizable names. Thereâ€™s also some history to possibly be made. At a projected seven nominations, Paul Thomas Andersonâ€™s action epic is poised to become the most nominated movie in the history of SAG. And thereâ€™s still room for one more in case Regina Hall makes the cut in supporting actress alongside Teyana Taylor.

The list of the most nominated films in SAG history is currently a six-way tie with five each: â€œShakespeare in Loveâ€ (1998), â€œChicagoâ€ (2002), â€œDoubtâ€ (2008), â€œThe Banshees of Inisherinâ€ (2022), â€œEverything Everywhere All at Onceâ€ (2022) and â€œWickedâ€ (2024). Of those, â€œShakespeare,â€ â€œChicagoâ€ and â€œEverything Everywhereâ€ went on to win the SAG Award for best cast ensemble before clinching the Academy Award for best picture. â€œDoubtâ€ took home best actress at SAG for Meryl Streep (but lost the Oscar) while â€œBansheesâ€ and â€œWickedâ€ both went home empty-handed.

Obviously, SAGâ€™s predictive strength extends to the film acting races as well. Since 2009, SAGâ€™s film acting nominees have overlapped with the Academy Awards an average of 16 out of 20 slots, an 80% match rate. The strongest alignment came in 2009, the year of â€œThe Hurt Locker,â€ when 19 of 20 SAG nominees went on to earn Oscar nominations. The weakest crossover occurred in 2021, the year of â€œCODA,â€ when the overlap dropped to 12 of 20.

Last yearâ€™s best actor winner, TimothÃ©e Chalamet (â€œA Complete Unknownâ€), continues his momentum and is back with his turn as table tennis prodigy Marty Mauser in Josh Safdieâ€™s â€œMarty Supreme.â€ Notably, no film actor has ever won back-to-back SAG Awards. That could open the door for someone else to take the top spot. Nonetheless, DiCaprio, Michael B. Jordan and Ethan Hawke are all expected to hear their names called. The organization has not been kind to non-English language performances, which is why a snub is projected for â€œThe Secret Agentâ€ star Wagner Moura. Despite emphatic praise from critics, the guildâ€™s longstanding hesitation to nominate non-English language performances â€” see Sandra HÃ¼llerâ€™s omission for â€œAnatomy of a Fallâ€ â€” remains a barrier.

Still, there is some expected recognition for non-English storytelling with Renate Reinsve, Stellan SkarsgÃ¥rd and Inga Ibsdotter Lilleaas all predicted to make their respective lineups for the Norwegian family drama â€œSentimental Value.â€

Actors who are mainstays at the ceremony such as Glenn Close (who has 10 individual nominations and could appear for â€œWake Up Dead Manâ€) or William H. Macy, who could find his way to a nomination for his work in â€œTrain Dreams,â€ which is predicted to land in the cast ensemble category.

On the television side, the drama series race will likely be dominated by streaming platforms, with Apple TVâ€™s â€œSeveranceâ€ and HBO Maxâ€™s â€œThe White Lotusâ€ expected to lead the pack alongside Netflixâ€™s final season of â€œStranger Things.â€ In comedy, FXâ€™s â€œThe Bearâ€ and HBOâ€™s â€œHacksâ€ remain fixtures, while Apple TV could break through with Seth Rogenâ€™s â€œThe Studio.â€

Some of the other individual acting categories showcase a mix of established favorites and veterans â€” Jean Smart, Jeremy Allen White, Adam Scott â€” and relative newcomers like Glen Powell for â€œChad Powers.â€

The limited series categories are heavily weighted toward Netflix, which could claim as many as eight of the 10 nomination slots across both male and female actor categories, led by their Emmy-winning miniseries â€œAdolescence.â€

Nominations will be announced Wednesday, Jan. 7, 2026. Final voting to determine the winners will take place from Jan. 14 through Feb. 27 at noon Pacific time. The 32nd annual Actor Awards, presented by SAG-AFTRA, will air live on Netflix on March 1.
