title: WPP Media Launches New Sports Practice While Ad Dollars Soar for Big Games
summary: There are plenty of sports on the TV and streaming schedules, but could there be a better way for advertisers to play this game? WPP Media believes so. The media-buying outlet, part of British ad giant WPP and once known as GroupM, is launching a new sports practice it says will harness better sets of […]
content:
There are plenty of sports on the TV and streaming schedules, but could there be a better way for advertisers to play this game?

WPP Media believes so. The media-buying outlet, part of British ad giant WPP and once known as GroupM, is launching a new sports practice it says will harness better sets of data to help clients place their advertising dollars with increased confidence.

Many advertisers have longstanding ties to certain sports events, but the amount of money being spent on professional and collegiate sports is soaring, says Martin Bilch, an executive director at WPP Media, and head of U.S. sports investments and partnerships, during a recent interview. â€œThe truths is we need to be able to say to the client, â€˜Hey, letâ€™s take a step back and look at data, understand who the fan is, understand who the league delivers and the platforms they have access to that can really drive business.â€ Bilch will lead the new offering.

WPP Media Sports, the new practice, will not only offer strategy and investment services, but also analytics; activation of sponsorships and partnerships; and content production tied to influencers. WPP Media Sports will use GumGum, a company that specializes in delivering digital ads in relevant environments, and Relo Metrics, which measures and tracks the value of sponsor logos and brand mentions across live TV broadcasts, streaming, social media, and other venues.

Popular on Variety

WPP Media launches a dedicated sports practice at the start of a heady year, one that will contain a Winter Olympics and a World Cup tournament, along with the usual NFL, NBA, MLB and NHL seasons. WPP Media has kept its eye on how sports has developed in a new era. In 2024, the company created a dedicated marketplace for womenâ€™s sports, starting in the industryâ€™s â€œupfrontâ€ market. Clients including adidas, Ally, Coinbase, Discover, Google, Mars, Nationwide, Unilever and NBCUniversalâ€™s Universal Pictures said at the time that they were interested.

The company is also seeking to redefine its business after several tough years marked by client losses and executive turnover. WPP Media Sports will vie with such entities as Publicis Media and the sports media operations of Omnicom Group, which recently acquired its rival, Interpublic Group .Advertisers have always relied on sports broadcasts to reach large audiences, but more of them are doing so in the streaming era. When traditional dramas and comedies are viewed increasingly at times of a consumerâ€™s own choosing, sports remains one of the few programming formats that draws broad crowds together all at once â€” meaning a sponsor can reach more potential customers in a single moment.

In recent months, top sports events have sold out earlier and with greater speed than in the past â€” including the Super Bowl. NBCUniversal sold the bulk of its commercial inventory tied to next monthâ€™s telecast of Super Bowl LX months ahead of schedule.

The heightened demand for sports has boosted prices for all games and matches. â€ That means thereâ€™s more realization that itâ€™s more expensive to make a mistake,â€ says Bilch. â€œYou can no longer just throw a piece of grass up in the arena and hope it flies in the right direction,â€ he says. â€œYou have to have data and make the proper decisions as part of it.â€

title: Inside the Oscar-Shortlisted and Annie-Nominated â€˜The Girl Who Cried Pearls,â€™ a Fable for Times of Unfettered Greed
summary: A haunting tale of a ragamuffin teen who puts wealth before love, the Oscar shortlisted â€œThe Girl Who Cried Pearlsâ€ also weighs in as the latest animated short from both the National Film Board of Canada and writer-directors Chris Lavis and Maciek Szczerbowski which bids fair for an Academy Award nomination this month.Â  ‘The Girl […]
content:
A haunting tale of a ragamuffin teen who puts wealth before love, the Oscar shortlisted â€œThe Girl Who Cried Pearlsâ€ also weighs in as the latest animated short from both the National Film Board of Canada and writer-directors Chris Lavis and Maciek Szczerbowski which bids fair for an Academy Award nomination this month.

â€˜The Girl Who Cried Pearlsâ€™ is already one of five titles which scored an nomination for the 53rd Annie Awards in their best short subject category, announced Monday.

An Oscar nomination would be Lavis and Szczerbowskiâ€™s second after the notable â€œMadame Tutli-Putliâ€ (2007) and the National Film Boardâ€™s 39th for an animated short. The NFB ranks as the third most-nominated entity in that category after Disney and MGM, as NFB chairperson Suzanne GuÃ¨vremont noted to Variety just before 2025â€™s Annecy Animation Festival.

Popular on Variety

Packing emotional force but also a fable about be-careful-what you-wish-for greed, â€œâ€The Girl Who Cried Pearlsâ€ is both an ode to the craftsmanship of stop-motion puppetry and a groundbreaking blend of tactile puppetry with digital innovation, reaffirming Lavis and Szczerbowski â€™s status as pioneers in contemporary animation, Variety has observed.

â€œThe Girl Who Cried Pearlsâ€ begins in Paris with the camera creeping up on a white marble mansion in a leafy street with a view of the Eiffel Tower â€“ the epitome of bourgeois success. The granddaughter of its owner, a crickety old man, discovers a pearl in an red apple-shaped holder. â€œOf all the treasures in the entire room, youâ€™ve guessed whatâ€™s most precious to me. It would seem someone has discovered my secret,â€ her grandfather confesses, quite willingly.

Pushed by his granddaughter to say what the secret is, he tells his tale of when he was a homeless street-kid in Montreal at the turn of the 20th century who spies on a young girl whose tears transform into iridescent small pearls. He falls in love with her, he says, but also secures two pearls which he sells to a pawnbroker â€“ and sets out to make the girl cry more, breaking her heart.

Throughout their career, Lavis and Szczerbowski have drunk deep at the well of surrealism, the artistic movement inspiring many of the 20th centuryâ€™s achievements which set out to decry the rationality and sense of propriety of middle-classes, priming the workings of the unconscious, chance and a lack of creative control.

â€œMadame Tutli-Putli,â€ the film 2008 Academy Awards contender which brought Lavis and Szczerbowski to notice, plays out, for instance, like the fever dream of a 1920s bourgeois flapper dreamt many decades later. The narrative imagines her younger self without a home and then on a train where logic is replaced by chance as she confronts her deepest fears: sex, robbery, helplessness, the death of others (the train has a morgue-like dining car) and the inevitability of extinction (she pictures a moth drawn to the light at the filmâ€™s finale). Or that at least could be one interpretation.

A highly useful article on the Canada National Film Boardâ€™s blog quotes Lavis and Szczerbowski about how their animation on â€œThe Girl Who Cried Pearlsâ€ was shaped by happy accident. One case in point: the original maquette of the decrepit house where the young boy shelters from winter cold was left outside the studio to dry. But an unexpected rain squall hit and by the time Lavis and Szczerbowski returned, the prop was warped out of shape.

â€œIt looked so much better that way, so we incorporated the warps into the final model,â€ they say.

Model for the house in â€˜The Girl Who Cried Pearlsâ€™ Credit: National Film Board of Canada

That is reminiscent of an anecdote about how the great surrealist Luis BuÃ±uel was sitting in Madrid bar Chicote drinking dry martinis trying to work out how he could cast Angela Molina as the supposed femme fatale of â€œThe Obscure Object of Desireâ€ when he already had Carole Bouquet under contract. BuÃ±uel realized that the film would work much better if they were both cast in the same role.

â€œThe Girl Who Cried Pearlsâ€ frames a tale within tale of the film, part set maybe 70 years later whose final stretches cannot be described without revealing multiple spoilers. Safe to say, however, that they add multiple levels of storytelling richness and reenforce the filmâ€™s social prescience in ages past and present of unfettered greed.

The 17-minute short is also animation art of the highest order, seen in the extraordinary bric-a-brac detail of a pawnshop, lending it an immersive authenticity. The puppetsâ€™ heads in the past are silicon moulds multi-layered by oil painting to look like aged wood. The film uses both claymation and plastic 3D printing and sets scrubbed with paint spread on garbage bags to make them look grimily weathered.

Variety talked to Lavis and Maciek Szczerbowski about â€œThe Girl Who Cried Pearlsâ€ which, produced by the National Film Board, was one of five shorts to open the 2025 Annecy Festival.

It also won the Short Cuts Award for best Canadian short film at the Toronto Festival and the Canadian Film Institute Award for best Canadian Animation at the Ottawa International Animation Festival, the second most important animation festival in the world.

In a conversation with your composer Patrick Watson and artistic director Brigitte Henry about making â€œThe Girl Who Cried Pearlsâ€ you say, Maciek, that â€œwithout the right story, there is no valueâ€ in anything else. The grandfather says much the same towards the end of the film. I suspect here, as indeed in the film at large, that one key was the long time you spent making it, which maybe allowed you to evolve everything, including the story, more than is traditional in animation.

Maciek Szczerbowski: This was our first story completely dependent on story. We joked that we usually make experimental films and the experiment this time was doing something traditional. For the most part, weâ€™ve been exploring the worlds of dream logic and Dadaist accidents that create story in a kind of symbolistic way which we try to curate and control. Here the trick was to tell a very specific, concise story. If you donâ€™t understand the two or three crucial moments, it probably means nothing. The result was almost like telling a jokeâ€” Proper timing. Good delivery.

Could you give an early example of a crucial moment?

Szczerbowski: Just a simple line which almost gets lost that the boy says about how he spent his days at Montrealâ€™s old port, how he stole from boxes that had fallen off ships.

Chris Lavis: Youâ€™re absolutely right about how the story evolved as we worked on it. Thatâ€™s a crucial element to the process. We had animated and edited the film and watched a first version and it didnâ€™t work. It wasnâ€™t virtuosic on any scale. It was stuttering. It had no proper structure. It was confusing. Two things happened. Our composer, Patrick Watson, made a suggestion that he needed the film to spend more time in the past, without cutting back to the present, for him to build the music properly.

And the second?

Lavis: It didnâ€™t feel like the grandfather was telling a story. Characters were just speaking dialogue in the grandfatherâ€™s voice. What we did â€“ maybe the oldest trick of filmmakers after that first hellish editâ€”was we went back to the first impulse: The original treatment we gave to the National Film Board of Canada. We had written that like a short story. Those little narrative bridges missing from the grandfatherâ€™s dialogue were there in the original treatment. When we weaved them back into the film, it was like Eureka! Suddenly, the movie had structure and shape.

Which connects to the grandfatherâ€™s comment that â€œItâ€™s always the story that gives something the valueâ€ and itâ€™s the story of a girl whose tears become pearls is what strikes spectators most from the filmâ€¦.

Lavis: The story has two pillars. One, we were really interested in this idea of the grandfather, being extremely rich and wealthy and powerful, at the end of his life, discovering his granddaughter stealing something from his office and telling her his darkest secret. The second pillar is the idea that storytelling itself creates belief and value.

Szczerbowski: In so many ways itâ€™s a commentary on what people like us or writers do. Youâ€™re making value out of nothing by inventing a narrative, by building a mythology around an object that could otherwise have become utterly worthless, and turning it into something that could end up in a museum or be priceless.

Storytelling dates back to the dawn of humankind. â€œThe Girl Who Cried Pearlsâ€ could indeed be said to be in some ways traditionalist and in others, highly innovative, as Variety noted of your work in general. Making the film was often about using the new or making the new look oldâ€¦..

Szczerbowski: We wanted the story to feel like it was found in a box from 50 years ago. Thatâ€™s the whole point of that process of aging and using garbage bags and paint. Oil paint is to remove the author from the process in a way. Especially when youâ€™re creating a fable, you donâ€™t want it to feel like a couple of guys were sitting around inventing a fable. It should feel like it came from the collective unconscious.

A highly useful article on the National Film Board blog quotes you about how your animation was shaped by happy accident. One case in point: how you incorporated the rain-drenched warped version of your original maquette into the final model.

Lavis: We call chance an invisible collaborator.

Szczerbowski: This is part of our education, I guess. At some point, we were reading an article about Frank Gehry, the architect. He would build a maquette for a building he was designing and when it hit a particular level of of satisfaction where he knew he could have actually stopped, he would throw it out the window, and take the elevator down to the sidewalk collect all the pieces and re-glue it, knowing that it would never actually fit perfectly ever again, that there would be an element of chaos and accident. What John Cage calls indeterminacy. Something beautiful happens. You have to have had some experience in removing your own ego from your work in order to even play with these things.

Lavis: You get sick of your own decisions, too. Thatâ€™s what makes it interesting.

Szczerbowski: And youâ€™re looking forward to surprise. The whole point of us working in in collaboration is to look forward to these moments when this kind of indeterminacy happens, either because of a thunderstorm or the other personâ€™s intervention. Usually what you get at the end is something that is really different than what you thought it would look like. For some that might be a failure, but to us itâ€™s always a boon.

title: Breaking Baz: Julia Roberts On â€˜After The Huntâ€™, The Perils Of AI & Looking Back At â€˜Pretty Womanâ€™: â€œTimes Change, People Changeâ€
summary: EXCLUSIVE: An AI version of Julia Roberts would be doomed from the start. A computer program could never replicate her signature gleaming smile â€” the one that lights up Notting Hill and Pretty Woman â€” or the inner turmoil that tortures Alma, the Yale philosophy professor she captures so astutely in Luca Guadagninoâ€™s riveting drama After the Hunt.  Hereâ€™s an […]
content:
EXCLUSIVE: An AI version of Julia Roberts would be doomed from the start. A computer program could never replicate her signature gleaming smile â€” the one that lights up Notting Hill and Pretty Woman â€” or the inner turmoil that tortures Alma, the Yale philosophy professor she captures so astutely in Luca Guadagninoâ€™s riveting drama After the Hunt.

Hereâ€™s an actor of quiet ambition, fire and energy who every so often unleashes a raw power that infuses a character with life and truth. Itâ€™s her best role since she played the titular Erin Brockovich a quarter of a century ago, collecting an Academy Award along the way. On Sunday, the star is a best dramatic actress nominee at the Golden Globes for After the Hunt.

Julia Roberts and Luca Guadagnino on â€˜After the Huntâ€™ set Amazon

Just the other day, Richard Curtis, who penned Notting Hill, voiced a belief that AI can never replace an actor, a screenwriter or any filmmaking creative.

â€œI donâ€™t believe itâ€™s possible either,â€ Roberts insists. â€œI think that at the root of every book and play and movie and TV show and essay and article is someoneâ€™s heart and soul, and those are not manufacturable.â€

Are we at a dangerous crossroads?

â€œYes,â€ she responds. â€œI think itâ€™s interesting what AI can do for medicine, things like that. I think thatâ€™s something that as a world we should be so proud of and interested in.â€

But she doesnâ€™t engage in AI, and sheâ€™s â€œnever used ChatGPT because I think itâ€™s a slippery slope, right? Anytime you find that shortcut for something, and at first you go, â€˜Oh, this is great.â€™ But is it?â€ Her voice sounds troubled.

These are concerns, too, for the future of the theatrical moviegoing experience.

Roberts shakes her head in agreement and says: â€œI think I like to maintain a robust sense of optimism for all things. I remember, there was a moment during Covid where I was talking to Bryan Lourd, my agent. We had this long conversation, and I got off the phone with him and â€¦ it was a moment where I thought, â€˜Itâ€™s over. Weâ€™ll never be in a movie theater again.â€™ I just sat in my little rocking chair and just wept.â€

The tears came, she tells me, at â€œthe idea of that part of our culture being gone was so heartbreaking because I do find it so meaningful and so fun.â€

RELATED: The Movies That Have Made More Than $1 Billion At The Global Box Office

Especially now, she continues, â€œwith everybody with their heads down like thisâ€¦â€ She lowers her head, as if reading a cell phone. â€œWhere else do you sit with a group of people where everybody has their heads up, and youâ€™re all kind of sharing energetically the same story? Itâ€™s a really unique thing to do in the theater â€” and in the movie theaterâ€” and the idea of that disappearing forever, itâ€™s too heartbreaking for me to believe it could happen.â€

Itâ€™s tricky though, isnâ€™t it, what with the theater of war that Netflix and Paramount are waging over the future of Warner Bros? â€œListen,â€ Roberts sighs, â€œitâ€™s all dollars and cents, right? So hopefully, people keep going.â€

Ayo Edebiri and Julia Roberts in â€˜After the Huntâ€™ Yannis Drakoulidis /Amazon

As much as After the Hunt follows a clash of cultures â€” the cancel kind, plus social and moral differences â€” that follow when Maggie (Ayo Edebiri), one of Almaâ€™s students alleges that faculty member Hank (Andrew Garfield) sexually assaulted her, itâ€™s the beautifully bizarre, damaged, wonderful marriage between Alma and Frederick, her psychologist husband (Michael Stuhlbarg) that grips.

RELATED: â€˜After The Huntâ€™: Read The Screenplay From First-Time Scribe Nora Garrett That Refuses To Offer Easy Answers

Nora Garrett wrote the screenplay, but itâ€™s Guadagninoâ€™s brilliant imagination that ensures Alma is the troubled beating heart of this film. And itâ€™s clear from our conversation that Roberts leapt at the opportunity to work with him. The result for her is a sublime performance; unmissable for me.

Heâ€™s one of the most thoughtful, knowledgeable, deep, passionate people sheâ€™s ever met, Roberts says. â€œIt goes on and on â€” what he knows, what he can absorb and comprehend and learn and retain and then share in a variety of languages. I mean, itâ€™s kind of astonishing. Iâ€™ve never really encountered a person like him,â€ Roberts says as she continues to richly exalt her Sicilian artistic benefactor.

Roberts believes that he was a springboard for â€œmy enthusiasm. â€¦ I think everything he said I wrote down, I was constantly making notes, thinking, â€˜I have to look up who this person is. I need to see what this book is about.â€™ Just to create this sense of the academic world as its own universe,â€ she says.

I share Robertsâ€™s enthusiasm for Guadagnino, having been a fan ever since Tilda Swinton tipped me off about his feature debut, The Protagonists, which she starred in for him back in 1999.

After the Hunt is studded with references to Alma and Frederickâ€™s marriage. At one point, Garfieldâ€™s Hank belittles the idea of Frederick because heâ€™s at home preparing a cassoulet for their supper, but Alma staunchly defends him: â€œHeâ€™s my husband. Heâ€™s always going to be there.â€

Roberts says that sheâ€™s had some really profound conversations with friends about the marriage in the movie, citing one in particular she had with George Clooney. â€œI think itâ€™s probably the most serious conversation weâ€™ve had in 30 years. It had so much to do with the marriage story in the movie and how he felt about that. I think that George, you, myself, weâ€™re kind of all of a certain age where we really appreciate when a story, a book, a movie â€” something that shows us the layers and the layers and the layers of something.â€

Most of the scenes involving Roberts and Stuhlbarg are when Alma and Frederick are alone together. The two actors developed a close rapport, though it would seem that both approach things differently, a comment that elicits giggles from Roberts.

Michael Stuhlbarg and Julia Roberts in â€˜After the Huntâ€™ Yannis Drakoulidis/Amazon MGM Studios

How so, I venture to ask? Itâ€™s something to do with how they each treated their copies of the script; Stuhlbargâ€™s pages were so pristine, Roberts recalls. â€œHis notes were tiny. He had these straight lines and these small squiggly lines, and it was like hieroglyphics. And my script notoriously looks like itâ€™s spent the night in a hamster cage. Itâ€™s my own madness, one that I never truly took note of until I looked at Michaelâ€™s script. And so I think that we melded within our differences. We just liked being with someone who was so different. And we also just had a real comfort in sharing physical space. I think he was comfortable with me physically. That scene in the kitchen where heâ€™s on his knees and heâ€™s got his head in my lap? We just understood our space together.â€

The film smartly foreshadows what will befall Alma and Maggie and Hank. When Alma and her students discuss Michel Foucaultâ€™s ideas concerning the panopticon â€” the idea that people can be controlled by extreme surveillance â€”itâ€™s a foreboding of the public torture that Alma will endure because of her reaction to Maggieâ€™s ordeal. Another instance is when Stuhlbargâ€™s Fredrick notes that seeking tenure will make Alma above accountability, which one can relate to the sheer lack of accountability we observe at the highest echelons of public life.

RELATED: Luca Guadagnino And â€˜After The Huntâ€™ Cast Talk Woody Allen Inspiration & The Filmâ€™s Politics: â€œItâ€™s Not About Making A Manifesto Of Old-Fashioned Valuesâ€ â€” Venice

â€œListen,â€ says Roberts, â€œthe timeliness of the parallels of just the idea of people striving to be in positions of power â€” for lack of a more interesting word â€” for the ultimate goal of not being responsible and accountable, thatâ€™s the horror of the modern world right now.â€

Roberts finds it â€œgreat and interestingâ€ to take â€œthis massive horrorâ€ and put it into the arena of academia. It is, she says, â€œa place thatâ€™s small enough that you can see the whole, you can see every cog in the wheel. Because sometimes I just feel like I read the newspaper and you almost canâ€™t comprehendâ€¦â€ Her face suddenly fills with anguish. â€œI think thatâ€™s very Luca to make something that you really can hold and examine.â€

So what ails Alma? Roberts reckons â€œher genesis is pain. â€¦ The tree of Alma, thatâ€™s where it starts. And so I think to understand why she is the way she is and speaks the way she does and performs the way she does, whether at home or at school, itâ€™s all trauma. â€¦ How did she find a place, make a decision to say to herself, â€˜How can I best make it work for a life?â€™ and part of it is the masonry, right? You build the wall. The bricks of her wall are made of all these philosophers and all these concepts and all these things that she can proclaim from on high, because if youâ€™re talking about all these other people and all these other things, youâ€™re never talking about yourself.â€

Julia Roberts in â€˜After the Huntâ€™

The reason Alma and Frederickâ€™s marriage â€œworks so beautifullyâ€ is, she believes, â€œbecause Frederick is the only person that knows her pain, sees all of her and loves her in spite of that, loves her because, loves her anyway, loves her always. And she knows that. And I think there is no Frederick without Alma. There is no Alma without Frederick. And I think thatâ€™s how she survives.â€

RELATED: â€˜After The Huntâ€™ Writer Nora Garrett Reveals The Political Event That Impacted Her, And Her On-Set Experience With Luca Guadagnino And Julia Roberts

Almaâ€™s attire is also part of her survival kit. Roberts explains that hair designer Massimo Gattabrusi (Queer, Challengers) and makeup designer Fernanda Perez (A Bigger Splash, Call Me By Your Name), both regular collaborators of Guadagninoâ€™s, molded her look, with Gena Rowlands at the center of their mood board.

â€œThey are avid researchers,â€ she says, â€œand they came in with a lot of materials for us to look at, and talk about â€” what the look was to be. Itâ€™s a uniform. Sheâ€™s not spending time getting ready, and yet, make no mistake, thereâ€™s thought put into every little piece of everything, every loafer, every brush of the hair. And so it was interesting to try to create this studied look that seemed effortless. And definitely Gena Rowlands [was an influence]. We had so many pictures of her in the hair and makeup room.â€

Interestingly, she and Rowlands appeared together in 1995â€™s Something to Talk About.

â€œSo I knew her,â€ Roberts says. â€œAnd I was able to adore her up close for a period of time. So many of the characters that she played, they had this internal [dynamic]. It was like a Jenga game, and you just didnâ€™t know when it was going to tumble. She was so good at that, the nuance of that quality. I think that was something that Luca and I discussed, just trying to find that internal nuance for Alma.â€

John Cassavetes and Gena Rowlands AMPAS

Sadly, she notes, Rowlands died the day after the film wrapped. â€œWe were all gutted. We couldnâ€™t believe it. Every day I would just sit and stare at pictures of her while I was getting ready for work in the makeup room. She was such a legend, such an inspiration.â€

RELATED: Gena Rowlands Dies: â€˜The Notebookâ€™, â€˜Gloriaâ€™ And â€˜A Woman Under the Influenceâ€™ Star Was 94

The mention of Rowlands makes us both hark back to a time when audiences welcomed challenging movies like After the Hunt, where the answers werenâ€™t fed to you. Like you would come out of the film and youâ€™d have a heated discussion on the way home with your wife or with friends. The added benefit of After the Hunt has been is the number of fights one has participated in over dinner â€” even Christmas Day lunchâ€” arguing over this movie. Itâ€™s rare, and I ask whether Roberts feels that as well.

â€œI do,â€ she responds. â€œI think that is my greatest sense of accomplishment with this movie, where this person thought this and this person thought that. My friends would see it and go, â€˜Oh, well, we have to see it again. I mean, because she thinks this and I think that.â€™â€

Roberts explains that when Guadagnino came to London to show her the film, she was on another movie, director Sam Esmailâ€™s thriller Panic Carefully, starring Eddie Redmayne, Elizabeth Olsen, Brian Tyree Henry, Joe Alwyn and Ben Chaplin. Roberts says that she refused to sit with Guadagnino, just the two of them, to watch the movie. â€œThat sounds like a complete nightmare,â€ she recalls telling him.

Guadagnino allowed her to invite Esmail, some cast mates from Panic Carefully, along with crew from After the Hunt that resided in London, about a dozen or so, and following the screening they hadnâ€™t reached the exit doors before they stopped in a huddle for half an hour. â€œIt was so wonderful just to hear how many different ways people examine it.â€

RELATED: â€˜After The Huntâ€™ Review: Julia Roberts Is Superb In Luca Guadagninoâ€™s Biting Campus #MeToo Drama â€“ Venice Film Festival

But while the film has its champions â€” such as Deadlineâ€™s film critic Damon Wise â€” itâ€™s also had its share of detractors, especially some critics and social commentators in the United States who have vilified it. Roberts thinks thatâ€™s what makes it really robust, saying, â€Everybodyâ€™s going to get something slightly different in their interpretation.â€

From left: Andrew Garfield, Luca Guadagnino, Julia Roberts, Ayo Edebiri and Chloe Sevigny at the â€˜After the Huntâ€™ premiere at the 2025 Venice Film Festival Getty Images

Like me, Roberts is fascinated about which movies â€œfloat to the topâ€ and what doesnâ€™t, and who exactly determines that. She suggests that sheâ€™d like to attend a dinner party at my house to further discuss this topic. I suggest she bring plenty of her own ammunition. â€œIâ€™m unafraid, Baz. Iâ€™m unafraid,â€ she says with mock bravado. (Actually, maybe not so mock!)

I ask her about rumors suggesting she might have plans to return to the stage. Is it true?

â€œI hope itâ€™s true, â€œ she responds. â€œItâ€™s been a long-held dream of mine to do that. And now that our kids are grown up, I think it affords me more of the space for something like that.â€

I saw her make her Broadway debut in Richard Greenbergâ€™s play Three Days of Rain, directed by Joe Mantello, with Bradley Cooper and Paul Rudd in 2006. â€œThe three of us, just scared out of our minds,â€ she says of that experience. Mantello, who also acted with her in the screen version of Larry Kramerâ€™s The Normal Heart, has remained a good friend all these years.

RELATED: â€˜After The Huntâ€™ Trailer: Julia Roberts, Andrew Garfield & Ayo Edebiri Star In Psychological Thriller

Sheâ€™s open to doing something here in London, she says. â€œOf course I would, yes. I mean, itâ€™s funny because there are these tiny theaters that are near our apartment in New York and little places near our house here [in San Francisco]. And I just think, â€˜Oh, that would be so fun to do a play in a really small space.â€™ Almost like a workshop, almost like going to theater school, but people have to buy tickets to school.â€ She lets out that famous laugh. â€œFingers crossed. It would be so great.â€

She doesnâ€™t return to it often, but she has long loved the idea of the stage. â€œI just think thereâ€™s really nothing like it; Iâ€™ve loved it since I was, like, a 7-year-old and saw Yul Brenner in The King and I at the Atlantic Civic Center Theater.â€ She remembers thinking, â€œThis is the most magical thing a person can do with their life.â€

Another movie with Guadagnino is also on her dance card. â€œHe already has an idea for us, and every time I see him, heâ€™s like, â€˜Darling, this is what weâ€™re going to do.â€™ I would pack my bags now to go do another movie with Luca,â€ she declares.

Andrew Garfield and Julia Roberts in â€˜After the Huntâ€™ Yannis Drakoulidis/Amazon

Is that a serious proposition or just polite casual conversation? Smiling, then sighing, Roberts explains: â€œThis is what I know about Luca: He is the most prolific. I mean, even this movie, this is the fastest I have ever read a script, talked to a director and ended up on a soundstage in my 30-plus-year career. The fastest. So when Luca says he has an idea, and heâ€™s going to write a script, it wouldnâ€™t surprise me if it comes as a late Christmas parcel.â€

Roberts seems eager to experience working with Guadagnino again, even to play a character the complete antithesis of her â€” just as Alma was.

â€œSheâ€™s so different from my personality, from every natural instinct that I have towards the day, a person, a space. [I am,] I would say, almost opposite to her. And so in that regard, itâ€™s very tiring and, in a way, kind of sad. I like to share a space, not command a space. And so I found those days the hardest in a way, especially with all those actors sitting at their desks looking at me with these big eyes with such expectations. And I was happy to leave it all behind, but I was alsoâ€¦â€ She looks for the words. â€œI felt so gratified.â€

She reveals that she keeps in regular touch with Guadagnino, Garfield and Edebiri and has done ever since the movie wrapped. What do they talk about?

â€œLife,â€ she shrugs. â€œI think Ayo and I became such good friends. I admire her so much, and I really, truly adore her. I think sheâ€™s one of the most talented young people I have ever spent time with,â€ Roberts adds her voice quivering on the verge of unexpected tears. Her feelings for Edebiri â€œare so profound,â€ she says.

The friendship developed during rehearsals, and then a confrontation in the film between their characters culminated in a slap. That â€œsealed the dealâ€ and it was like â€œfriends for life,â€ she trills.

RELATED: Ayo Edebiri Recalls Slapping Julia Roberts For â€˜After The Huntâ€™ Scene After Bonding During Rehearsal: â€œIt Was Horribleâ€

Our conversation goes on to encompass her romantic comedy classics, such as Roger Michellâ€™s Notting Hill, based on a script by Richard Curtis. Did she have any sense, 27 years or more ago, that it would become an enduring favorite?

Julia Roberts in â€˜Notting Hillâ€™ (1999) Everett

â€œGosh, I just remember when my agent called me about Notting Hill and I thought, â€˜Well, that sounds like the dumbest idea of any movie I could ever do. Iâ€™m going to play the worldâ€™s biggest movie star and I do what? And then what happens? This sounds so f*cking stupid.â€™ And then I read the script, and I was like, â€˜Oh. This is so charming. Itâ€™s so funny. Oh, shit.â€™ And then I went to lunch with Richard [Curtis] and [producer] Duncan [Kenworthy] and beloved Roger Michell, may he rest in peace.â€

RELATED: Roger Michell Dies: â€˜Notting Hillâ€™ Director Was 65

The lunch was fun, she recalls, even though her initial intent was to tell them, â€œNo, this isnâ€™t going to work. Iâ€™m passing on this movie.â€ â€œAnd they were just so charming and sweet and funny. And I thought, â€˜Wow, this is really going to happen.â€™ And we had a beautiful time doing it. It was cast to perfection [by Mary Selway], all the friends, everybody. It was so great. And we had a beautiful time. And I think Roger, he just created the film in a way that it just, at every turn, it succeeded. It accomplished its goals with everyâ€¦â€ She pauses. â€œAlec Baldwin!â€ she exclaims. â€œThatâ€™s brilliant casting.â€

We chat about comedy; the structure, the architecture of it. Thereâ€™s a math to it, Roberts suggests. â€œBecause there is a math, but I think it changes depending on the kind of comedy that it is. Garry Marshall [who directed her in Pretty Woman] would always say that a joke is in three parts, like a drum beat. I mean, people have their different ways of looking at it. For me, I think it would just depend on what the goal is. But I mean, the joy of life is making people laugh for me. Especially my husband, if I can make my husband really laugh â€” because he makes me really laugh â€” then it just fills me up.â€

Whatâ€™s the secret sauce of a Julia Roberts laugh? A cinematic treasure, I wonder? â€œItâ€™s not something for oneself to analyze,â€ she theorizes. â€œI think it comes from an authentic place of complete joy that I was just born of. Itâ€™s a credit to my parents, I suppose.â€

Skirting back to Pretty Woman, it occurs to me to ask whether the philosopher Alma would have approved of the Vivian Ward character Roberts plays and of the film itself? Roberts roars with laughter. â€œThis is going to be food for thought for the day!â€

Also, would Julia Roberts â€” had she been the right age â€” made Pretty Woman today?

Richard Gere and Julia Roberts in â€˜Pretty Womanâ€™ (1990) Touchstone Pictures

â€œOh, itâ€™s impossible. I have too many years of the weight of the world inside of me now that I wouldnâ€™t be able to kind of levitate in a movie like that, right? I mean, not weight of the world, like, negative, but just all the things that we learn, all the things that we put in our pockets along the lane. It would be impossible to play someone who was really innocent, in a way. I mean, itâ€™s a funny thing to say about a hooker, but I do think that there was an innocence to her, a kind ofâ€¦â€ She pauses. â€œ I guess itâ€™s just being young.â€

Over the years, many have stopped seeing Pretty Woman as an affectionate fairytale.

â€œWell, I think anytime you have a huge passage of time and cultural shiftsâ€¦â€ she muses. â€œThink about all the movies and plays of the â€™20s and â€™30s and â€™40s â€” you would look at them now and just be like, â€˜How are people saying these things, doing these things?â€™â€

Look at Gone With the Wind, for example, she says. â€œI think these are the choices that we make as artists, as art appreciators and people that love to read books and go to the theater and yeah, times change, people change, ideas change.â€

Roberts famously supports Manchester United and loves watching the footy on television. â€œOf course itâ€™s more exciting when youâ€™re there, live. Everything is,â€ she chortles. The World Cup looms large in her future with the hope of tickets to see the elite players perform at the gameâ€™s ultimate competition.

RELATED: FIFA 2026 World Cup: Full Schedule & Fixtures For Groups And Knockout Stages

â€œThis has been quite the constant conversation on our house,â€ Roberts admits as a megawatt smile begins to form.

Before that, though, is the chance to get her feet wet one more time in Oceanâ€™s 14. Is that on, I ask? â€œThatâ€™s what George says. Iâ€™m on his team.â€

This is where pure mathematics is deployed to reassemble the ensemble. â€œWe finally figured out how to align our schedules,â€ she says. â€œThese are complicated schedules,â€ she notes while relaying that her Oceanâ€™s teammate Don Cheadle will be starring with Edebiri on Broadway in a revival of David Auburnâ€™s play Proof for a limited run in the spring and early summer. â€œThereâ€™s so many things to have to consider, but when George gets a bee in his bonnet, things happen.â€

George Clooney and Julia Roberts

Speaking of Clooney, we chuckle over the running gag in Jay Kelly where his eponymous character, a movie star, finds that every set, hotel and trailer he visits includes a rider that dictates a slice of cheesecake at every stop, even though he detests the dessert. After watching the film, Roberts started to notice that everywhere she goes, â€œthere is either a huge bag or a huge bowl of raw almonds. I have no idea why,â€ she shrugs.

RELATED: George Clooney Plays A Fictional Movie Star In â€˜Jay Kellyâ€™ But Heâ€™s Not The First â€“ Hereâ€™s 10 Of The Bestâ€¦

And does she even like these nuts? â€œI like them, but not in bulk!â€ she says, gesticulating wildly with her hands. â€œI mean, theyâ€™re everywhere I go. Itâ€™s so funny. And so I just recently sent an email since watching Jay Kelly, since seeing all these almonds, I sent email and said, â€™In the new year, one thing I would really like to do is review any and all riders that pertain to me in this world, because I think it might be time for a little reset on the almonds.â€™â€

content:
Amazon Prime Video has rounded out the cast for its â€œTomb Raiderâ€ series.

Officially joining the video game adaptation are Sigourney Weaver, who Variety previously reported to be eyeing a role, as well as Jason Isaacs, Celia Imrie, Bill Paterson, Martin Bobb-Semple, Jack Bannon, John Heffernan, Paterson Joseph, Sasha Luss, Juliette Motamed and August Wittgenstein. As previously announced, Sophie Turner leads the series as Lara Croft.

Of them, three are playing previously existing roles within the â€œTomb Raidersâ€ franchise: Isaacs plays Laraâ€™s uncle Atlas DeMornay; Patterson plays Winston, the Croft family butler; and Bobb-Semple plays Zip, Laraâ€™s tech support and friend.

Popular on Variety

Weaver plays one of the new characters: Evelyn Wallis, who is described as â€œa mysterious, high-flying woman who is keen to exploit Laraâ€™s talents.â€

Bannon plays Gerry, â€œLaraâ€™s personal pilot and snack collector.â€

Heffernan plays David, â€œan exhausted government official who finds himself tangled up in Laraâ€™s unusual world.â€

Imrie plays Francine, the head of advancement at the British Museum, focused solely on raising funds and glasses of champagne.â€

Joseph plays Thomas Warner, â€œa senior government official brought in to clean up an almighty mess.â€

Luss plays Sasha, â€œa fierce, deeply competitive new adversary of Laraâ€™s.â€

Motamed plays Georgia, â€œa devoted, by-the-books curator at the British Museum, dedicated to the â€˜properâ€™ preservation of history.â€

Wittgenstein plays Lukas, â€œan illegal raider who shares history with Lara in more ways than one.â€

title: â€˜Industryâ€™ Season 4 Is a Wildly Ambitious Reinvention That Cranks the HBO Finance Drama Up to 11: TV Review
summary: Thereâ€™s a lot of talk about narrative and messaging in Season 4 of HBOâ€™s â€œIndustry.â€ â€œIn America, your story begins when you start telling it,â€ proclaims one aspiring titan of finance. â€œListeners tune in to the belief of the teller,â€ a nervous CEO is told mid-pep talk. â€œWe donâ€™t need proof,â€ a trader says of […]
content:
Thereâ€™s a lot of talk about narrative and messaging in Season 4 of HBOâ€™s â€œIndustry.â€ â€œIn America, your story begins when you start telling it,â€ proclaims one aspiring titan of finance. â€œListeners tune in to the belief of the teller,â€ a nervous CEO is told mid-pep talk. â€œWe donâ€™t need proof,â€ a trader says of their most audacious play yet, â€œbecause we finally have a good story to tell.â€

Within â€œIndustry,â€ such statements are used to interrogate the line between masters of the universe who bend fate to their will and outright frauds. Antiheroine Harper Stern (Myhaâ€™la) is arguably the latter, having parlayed a fake college transcript into a position atop her very own fund. But Harper may have met her match, or at least a mirror, in Whitney Halberstram (Max Minghella), another American whoâ€™s attempting to reinvent themselves in Londonâ€™s money market. Whitney is the co-founder and CFO of Tender, a payment processor known for supporting gray-market industries like gambling and pornography thatâ€™s trying to evolve into a legitimate bank. Harper is running a shorts-only operation, betting against companies she sees as overvalued and (hopefully) making money in the process. When Harper sets her sights on Tender, she ignites a war that gives the season its heart-pounding momentum.

Zoom out, however, and you can see why â€œIndustryâ€ creators Mickey Down and Konrad Kay are so concerned with external perception. At the end of Season 3, the former Oxford classmates â€” whose brief stints in banking inspired the show â€” effectively burned their initial setup to the ground. â€œIndustryâ€ began with a quartet of new graduates, including Harper and pampered publishing heiress Yasmin Kara-Hanani (Marisa Abela), getting hired as grunt-work analysts at the fictional Pierpoint & Co. Slowly and then all at once, this shared setting started to fracture. Harper got fired for the aforementioned deception. Ensemble members like David Jonsson and Harry Lawtey left to pursue other opportunities, and thus their characters did as well. Yasmin exited finance altogether, embracing her destiny as the socialite bride-to-be of blue-blooded aristocrat Henry Muck (Kit Harington). And to cap it all off, Pierpoint itself collapsed after an ill-advised pivot into so-called ethical investing. The trading floor that saw so much of the seriesâ€™s action is no longer in operation.

Popular on Variety

Down and Kay couldâ€™ve called it right there, leaving â€œIndustryâ€ a tight, compressed yarn about the compromises of early adulthood. Instead, they opted to forge ahead, in part because Season 3 was the first to be a bona fide hit rather than a cult favorite of critics like myself. The downfall of Pierpoint has afforded the pair, who direct half of the new season in addition to showrunning, that most exciting and terrifying of prospects: a blank slate. The resulting vacuum creates the potential for wildly divergent paths in the meta arc of the show. One is that â€œIndustryâ€ rises from the ashes to become bigger and more ambitious than ever, joining the upper tier of HBOâ€™s roster. The other is that, without its distinct angle and grounding ballast, â€œIndustryâ€ tips over into grandiosity, never quite establishing a sound basis for moving past such a natural endpoint.

Over eight episodes, Season 4 hews much closer to the latter end of this spectrum than the former. The transition is not, nor would it likely ever be, seamless; about once an episode, especially the early ones, thereâ€™s a moment that made me worry â€œIndustryâ€ had jumped the shark into pure provocation. But as the Tender plot â€” which Down and Kay have said was inspired by â€œMichael Clayton,â€ an influence that grows increasingly more apparent â€” gets going, the season tightens and accelerates. And â€œIndustryâ€ continues to drill down on Harper and Yasminâ€™s relationship, a dynamic Season 3 identified as the heart of the show by elevating Abela to effective co-lead. She and Myhaâ€™la are better than ever in Season 4 as both their characters start to understand their seeming happy endings didnâ€™t afford them as much freedom as they thought.

Itâ€™s true that the loss of a bottom-up perspective makes â€œIndustryâ€ less distinct on the page from analogs like â€œSuccessionâ€ or â€œBillions.â€ In fact, â€œIndustryâ€ positively revels in its charactersâ€™ newfound status; the premiere sees a comfortably retired Eric Tao (Ken Leung) share a golf course with a distant, red-capped figure weâ€™re meant to understand is Donald J. Trump, while Harper goes to visit her benefactor Otto Mostyn (Roger Barclay) in Parliament, where heâ€™s recently joined the House of Lords. Once upwardly mobile strivers, these people are now firmly ensconced in the halls of power â€” an ideal opportunity for them to reenact the abuses they used to suffer from above.

Thatâ€™s the real difference-maker: The audience didnâ€™t meet Harper and Yasmin at the top. We know exactly what itâ€™s taken and all theyâ€™ve endured to get where they are, from the strong implication that Yasminâ€™s father sexually abused her to Harperâ€™s estrangement from her mother and twin brother. So when Harper realizes Ottoâ€™s backing comes with more strings than heâ€™d led her to believe, or Yasmin has to do the heavy lifting when Henryâ€™s loss of a safe parliamentary seat sends him into a tailspin of depression, we feel their disappointments as acutely as their triumphs. Theyâ€™re the bridge that takes â€œIndustryâ€ from Pierpoint into its wider, if not necessarily brighter, future.

This transition nonetheless necessitates an infusion of new blood, especially from outside the world of finance. At Tender, Whitney clashes with his more hedonistic co-founder Jonah (Kal Penn) and bosses around his assistant Haley (Kiernan Shipka). Harper is tipped off to Tenderâ€™s shady dealings by reporter Jim Dycker (Charlie Heaton), widening a foothold in the world of journalism previously established by Henryâ€™s tabloid baron uncle Alexander (Andrew Havill). Henryâ€™s election defeat reflects the real-life Labour wave of 2024, introducing fresh faces like business minister Lisa (Chloe Pirrie) and MP Jenny (Amy James-Kelly) for Tender to lobby as it navigates regulatory hurdles. What was once a show about business is now a cross-section of the overlapping institutions that make up the status quo, and how much disruptors like Harper and Whitney can â€” or canâ€™t â€” change them.

Alumni of shows like â€œMad Men,â€ â€œStranger Thingsâ€ and â€œDept. Qâ€ are a sign of â€œIndustryâ€™sâ€ increased sway, though none ever threaten to steal the show from Harper and Yasminâ€™s electric, resentment-laden frenmity. (Yasmin may no longer have anything as tawdry as â€œa job,â€ but her new role as a behind-the-scenes connector of the rich and influential keeps her in Harperâ€™s orbit.) But for those who stick around, a standout can work their way into the showâ€™s core with surprising speed. It can be hard to remember Sweetpea Golightly (Miriam Petche), the Pierpoint intern who paid her way through university with OnlyFans nudes, was introduced only last season. Now doing research for Harper, whose adamant defense of Sweetpeaâ€™s erstwhile gig reveals a soft side to the ruthless Machiavellian, sheâ€™s by far the easiest ensemble member to root for. Though with this crowd, thatâ€™s not a high bar.

The widening scope makes it more difficult for â€œIndustryâ€ to maintain a consistent baseline. Often, Down and Kay play this to their advantage; a West African interlude quite literally takes the show to new places, while a spotlight on Yasminâ€™s domestic disappointment swaps Nathan Micayâ€™s electronic score for â€œBarry Lyndonâ€-like strings. At other times, the sex and drugs that have been part of the â€œIndustryâ€ DNA from the start begin to feel more discordant. The show continues to up the ante of everyoneâ€™s after-hours activities, even as they mature and have more to lose. Keeping everyone together, or even on the same continent, requires some mild contortions: a move to New York Harper floated in the Season 3 finale clearly did not come to pass, while a diminished Rishi (Sagar Radia) continues to hang around even after his life has completely collapsed.

But stepping back to consider the sheer difficulty of what â€œIndustryâ€ is attempting puts these growing pains in perspective. Season 3 was the culmination of several years of pent-up tension. Season 4 is building something, if not entirely new, then without much of the scaffolding that once gave â€œIndustryâ€ a consistent structure. Itâ€™s an effort so commendable in principle and enjoyable in practice that a little leeway is the least â€œIndustryâ€ can ask. And by moving this far beyond Pierpoint, the show has proven it can, and should, keep going further still.

â€œIndustryâ€ Season 4 will premiere on HBO and HBO Max on Jan. 11 at 9 p.m. ET, with remaining episodes airing weekly on Sundays.

content:

Danny Peykoffâ€™s Big Newport Studios and Josh Bernsteinâ€™s comics publisher Z2 are unveiling the book series following completion of production of the film, which is inspired by punk band Rancid and its 1995 album â€˜And Out Come the Wolvesâ€™, the filmâ€™s original title. The story follows two best friends fighting for survival in the 1990s East Bay punk scene, surrounded by poverty, drugs and danger.

â€¦And Out Comes the Wolf marks Peykoffâ€™s directorial debut. The producer, director and writer founded Big Newport, with the Rancid film as its debut. He was an executive producer on Kevin Costnerâ€™s Western trilogy, Horizon: An American Saga.

title: â€˜Iâ€™m Chevy Chase and Youâ€™re Notâ€™ Review: Marina Zenovichâ€™s Fascinating Doc Explores How Chevy Chaseâ€™s Dark Side Was the Flip Side of His Genius
summary: Zenovich isnâ€™t launching harangues against "cancel culture." Sheâ€™s asking, in a far more ingenuous and exploratory way: What do we think about someone like Chevy Chase? How do we square his offscreen cruelty with his laid-back comic artistry, especially when you can see a distinct glimmer of the former in the latter?
content:
When you watch â€œIâ€™m Chevy Chase and Youâ€™re Not,â€ Marina Zenovichâ€™s spry and fascinating dark-side-of-a-comedian documentary, you hear countless tales of Chevy Chaseâ€™s casual cruelty and too-wise-for-you attitude and devotion to behaving badly â€” or, at least, mouthing off so rudely that it became a form of behavior. If you go into the movie wanting to be shocked and appalled, you wonâ€™t be disappointed. Off camera, a lot of comedians have prickly and difficult personalities. But thereâ€™s prickly and then thereâ€™s the unique drive-by karma of Chevy Chase, a comedian who helped to invent â€œSaturday Night Live,â€ who proved to be a singular and hilarious master of ironic barbed detachment, who became one of the most celebrated movie stars of the 1980s, and who was such a famously nasty and unpleasant person to deal with that the word â€œassholeâ€ followed him around as if it was his middle name.

The stories are legion, and they all get told here. According to Chaseâ€™s old friend Peter Aaron, who met him at Bard College in 1965, Chevy, in the dining-hall commons, would pull stunts like reaching for the salt and knocking a glass of water over onto someoneâ€™s lap. He was a jerk, yet in his way he was already warming up for â€œSaturday Night Live.â€ Ten years later, as â€œSNLâ€ was being pulled together, Lorne Michaels wanted him to be a writer, but Chase insisted that he be on camera. We see his audition tape, and two things strike you about it: that he was shockingly tall and handsome for a comedian, with a puckishness that someone this good-looking wasnâ€™t supposed to have, and that the hostility came off him like plumes of electro-static. Backstage, he was so high-handed that he took it upon himself to give the other cast members notes.

Popular on Variety

After becoming a movie star, Chase gave Mike Ovitz a Cartier clock engraved on the back with â€œKeep getting me the $6 million.â€ John Carpenter says that working with Chase on â€œMemoirs of an Invisible Manâ€ (1992) was so hellish it made him want to quit the business. And when Chase hosted â€œSaturday Night Liveâ€ in 1985, he fastened on Terry Sweeney, the showâ€™s first openly gay cast member, and baited him for being gay, suggesting that in the midst of the AIDS epidemic there might be a comedy routine in Sweeney getting weighed each week.

â€œI could see right away,â€ recalls Aykroyd in the documentary, â€œthat this guy was simultaneously talented and very dangerous.â€ Alan Greisman, a film producer who became a friend of Chaseâ€™s (even though Chevy, on the set of the 1981 movie they made together, â€œModern Problems,â€ did as much cocaine as the burnout character he was playing), says, â€œI donâ€™t think he consciously wants to be an asshole. I think the asshole version of him is somebody who is desperate for something he either lost or doesnâ€™t have.â€ Based on what we hear in â€œIâ€™m Chevy Chase and Youâ€™re Not,â€ to say that Chase acted like an asshole doesnâ€™t do justice to his distemper. He was a passive-aggressive bully who perfected his own sadistic brand of Zen flippancy. He was a person who would bait you to your face, then add insult to injury by implying that it was all a joke.

It seemed, at the time, an attitude that was quite contempo in its heartlessness. But Chaseâ€™s sense of humor was actually based on something that had its roots in the 1960s. At the time, it was called the put-on. You say something, you donâ€™t mean it (except that maybe, deep down, you do), and itâ€™s all an act of thinly veiled aggression, because youâ€™re putting one over on The Man, or someone you donâ€™t like, or a person who doesnâ€™t deserve to be talked to straight. But Chase ratcheted up the put-on in two ways. He made it crazy and surreal, and unlike Bill Murray, who had an affectionate counterculture shagginess, Chase stripped the put-on of any vestige of social-political morality. He was putting on just becauseâ€¦he wanted to fuck with you. And that became his entire personality.

As a documentary filmmaker, Marina Zenovich has long been drawn to difficult personalities, like Roman Polanski (she made two films about him) and Robin Williams, but itâ€™s not just because she sees the drama in their turbulence (though thatâ€™s part of it). She also wants to grapple â€” and does, brilliantly â€” with what you might call the primal issue of politically incorrect artists. Namely, what are we supposed to do with these figures who create extraordinary things, who are cherished by people around the globe, yet have seriously problematic lives and personalities? Zenovich isnâ€™t doing a harangue against â€œcancel culture.â€ Sheâ€™s asking, in a far more ingenuous and exploratory way: What do we think about someone like Chevy Chase? How do we square his offscreen cruelty with his laid-back comic artistry, especially when you can see a distinct glimmer of the former in the latter?

Zenovich interviews the 82-year-old Chevy Chase today, seated at a table in his comfy suburban home in Bedford, NY, and the interview, in its way, is a performative psychodrama. Chevy wants to be honest, he wants to tell it like it is, but heâ€™s also a compulsive cut-up and control freak whose guardedness takes the form of lashing out. â€œThis is the way I am, at my age,â€ he says after telling an X-rated joke about Bill and Hillary Clinton. â€œJust a child. An angry child.â€ He knows himself too well. A child is exactly what Chase is. He wonâ€™t grow up. Early on, Zenovich tells him that sheâ€™s simply trying to figure him out. â€œNo shit!â€ he says, adding, â€œItâ€™s not going to be easy for you.â€ Why not? â€œYouâ€™re not bright enough. Howâ€™s that?â€ Then he gives her a frozen smile of triumph. â€œMy answer is: Iâ€™m complex, and Iâ€™m deep, and I can be hurt easily, and I react spontaneously to people who want to figure me out.â€

The film shows you how he got to be this way: raised by a mother with possible schizophrenic tendencies who would wake him up by slapping him, and by an abusive stepfather. His childhood was a hellhole. His entire â€œIâ€™m Chevy Chase and youâ€™re not, and by the way go fuck yourselfâ€ personality is a damaged personâ€™s defense mechanism. So maybe itâ€™s no surprise that while the Chase we see here is undeniably a dick (at this point itâ€™s his brand), he also has disarming spasms of vulnerability and guilt, and when he wants to be heâ€™s quite sweet. Heâ€™s someone who made the choice, over and over again, to be an asshole. Yet his fans adore him. He gets a large bag of fan mail each week, all of which he answers by signing photographs, and we see him at holiday time, going on his annual jaunt to speak at local showings of â€œNational Lampoonâ€™s Christmas Vacation,â€ a movie as beloved by children of the â€™80s as â€œA Christmas Storyâ€ is. He treats his fans with grace and something like modesty. He has also been married, for 43 years, to Jayni Chase, an agile sweetheart who appears devoted to him. Does any of this give him absolution? No, but it does make him a complicated asshole.

Fifty years later, the extraordinary rocket ship of Chaseâ€™s career is still a marvel to behold â€” how he helped to define â€œSNL,â€ inventing Weekend Update as a showcase for his WASP-on-nut-pills aggro deadpan, and how he left the show way too early, because Hollywood was calling (and because his second wife, Jacqueline Carlin, refused to move from L.A. to New York). Over the last year, Iâ€™ve called both â€œAnnie Hallâ€ and â€œWhen Harry Met Sallyâ€ the launchpad of the revival of the romantic comedy, but â€œIâ€™m Chevy Chase and Youâ€™re Notâ€ made me realize that I was wrong. Both those films were instrumental, but the launch of the cheeseball genre that the rom-com became really goes back to Chaseâ€™s first big movie, â€œFoul Playâ€ (1978), a film that looks better in hindsight. He and Goldie Hawn had a skewed chemistry in it, and Hawn is on hand in the doc testifying to how much the asshole could, at moments, be a mensch.

But Chase, as Mike Ovtiz explains quite accurately, didnâ€™t run his career in a logical fashion. He was sublime in â€œCaddyshack,â€ but he didnâ€™t make good on his leading-man promise. The â€œVacationâ€ films saved him, of course, and he was vintage Chevy in them, but by the mid-â€™80s his shtick had begun to lose its surprise. You could feel that in â€œDeal of the Centuryâ€ and â€œThree Amigos!â€ and â€œSpies Like Us,â€ where the Chase mystique was running on fumes. Even after his career wound down, he never stopped popping up in movies, though by the late â€™90s and 2000s none of his supporting turns could match the comic drama of his contentious appearances on â€œThe Howard Stern Show.â€

â€œIâ€™m Chevy Chase and Youâ€™re Notâ€ devotes its second half to Chaseâ€™s troubled childhood, and to how he cleaned himself up after too many years in the drug wilderness, and also to the extraordinary war zone that â€œCommunity,â€ the NBC sitcom that revived his career, became. The young cast of â€œCommunityâ€ resented his entitlement; he was 66 years old and still irascible. And when the tension exploded in Chase using the N-word on set, as he was trying to explain how he would use it with Richard Pryor on â€œSNLâ€ (the doc includes their famous racial-epithet sketch, perhaps the ultimate example of you-could-never-do-that-today), the series became a meltdown. After all of this, is Chevy Chase chastened? Yes and no. You can see that he knows he sometimes went too far, yet during the 50th anniversary show of â€œSaturday Night Live,â€ when he was not invited to perform, even for one moment, that was basically the entertainment industry blackballing him for 50 years of snark-fueled transgression. He admits on camera how much it hurt. You could say, in that way, that he has paid his dues. Heâ€™s still Chevy Chase, but by the end of this movie youâ€™re almost grateful youâ€™re not.

content:

â€œI have been a filmmaker for over 50 years and have seen firsthand how the evolution of the VFX industry has unlocked amazing new types of storytelling time and time again.â€ Bruckheimer said. â€œSome of the most memorable collaborations of my career have been on projects where the VFX artists and technologists bring their magic to the screen. content:
Ben Affleck appeared on â€œJimmy Kimmel Live!â€ amid his press tour for Netflixâ€™s â€œThe Ripâ€ and looked back on the â€œmassive embarrassmentâ€ of being snubbed at the Oscars for best director with â€œArgo.â€ Affleck was a frontrunner to land a nom. He won best director honors at the Golden Globes, Critics Choice Awards and BAFTAs. Alas, Affleck was snubbed while â€œArgoâ€ went on to earn seven Oscar nominations and win best picture and two other prizes.

â€œIt was the year, the horrible thing of everyone telling you, â€˜Youâ€™re gonna get nominated, youâ€™re gonna get nominated for director,â€™â€ Affleck remembered. â€œAnd so, of course, I wake up that morning, and sure enough â€” and, by the way, itâ€™s not [unlike] any other morning that I had not been nominated for best director. But all of a sudden, itâ€™s a massive embarrassment. I woke up and people [said], â€˜You didnâ€™t get nominated.â€™â€

Affleckâ€™s story reminded Kimmel of being at the Critics Choice Awards the night prior, where â€œOnce Battle After Anotherâ€ picked up major honors for best picture, director and adapted screenplay but left leading man Leonardo DiCaprio shut out for best actor (which went to Timothee Chalamet for â€œMarty Supremeâ€).

Popular on Variety

â€œI was thinking, boy, heâ€™s got so many better places to be,â€ Kimmel quipped about DiCaprio. â€œAnd the movie wins best picture. The director Paul Thomas Anderson wins best director, and then he doesnâ€™t win. And Iâ€™m thinking he must be so pissed that [he had to leave] whatever he got airlifted from â€” a yacht somewhere â€” and couldnâ€™t be there anymore. He came to lose.â€

â€œThis is maybe the worst award-show situation ever,â€ Kimmel continued. â€œI think youâ€™re underselling this. Because â€˜Argo,â€™ not only was it nominated for the Oscar for best picture, you won best picture. You starred in it and directed it, and you were not nominated in either category â€¦ itâ€™s as if the movie directed itself.â€

â€œThatâ€™s sort of what it felt like,â€ Affleck replied. â€œThe day of the snub, which all of a sudden itâ€™s a negative event and a horrible thing, I had to go to the Critics Choice Awards. I remember getting there and thereâ€™s a red carpet line, like 500 people dying to talk to me, and every single one of them was like, â€˜Hi! So the snubâ€¦â€™ What do you say to that? â€˜Itâ€™s a bummer!â€™ I did end up winning the Critics Choice Award.â€

â€œHonestly, itâ€™s just embarrassing,â€ Affleck added. â€œI wasnâ€™t the one going out there being like, â€œIâ€™m going to be nominated!â€™ Itâ€™s having to be put through the ritual of then answering for why you didnâ€™t get nominated. I didnâ€™t say I was [going to be]!â€

Someone who can relate to what Affleck is talking about is Bradley Cooper, who was similarly snubbed for best director with â€œA Star Is Bornâ€ despite landing nominations from the Golden Globes, Criticsâ€™ Choice Awards and Directors Guild of America. Cooper also said the snub was â€œembarrassing.â€

â€œThe first thing I felt was embarrassment, actually. Think about it. I felt embarrassed that I didnâ€™t do my part,â€ Cooper told Oprah in 2019. â€œEven if I got the nomination, it should not give me any sense of whether I did my job or not. Thatâ€™s the trick, to make something that you believe in.â€

Cooper explained that did not set out to make a movie that landed Academy Award nominations, adding: â€œThe only thing I set out to do was to tap into as an authentic place as possible. [An authentic place] in myself and everybody I asked to make this movie â€” to tell a human story of people who are going to deal with their family life, trauma as a child, addiction in a real way, love in this life and finding your voice.â€

Noting on the IMO with Michelle Obama & Craig Robinson podcast that he â€œworks a lotâ€ and has â€œseveral jobs,â€ including his History Channel series Hazardous History, he said, â€œPeople keep asking me am I gonna retire, or, â€˜Have you retired?â€™ And I think that is the furthest thing from my imagination. I will retire when I am not able to [act] again, more.â€

content:
Hereâ€™s one Olympic competition that is now closed to certain entrants.

NBCUniversal said Tuesday that it has sold out of all the commercial inventory tied to its coming telecast of the 2026 Winter Olympics from Milan Cortina, offering the latest example of the growing dependence traditional media companies have on sports and live events. The ad-sales milestone comes after NBC has dispensed with all the ad time tied to its looming February broadcast of Super Bowl LX as well as the NBA All-Star Game. The three events boosted NBCUâ€™s status in last yearâ€™s â€œupfrontâ€ sales market.

NBCU sold approximately $900 million in advertising tied to each of its most recent Winter Olympics efforts, the 2022 Games from Beijing and the 2018 spectacular from PyeongChang. The company said its Milan Winter Olympics had secured â€œthe highest linear and digital revenue in Winter Olympics history,â€ without offering a specific number.

Popular on Variety

â€œFor the first time in our companyâ€™s history, we have seen such unprecedented demand that we are officially sold out of our inventory this far in advance of a Games,â€ said Peter Lazarus, executive vice president of NBC Sports & Olympics, Advertising and Partnerships, in a statement. â€œWe are excited to once again deliver fans a word class viewing experience; while providing brands the powerful halo effect the Olympics has to offer.â€

NBC had reason to focus on sports ad sales. The company had hundreds of hours of sports to sell last year, with a February that is crammed with Olympics telecasts, Super Bowl programming and NBA matches. More is on the way, with a new rights deal with Major League Baseball that will give NBC games to show on Sunday nights in the interim between its NBA and NFL deals.

â€œWith the resurgence of the Olympic movement, our strongest Sports Upfront in history, the early sell out of Super Bowl LX, and the remarkable return of the NBA, NBCUniversal has solidified itself as a sports powerhouse and brands have taken notice,â€ said Mark Marshall, chairman, global advertising & partnerships, NBCUniversal, in a statement.

NBCU is harnessing momentum from its recent Summer Olympics telecast from Paris. The event relied more heavily on bespoke streaming experiences, smart curation of events for broadcast primetime and lots of celebrity cameos. The company said more than 100 advertisers committing to the Winter Olympics were new to the event. Nearly 60 invested in unique elements tied to the Games and more than a dozen invested in sponsorships that will offer fans more live sports viewing.

title: NBCUniversal Sells Out Ad Inventory For Milan Cortina Winter Olympics A Month Before Opening Ceremony
summary: With a month to go before the start of the Winter Olympics in Milan Cortina, Italy, NBCUniversal says it has sold out of its advertising inventory for the Games. The number of advertisers has hit a record for the Winter Olympics, NBCU said, and the sellout is the earliest ever recorded. The Games will be […]
content:
With a month to go before the start of the Winter Olympics in Milan Cortina, Italy, NBCUniversal says it has sold out of its advertising inventory for the Games.

The number of advertisers has hit a record for the Winter Olympics, NBCU said, and the sellout is the earliest ever recorded.

The Games will be part of what the media giant is calling a â€œLegendary Februaryâ€ of programming, alongside the Super Bowl and the NBA All-Star Game.

Along with linear networks, streaming flagship Peacock will play a key role in covering the Winter Olympics. The 2024 Summer Olympics in Paris boosted subscriber levels for Peacock and saw a record ad revenue haul north of $1.25 billion. In announcing the Winter Games sellout, NBCU did not provide any estimates of rates or revenue, though it said it is a new record for the Winter Games on both linear and digital.

Super Bowl LX, which will be played outside San Francisco, also sold its ad inventory early, and NBCU says it had the strongest sports upfront in history in the 2025-26 cycle.

Watch on Deadline

NBCU â€œhas solidified itself as a sports powerhouse and brands have taken notice,â€ global ad and partnerships chief Mark Marshall said.

More than 100 advertisers are new to the Games, with 85% of overall buyers opting for digital placements. Nearly 60 advertisers have invested in â€œunique marketing elements,â€ NBCU added, which is up 174% from Beijing 2022.

Last year, NBCU parent Comcast paid $3 billion to extend its Olympic rights through 2036. That agreement also designates the company as a strategic partner, not just a rights holder.

title: â€˜No Other Choiceâ€™: Read The Screenplay For Park Chan-Wookâ€™s Dark Comedy Thriller About A Fired Workerâ€™s Plot To Eliminate His Competition
summary: Director Park Chan-wook’s No Other Choice (Eojjeolsugaeopda), a satirical dark comedy thriller based on Donald E. Westlake’s 1997 novel The Ax, had its world premiere in the main competition at the 82nd Venice Film Festival. The film garnered significant critical attention, receiving a nine-minute standing ovation on the Lido and later going on to win the inaugural International […]
content:
Director Park Chan-wookâ€˜s No Other Choice (Eojjeolsugaeopda), a satirical dark comedy thriller based on Donald E. Westlakeâ€™s 1997 novel The Ax, had its world premiere in the main competition at the 82nd Venice Film Festival. The film garnered significant critical attention, receiving a nine-minute standing ovation on the Lido and later going on to win the inaugural International Peopleâ€™s Choice Award at the Toronto Film Festival. It has since been selected as South Koreaâ€™s entry for the Best International Feature Film at this yearâ€™s Oscars.

Neon landed No Other Choice ahead of its festival run and released it in the U.S. on December 25, grossing $22.6 million to date. It has picked up Golden Globes nominations for Best Picture â€“ Musical or Comedy and Non-English Language as well as a nom for star Byung-hun Lee. It also scored a Best Pic nom from the Gotham Awards and a Foreign Language nom from Critics Choice. Critics Choice and the Gothams also nominated the adapted screenplay credited to Park, Lee Kyoung-mi, Jahye Lee and Don McKellar.

Watch on Deadline

Set in Busan, South Korea, the script immediately establishes the perfect, albeit precarious, domestic world of Yoo Man-soo (Lee) and his proud wife, Lee Mi-ri (Son Ye-jin), and their two children. The film opens with a deceptively serene scene: Yoo is happily barbecuing an eel, a supposed gift for his hard work at the factory â€” unaware that it is, in fact, a severance gift.

Yoo, an award-winning paper factory manager, is abruptly laid off with his colleagues, marking the beginning of his devastating decline. In a moment of false bravado at a group counseling session, the once-proud father declares an optimistic, yet fatally flawed, â€œIn three months, Iâ€™ll get hired again! I feel great!â€ This declaration is a key turning point, setting into motion the dangerous and morally corrupt oath he takes to reclaim his respect and status as a provider.

The screenplay efficiently charts Yooâ€™s humiliating and accelerating financial ruin. Months later, heâ€™s reduced to working at a grocery store. A prospective job interview â€” one where he fails to answer the seemingly innocuous question, â€œWhat is your weaknessâ€ â€” underscores his deep-seated inability to adapt or self-reflect. The material challenges pile up: escalating mortgage bills, downgrading their car, a persistent toothache that mirrors his internal rot, and the devastating notice of an impending foreclosure on his childhood home.

In desperation, Yoo hatches a chilling yet darkly logical plan. He posts a job advertisement for a fictitious paper company to solicit rÃ©sumÃ©s from his former colleagues and industry rivals. He then systematically targets and murders the qualified candidates, attempting to destroy the competition and increase his own negligible chance of re-employment.

The scriptâ€™s sharpest focus is on the theme of identity and masculine pride of unemployed men who view working in â€œlesserâ€ roles as beneath them, contrasting sharply with the stress and practical sacrifices endured by their wives and families. Yoo is a perfect vehicle for this satire, as his ultimate act of violence is driven not by necessity but rather a pathological need to maintain an image of success.

The filmâ€™s title is derived from a key scene where Yoo uses the tapping method (a coping technique taught in his counseling sessions), repeating the phrase â€œno other choiceâ€ as a warped mantra before committing one of his calculated murders. This brilliantly encapsulates the dark irony: his actions are not a last resort but a grotesque consequence of his own inability to accept reality or compromise his ego.

Park was fascinated by the novelâ€™s core psychological mechanism: the process by which an â€œordinary person who was perfectly normal, ends up like this in a social system.â€ He notes that the victims Yoo targets are essentially his alter egos â€” men facing the same existential crisis. He highlights the irony that Yoo doesnâ€™t target the company or the capitalist system that wronged him, but instead goes for those who are equally as pitiful as he is.
