title: â€˜Rock, Paper, Scissorsâ€™ Filmmakers On Humanizing The Realities Of War Between Russia & Ukraine
summary: In the game of war, there are no winners, no losers, only casualties. Both unsettling and tender is Franz BÃ¶hmâ€™s BAFTA-winning short film Rock, Paper, Scissors, which follows the true story of Ivan (Oleksandr Rudynskyi) as he helps his father (Sergey Kalantay) run a makeshift hospital near the frontline of the Russia-Ukraine war. When Russian […]
content:
In the game of war, there are no winners, no losers, only casualties. Both unsettling and tender is Franz BÃ¶hmâ€™s BAFTA-winning short film Rock, Paper, Scissors, which follows the true story of Ivan (Oleksandr Rudynskyi) as he helps his father (Sergey Kalantay) run a makeshift hospital near the frontline of the Russia-Ukraine war. When Russian aircraft carrier bombs thwart their plans to seek a more undisturbed area, Russian soldiers start to seek out their bunker. To keep the most vulnerable safe, Ivan has to decide to confront the soldiers or deceive them at the potential cost of his life.

The 20-minute short film, produced by Hayder Rothschild Hoozeer and backed by the National Film and Television School, in addition to winning Best Student Film and the Best Short Film Grand Prize at HollyShorts London, has also landed the 2026 Oscars shortlist.

Below, Hoozeer and BÃ¶hm talk to Deadline about the emotional vulnerabilities and dangers of war.

Watch on Deadline

DEADLINE: How did your meeting with Ivan inform Rock, Paper, Scissors?

FRANZ BÃ–HM: I met Ivan during his time in the U.K. We met by coincidence and created a wonderful friendship. At some point, I asked about a scar he had on his leg, and he told me this incredible story about the impossible decisions he had to make during the war [in Ukraine]. I was very impressed by his moral courage and bravery, and very impressed by how, over the span of a day, he was forced to grow up and lose any sense of teenage freedom he mightâ€™ve had. He volunteered afterwards to serve in the Ukrainian military, but we were able to write a screenplay together, and I also got his advice on location scouting. It was a wonderful collaboration.

Rock, Paper, Scissors National Film and Television School

DEADLINE: Oleksandr Rudynskyi plays Ivan. Talk about that collaboration between you two.

BÃ–HM: Collaborating with Oleksandr was an enormous honor and pleasure. Heâ€™s incredibly talented, experienced and a wonderful actor. We worked really hard to get him in Ukraine; he is a very well-known actor, and when Ivan learned that Oleksandr was going to play him, that was a huge surprise.

HAYDER HOOZEER: I think itâ€™s also worth mentioning that during the time of the production itself, when we were shooting the film and even pre-production, the real Ivan was in Ukraine at the frontline. So, the events the story is telling you are happening in real time for many other Ukrainians. Even up until this point, the conflict is still ongoing at the frontline in Ukraine. Ivan also passed before seeing the complete version of this film. We had an alternative ending that we had intended to do, but Iâ€™m sure people will understand this: you never really meet someone knowing that they are going to die [relatively soon].

Thatâ€™s the weight weâ€™ve carried throughout everything to this point: Ivan was alive whilst we were making this film, and then he was killed. There isnâ€™t anything that prepares you for that reality, especially in filmmaking. When he passed, we cut out parts of that other ending because ethically and morally it didnâ€™t feel right to continue his story in the direction that we were going to do as a result of honoring his death.

DEADLINE: Because this situation is still ongoing, was there fear in covering this topic?

HOOZEER: Well, we now have the support from the Office of the President of Ukraine â€“ I had gone over to Ukraine during active bombardment twice in 2025. What was so heartbreaking and inspiring was the quiet bravery and resilience of the people in Ukraine. It was really important for us to ensure this story was as authentic as possible and was supported by that community. We brought over Ukrainian actors from Germany. We worked with the Ministry of Culture to bring over Oleksandr to be able to shoot in the U.K., and even that had its own level of complications because as soon as he arrived, his best friend was killed in Ukraine. Franz and I had a conversation about how we should postpone the shoot because his family and friends were far more important than the film we were making. We spoke to Oleksandr about this, but he said he felt a stronger drive to portray Ivan in this film because he understood the mission we were trying to achieve.

As filmmakers, we understand the impact of storytelling; we understand that through the power of filmmaking, we can help people connect with different themes and realities affecting people far away and, subsequently, those who are really close.

BÃ–HM: Our team and our cast members transformed fear into urgency. We had a high level of commitment to authenticity across all disciplines, sound design, music, production design and the performances themselves. Many thoughts went into every detail of this film.

DEADLINE: Why was the handheld camera style the most effective way to tell this story for you?

BÃ–HM: We had the real pleasure of working with an extremely talented and international head of departments on this project. And we had enough time to prepare for the shoot and to figure out the audiovisual language and the overall design of the project. This was done through extensive testing, location scouting, and meetings. We also watched a lot of films [for inspiration]. So, the choice to use the handheld style was a result of those meetings. We wanted to deploy that specific style because the audience is never smarter than Ivan, our main character, and we wanted to be as close to him as possible throughout the whole film. We incorporated that into the score and sound design as well to resemble what Ivan is feeling during certain moments. For example, the moment when he shoots himself in the leg, youâ€™re getting [to see] this incredible pain, and oftentimes [when] people have [severe injuries] like this, thereâ€™s a lot of difficulty [in trying to communicate] because all you can hear is your blood pumping through your veins so loudly. So, we tried to recreate that with both the sound design and score.

DEADLINE: Talk about the importance of the title Rock, Paper, Scissors. Why did this fit the story you are telling?

HOOZEER: There are a couple of reasons why the title is important. Rock, Paper, Scissors is fundamentally a childrenâ€™s game. Thereâ€™s an innocence to it. Itâ€™s the idea that, over the course of this film, the reality mirrors how we see Ivan lose his innocence. The game also mirrors war in the sense that there arenâ€™t really any real winners, just like there are no real winners in Rock, Paper, Scissors. With the film focusing on the civilian point of view, when Ivan is out in the world, we can hear those jets flying over. But in that situation, you donâ€™t know if theyâ€™re friendly or if theyâ€™re foes. This could be the last time you step outside. Survival in war is a game of luck and a game of chance. And it really felt like, especially with the story of Ivan itself, almost a coming-of-age story for Ivan. Itâ€™s a war thriller.

BÃ–HM: The film is not really about war in the first place. Itâ€™s about people and how they react and have to behave when the systems around them, created to protect them, just collapse. And I think thatâ€™s what Rock, Paper, Scissors is trying to tell through Ivanâ€™s harrowing, brutal story.

DEADLINE: Youâ€™ve won the BAFTA and scooped up awards from various international festivals and now have landed the Oscars shortlist. As a producer, what have you noticed about the different reactions to the regions that youâ€™ve played this in?

HOOZEER: This story humanizes the realities of war. Globally, weâ€™ve had quite a successful festival run. Weâ€™ve had the film show in New Zealand, LA, across the U.S., the U.K., in Europe, even in Africa and Mauritius. Weâ€™ve had quite a lot of international response to the film, and I think itâ€™s less about the glorification of heroism. The character is not a Hollywood hero. The idea is that heâ€™s a civilian, heâ€™s a human. I think the film explores choices made under pressure, the drive to save everyone without leaving anyone behind, the risk for the greater good, resilience when everything crumbles and the steadfast defense of what we hold dear. These themes unfold with deliberate intensity, and thatâ€™s been universal everywhere weâ€™ve taken this film.

Rock, Paper, Scissors National Film and Television School

DEADLINE: Franz, youâ€™re still in your mid-20s. Between this and your previous documentary, Dear Future Children, there seems to be a desire to tell stories about people living under oppressive regimes. Donâ€™t you just want to be a guy in his 20s? These are some complex topics.

BÃ–HM: My connection to film was created when I was still quite young. I lost my father when I was 11, and that was a very difficult time for my mother and I. During that time, I found a personal escape in watching films, especially adventurous ones set in other countries or those in which the lead characters had to transform themselves. I remember being quite young and getting fascinated when I researched what all the different credits on a film meant, like what a DoP or a producer does.

I was a 14-year-old living in South Germany when I stepped onto my first film set as a runner and immediately fell in love with the process of making films, which, to this day, I think is deeply magical and amazing. I know I have experienced it firsthand how much films can help people. Obviously, when I say â€˜help people,â€™ it sounds like a simple phrase, but I think it means helping people understand one another. Film helps us understand a subjective experience that somebody else might have. For example, in Germany, it helped understand the devastation of the Holocaust and all its different factions and the consequences massively.

Cinema often helps us zoom in on a conflict, tragedy, or even a positive moment in a particular story, experience, or character to share the value of that experience. Thatâ€™s what cinema is about to me. Iâ€™m very grateful that, as a young boy with no prior connection to the industry â€“ I have no family members who work in the media industry â€“ I was able to get into the industry this way. Iâ€™m grateful for the many collaborators Iâ€™ve had on this journey, and Iâ€™m looking forward to many more that Iâ€™ll hopefully meet in the future. Iâ€™m grateful I was able to study at the National Film and Television School, a place that was always a dream for me. I was able to meet so many incredible fellow students, many of whom helped me create Rock, Paper, Scissors. And in todayâ€™s world, there are so many conflicts brewing alongside new political movements and emerging problems. If you look at cinema over the last few years, I would say films have done an excellent job of helping us as a society debate these problems, and thatâ€™s what Iâ€™m really excited and passionate about.

[This interview has been edited for length and clarity]

content:
â€œI swear to God. Iâ€™m going to kill myself,â€ Kristen Stewart says, ribbing her longtime friend Jesse Eisenberg for watching her directorial debut, â€œThe Chronology of Water,â€ on his laptop.

The â€œTwilightâ€ star, who earned an Oscar nomination for portraying Princess Diana in â€œSpencer,â€ vowed to quit acting until she could adapt Lidia Yuknavitchâ€™s 2011 stream-of-conscious memoir about a young woman (played by Imogen Poots), sexually abused as a child, who eventually finds her voice through writing and swimming. Stewart didnâ€™t labor for nearly a decade to secure the filmâ€™s financing only for someone to see her passion project on a computer screen.

â€œItâ€™s supposed to be a sonic experience,â€ she sighs and keeps roasting Eisenberg. â€œYou know about movies? Have you ever made a movie?â€

Stewart and Eisenberg met on 2009â€™s coming-of-age comedy â€œAdventurelandâ€ and reunited on 2015â€™s stoner adventure â€œAmerican Ultraâ€ and Woody Allenâ€™s 2016 romantic drama â€œCafe Society.â€ Since then, Eisenberg has directed two films, 2022â€™s dramedy â€œWhen You Finish Saving the Worldâ€ and 2024â€™s Oscar-nominated â€œA Real Pain.â€ So yeah, he knows something about making movies, as well as a directorâ€™s desire for audiences to see them on the big screen.

â€œIâ€™m aware of that and was taking all of that into account,â€ Eisenberg wryly retorts before complimenting his pal. â€œI was astounded. Iâ€™ve never seen something made like this by someone I know who is also funny.â€

Stewart and Eisenberg continue to tease each other during their conversation, in which they discuss how directing has changed their perspective as actors and whether they care if their films make money.

Jesse Eisenberg: Are you OK?

Kristen Stewart: That should be the intro: â€œAre you OK?â€ Iâ€™m not kidding. Thatâ€™s often how we greet each other.

Eisenberg: Weâ€™ve known each other for a long time â€” 15 years, right?

Stewart: I was 17 when we met. Iâ€™m 35.

Eisenberg: Oh my God, really? I saw your movie 24 hours ago. I was blown away. My first thought was â€œWe can do that? I didnâ€™t know we could do that.â€ Itâ€™s unbelievably audacious. You read this book, but how did you convey it to other people? (I know these are junket questions.) What does the script look like?

Stewart: You and I are fairly shy people, but thereâ€™s an innate, stifling invisibility that women have to grapple with, even if they werenâ€™t abused by their father. I didnâ€™t want to make statements, like, â€œThis is what the movieâ€™s about.â€ There was just something about the book that spoke to the universality of being a young girl trying to excavate a voice thatâ€™s been told to shut up.

Eisenberg: You and I have the advantage of being known actors. It allows, or maybe gives, us the responsibility to make something thatâ€™s harder to convey. Is that part of the reason you were able to do something so abstract? The result is astounding, but thatâ€™s not guaranteed.

Benedict Evans for Variety

Stewart: It wasnâ€™t easy for me to make the movie. It took eight years. People that love me were genuinely sick and tired of hearing me be so upset about it. And then those things are baked into the plot of the movie. Itâ€™s about the malleability of our realities. I had to continuously remind people that we were doing a poem.

Eisenberg: What I was asking before, if I can ask it better, is â€”

Stewart: I can answer it better.

Eisenberg: This is my question: Did you feel a responsibility to make something unusual because youâ€™re a well-known actor, or is this just entirely your taste?

Stewart: This is entirely my taste. I could never make something straightforward. I like associative, open-ended things that say something very particular but invite people to disagree.

Eisenberg: How did your taste develop?

Stewart: I donâ€™t like being told what to do. I donâ€™t want to tell people what to do.

Eisenberg: I read something you said, which I thought was funny and reminded me of myself. Somebody asked you, â€œDo you think of being an actor in a movie differently now?â€ Youâ€™re like, â€œOf course. Iâ€™ll go to the director and say, â€˜Iâ€™ll do whatever you want me to do.â€™â€

Stewart: Iâ€™ll never question anything again. Iâ€™m like, â€œAnything you want.â€ The idea of being like, â€œYou should cast this person.â€ Iâ€™m like, â€œExcuse me? You donâ€™t know anything.â€

Eisenberg: Isnâ€™t that fascinating? A lot of people in our position go the other way. They feel even more like they need control because they have an experience where they were controlling everything. The story I always tell about you â€” because Iâ€™ve been asked about you for 18 years â€” is when we were doing â€œAdventureland,â€ there was a dramatic scene at night, and you were like, â€œCut. Iâ€™m lying.â€ You were 17, and I was shocked. I felt like I was watching a master. Would you have done that now?

Stewart: I get mad at people now for cutting, because Iâ€™m like, â€œI know you questioned yourself, but that moment of question was gold.â€ I want to try and not do that. [As an actor] I donâ€™t want to be misinterpreted. When a director is like, â€œIt seemed like you were feeling it.â€ I always say, â€œI donâ€™t care if it looks good; I want to do it again.â€ Iâ€™m selfish. I want to taste it.

Benedict Evans for Variety

Eisenberg: â€œI want the catharsis.â€ One of the other stories I tell from â€œAdventurelandâ€ was a quick scene. I had my first panic attack on set; I was self-aware in the worst way, and I shut down. After the tape, I was mortified. Greg [Mottola, the director] goes, â€œI didnâ€™t notice, but Iâ€™m so sorry you felt that way.â€ He said, â€œI donâ€™t understand how actors arenâ€™t having panic attacks all the time. Youâ€™re in front of strangers, and you have to be vulnerable.â€ For years, I remember thinking, â€œItâ€™s a sweet thing he said, but heâ€™s pitying actors too much. Weâ€™re lucky. We have an easy job. We memorize lines.â€

Now I have respect for the job in a way I never did personally. Because I was so self-critical, I couldnâ€™t have a good feeling about it. It seemed like, â€œYouâ€™re overpaying me.â€ Then Julianne Moore was in my movie, and after her first scene, I turned to my producer and was like, â€œCan we pay her more?â€ Did you have that feeling with Imogen? Iâ€™ve done three movies with her. But not in the same way Iâ€™ve done three movies with you. How did you choose her?

Stewart: Youâ€™re one of the reasons. I was like, â€œIâ€™m sure we would be close because you guys are friends.â€ She did an audition. She sent a tape and I was like, â€œOh my God.â€ Thereâ€™s something about her being 35 and me being 35. We should have been friends since we were younger. We just never met. Then we did, and it was the perfect time to go, â€œWe need to shove everything weâ€™ve never said to each other into this movie.â€

Eisenberg: Do you feel you could have this style and use it going forward?

Stewart: Iâ€™m always asked if I would continue to work as an actor in studio films, or if feels like youâ€™re selling a homogenized idea that doesnâ€™t land on an individual, necessarily, but satisfies a group? I wouldnâ€™t be good at that job.

Eisenberg What do you mean? To direct a more commercial thing?

Stewart: More and more, commercial means standard and digestible. I want to be allowed to make movies that allow for time to figure out a structure and mission statement. The next movie I want to make utilizes different formats. Not because itâ€™s nerdy film stuff, but because itâ€™s more interesting to make movies about how you see something instead of what you see.

Eisenberg: Your movie is coming out soon. Do you think or care about it making money?

Stewart: It would be great if it did because then maybe it wouldnâ€™t be as difficult to make my next movie. But at the same time, the next movie I want to make functions outside of the business structure weâ€™re used to. People love to hear that.

Eisenberg: â€œThis doesnâ€™t even exist in your structure.â€

Stewart: Well, it doesnâ€™t. You need to find new terms for all of this because, Iâ€™m sorry, but the language and structure are oppressive.

Eisenberg: Thereâ€™s no English on this set. It doesnâ€™t apply to what weâ€™re doing.

Stewart: Actually, the title of the movie is in Spanish. Iâ€™m not going to tell you what it is.

Eisenberg: I wouldnâ€™t understand it.

Stewart: Yeah, youâ€™re just a dummy.

Eisenberg: So you care insofar as it helps you make the next one. You care insofar as it pays the people back who paid for it. But youâ€™re not caring about what other people might think about it? People ask me too. I guess I donâ€™t care about it being a successful business thing. My mind doesnâ€™t go there, or I canâ€™t conceive of it.

Stewart: For sure. I love the movie. I birthed it. I probably would have made this movie if I was never an actor. I didnâ€™t feel like I was graduating into like, â€œNow I want to check that box.â€ I think this thing needs to exist.

Eisenberg: Weâ€™re directing everything, but weâ€™re also desperate actors. So all Iâ€™ll say is this: I can learn Spanish for your next project.

Stewart: You need to put yourself on tape.

title: â€˜Stranger Things 5â€™ Sets New Yearâ€™s Day Netflix Viewership Record With Finale, Enters Most Popular List; â€˜The Great Floodâ€™ Makes Non-English Film List
summary: The two-hour finale of Stranger Things, released in the evening of New Year’s Eve, fueled Netflix to its most views ever on a New Yearâ€™s Day. The streamer would not reveal how many those views were but announced that the entire fifth season of the supernatural series delivered 31.5 million views for the week of […]
content:
The two-hour finale of Stranger Things, released in the evening of New Yearâ€™s Eve, fueled Netflix to its most views ever on a New Yearâ€™s Day. The streamer would not reveal how many those views were but announced that the entire fifth season of the supernatural series delivered 31.5 million views for the week of Dec. 29, which included four full days and a few extra hours of viewing for the finale in addition to seven days for Episodes 1-7.

With all episodes factored in, Netflix has now put Stranger Things 5 on its Most Popular English TV list, with the season officially entering the Top 10 at No. 9 with 105.7 million total views.

How did the streamer come up with that number? Itâ€™s complicated. Netflix has unveiled a complex methodology for calculating views on split seasons. Consumption of each batch of episodes is measured over their first 91 days of release, with Stranger Things 5 Vol. 1 views not counted past Feb. 24, Vol. 2 past March 25 and the finale past March 31.

Watch on Deadline

Making things even more convoluted, Netflixâ€™s reported weekly views during each window of availability are calculated over the number of available episodes during that window: 4 from Nov. 26 through Dec. 24, seven from Dec. 25 through the evening of Dec. 31 and eight beyond that.

The most popular list calls for the entire viewing of a season to be divided by its full runtime. Because of the complex split season methodology, there is no way to verify the views Netflix puts up for Stranger Things 5 on the Most Popular list where Stranger Things 4 â€” another split-season entry â€” is currently at No.3.

A very simplistic calculation based on publicly released viewership information, which factors in four episodes for the first four weeks of Stranger Things 5 release, seven for Week 5 and eight for Week 6, delivers an in-the-ballpark but inflated by overcounting season average of 119M views to date. Additionally, more than 1.1M fans watched the series finale of the Duffer Brothers hit series in theaters on Dec. 31 â€“ Jan. 1.

Stranger Things 5, which topped the weekly Top 10 English TV list with 31.5M views, was once again joined by Season 1 at No. 3 (7.6 million views), Season 2 at No. 5 (5.5 million), Season 3 to No. 7 (5 million), and Season 4 to No. 8 (4.8 million), making this the sixth record-setting week that the series has had all its seasons on the list.

Elsewhere on the English TV Top 10, the latest Harlan Coben limited mystery series Run Away opened at No. 2 with 12.7 million views, Emily in Paris Season 5 was at No. 4 (7.4M) as the comedy earned a Season 6 renewal, and Ricky Gervaisâ€™s new special, Mortality, debuted at No. 6 with 5.1 million views.

On the film side, Korean disaster movie The Great Flood was No. 1 again on the non-English film list with 11.1 million views and, three weeks into its release, it also entered the Most Popular non-English film list at No. 7 with 72.1 million views.

content:

Levy has spent the past 18 months as President of Vanderpump Rules producer 32 Flavors. She begins the new role later this month.

Watch on Deadline

She will also be in charge of MGM Alternative, which now reports to Friedlander after it moved under Amazon MGM Studios. The division, previously run by Barry Poznick, produces series including The Voice and Survivor and operates production companies including The Real Housewives of Beverly Hills producer Evolution Media and On Patrol: Live producer Big Fish Entertainment.

Levy was part of the Netflix team behind unscripted smash Love Is Blind and she will be tasked with finding similar success at Amazon, which has struggled to define its unscripted strategy in recent years.

She left Netflix in January 2024 when she was VP Unscripted. She had been with Netflix since 2017, having joined as Director of Unscripted Originals from NBCUniversalâ€™s Bravo, where she had spent nine years. She was the companyâ€™s unscripted chief Brandon Rieggâ€™s first hire after he joined the company at the end of 2016 and was also behind series such as Queer Eye, Nailed It!, and The Ultimatum.

In a note to staff, Friedlander said having a â€œsingle threaded leader for this vital piece of our business is crucial.â€

content:
In a move that reflects the downsizing of late-night TV, ABCâ€™s â€œJimmy Kimmel Liveâ€ will be decreasing its music performances in the coming weeks, a source confirms to Variety.

The news was first reported late Monday by the Hollywood Reporter, which cited sources saying music performances will be cut back to twice a week, but Varietyâ€™s source said that the number is more likely to vary. However, the show will no longer feature musical performances every night it airs.

Reps for the show did not respond to requests for comment; no reason was cited for the decision but it seems likely that budget considerations played a role.

Popular on Variety

Musical performances have been a cornerstone of the show since its inception and have ranged from superstars like One Direction, Eminem (performing live from the Empire State Building) and the Weeknd to countless up-and-coming artists.

The move reflected a sadly common trend as late-night TV has diminished in general, with shows hosted by Seth Meyers and Stephen Colbert losing their house bands and/or number of musical performances. Only Jimmy Fallonâ€™s â€œTonight Showâ€ will still regularly feature musical guests.

Variety reported last month that Kimmel and ABC parent company Disney struck a new deal that will keep him as the host of ABCâ€˜s â€œJimmy Kimmel Liveâ€ for another year, according to three people familiar with the matter. Kimmelâ€™s current deal with Disney was believed to expire in 2026; the comedian confirmed the deal renewal in an Instagram post, writing, â€œI am pleased to announce another no-talent year!â€

The renewal came after Disney pulled Kimmelâ€™s show off the schedule for a few days in September after two large owners of affiliate TV stations, Nexstar and Sinclair, complained about a monologue in which the comedian discussed Charlie Kirk, the young Republican figure who was assassinated earlier that month.

Variety will have more on the situation as it develops.

Additional reporting by Michael Schneider and Brian Steinberg.

content:
Broadway welcomed the New Year with reason for high spirits as the 33 productions grossed an impressive total of $52,037,125. Some 24 of the shows were sell-outs (or within a fraction) and only one filled fewer than 90% of their available seats. More on that later.

While the $52M mark is a 4% drop from the previous week, and about 7% down from the same time â€“ Week 32 â€“ last year, those slips reflect the always-lucrative Christmas week highs (Christmas fell within Week 32 last season).

Some stand-outs for the week ending January 4, 2026, included Mamma Mia!, playing the best week of its limited return engagement at the Winter Garden Theatre, grossing $2,594,204 for nine performances. The engagement ends February 1.

Setting a new eight-performance house record at the Minskoff was The Lion King, grossing $3,145,899. That figure marks the 34th house record set by the musical.

Watch on Deadline

Total attendance for the 33 shows was 313,513, about even with the previous week and previous season.

Two shows â€“ Beetlejuice and Waiting For Godot â€“ closed last week, with the demonic musical posting a big $311,282 gain over the previous week, taking in $1,373,691 and selling 96% of its seats. Godot, starring Keanu Reeves and Alex Winter, was a sell out yet again, grossing $1,549,152.

In addition to Mamma Mia!, The Lion King and Godot, other sell-outs for the week were & Juliet, Aladdin, Buena Vista Social Club, Chess, Death Becomes Her, Hadestown, Hamilton, Harry Potter and the Cursed Child, Just In Time, Mamma Mia!, Marjorie Prime, Maybe Happy Ending, MJ, Moulin Rouge, Oh, Mary!, Operation Mincemeat, Ragtime, The Book of Mormon, The Great Gatsby, The Outsiders and Wicked.

Deadlineâ€™s Read the Screenplay series spotlighting the scripts behind the awards seasonâ€™s most talked-about movies continues with 20th Century Studiosâ€˜ Springsteen: Deliver Me from Nowhere. Directed and written by Scott Cooper based on a book by Warren Zanes, the micro-biopic chronicles the making of Bruce Springsteenâ€™s 1982 acoustic album Nebraska.

Set in autumn 1981, the story follows a 31-year-old Springsteen, who despite the massive success of his previous album The River and its subsequent tour, finds himself at one of the lowest points in his life. Instead of returning to the studio to record more hits as his label executives expected, Springsteen retreated to a quiet house in Colts Neck, NJ, to rest. During this period of isolation and burgeoning depression, he used a simple 4-track cassette recorder to self-record the 10 raw, haunted songs that would become Nebraska. The film is a character-driven drama that explores the man behind â€œThe Bossâ€ icon, staring inward at a personal and creative crossroads.

20th Century scooped up rights to finance and release the pic back in April 2024 with Jeremy Allen White aboard to star. The film world premiered at the Telluride Film Festival and hit theaters at the end of October. It has grossed $45.2 million at the global box office, and White has been nominated for a Golden Globe for his portrayal.

Watch on Deadline

Central to Deliver Me From Nowhere is an exploration of isolation and the healing power of music. The story show Springsteenâ€™s retreat from the world not just as a creative choice, but also as a response to a period of burgeoning depression and loneliness. Cooper and White described the film as the story of a â€œneglected soulâ€ repairing himself through music, suggesting that the recording of Nebraska was an unplanned necessity born from a deep-seated need to confront unresolved trauma. This internal struggle is portrayed with raw honesty, focusing on the darker, mournful corners of humanity that inspired the recordâ€™s lyrics.

This internal journey is deeply tied to the ghosts of Springsteenâ€™s past, particularly his complex relationship with his father, Doug Springsteen. The film examines how the elder Springsteenâ€™s struggles with mental health and alcoholism spiritually haunted Bruce, influencing his perspective and his own battles with depression. These family dynamics are intertwined with a fear of success; the narrative depicts Springsteen worrying that his rising stardom might distance him from the working-class identity of his youth in Freehold, NJ.

The filmmakers emphasize a commitment to authenticity over mythology, choosing to strip away the rock-star icon to find the person underneath. This focus on the intimate details of the creative process highlights the burden of artistic vision, showing Springsteenâ€™s persistence in honoring a somber, non-commercial direction even when it defied the expectations of label executives. Ultimately, the film is presented as a study of an artistâ€™s quest for truth during a time of quiet, internal unraveling.

content:
Speaking to an audience of her fellow SAG-AFTRA actors, Hannah Einbinder admitted it was â€œspookyâ€ to watch Stephen Colbertâ€™s cancellation mirror a plot line from her hit series â€œHacks.â€ Einbinder made her national television debut doing a stand-up set in March 2020 on â€œThe Late Show With Stephen Colbertâ€ and has returned as a guest over the years.



Einbinder, who recently won an Emmy Award for supporting actress in a comedy series, discussed how the fourth season was a love letter to late-night television, with Jean Smartâ€™s Deborah Vance finally launching her own show. Things come to a head in the May 22 episode â€œA Slippery Slope,â€ when Deborah is ordered to fire Ava. Two months later, it was announced that CBS would not be renewing â€œThe Late Show,â€ with speculation widespread that the choice was due to the hostâ€™s outspoken criticism of President Donald Trump. Two months later, fellow late-night host Jimmy Kimmelâ€™s show was abruptly suspended after he addressed the shooting of Charlie Kirk in his monologue. FCC chair Brendan Carr had threatened to pull ABC affiliate broadcast licenses and soon station groups Nexstar and Sinclair announced they would not air the show. Kimmel returned to the air days later, due in part to a massive public outcry.

The â€œHacksâ€ scenes were filmed at least a half year prior to the Colbert announcement, and Einbinder does say it was strange to see it unfold. â€œI think it was like, holy shit, this is really crazy and also spooky that it was specifically late night and specifically that type of censorship,â€ she noted. â€œItâ€™s so bizarre.â€

However, she added, in some ways, it was not unexpected. â€œKind of observing the way that things have been going for quite some time, I didnâ€™t find what happened to Stephen Colbert and Jimmy Kimmel to be a shock at all because of all the censorship that weâ€™ve seen. Einbinder went on to praise show creators Paul W. Downs, Lucia Aniello and Jen Statsky for how the story was addressed and worked into the show organically. â€œIâ€™m really proud of Paul, Lucia and Jen for handling that issue and for speaking on that and for doing it in a way that is beautiful and also earned within the narrative,â€ she revealed. â€œItâ€™s not like forcing anything down anybodyâ€™s throat. Itâ€™s really justified and grounded in reality, as we know.â€

Einbinder also hinted that in the upcoming season they are â€œsimilarly facing certain issues of the day, and it just makes me really proud.â€

Einbinder also discussed how â€œHacksâ€ was her first acting job after started her career as a stand-up. She reiterated her love for the medium, but did admit there were some bumpy times. â€œIâ€™ve felt pain, I have done it all,â€ she said. â€œI have been booed at a fucking saloon in rural Washington during a goddamn pool tournament. He had an earring,â€ Zhao told Varietyâ€™s Angelique Jackson, who moderated both conversations. â€œI just said to him, â€˜Have you ever thought about playing young William Shakespeare?â€™ and he said, â€˜Well, if youâ€™re talking about â€œHamnetâ€¦â€ Because I love the book. You have to read the book. It is perfect for you. Itâ€™s not what you think it is.â€™â€

Zhao took Mescalâ€™s advice and read Oâ€™Farrellâ€™s 2020 novel, which tells a mostly fictional story about how the death of William and Agnesâ€™ son Hamnet inspired the Bard to write â€œHamlet.â€ When Zhao read it, she immediately thought of Jesse Buckley for Agnes. â€œAll I saw was Jesse,â€ the filmmaker recalled. â€œIt was very tunnel vision.â€

Casting Buckley proved fruitful not just for her committed performance but for her contributions to the production as a whole. Zhao explained that the actress helped her and Oâ€™Farrell rewrite the ending. While the novel ends with the emphatic line â€œRemember me,â€ and the initial script concluded with Hamlet dying on stage during the playâ€™s debut performance at the Globe Theatre, the film added an emotional final scene of Agnes and the Globeâ€™s crowd reaching out towards the actor in a moment of collective grief and empathy.

â€œJesse sent me Max Richterâ€™s â€˜This Bitter Earth,â€™ which is a lyrics version of â€˜On the Nature of Daylight,â€™â€ Zhao recalled. â€œI was listening to the song in the car, and I started to cry. I felt tightness in my heart, but also opening. And then I started reaching out to the window. I was trying to touch the rain outside.â€ Zhao was going through a personal loss at the time, she explained. â€œBut this gesture, I realized, I was trying to reach for something bigger that I could be a part of, so that I would have the strength to let go. And then I realized thatâ€™s what Hamlet needed.â€

â€œHamnetâ€ filmmaker ChloÃ© Zhao poses with Kering Americas president Ewa Abrams at the 37th annual Palm Springs International Film Festival. Vivien Killilea/Getty Images for Palm Springs International Film Society

That collaborative spirit and emotional intuition are indicative of why Amblin wanted Zhao to direct â€œHamnetâ€ in the first place. Zhao jokes that empathy has always been a part of her nature, and that she can now prove to her parents that the â€œoversensitive child had a purpose.â€

More sincerely, though, she said, â€œSometimes weâ€™re made to be ashamed of the part of ourselves that seeks connection and relatedness and love as if itâ€™s less important, not productive or weak, but that is the life force. That is the force that binds. That is the creative energy that crosses everything together, that sustains and fosters growth and enhances everything in life. So as vulnerable as it feels, I would try to create from that place and seek that connection.â€

Mona Fastvold is no stranger to leading from a feminine lens, either. As a director, her filmography consists of â€œThe Sleepwalker,â€ â€œThe World to Comeâ€ and now, â€œThe Testament of Ann Leeâ€ â€” all of which focus on powerful female characters. Only recently, however, has she come to embrace the label of a â€œfemale director.â€

She associates some of that empathetic approach to â€œfemale leadership,â€ which she suggests, â€œdoesnâ€™t just mean women. It means the feminine consciousness in all people is drawing strength from interdependence, not dominance. Itâ€™s drawing strengths from intuition, relationships, community and interdependence.â€

Regarding being just one of nine women out of 111 directors who helmed 2025â€™s 100 top-grossing films, Zhao says the data indicates that a more feminine approach â€œdoesnâ€™t fit into the current model that we exist in, the container we exist in. Itâ€™s difficult to come through, and I feel very lucky that I had people in power that trusted that this way of leading is needed for this story.â€

â€œI used to resent being called that, and now I love it,â€ Fastvold told Variety, seated next to the filmâ€™s star, Amanda Seyfried. â€œI will take it. I will be a â€˜female director,â€™ and tell feminist stories about women. Iâ€™m very proud of it.â€

Seyfried plays the titular heroine, a real-world figure who lived in the 18th century and founded the Shakers, a religious movement that championed gender equality and communal living, and whose followers expressed faith through dance. As chronicled through the film, Leeâ€™s followers began to see her as a female messiah while others marked her for persecution.

â€œThe Shakers worship through ecstatic song and dance,â€ Fastvold explained. â€œThere was something about this idea of expressing faith through movement and song in such a free and intense and guttural way that was very exciting to me and scary.â€

Accordingly, the film is a historical musical. Fastvold initially expressed trepidation towards directing her first musical, but saw the genre as unavoidable given the subject matter.

â€œMaking a musical is scary, even though itâ€™s a different kind of musical,â€ the director reflected. â€œIâ€™d never made a musical before. My background is in dance, but I knew that I had to approach it in a different way and that I couldnâ€™t really look to other projects as inspiration for this. So it was kind of terrifying. But the short answer is it had to be a musical because thatâ€™s how they worshipped. They kind of lived their life in that way.â€

The director cast Seyfried partially because of her singing and dancing capabilities, as showcased in her roles in â€œMamma Miaâ€ and â€œLes MisÃ©rables.â€ Even so, embodying Lee and choreographing her intense movements proved to be demanding for the seasoned actress.

â€œAs challenging as it was for me to memorize those moves, once I got there, I felt closer to Ann Lee and once we were all moving in unison, it just takes you to another place,â€ Seyfried said. â€œYou just had to feel like it was part of you. It was an extension of your body, and then it becomes real for that moment in time.â€

Part of the challenge came from the fact that the Shakersâ€™ choreographies are buried in history. Seyfried worked with choreographer Celia Rowlson-Hall to create and execute dances that were â€œbased on these paintings and drawings and descriptionsâ€ of events that took place over two centuries ago.

â€œThe Testament of Ann Leeâ€ star Amanda Seyfried and director Mona Fastvold in conversation with Varietyâ€™s Angelique Jackson at the 37th annual Palm Springs International Film Festival. Presley Ann/Getty Images for Palm Springs International Film Society

Seyfried credits the artisans and practitioners across all departments for their thorough research in recreating Leeâ€™s story and the Shaker movement, and she expresses profound esteem for Fastvold, whom the production affectionately referred to as â€œMother Monaâ€ on set.

â€œShe is very nurturing,â€ Seyfried said of Fastvold. â€œHer job as the director is mothering. The leadership comes from this beautiful, nurturing, female, empowered artist. The nurturing quality of her really impacts how we felt on set and I think it went a long way.â€

Similarly, Fastvold shared how the opportunity to tell a story about a woman whose historical impact had been unsung fueled her sense of purpose while making the film.

â€œThere are so many wonderful, exciting, important female historical figures that are overlooked,â€ she said. â€œI feel very lucky that I found Ann Lee.â€

title: White House Debuts January 6th Revisionist History Website As Democrats Mark 5th Anniversary Attack On Capitol
summary: The White House tried to revise the history of January 6th, debuting a website with false claims to blame Capitol Police for fomenting the attack on the Capitol, while casting Donald Trump’s then-vice president, Mike Pence, as culpable and cowardly. The website appeared to be a way to counter what has been a daylong commemoration […]
content:
The White House tried to revise the history of January 6th, debuting a website with false claims to blame Capitol Police for fomenting the attack on the Capitol, while casting Donald Trumpâ€˜s then-vice president, Mike Pence, as culpable and cowardly.

The website appeared to be a way to counter what has been a daylong commemoration at the Capitol, featuring primarily Democrats, to mark the riot and insurrectionâ€™s 5th anniversary.

A White House timeline of the events of that day stated that at around 1:10 p.m. ET that day, â€œCapitol Police aggressively fire tear gas, flash bangs, and rubber munitions into crowds of peaceful protesters, injuring many and deliberately escalating tensions. Video evidence shows officers inexplicably removing barricades, opening Capitol doors, and even waving attendees inside the buildingâ€”actions that facilitated entryâ€”while simultaneously deploying violent force against others. These inconsistent and provocative tactics turned a peaceful demonstration into chaos.â€

But in reality, as was seen on live TV that day, demonstrators overwhelmed security barricades to gain access to the Capitol, smashing windows and forcing their way to the House and Senate chambers.

Watch on Deadline

The White House timeline mentions that Trump, at a rally at the Ellipse, urged his supporters to march to the Capitol to â€œpeacefully and patriotically make their voices heard.â€ But Trump also used other inflammatory rhetoric in his speech, telling the protesters, â€œAnd we fight. We fight like hell. And if you donâ€™t fight like hell, youâ€™re not going to have a country anymore.â€

In another part of the timeline, the White House claims that between 2:24 p.m. and 4:17 p.m.ET, Trump â€œrepeatedly calls for peace, tweeting support for law enforcement and releasing a video telling supporters â€˜go home in peaceâ€ while reiterating love for them and election concerns. He consistently promotes non-violence despite the attack on attendees and emotions running high.â€

In fact, at 2:24 p.m. that day, Trump posted on Twitter, â€œMike Pence didnâ€™t have the courage to do what should have been done to protect our Country and our Constitution, giving states a chance to certify a corrected set of facts, not the fraudulent or inaccurate ones which they were asked to previously certify. USA demands the truth!â€ Trump sent tweets at 2:38 p.m. and 3:13 p.m. calling for peaceful protest and no violence, but by then the situation was out of control, and it was not until 4:17 that he posted a video instructing those who stormed the Capitol to leave.

The White House site, in casting the protests as peaceful until Capitol Police exacerbated the situation, contradicted even Trumpâ€™s own words in the days after the attack. In a speech on January 8, 2021, Trump said, â€œTo demonstrators who infiltrated the Capitol: you have defiled the seat of American democracy. To those who engage in the acts of violence and destruction: you do not represent our country. And to those who broke the law: you will pay.â€

The new White House site also attempts to blame Democrats, and more specifically then-House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, for not doing more to stop the attack. It claims that Pelosi ignored Trumpâ€™s offers of National Guard troops. But Politifact and other sites have long deemed such claims as false, and Pelosi herself addressed the claim in an appearance at the Capitol on Tuesday.

â€œFor over three hours we begged him to send the National Guard,â€ Pelosi said. â€œHe never did it. He took joy in not doing. He was savoring it.â€ She noted that as president, Trump has authority over the D.C. National Guard, which he has since deployed to the city in his second term. Video footage also shows the extent to which Pelosi was a target of the rioters, as they stormed and ransacked her office.

The White House site pays tribute to the rioters who died during the assault or shortly afterward, but does not mention the law enforcement officers, reportedly totaling more than 140, who were injured.

No mention is made of the demonstratorsâ€™ erecting of a gallows on the Capitol lawn and chants of â€œHang Mike Pence.â€ Instead, the White House site calls Penceâ€™s refusal to delay election certification â€œan act of cowardice and sabotage.â€ Pence has long said that, after consulting with legal advisers, delaying the certification was outside his power as vice president.

On his first day in office last year, Trump granted clemency to all the January 6th rioters, even those convicted of assaulting police officers.
